PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; ANDREW; BEALE; BILNEY; BRUMBY; CADMAN; CAMERON; CAMERON; COHEN; COWAN; DOWNER; EDWARDS; FISCHER; FITZGIBBON; GRIFFITHS; HAND; HICKS; JONES; JULL; KATTER; KELLY; LAMB; LEE; LLOYD; MACPHEE; MILLAR; MOUNTFORD; NEHL; PORTER; PRATT; REITH; ROBINSON; ROCHER; SAWFORD; SCOTT; SHACK; SHARP; SIMMONS; SMITH; SPENDER; SULLIVAN

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 162 citizens), Mr Andrew (from 54 citizens), Mr Beale (from 289 citizens), Mr Bilney (from 162 citizens), Mr Brumby (from 214 citizens), Mr Cadman (from 15 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 15 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 160 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 27 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 54 citizens), Mr Downer (from 152 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 54 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 26 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 41 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 27 citizens), Mr Hand (from 48 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 159 citizens), Mr Barry Jones (from 27 citizens), Mr Jull (from 213 citizens), Mr Katter (from 27 citizens), Mrs Kelly (from 27 citizens), Mr Lamb (from 28 citizens), Mr Lee (from 27 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 81 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 54 citizens), Mr Millar (from 216 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 54 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 67 citizens), Mr Porter (from 69 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 71 citizens), Mr Reith (from 525 citizens), Mr Robinson (from 27 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 21 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 27 citizens), Mr John Scott (from 108 citizens), Mr Shack (from 304 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 27 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 83 citizens), Mr Smith (from 160 citizens), Mr Spender (from 27 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that there is too much crime and violence on Television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to call on the Federal Government to require Television Stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programmes by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr (from 42 citizens) and Mr Miles (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Lyne electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Urge TV stations to clean up their act and improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 130 citizens) and Mr Macphee (from 62 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol on Radio and Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen (from 657) citizens) and Mr Miles (from 559 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Song
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned, request that the last line in each chorus of the National Song be altered from: Advance Australia Fair to God Bless Australia Fair.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Dumped Cement and Clinker
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House their concern at the imminent prospect of imported cement and clinker being dumped on the Australian market, as it would lead to widespread disruption and extensive loss of Australian jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to call on the Federal Government to take immediate action to prevent dumped cement and clinker being imported into Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement and Veterans' Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Mitchell draws to the attention of the House the constant changes to retirement and veterans benefits.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to reject the Federal Government's punitive treatment of those who have prepared for retirement by careful saving and wise investment.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Entitlements and Fringe Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain parents and staff of subsidised child care centres, call on the House of Representatives to urge the Government to continue to allow government subsidised child care centres to assess family income for fee relief purposes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Buddhist Leaders: Imposed Death Sentences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned, 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the highest order, being scholars in Buddhist Scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

PETITION.TITLE: Buddhist Leaders: Imposed Death Sentences
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned do humbly and earnestly beseech the Parliament to use their best endeavours and influence to persuade the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to rescind the sentence of death passed by the Court of The Socialist Republic of Vietnam in Saigon on Nguyen Van Thuong, a Professor of the University of Saigon and noted author who is known as the Buddhist Monk Thich Tue Sy and Le Manh Thac, a Professor of history, and Buddhist Monk whose ordained name is Thich Tri Sieu and in support of our petition we do beg the Honourable members to be aware that these two senior Buddhist Monks are men of great integrity and personal academic ability such as to be enshrined in the hearts of Buddhists all over the world as shining examples of the teaching of our Lord Buddha. As living examples they provide teaching and guidance to millions of devoted Buddhists. Their execution will very greatly affect the Buddhist faithful all over the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hire and Sale of R, X and Non-Violent Erotica Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
The video industry has no right to promote anti-social behaviour
Community and professional concern has been publicly expressed over video violence and anti-social content.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ban the hire and sale of all R-rated, X-rated and proposed Non-violent Erotica rated videos from all outlets patronised by the general public.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Eligibility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Australian Labor Government has proposed to introduce new rules for pension eligibility that will disadvantage many pensioners. The new rules are unacceptable in that they penalise pensioners with existing investments, encourage pensioners to invest in inappropriate or non income earning investments and discourage people from saving for their retirement.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House review the proposed changes to rules for pension eligibility.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Jesus Christ personifies the perfect standard of behaviour and ideals for humanity as set out in Holy Scripture:
Any attack on the perfection of Jesus Christ is a vilification of Christ, and of Jehovah as portrayed in the Scriptures, and Who is worshipped on the basis of Scriptural portrayal:
The film, ``The Last Temptation of Christ'', is just such an attack on the basics of the values held by many Australian citizens.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House immediately act to have the film banned from Australia and so cease to condone the public vilification of Christian ethics.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Material and Adult Advertising on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Television programs after 8.30 pm are suitable for adults and are unsuitable for family viewing
Present television standards do not take into account the reality of family television viewing
Children under 15 years of age are often still watching television until 9.00 pm.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House require television stations to refrain from showing any adult material or adult advertising until after 9.00 pm.

PETITION.TITLE: PAYE Taxes and Sales Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
The Federal Government has reaped an unprecedented amount of revenue in taxation recently, over and above expectations;
PAYE taxpayers are losing one quarter and more of earnings through direct tax deductions;
Sales taxes which are charged on a vast range of everyday goods and necessities add to the taxes already imposed on wage earners;
The range of compulsory licences, fees, and charges imposed by governments and statutory authorities further erode family disposable incomes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House immediately reduce PAYE taxes and all Sales Taxes by one third and hold all Government and Statutory Authority charges at the current level for a minimum four-year period.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House compel TV stations to improve the standards of shows, new and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes, by fifty per cent.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration of Homosexuals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned voters shows:
that the homosexual lifestyle is associated with a high rate of serious disease such as syphilis, gonorrhea, hepatitis B and bowel diseases;
that the incurable, fatal disease AIDS was first brought to Australia by homosexuals and is largely transmitted by homosexuals or bisexuals who practise sodomy;
the homosexual cohabitation is in no way equivalent to a legal marriage or family relationship
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives should:
immediately request the Minister for Immigration to forbid entry to Australia by homosexuals under the ``family reunion'' program.

PETITION.TITLE: X-and R-Rated Video Material: Classification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned, note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the House of Representatives to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wannon electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and depicted in videos and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Urge TV stations to reduce the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
2. Introduce tighter controls on the sale and classification of videos so as to limit the access of children to inappropriate material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Merino Bush Nursing Hospital
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Merino and district draws to the attention of the House that a reduction in Government funding has caused a financial crisis for the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ensures that the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital is able to continue its vital role in the Merino community.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:
Following the recent uncontrolled shootings in Melbourne, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:

About the evil caused by the fact that X-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra, and are freely available, not only at video outlets.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
We also express concern that the Senate Select Committee formed three years ago to investigate this problem, has so far, not produced a report.
The laws regarding obscenity and violence in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Muswellbrook, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the inadequacy of the current arrangement whereby no full-time office of the Department of Social Security exists in the Upper Hunter Region of New South Wales to serve the people of the area (the Upper Hunter Region being defined as the Local Government Areas of Murrurundi, Scone, Muswellbrook, Merriwa and Singleton). Instead the area is served by a part-time visiting service which only provides a service to the towns of Singleton and Muswellbrook on one day per week in each town.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House consider the establishment of a full-time office in the town of Muswellbrook to serve the Upper Hunter Region.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of ``food irradiation'' by Cobalt 60, Cesium 137, cesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

We call on the House to ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.
We also call upon the House to request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Cooperative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.

PETITION.TITLE: Western Tasmania Stage 2
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia humbly suggests the area known as Western Tasmania Stage 2, containing Australia's longest and deepest caves, sites of international archaeological significance, Australia's most glaciated landscape, and the tallest flowering plants on earth, is in urgent need of protection.
Your petitioners therefore request that Western Tasmania Stage 2 be immediately nominated for World Heritage listing.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5) They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of we, the undersigned electors of Ballarat respectfully showeth that:
1. roads form a valuable part of the nation's infrastructure;
2. the road construction industry is an important employer;
3. roads support the social fabric of country communities;
4. roads are a vital part of a district's commerce;
5. country roads are deteriorating;
6. deteriorating roads threaten the lives of Australians;
7. road surface maintenance affects the efficiency of road transport;
8. insufficient funds are being spent on roads.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
1. the Parliament recognise the importance of roads to the economy;
2. the importance of roads to country people;
3. the Parliament increase funding to maintain the road system; and
4. grant a greater proportion of fuel taxes to road funding;
5. the Parliament continue to grant specific Federal Funds for roads.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treaty Between Aboriginal and Other Australians
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
1. there is a need for continuing reconciliation between Aboriginal and other Australians to enhance the unity of the Australian nation.
2. the Federal Government proposes a ``Treaty'' between Aboriginal and other Australians.

3. as a ``Treaty'' is an agreement between two sovereign states, such an agreement would recognise Aborigines and other Australians as two separate nations and thereby divide Australia and set back prospects for reconciliation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House opposed the conclusion of a Treaty between Aboriginal and other Australians or any proposal which divides rather than unites Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House the concern of certain citizens at the possibility that the film `The Last Temptation of Christ' will be permitted to enter Australia for screening.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House rejects the entry into Australia of the film `The Last Temptation of Christ', which has been described as blasphemous by Christians in other countries.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Electoral Commission: Burnie, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain electors of the Division of Braddon draws the attention of the House to the proposal to close the Burnie Office of the Australian Electoral Commission.
We believe:
1. That the proposed closure is not in the best interests of democracy.
2. That closure will further erode jobs in regional areas of Australia.
3. That we oppose the further centralisation of government services at the expense of rural and isolated communities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will oppose the closure.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House, the plan proposed by the Government of Rumania, to re-structure the Rumanian countryside. Some 7000 villages, many of them in Transylvania, at this time still occupied by the descendants of those Hungarian-extraction citizens of Rumania, whose ancestors lived there for over 1,000 years, are earmarked for total destruction. The Rumanian Government's intention is, that no trace of such inhabitation remain. The reasons proposed for the destruction, that is: to ``provide arable land'', is nothing but a ruse.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully urge the house, to ask the Australian Government, to call on Rumania to forthwith desist from any action envisaged in the bulldozer-policy.

Rumania signed many international instruments which provided guarantees to the human rights and the rights of the minorities living in Rumania. Now the rights of all people living in the 7000 Villages are in danger, of not only being eroded, but irrevocably destroyed.
The destruction would not only affect homes, the monuments, the cemeteries and the churches, some 9024 (!) churches of many denominations, would disappear forever.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office: Dundas, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strenuously object to the proposal that the post office at Dundas N.S.W. be closed.

The post office is a vital community service and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, banking, payment of various accounts the post office accepts and to collect our articles, parcels, security and certified items.

Many of us have small children or are elderly. The next nearest post office cannot be reached by public transport and the cost of public transport to an office further afield is a financial burden to those of us who are pensioners or have young families. We maintain that the purpose of post offices should be to provide an essential service to the public and offer as many services as they can and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the house can take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Dundas agency, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Government Analytical Laboratories
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of Parliament assembled the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

1. That we are extremely concerned over the discovery of the bacteria Listeria Monocytogenes in imported cheese found in Australia. The bacteria has been identified with deaths in America and Switzerland and can cause abortion in pregnant women, meningitis and perinatal septicaemia in newborn infants.
2. That the work of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories in sample testing and analysis of food products has been severely reduced due to ill considered budget cutbacks.

3. That the public interest functions of A.G.L. have been put in jeopardy through these budget cutbacks and through a failure to establish a compulsory programs of regular testing of both imported and domestic food products.
Your petitioners therefore call on the House to-
(a) Give the highest priority to establishing the public interest functions of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.
(b) Require the Departments of Primary Industry and Energy and Health to put in place a regular compulsory program of analysis and testing of food products, both imported and domestic.
(c) Require that such testing be conducted through the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Violent Erotica Video Classification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will not adopt an N.V.E. Video classification, that N.V.E. will not be permitted in cinemas, that section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations remain as it is, and that ALL Censorship criteria be controlled by substantive legislation; in order that NO Attorney General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament, because
the A.C.T. Ordinance has degraded men
the A.C.T. Ordinance has lowered the status of women
the A.C.T. Ordinance has affected the safety of children
the A.C.T. Ordinance has escalated crime and sexual crime
and because Parliament has a role to play in the well-being of the people of this Nation, of far greater importance than rapacious Multi-nationals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give these matters your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has legalised the screening of blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity.
Because Parliament has traditionally respected the beliefs of its people, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulation as is;
2. control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation;

3. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without full and thorough debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Equipment
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:
The undersigned are gravely concerned about the proposed changes to the Customs Act and regulations regarding the export of military equipment. We understand that these changes:
will impose a threat to human rights as they restrict the Government's ability to prevent sales should the final destination be in doubt;
will harm the integrity and international reputation of Australia as a peace loving nation, having a record of long-standing opposition to exports of military equipment;
will allow Australian producers to join the arms race, which is clearly a wasteful and costly exercise and is abhorrent to us;
will increase the possibility of foreign military investment in Australia, which is also abhorrent to us;
are generally immoral and, as such, impose moral costs upon Australian citizens which outweigh any benefits based on economic principles.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
maintain the Customs Act in its present form which regulates the export of military equipment and to oppose any further expansion of Australia's military equipment industry.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mail Delivery: Pipers River Road Area, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petitioners wish to draw attention to the inadequate nature of the postal service in the Pipers River Road area of Tasmania. We call for the introduction of a five times weekly delivery of mail in this area in order to properly service the growing requirements of the residents.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Manufacture and Sale of Toys of War and Violence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens, ask that the manufacture and sale of toys of war and violence be banned in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Age Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House-

That we welcome the Government's increasing the Pensioner Tax Rebate to $430 but point out this still leaves the allowable earnings before tax has to be paid to be less than applied in March 1983 and by June next year will be very small indeed.

We also point out that the pension has not increased in real terms since 1983 and the six weeks delay from May and November to June and December further deprives pensioners of their just entitlements. We therefore call on the Parliament to:
1. To immediately restore the May/November adjustment dates for the pension and move quickly to implement the Government's promise of 1983 to reduce the delay to only one month.
2. To increase the Pensioner Tax Rebate to $800 and index this rebate.
Your petitioners therefore in duty pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Facility: Runaway Bay and Helensvale Districts, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Moncrieff draws to the attention of the House the absence of a Medicare facility in the Runaway Bay and Helensvale districts,
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urgently look into establishing a Medicare facility as soon as is possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws the attention of the House to the public concern over the creation of human embryos for the specific purpose of fatal experimental research. The citizens are concerned that human life is deliberately being created with the premeditated intention to destroy it. They believe that this is a gross breach of the responsibility that each member of the human race has to another to ensure life is allowed to thrive and develop according to nature.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House do all in its power to ban the creation of embryos for the specific purpose of life destroying research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I present the Committee's report on counselling and ancillary services for Vietnam veterans, together with the minutes of proceedings and the evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Its choice of this reference, the services provided to Vietnam veterans, reflects the importance of the subject to members of the Committee. It was never intended to question the merits of the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service but rather, through it, to gain direction on the best way to provide more assistance to Vietnam veterans and to their families. It became clear to the Committee that the Counselling Service has developed a strong bond of trust and acceptance. In some instances it is the only instrument of government in which some veterans maintain confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: In total the Committee received 120 submissions and held six formal public hearings. We visited all the capital cities and a number of regional centres to hold informal meetings and discussions with over 300 veterans and their families. At the outset it should be emphasised that the majority of Vietnam veterans have made a successful transition from service to civilian life. However, this has not been easy and many veterans still experience health, social and other problems stemming from their involvement in Vietnam and its aftermath.

The Committee has made 27 recommendations to the Government to improve and expand the services offered to veterans and their families. I will not expand on them now because they are clearly set out in the report, which is to become a public document. However, we have recommended that the Counselling Service be given greater independence and a substantial increase in staffing levels.

I wish to place on record my thanks to my fellow Committee members for their interest and the efforts they have put into this work. We wish to convey our appreciation of the efforts of our Committee secretariat. Mr Nordin and his staff have been required to liaise with many groups and organisations. They have had to handle a large volume of personal and sensitive material. They have conducted themselves patiently and professionally in this process, for which they have our thanks.

A number of Committee members want to speak on this report, so I conclude by thanking the many veterans and family members who made personal submissions and who attended informal meetings at various centres. Many of these discussions were intense and distressing. However, they gave the Committee the opportunity to experience at first hand the depth of concern and feeling which exists. Above all, the Committee acknowledges that although Vietnam veterans and their families are in need of support, primarily they want to help themselves. The Committee believes that the adoption of its report will greatly assist this process and looks to the Government to respond positively to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Vietnam veteran and as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, it was a privilege to serve on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I believe that by degrees, veterans, including Vietnam veterans, will be fortified by the contents of the report. I commend all who have been involved with the Committee, including the Chairman, the staff and the many veterans who came forward, including Mr Tim McCombe of the Vietnam Veterans' Association, who is in the gallery today. They provided to the Committee their thoughts, concerns, practical suggestions and submissions in relation to the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many remaining problems associated not only with Vietnam veterans but also with veterans of Malaya and Korea, whose contribution and sacrifice are quite often overlooked. There are also veterans of World War II, World War I and the other conflicts in which Australia has been involved. In times of need, veterans in country areas have difficulties getting access to many of the support services provided by the various departments and organisations. It is especially so in places such as northern Queensland and many other country areas. I commend the fact that the report is very positive about this aspect, with particular reference to my own electorate in the location of Albury-Wodonga. I especially commend that recommendation to the Government.

I say to the nation, in relation to and following upon the tabling of this report about strengthening the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service: You are extending increasing understanding to veterans. For that I express my thanks. But please continue to expand that understanding and that sympathy because it is needed, not only for Vietnam veterans but also for veterans of other conflicts, in Malaysia and Korea, veterans from World War II, World War I and other activities in which Australian service personnel have been involved overseas, including the five groups of Australians overseas at this very time-a fact which is quite often overlooked.

Of all veterans, I would simply say this: We were sent by our country; we served our country; we did our best. We remember those who did not return, and we should continue to remember in a positive and helpful way those who have returned. This report is a step in that direction, particularly for those veterans who live outside the capital cities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me enormous pleasure to be one of those speaking endorsing this report, as it did to be a member of the Committee. I think it is important that even though there have been many previous inquiries into counselling services for Vietnam veterans, the 120 submissions that our Chairman referred to and the many people who came before us reflected the importance and justified the need for this particular inquiry, and all the recommendations again are a justification for that inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said, throughout the period of the inquiry we met many dedicated people, people who have never stopped working for the veterans, whose needs they understand so well, and indeed, for the families of the veterans. I, too, mention Tim McCombe, now the National President of the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia, because he, to me, represents those people who have worked so long on behalf of the veterans. I first met Tim McCombe before I was a member of parliament, when he and many others, such as the late and well remembered Phil Thompson, were appealing to the Government to consider the needs of veterans. For someone like me, who was always a passionate opponent of the war in Vietnam, it was extremely important that I had an opportunity to show my dedication to the people who went to fight in that war. It has often been said that they did not get the recognition that they deserve.

One of the recommendations in the report harks back to those days when Phil Thompson, Tim McCombe and others were appealing to the Government on behalf of their fellow veterans. Substantial concern continues to exist in the Vietnam veteran community about the effects of Agent Orange and other chemicals used in Vietnam. Amongst all the other very constructive recommendations I refer to just two. Paragraph 5.65 states:
The Committee recommends that an experienced research officer be seconded to the National Office of the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service to identify the specific research needs in this field-
chemical agents-
and to assist the National Director in co-ordinating and conducting this research.
Paragraph 5.66 states:

In addition, the Committee recommends that the National Office of the Vietnam Veterans' Counsel- ling Service take a leading role in monitoring the emerging data on the effects of exposure to chemicals in Vietnam.
We will be many years repaying to the servicemen in Vietnam the debt we owe them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to endorse the comments of my colleagues on this report from the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service. As a member of that Committee, I found the inquiry very interesting and informative and also something of an eye opener. I suppose the most striking realisation for me was that the problems which many Vietnam veterans have now and have had since their return are due as much to what happened after they returned as to what happened in the theatre of war.

SPEECH.PARA: The Vietnam war was an unpopular war and in the end it was a lost war. Veterans on their return were not treated as conquering heroes as other veterans have been and they were not feted with march pasts and flag waving and cheering. They were in many cases spirited back into the country in the middle of the night. They were told to get out of their uniforms as fast as possible and forget they had ever been there. This kind of treatment, this kind of reaction, led to anger and frustration in many cases and suppression of feelings which have later manifested themselves in many psychological and social problems, depression and aggression and marital and employment problems in particular. It is good to see that in the past year or so many Vietnam veterans have admitted that they are veterans, coming out of the closet so to speak.

Of particular interest to me were our dealings with the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service in Adelaide. The director, Glen Edwards, and staff are doing a wonderful job in dealing with any problems that Vietnam veterans in Adelaide may have. In particular, I commend that service for one innovation, namely, the after hours telephone counselling service. As we all know, crises do not usually occur from Monday to Friday between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m.; they tend to occur at night and over the weekend. This telephone counselling service has been invaluable to veterans in Adelaide. It is staffed principally by Vietnam veterans who have had some sort of counselling training and who refer the veteran to a professional counsellor. It is very pleasing that one of the recommendations of the report is that that service be extended to other States. I thank the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), for his competent and conscientious chairmanship, and I also thank the Committee staff, who are in the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dubois Mr S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is significant that the first report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs relates to the Inquiry Into Counselling and Ancillary Services for Vietnam Veterans. All members of this Committee shared a concern for the welfare of these veterans and gave this matter our top priority. The report makes certain recommendations on how the support services for Vietnam veterans could be strengthened. The difficulties that our Vietnam veterans faced when they came home have hardly been documented. They were not welcomed home as heroes. In fact, their welcome home march had to wait 15 years until October 1987. They did the job given to them by the government of the day. It took some time before the Returned Services League (RSL) accepted them as returned servicemen. The veterans felt that they had come home to an ungrateful people and were shunned for having done their duty. They had to rebuild their lives and, of course, some coped better than others. Various support services were established to help them. Commendable as these services are, the Committee believes that they can be expanded and improved. I was impressed by the people who addressed the Committee and their constructive approach. They always had the interests of the veterans at heart. I was pleased to hear the Prime Minister announce that a national memorial to the Australian Vietnam forces would be built. I believe that is timely recognition. I hope that the Government will respond quickly and positively to the recommendations contained in this report. I would like to add my recognition of the role that the Chairman, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), played in this Committee and I thank the staff of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very happy to be associated with the Standing Committee on Community Affairs and its inquiry into the services conducted by the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service. In fact, I have some personal experience in the sense that I was one of those who was lucky, or unlucky, in that my number did not come out of the barrel. Those who were born on 13 June were not called up and those who were born on 12 June were called up. SPEECH.PARA: The Committee listened to many people. Some veterans came back without problems, but many did not and it is those who came back with problems, psychological or otherwise, who must be considered. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) made a very good contribution, and I commend the report. I commend the staff as well; they were fantastic.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters I present the Committee's report relating to the report on the efficiency scrutiny into regionalisation within the Australian Electoral Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The report is concerned with the organisational structure of the Australian Electoral Commission and, in particular, whether the Commission should continue to have 148 divisional offices. The report is of vital interest to all members of the Federal Parliament and indeed all voters. The report details the Committee's findings from its inquiry into a 1987 efficiency scrutiny of the divisional structure of the Electoral Commission. The scrutiny was conducted by Dianne Saunders, the Deputy Australian Electoral Officer for Victoria, and recommended that up to seven divisional offices be amalgamated to form regional offices to reduce costs and allow office computerisation to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's report is called Is this where I pay the electricity bill? This title may seem a little strange but I shall explain its origin. During the inquiry the Efficiency Scrutineer, Dianne Saunders, told the Committee:

If you go around the divisional offices to talk to staff about something, it is most unusual for somebody to come into the office. They are often there to pay the electricity bill anyway-they have mistaken us for the electricity commission. In fact, we had the official opening of the new office for the division of McEwen when the new division was set up, and we were all there with Lady McEwen and various members to have the official opening ceremony, and a gentleman walked in saying, `Is this where I pay the electricity bill?'!
This anecdote typifies the difficulty that many Australians have in understanding the role of the Electoral Commission.

Submissions and evidence received by the Committee have shown there to be clear differences of opinion between the Electoral Commission, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA), divisional returning officers (DROs) and others as to the best organisational structure for the Electoral Commission. While the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes, and other senior staff of the Commission have argued strongly in favour of regionalising the Commission's divisional offices, most of the submissions and evidence received by the Committee have argued for a continuation of the status quo.

In its inquiry the Committee has considered a number of important issues. The issue of computers in the Electoral Commission has been of particular concern and the Committee has found there to be an urgent need for the Electoral Commission to make better use of modern computer systems. The Committee believes it is a serious deficiency in the Commission that its existing computer systems cannot cope with all the demands placed upon them and that some systems such as finance and personnel systems are not computerised. The Committee has concluded that as a matter of priority the Australian Electoral Commission must pursue the acquisition of modern computer equipment and the Committee has made two recommendations in this area. First, the Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission seek independent external advice on the computer equipment and systems needed in the Commission's offices which would enable the Commission to best achieve its goals. Secondly, the Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission adopt a more determined approach in seeking funds from the Government for the purpose of acquiring the modern computer equipment and systems it needs.

However, the Committee's major recommendations relate to the organisation of the Commission's divisional offices. In reaching its conclusions and recommendations on regionalisation the Committee has sought to consider broad issues rather than examine electorates on a case by case basis. The ACOA, DROs and some parliamentarians argued that having an Electoral Commission Office in each division provided a more convenient service to electors and ensured DROs had better local knowledge. The Committee believes that in some, but not all, cases DROs have developed extensive local knowledge under the existing divisional office structure. However, a regional office structure should not preclude staff from gaining local knowledge.

The Committee understands from evidence received during its inquiry that in most divisional offices no more than 15 electors visit the office during a typical week and that most enquiries are dealt with by telephone or by mail. The Committee concluded that regionalisation of up to three divisional offices in metropolitan areas would not seriously affect roll maintenance, election management or service to electors because of the transport and communications services which are available in these areas. However, the Committee concluded that regionalisation should not proceed in rural areas because of the great distances involved and the resulting transport and communications barriers which would affect service to electors and election management.

While the Committee has been presented with different regionalisation schemes it has had no desire to draft specific proposals for the regionalisation of metropolitan offices. The Committee believes the task of formulating a final regionalisation scheme to be the responsibility of the Australian Electoral Commission and the Government. However, the Committee may wish to comment on the Electoral Commission's future proposal for regionalisation.

The Committee has, therefore, recommended that regionalisation of the Australian Electoral Commission's divisional offices occur only in metropolitan areas. The regional offices should be formed by the combination of up to three divisional offices. The Committee recommends that senior staff within a metropolitan regional office at the administrative service officer 4, 5, or 6 level have continuing responsibility for specific divisions and be designated as divisional returning officers for specific divisions.

I would like to thank all those who contributed to the Committee's inquiry and, in particular, the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes; the Efficiency Scrutineer, Dianne Saunders; and those DROs who made submissions to the Committee. Similarly, the Committee also thanks Julie Pagonis from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and members of this Parliament for their contribution. The Committee is grateful for the work undertaken by its staff and, on behalf of the Committee, I thank Mrs Helen Misa, who is in the gallery today, Mrs Lexia Noakes and Trevor Rowe, the Committee's Secretary.

In closing I mention that this report is a unanimous report. I thank all members of the Committee, including the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), and other members for their cooperation in finalising this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable pleasure that I support the remarks of the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). It was a pleasure to work on this very important report. People may think that a report into the administration of the Commonwealth Electoral Office is a fairly dry and fairly immaterial matter. It is not. It goes to the very heart of our system of democracy and it is something to which there should be a bipartisan approach. I am pleased to say that there was on this Committee inquiry. The report of the Committee-it was made up of representatives from all of the major parties in this Parliament-was a unanimous report. For that reason I support the Committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would simply like to add emphasis to the Chairman's remarks and perhaps amplify one or two areas. Many people would think that the primary role of the divisional returning officer (DRO) is to maintain the electoral rolls. Of course, that is a very important responsibility but it is a long way from being the only responsibility of a DRO operating in our electoral system. Roll maintenance and roll review go on in the period between elections, as do a number of other functions. The Committee has recommended that there be no regionalisation or amalgamation in areas outside the metropolitan areas of Australia for a very good reason. Subsequent to the last election and also the recent referendum campaign, there has been criticism of the way the elections and the vote were conducted. The Commonwealth Electoral Commission has undertaken studies which have revealed inadequacies in its own procedures and revealed errors in the count. This is very serious. Whilst I do not want to overdramatise the consequences of these errors that have been revealed I want to say that it is important in a democracy that our system of determining the will of the people be above question and the people who are at the front line in determining that are the divisional returning officers of the Australian Electoral Commission. It is important that they are in a position to do their work well, efficiently and effectively.

Over and above maintaining the roll, there is a responsibility on a divisional returning officer to ensure that the mechanics of a poll are working accurately and effectively. Of course, this means ensuring that the staff responsible on polling days are educated, experienced and informed; that there is a non-partisan approach on the part of those staff; that polling places are adequate and are appropriately sited; and that the people responsible for counting votes when they are cast know what they are doing.

There is also a need to conduct an education function throughout the community. It is a far broader task than simply receiving enrolment claims, processing them and ensuring that the names go onto the list. For that reason I believe that our Committee has come down in its report with a recognition that, in the rural areas of Australia where the distances are great and the populations sparse, there is a need for a local identifiable officer to be responsible for a specific electoral division. If Australia were to move away from that concept, the system of democracy and voting that we have would be less acceptable to the community than it is at present. It is for that reason that I hope that the Government will recognise the validity of the arguments contained in this report, which have been supported unanimously, and accept our recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very brief statement in support of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The Australian Electoral Commission needed to look for ways in which it could increase the efficiency of its operation to meet its obligations under the 4 per cent second tier agreement. The Committee had some difficulty trying to decide on a role, and after much debate and thought we have reached a decision that does have strong bipartisan support-that is, that there be limited regionalisation in the cities. As the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has said, we found it hard to work out how we could not allow some regionalisation in the metropolitan areas if it was still possible to retain the unique role of the divisional returning officer. We saw country areas as being different, as having a specific focus in a regional centre and a community of interest. We felt that we would be changing the nature of the electoral office if we were to have any sort of regionalisation. I simply say that we have strong bipartisan support for limited regionalisation. We hope that the Government will take up the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lee) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's report on the Canberra leasehold system.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April this year a reference covering all aspects of the Australian Capital Territory leasehold system was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report. The terms of reference also gave the Committee the power to consider and make use of Professor Max Neutze's paper entitled The Canberra Leasehold System which the former Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory had commissioned in 1987. In response to a growing perception that the administrators of the leasehold system were not using the strengths of the system effectively to ensure balanced harmonious redevelopment of Canberra, particularly in Civic, the Senate referred Professor Neutze's paper to its Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report also. The resolutions referring the matter to the respective standing committees also empowered the committees to sit as a joint subcommittee to consider the ACT leasehold system. This report was prepared by that joint subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, which includes a minority report, looks at the establishment and functions of the leasehold system, including reasons for leasehold, the concept of leasehold, the functions of leasehold tenure, as well as leases and lease ordinances and benefits of the leasehold system. Issues which the joint subcommittee addressed cover a range of specific aspects of the leasehold system, such as length of lease, responsibility for planning and estate management, role of lease administration and redevelopment, effects of plans on planning and development authorities, and private sector involvement.

An area in which concern was expressed to the joint subcommittee was in the administration of the leasehold system. There was concern with the way the administration carried out its ground landlord role. Several areas where administrative reform is needed have been identified in chapter 4. These include amendments to lease purpose clauses, betterment, breach of purpose clauses, ordinance simplification and consolidation, and development rights.

In the final chapter the joint subcommittee addressed the question of public participation. Public participation is the essence of the political process and it is necessary and vital to the effective functioning of Canberra's leasehold system of land tenure. There are three areas where public participation, openness and accountability can be enhanced in the operation of the leasehold system of land tenure. These are public participation in planning decisions under section 11a of the City Area Leases Ordinance, section 17 of the City Area Leases Ordinance, and section 72a of the Real Property Ordinance.

The Committee has made 18 recommendations. In recommendation 1 the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth retain ownership of land in the ACT. Section 125 of the Australian Constitution states in part:

The seat of Government of the Commonwealth shall be determined by the Parliament, and shall be within territory which shall have been granted to or acquired by the Commonwealth, and shall be vested in and belong to the Commonwealth . . .

The majority of the Committee recognises that Canberra land is part of the national heritage, to be safeguarded and used for the benefit of the nation, and also that it is of vital importance to residents. The leasehold system provides an effective means of reconciling these qualities. Leasehold has provided a structure for planned, orderly and predictable development and has prevented speculation. It has ensured certainty and lessees know they have an enforceable contract in which rights and obligations are clear. It is also clear from the rate of development and redevelopment that the claim by a few large developers that the leasehold system has been a disincentive to investors is nonsense.

In recommendation 2 the Committee affirms the view that the leasehold system of property tenure provides an effective basis for land planning and management in the ACT and that it should be retained. The majority of the Committee believes that the system of public ownership of land with leasehold tenure has the capability to continue to serve the needs of the ACT at both the national and territorial level. However, there are weaknesses and deficiencies with the administration of the leasehold tenure system which has allowed Canberra land to be treated as the property of the lessees. These areas are identified in chapter 4, and recommendations 9 to 13 address these administrative weaknesses and deficiencies. The Committee also made recommendations on specific aspects of the leasehold system such as length of lease, responsibility for planning and estate management, role of lease administration and redevelopment, adherence to approved policy and development plans and private sector involvement.

One area which directly touches most residents of Canberra is residential leases. The Committee was aware of the special consideration which residential leases merit. The desire to hand down one's home and property from one generation to the next is a feature of the Australian sentiment and culture. Residential leases in Canberra are granted for 99 years. At present these leases will be renewed at the end of their term without payment of a further premium. Although renewal of residential leases has taken place, there is no legislation to give effect to this. By amending the City Area Leases Ordinance to incorporate a statutory right of renewal of residential leases, residential leases would have the security of knowing that their leases will be renewed. Thus the majority of the Committee has recommended that the City Area Leases Ordinance be amended to provide for the automatic renewal of residential leases at the end of 99 years without further charge.

The Committee's recommendation approximates residential leases in perpetuity, but the lease purpose clause still controls land use, and development rights are still clearly retained by the Commonwealth.

There has been an ongoing argument that leases should be converted to leases in perpetuity. One of the difficulties with perpetual leasehold is that it is fraught with contractual problems. The proposal for leases in perpetuity has been pressed by those concerned about the attractiveness of Canberra for investment purposes. However, as I have already said, it is quite clear that the leasehold system has not been a disincentive to investment as some people have argued. The value of the leasehold system for developers is reflected in a statement made by the founder and then Managing Director of Lend Lease Corporation Ltd, Mr Dusseldorp. He said:

As to the principle when they put it up for auction, not only did every bidder know exactly what he could and could not do with his particular site, but he also knew what everyone else-the other eleven owners in that particular block-could and could not do. One doesn't have to fear as to what is going to happen next door to him, what is going to happen in front of him.

The majority of the Committee has recommended that leases should be for a term of years rather than in perpetuity. Residential leases should be for 99 years and non-residential leases should be for 99 years or shorter periods. Their renewal should be at the discretion of and on terms negotiated with the ground landlord, and will include the payment of a further premium.

Four of the Committee's recommendations address public participation in planning decisions, public notification of changes to lease purpose and public information. There has been a lack of coordination and consultation between the planning and estate administration authorities. The Committee sounds a warning that in the planning and development of Canberra it must not be forgotten that Canberra is a national heritage to be safeguarded for all Australians. This is one of the major reasons why the majority of the Committee recommends the retention of the leasehold system of land tenure. I would like to express wholehearted appreciation to Professor Max Neutze, whose thorough, reasonable and judicious report led to this inquiry. I would also like to thank warmly all those who contributed to the inquiry through their submissions, and in particular to wholeheartedly acknowledge the able, accurate and efficient work of our secretary, Jane Vincent, and the other staff of the sub-committee secretariat, Glenice Castles and Jean Thompson. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I and some of my coalition colleagues have put in a minority report to this report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) leasehold system because we do not accept that the Commonwealth should maintain the leasehold system of property tenure for a limited life of 99 years for residential leases and 99 years or less for non-residential leases, as recommended in the report. Throughout Australia the concept of land tenure based on the principle of freehold has been widely accepted, particularly for residential property. Freehold tenure is an important element of our social and economic structure and, more than that, our national ethos. Australians have traditionally strongly opposed the concept of the nationalisation of land and that is the situation here in the ACT which is being supported by this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians broadly accept that freehold provides for greater security of tenure and that is why in 1980 most of the Northern Territory's crown leases were automatically converted to freehold. There is no logical reason why the people of the Australian Capital Territory should be denied at least the privilege of perpetual leasehold which is available to other Australians. My preferred option is, without doubt, for freehold tenure for both residential and non-residential land, but section 125 of the Constitution raises very real questions about whether that would be constitutionally feasible. Nevertheless, there is no question whatsoever that perpetual leasehold is a clear constitutional option.

The reasons for limited leasehold tenure being introduced in the first place were, first, to prevent speculation of land resulting from the siting of the national capital; secondly, to enable the Government to defray the cost of establishing and maintaining the capital through revenue derived from land rents; and, thirdly, to distribute throughout the community profits made from the increase in the value of the land. These reasons may have been relevant in the mid-1920s and into the 1930s, but they are no longer relevant to a city which has become mature and has developed its own momentum. I refer to Justice Else-Mitchell's inquiry into land tenure in the Australian Capital Territory, which reported in 1976 and which supported the proposition that I and my colleagues are putting forward, that:
Residential land in the ACT should be held under perpetual leases.

Proponents of the leasehold system argue principally that it facilitates planning. I would point out to the House that in every State of Australia there are State and local government statutory planning systems and there is no reason why a statutory planning system, with self-government coming in the Australian Capital Territory, would not be an acceptable proposition here.

I would also add in support of my very strong philosophical commitment to freehold, or in the context of the Australian Capital Territory, perpetual leasehold, one or two other arguments for changing the system from a limited leasehold to a perpetual leasehold system. First, to renew leases as the principal planning tool is to provide for piecemeal redevelopment because leases may expire at different times. In other words, it is a rather incomprehensible tool to use for planning if one is serious about giving a definite tenure for a lease. If, of course, one is not serious, if one takes the view that one may need to intervene after all at a certain stage, regardless of the tenure of the lease, then why bother with a tenure for a lease? It does not make very much sense. If one looks at what happens in suburbs such as Civic, Kingston, Turner and Braddon, one finds that land use has been significantly reviewed and changed regardless of the fact that there have been 99-year leases in those places. Another point the Opposition would certainly want to make is that freehold or perpetual leasehold may well increase the attraction to interstate investors of privately developed land. That is something that is important for a developing city such as Canberra for developing districts such as the Australian Capital Territory.

In conclusion, let me say that my view not only is supported by Mr Justice Else-Mitchell and by my colleagues on this side of the House, but also would be widely supported by the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. Indeed, it is supported in a working document prepared by the Department of Territories' Development Division in May 1987, which comes to this very logical conclusion:
Based on the foregoing discussion-
I have not time to go into all that-
it is recommended that the present system of 99-year term leases be changed to a system of leases in perpetuity.

I know there are officers in that Department who take an even stronger view that we should move in the Australian Capital Territory towards freehold and that constitutional implications of that ought to be and deserve to be examined on behalf of the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

We on this side of the House do not support, as the other side does, the nationalisation of land. We will never support the nationalisation of land. We support private ownership of land as the fundamental basis of Australian society. I am sorry that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) disagrees, but I am not with him on the nationalisation of land.
Motion (by Mr Langmore) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
