SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the Committee's third report, entitled Publication of Tabled Papers, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Publication of Tabled Papers report, the third report of the Procedure Committee for the Thirty-fifth Parliament, concerns the practices of this House in regard to the publication of tabled papers. As honourable members will probably know, where it is thought certain papers tabled may contain actionable material, their release is restricted. This report reviews our current practice and proposes amendments to standing order 320, the standing order that directly relates to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of background, Mr Deputy Speaker, may I briefly outline the current procedures that apply for the distribution or publication of papers tabled. The vast majority of papers tabled in this House are made freely available to members, the press and others, subject to certain distribution guidelines. The publication of papers to members is absolutely privileged. This privilege is provided by section 11 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. It does not apply to publication by officers of the House to persons other than members, nor does it apply to further or wider publication by the members themselves.

Where it is thought a paper may contain actionable material and it is considered it should be distributed widely, a motion is moved in the House to authorise its publication. These instances are not many-they average 14 each year-and usually apply to reports of the Auditor-General or reports of royal commissions. Papers that the House has ordered to be printed are also absolutely protected, but that protection is considered to apply only to those copies of the paper bearing the imprint of the Government Printer indicating that they are parliamentary papers. These copies become available some time after tabling.

In those cases where it is thought a paper may contain actionable material and the House has not authorised its publication, copies are provided to members on request with a stamp indicating that the document was provided in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. If a request is received from persons other than members, copies are not always made available as there is a potential liability because of the limitation of the scope of absolute privilege.

The question of the possible extension of absolute privilege to all papers tabled has been considered before. In 1984 the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege expressed a reluctance to recommend any changes that might extend the protection of absolute privilege beyond the borders of what it regarded as fundamentally necessary for the workings of Parliament. Section 11 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act reflects that recommendation.

Earlier this year the Senate considered the matter and replaced its standing order 362, which was similar to our standing order 320, with a standing order that authorises unrestricted publication of all papers tabled in the Senate. Following the Senate action, Madam Speaker wrote to the Committee requesting that it consider the matter and report to the House in due course. The Committee resolved to inquire into the matter and requested the Clerk of the House to submit a paper on the issue. In the course of its deliberations the Procedure Committee considered two questions: Firstly, should absolute privilege be extended to the publication of all tabled papers to any person? Secondly, should standing order 320 be revised to remove possible ambiguities?

There are a number of arguments for and against the extension of absolute immunity. These are listed in detail in the Clerk's paper appended to the report. The current arrangements could be seen as contrary to the spirit of the Standing Orders as there should not be any impediment to the free dissemination of tabled papers. They could also be seen as irksome and possibly risky. The differing practices of the House and the Senate could be seen as undesirable and confusing. The Committee has considered these issues and also sought the views of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife).

Whilst appreciating that there are definite advantages in providing for unrestricted publication with absolute immunity, the Committee has concluded that the present arrangements, whereby a positive publication order by the House is required to grant absolute immunity, should be retained. There is always a risk of damage to individuals and groups in the community should there be repeated and malicious publication of statements or allegations beyond the parliamentary sphere. The Committee has concluded that this risk outweighs the benefits of unrestricted publication. It must be remembered that this does not restrict the availability of a paper to any member, and the papers at issue are a very small proportion of those tabled each session. In practical terms, there will be very little restriction on the access to papers.

Under the arrangements proposed, the interests of the House and its members are recognised and the dangers of misuse are lessened. On the second matter, the adequacy of standing order 320, the Committee has recommended that the standing order be reworded to reflect the conclusions of the report and to remove a possible contradiction between the first and second sentences of the standing order. It is therefore proposed that the standing order provide that, with respect to those papers not authorised for publication nor ordered to be printed, access for non-members be subjected to the discretion of the Speaker where it is considered they may contain actionable material.
In conclusion, I would like to thank members of the committee, Mr McRae, secretariat staff, and Mr Bernard Wright for their assistance in this inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure entitled Publication of Tabled Papers. I believe there are good reasons why automatic privilege should not be given to documents merely because they are tabled in the Parliament. The House has available to it a method of providing privilege to documents which it considers should have privilege and that motion should be used only where it is considered necessary to provide privilege in order to protect persons or to provide information which the House itself believes should be generally available but which may contain items which could under some circumstances be actionable.

SPEECH.PARA: The consideration of this report was made more difficult by the fact that the Senate had already decided to introduce an automatic privilege provision for all tabled documents. But it was the belief of the Committee, and it certainly is my belief, that it is highly improper for the privileges which are accorded to this Parliament to be loosely used in a manner whereby all that is required for a person to be slandered or for other material to be published which can be damaging to individuals, organisations or persons in the community is for that information to be tabled in the Parliament, without at least the House where that information was provided having considered that the release of that information is in the public interest.

There have been instances-fortunately very few-where tabled documents have contained allegations which have been found to have little or no substance in fact but where the damage to individuals because those statements and documents were able to be repeated ad infinitum was such as their reputations could never have been properly recovered because of the lack of sensationalism about the fact that some report or tabled document was subsequently found to be in error.

I think the worst occasion that I can recall of a document being given privilege-it was given privilege by the House concerned-was when the so-called Khemlani papers were tabled in the Senate some time ago and were given privilege. Those documents contained very little which could have been said to have been of real factual substance but rather were political documents tabled for a political purpose. They were given privilege so that they could be exploited for political purposes. I hope that this Parliament will never see itself in that position again. During the time I have been here at least one document has been tabled in the House of Representatives which should never have been given privilege in my opinion.

The report cleans up some of the misunderstandings and the difficulties which exist with the present standing order. But it should be made clear that the consequence of the standing order is that, whilst a member has absolute access to tabled documents, the member does not have any immunity from prosecution if the member chooses to distribute tabled documents which have not been given the immunity of the Parliament. It is something that many members do not take account of. But if a member chooses to distribute a document which is his by right as a member of this Parliament, which contains actionable material and which has not been given privilege by the House, then the member takes the risk of action. It should be clearly understood that the risk is upon the member. It is no good complaining afterwards. Similarly, if a document is leaked or passed to a person and subsequently published, then the material has no protection because of its tabling in the Parliament unless the Parliament has taken the appropriate action. By that, I mean the House of Representatives because the Senate has chosen to act differently.

I support the report. I believe that the House should adopt it. I think it is a proper and responsible matter for a House of Parliament to act on. I do not believe that it is our responsibility, nor should we have the right, to publish, without due consideration, material which may be damaging to another person and which may not have been given the proper consideration of this House. I commend the report.
Motion (by Mr Mountford) proposed:
That the report be adopted.

—Pursuant to section 12aa of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, I present the Remuneration Tribunal 1988 Review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes with concern the problems confronting nursing homes, aged persons hostels and other aged persons facilities as a result of the most recent changes to Commonwealth funding of those facilities.

The House may recall that last week I spoke of the threatened closure of the Lilliane Brady retirement village in Cobar. This state of affairs has been brought about by the implementation of new funding arrangements by the present Federal Government for nursing homes and hostels throughout Australia. As we all know, these establishments have the responsibility of providing accommodation for the elderly and infirm who can no longer care for themselves.

As I related to the House on a previous occasion, aged care industry organisations Australia-wide are concerned that standards established by the Government for Commonwealth funding of staff care hours for nursing home residents are unrealistic, artificial and impractical. Like many, I fear that the Government may have deliberately set artificial standards in the resident classification instrument (RCI) to limit the number of nursing home residents and, therefore, under the new funding arrangements, its financial obligations to the industry.

I would like to bring to the attention of the House the present serious situation pertaining to the mining city of Broken Hill, which is a typical example of what must be happening in all centres of Australia in relation to care for our elderly and infirm citizens. Of course, the situation is particularly grave in the more isolated communities. Broken Hill has two nursing homes-the Home of Compassion and the Broken Hill Centenary Nursing Home. These have been founded out of the generosity of the people of Broken Hill and their concern for their pioneering citizens. Up until now various Federal governments have generously assisted in the establishment of those homes, and between them they care for 110 residents. Both are administered by Southern Cross Homes Inc. Broken Hill.

Broken Hill also has hostel accommodation at Aruma Lodge, which is another manifestation of the concern that Broken Hill people show for their senior citizens. Aruma Lodge has 46 permanent residents and one respite care resident. In addition to these establishments, the Broken Hill Base Hospital is presently catering in its geriatric wards for 58 long stay patients who, because of the lack of nursing home and hostel accommodation in Broken Hill, have nowhere else to go.

The geriatric section of the Broken Hill Base Hospital consists of Elleoura Court, with 36 women residents, and Corrindah ward for men, with 22 residents. This in itself is an horrendous situation because these wards are located in buildings that could be up to 100 years old. They are a legacy of neglect by previous State governments and can at best be described as fire hazards. They are suitable only for demolition to make way for geriatric care wards more in keeping with 1988 and the way in which the Broken Hill people would wish to care for their elderly citizens.

The whole depressing state of affairs in the care for the elderly in Broken Hill has recently come to a head with a press statement from Mr Bob Taylor, the Regional Director of the Department of Health located in Dubbo, that indicates that he and, therefore, the State Government believe, based on criteria laid down by the Federal Government, that there is a gross oversupply of nursing home-type beds in Broken Hill, and, in order to avoid duplication of service for which the Federal Government should be responsible, that the number of long stay beds, now standing at 58, should be reduced to 30. He also indicates that the provision of hostel bed accommodation will overcome the problem, as will home care help.

While I am not happy at the State Government's attitude, I can in no way totally blame Mr Taylor and the State Government for the parlous position in which they find themselves, caused by drastic Federal funding cutbacks to the States and, in particular, New South Wales. The State Government, therefore, has had no alternative but to try to make the Federal Government shoulder its responsibilities in regard to care for the aged and infirm. To do otherwise would place even further burdens on its under-funded health system, which is being stretched to the limit.

If we look at a recent survey of the Broken Hill situation we find that, based on Commonwealth Government figures, which to me are at best Dickensian Scrooge in their bias, we are led to believe that Broken Hill has a surplus of 83 nursing home beds, despite the fact that we have already 28 people in the Broken Hill Base Hospital who, according to the health bureaucracy, should be nursing homes or hostel-type accommodation.

We also have 100 people who are presently on waiting lists for nursing home accommodation in Broken Hill. In relation to hostel accommodation, and even according to the Scrooge figures of the Federal Government, we presently require an additional 60 places in hostel-type accommodation in Broken Hill. Despite this revelation, we have Southern Cross Homes applying to build hostel-type accommodation and being refused by the Federal Government bureaucracy. In fact, despite what Government figures might say, we presently have 160 elderly citizens waiting for hostel-type accommodation in the city. This means there are at least 260 elderly citizens urgently requiring nursing home or hostel-type accommodation in Broken Hill.

What about home care help? Honourable members will recall that the Government on many occasions has said that a reduction in nursing home beds will be offset by an increase in hostel beds and an increase in home care aid to enable the elderly to remain in their own homes. No-one in this House would deny that the best situation for elderly people is in their own homes but, of course, eventually that is not the case; they have to leave their homes to receive that care they require. Despite this, we find in Broken Hill, and no doubt in other centres, that funding for home care has not increased over the last three years. This has seriously affected the services that Home Care can provide in Broken Hill despite the devoted work being done by the staff of that organisation. Any move to force elderly patients in the Broken Hill hospital back into the community would make the home care aid situation untenable.

One of the problems, of course, is that we now have a system of funding that is based on a categorisation of residents in nursing homes that goes from one to five, with the residents who are most in need of care being category one. Category one also attracts the most funding. This in itself causes problems because we find nursing homes having to obtain high category residents in order to remain viable.

We also have hostels without adequate facilities trying to provide accommodation for people who should be in nursing homes. This is also done in order that adequate funding can be obtained. These conditions, of course, cannot be sustained and eventually the whole system will fall apart at the seams to the detriment of the infirm and the aged.

According to Government figures, there would normally be throughout Australia 10 per cent of nursing home residents in category one. In Broken Hill, in a nursing home population of 110, there is not one resident classified in that category. Therefore, the income of the nursing homes is seriously affected. If this trend in funding continues, it will be only a matter of time before both Broken Hill nursing homes will be unable to fund their operations, and the city will find it has a catastrophe on its hands so far as care for the elderly and infirm is concerned.

The nearest alternative nursing homes to Broken Hill are situated in Mildura, nearly 300 kilometres away, and Adelaide, which is approximately 500 kilometres from Broken Hill. These establishments find it hard to accept residents because their situation is similar to that being experienced in Broken Hill. Of course, the people of Broken Hill do not want their senior citizens, who are a vital link with the history of the city and who are their loved ones, living so far from them. As most people would know, Broken Hill at the moment is facing a difficult industrial situation with a number of people being retrenched from the mines. A number of those young people, of course, have to leave the city and travel to other major centres for work. They do not want to leave that city knowing that their parents cannot get into nursing homes or hostels and concerned that their parents will be forced to live out their last years in their own homes where they will not be properly cared for.

The people of Broken Hill are noted for the care and concern they show for their elderly citizens, as they are noted for their militancy when it comes to fighting for justice in matters which adversely affect their city. I am sure that they will add their support to communities throughout Australia who are angry at the way their senior citizens are being treated by the present Federal Labor Government. This is a Government that is supposed to be concerned with compassion for everyone who is underprivileged. But we see here, of course, in the situation that is developing in the home care or the nursing area and hostel accommodation-in fact, right across the board in care for our elderly citizens-that the Government is not facing up to its responsibilities.

The situation is now at a critical stage. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)-indeed, I ask the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-to do something constructive immediately in order to relieve the uncertainty, suffering and misery that elderly citizens and their families in Broken Hill and throughout Australia are now experiencing as a result of the Government implementing a policy that puts dollars before the peace of mind of our aged but valuable citizens.

I know that there is a speaker on the Government side who will be taking part in this debate. I would like to ask him to let honourable members know exactly what the Government has in mind in order to alleviate the situation. The situation exists not only in Broken Hill. I mentioned last week the Lilliane Brady Retirement Village in Cobar. There is a problem in Narrandera so far as care for the elderly is concerned. The fact is that the State Government can no longer meet its commitments because of Federal funding cutbacks. I would ask the speaker-in fact, I would ask the Minister and the Prime Minister-to please do something for these people who need our attention, who need to be in nursing homes, who need to be in hostel care accommodation and who need home care help.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respect the position taken by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) in his concern for the elderly people in his electorate, but I really think that the motion he has moved today is a tongue-in-cheek exercise, or else he has either been misled by those who helped him research his material or he is totally ignorant of the very positive and progressive policies that have already been implemented by the Hawke Labor Government-policies that contrast with the dismal record of the Liberal-National parties prior to 1983. My personal view is that this issue should be an apolitical one. It is one that concerns every parliamentarian and every person in our community who is really concerned about the elderly.

SPEECH.PARA: We appreciate that Australia is an ageing society; it is an ageing community. Recently I had the privilege of opening a new recreation centre in the township of Biloela. I took out some points raised by the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, at another meeting where he pointed out that in America there are about 100,000 Americans who are already over 100 years of age. Coming back to Australia, that suggests we already have something like 5,000 Australians who are already over 100 years of age. One starts to appreciate that, for every elderly person, there is in the work force at the moment something like five people. However, within 35 to 36 years, on the present ageing character of our nation, for every elderly person out there, there will be only two in the work force. So we have a major problem, a very serious problem. It is the Government that has begun to grapple with that problem.

It is a great pity that in the past governments have not set their priorities clearly at resolving the future needs of the community and the future needs of elderly people. Up until we came to government-and I ask the honourable member for Riverina-Darling to take this on board-93 per cent of all funds were being spent on 7 per cent of the elderly who were in the institutions. We had 7 per cent being spent on the 93 per cent of the population still in their homes. There was a total imbalance. It resulted in a very high per capita rate on nursing homes but a very low coverage for those people needing domiciliary care.

I know the honourable member's personal interest and his concern, but he has to understand that since 1983 there have been numerous reports, time and time again, from caring bodies officially set up by this Parliament and by the States. They have brought down reports after thorough investigation of the need for fairer and more efficient aged care support systems. It has taken this Government to act upon them. I agree we need to do so much more, because I have waiting lists in my own electorate. But when one starts to appreciate what we are doing and where the money is being spent, I think the criticism by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling is unfair when he says we should start shouldering our responsibilities. I suggest that is what is happening.

The honourable member mentions hostel places, but over the last five years we have had a 67 per cent increase in the number of hostel places. In dollar terms, in 1983 we were spending $36m on hostels. This year it will be $121m. That is 3 1/2 times what we were spending 5 1/2 years ago. The number of hostel places has doubled since the Hawke Labor Government came to power. We have spent some $376m in the construction and upgrading of new hostel and nursing home beds since 1982-83. That is a lot of money. We have seen the home and community care-HACC-program introduced. In 1983-84 we were spending $65.4m. This year $209m-more than three times as much-will be spent on those people who want and need to live in their own homes under the home and community care program. In 1983, nursing home subsidies totalled $697m. That figure has now almost doubled to $1.265 billion.

We see a government in action, a government trying to solve the problems and trying to set its priorities correctly. It has established the HACC program; it has upgraded the range of domiciliary services to the elderly and young people with disabilities; it has extended the range of hostel subsidies to increase choice; and it has introduced the respite care system. Previously, relatives who tried to look after their elderly loved ones had to do so for 52 weeks a year. This Government has introduced an initiative whereby beds are set aside in the institutions for those elderly folk. In some cases in my area beds are set aside in hospitals to give relatives some relief. The elderly people go into the institutions and are cared for. The same is true of recreation areas. It is not just a matter of providing beds but of ensuring quality of life, and I believe the initiative is quite exciting. I talk to the church and community groups who run these homes, hostels and institutions, and they applaud what this Government is doing to provide recreation facilities. There is also ongoing funding for nursing homes. While the emphasis is now on domiciliary care, there is still ongoing funding for nursing homes which, as I said, has almost doubled since the 1983 financial year.

We have also introduced an assessment program. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling asks, `What are you doing?'. Very often in the past when people reached a certain age and there was no-one in the town to care for them or if their relatives could not do it because of the scope of their home or the lack of facilities there, those people were put into an institution. Today there is an ongoing assessment program that is determining the individual needs of those elderly people and addressing the people with special needs and disabilities. We also have programs that cover those who have special ethnic problems and those who live in isolated areas, aspects that were not addressed previously. With all due respect to the honourable member for Riverina-Darling, I believe that the pre-1983 record was dismal, for there was an emphasis only on nursing homes. The emphasis lacked balance. There was a poor, or perhaps non-existent, assessment procedure and a lack of coordination between the States and the Commonwealth. The funding simply encouraged inefficiency and I suggest that it was ad hoc. Instead of condemnation, there should be commendation, and commendation has come from many groups which understand the problem and which urge the allocation of extra funds but which accept the priorities, the program and the all-encompassing and very careful strategy.

Recently I spoke with the local authorities in the township of Mount Morgan. That area was given $80,000. That sum may not sound much when we consider the total budget of this nation for aged care, but that $80,000 was to build four attached cottages for elderly folk in the township of Mount Morgan. Recently, the Bill Shuttlewood Lodge was built in Yeppoon, again to help those who wish not to go into institutions but to live in a sense of community in a lodge with other elderly people. That was built with moneys provided in the main by the Federal Government. Just this year $16m will be spent on local government and community accommodation programs. We are trying to address not just one aspect, not just those who need nursing home care; the broad canvas is gradually being painted and completed. It is a canvas that takes in a strategy for superannuation.

As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling knows, previously people who took superannuation paid 15 per cent tax on the first $55,000 and 30 per cent tax on the sum over $55,000. If people received a lump sum of $100,000, the tax at that time would have been about $22,000. But to encourage people to care for themselves in the future, we have changed the tax system so that there is now no tax on the first $60,000 and only 15 per cent tax over that. On a lump sum of $100,000, previously people would have paid $22,000 in tax and now they will pay $8,000. Again, this is an indication of a government carefully going through the problems, spotlighting the anomalies and difficulties.

I suggest that the Opposition has its role, and it is the job of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling to look after his own electorate. The Opposition has a role to criticise, but it also has a responsibility to present alternatives. I have not heard those alternatives. I would like to know whether the Opposition will pursue a privatisation line under which it would hand over all these areas to private enterprise. We have only to look at the lack of care in countries such as the United States of America, where the emphasis is on the private enterprise realm to provide care and security for the elderly. The attitude is, `If you haven't got the money, you can sleep in the streets'. That is not the emphasis of this Government; it is not the emphasis of the Australian Labor Party, but I have not heard what the Opposition's policy really is. Will it return to an emphasis on institutionalised care? Will it move away from the HACC program and domiciliary care and go back to the pre-1983 situation with the emphasis on, and moneys being spent on, only those who lived in institutions? Will it hand the matter to the States, or will it simply play politics? People have a right to know. Is the Opposition against the redistribution of resources that is taking place to ensure a new quality of life for the elderly in our community? Is it against the HACC program? Is it against greater community involvement in planning? There will always be room for improvement, and every member of the Government accepts that; every member of the Government, working in committees and working individually with Ministers, is working for this.

I would like consideration to be given to special loan arrangements to help those who stay in their homes to maintain the quality of their homes, to be able to build security rails in the bathrooms, to have the steps fixed and to have the houses painted. One of the problems facing elderly people is that they lack the capacity to upgrade and maintain their homes. Because they live on a pension and because they do not have extra funds, they get to the point where they simply cannot put money back into their home. Even mowing the lawn becomes a financial burden at times. Somehow-and I do not know how we are to address the situation-we must come up with a system whereby the blue army, which operates in some areas with people working on a part-time basis, or some loan arrangement could assist people to upgrade and improve the standard of their homes so that they can stay there. Honourable members would know that in Queensland many of the houses are on stilts or posts. That is all right when people are young, but the elderly find it very hard to negotiate the steps. That is a problem. We must consider the special and individual problems of people.

Whilst I appreciate that there must be ratios of funding when it comes to the number of beds in a certain area based on the elderly component in our communities, I question whether the regional system is the best. The Fitzroy region that I represent has, over many years, seen the development of aged care facilities, such as in Rockhampton and some of the other larger areas, but in more recent times the elderly people have moved to the Capricorn Coast to places such as Mount Morgan, where aged facilities are not provided for them. There is nothing worse than having to dislocate the elderly, to move them 25 kilometres or 125 kilometres-no matter what the distance, they are dislocated from their loved ones, friends and relatives. Whilst keeping in mind the need to ensure an even playing field in expenditure, we must rethink our attitude and understand that in some areas, because of changes in the population structure, there is a greater movement of elderly people. I ask that consideration be given to that matter.

I come back to the motion; I believe it is unfair. I understand the concern of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling, and I applaud him for that. It is proper that he stand up in this chamber and argue for his people, but I believe that his facts are wrong. He has not thought through the real effort of this Government, the things it has done to address a problem that can only get worse. It is up to the Opposition, when it criticises, to put up the alternatives. I believe that this Government has turned around the problem and that, given the strategy that is in place, we can depend upon a new quality of life for millions of Australians in the next two decades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this motion, no matter how briefly, and I certainly support the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). I do not really want to attack the previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), but I must say that it is all right for him to stand up in the Parliament of Australia, being listened to by Australian citizens over the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and trot out these statistics. But it is empty rhetoric. The reality is that out in the electorate people are not getting sufficient care. There is a great need.

SPEECH.PARA: Only two weeks ago I spent two hours at a meeting with members of the board of the Autumn Lodge Retirement Village in Macksville in my electorate and representatives of the hospital. They are in desperate straits because the system is not working. On the other hand, in the southern part of my electorate, the Port Macquarie Garden Village is a superb elderly care centre providing units, a hostel and a nursing home. That has been built without costing the Commonwealth Government one single penny of capital expenditure and right now, because of the need, not because of the statistics but the real need on the ground, the group involved has offered to build facilities and provide 20 more nursing home beds at no cost to the Government, But the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) says no. I cannot understand why. I know there is an ongoing cost, but the need is there.

Just as the honourable member for Riverina-Darling said that in Broken Hill there is an inadequate number of beds because the formula is not working and is wrong, equally it is wrong on the north coast. I refer particularly to my electorate of Cowper and the fact that because it has the best climate in Australia so many people want to retire and live in places from Port Macquarie to Coffs Harbour. The proportion of people aged 65 years and over is more than 50 per cent greater than the rest of Australia. Yet the provision of nursing home beds goes along with the population formula, and it is wrong and inadequate. Right up and down the north coast of New South Wales there is a great need for more nursing home beds and the Government, because it is committed to this formula, is not taking action and is not permitting the people who are prepared to provide the facilities to go ahead and do so.

I also take this opportunity to refer to the home and community care program. The honourable member for Capricornia suggested that the Government needed commendation rather than some form of attack. I will commend it on the principle of its program and on the way it is worded in the book because, yes, we do want our elderly folk to stay in their own homes as long as possible. Anyone with any sense wants that; and the elderly themselves and the community want that. But the reality is that the infrastructure is not there. We cannot say to people who are unable to tie their shoelaces or cut their toe nails `Stay and look after yourself' unless we have the infrastructure. The Meals on Wheels Service must be available, as well as home care services. There have to be people to come in and do a bit of cleaning because the old people we are talking about cannot even bend down. This is where the program falls down. It is all right in theory but we are not dealing with theory or statistics. We are dealing with elderly Australians who need care and support and, quite frankly, in spite of the desire by the honourable member for Capricornia for praise, praise is not due. There is no way that it can be given. What we have is rhetoric; a system which on paper is fine.

In the last couple of weeks I have had calls from very distressed people because their 94-year-old mother had to be turfed out of the hospital and there was no nursing home bed available for her to go. I am not speaking about the distances that exist in the Riverina-Darling electorate or that the people of Broken Hill have to endure, but even within a more closely settled area like the north of New South Wales if our grandmother or grandfather has to go into a nursing home we do not want that home to be in Newcastle when we are in Kempsey. We do not want our elderly to be in Brisbane or some similar distance away because the whole fabric of care for elderly people involves the family and the support of friends and people being in their own environment. I cannot imagine anything worse for an elderly person needing nursing home accommodation than to be shunted off a couple of hundred kilometres from where they lived their lives; shunted off from their family, their friends and the environment they know so well. This is happening all over Australia; I am not talking about isolated instances. Elderly Australians are being treated as numbers and not as people, and it is not good enough.

I have no hesitation in giving the honourable member for Riverina-Darling my strongest possible support because I know from my personal experience and from my contacts with nursing homes and hostels throughout the electorate of Cowper that the need is still there to provide more care, and I also know from talking with many agencies of the need for home care as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) commends the Dalai Lama for his past efforts to resolve the problems of Tibet through negotiation with the People's Republic of China and for dissuading the Tibetan people from using violence to regain their freedom;
(2) commends the Dalai Lama for his new proposal in his continued quest for peace and expresses its support for the thrust of his proposals;

(3) calls on the leaders and the Government of the People's Republic of China to respond positively to the proposal of the Dalai Lama and to enter into earnest discussions with the Dalai Lama, or his representatives, to resolve the question of Tibet along the lines proposed by the Dalai Lama; and

(4) calls on the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to express the support of the Australian Parliament for the proposals of the Dalai Lama and to use their best efforts to persuade the leaders and the Government of the People's Republic of China to enter into discussions with the Dalai Lama, or his representatives, regarding the proposal of the Dalai Lama and the question of Tibet.

Tibet is a 2,000-year-old country with a unique culture, language, spiritual tradition, and history, which has been occupied by the People's Republic of China since 1950. The Tibetan people have persistently struggled to regain their independence ever since. But the Tibetans have rarely used violence in their struggle, and therefore have rarely achieved the attention given to areas of the world where violence is the norm, such as the Middle East and Northern Ireland. Recently, within Tibet, there have been unrest and clashes between police and the public with the resulting death of a number of Tibetans and the imprisonment of many more. These events provide a glimmer of much larger problems in Tibet.

On 21 September 1987 the Dalai Lama issued a five-point peace plan for Tibet. It is a dramatic contribution to a potentially peaceful resolution of the growing Tibetan crisis. This peace plan deserves the kind of attention currently being given to peace plans for the Middle East, Afghanistan, and Central America. The plan has five basic components, which can be summarised as follows: firstly, transformation of the whole of Tibet into a zone of peace; secondly, abandonment of China's population transfer policy, which threatens the very existence of the Tibetans as a people; thirdly, respect for the Tibetan people's fundamental human rights and democratic freedoms; fourthly, restoration and protection of Tibet's natural environment and the abandonment of China's use of Tibet for the production of nuclear weapons and dumping of nuclear waste; and fifthly, commencement of earnest negotiations on the future status of Tibet and of relations between the Tibetan and Chinese peoples.

The implementation of the first part of the plan would entail the removal of Chinese troops and military installations from Tibet, which would enable India to remove its border troops. The Dalai Lama has stated that the whole area would be `transformed into a zone of ``Ahimsa'' '-non-violence-`and once again act as ``a buffer state separating the continent's great powers''.' An international agreement would define and satisfy the border security interests of Tibet, China, and India, thus defusing border tensions and contributing to regional harmony. The second component of the plan refers to the fact that China is currently engaged in a massive program to encourage Chinese to move to Tibet and settle there. Under this policy Tibetans are already a minority in their own country with some 7.5 million Chinese settlers as against 6 million native Tibetans. In addition, there is a Chinese military force estimated at 500,000 soldiers. This population transfer is an age-old strategy to impose dominance, and needs to be stopped and reversed.

The human rights and democratic freedoms, referred to in point three, are severely curtailed at present. Estimates of current political prisoners range from 3,000 to 4,000. Geshe Lobsang Wang-chuk, a monk and Buddhist scholar who was arrested in 1981 for writing about the history of independent Tibet, died on 4 November 1987, in Drapche Prison in Lhasa; he had been adopted by Amnesty International as a prisoner of conscience. There are reported to be some 100,000 Tibetans imprisoned in labor camps.

Reports of violations of human rights are well documented. Many affidavits are available and honourable members who are interested can come to my office to see them. I have many from Amnesty International and the Human Rights Commission in Geneva. On 24 October this year the Human Rights Commission in Geneva faxed to me an analysis of 21 reports of violations of human rights of people in detention in Sangyip and Gurtsa prisons in Lhasa. It is worthwhile quoting from some of the analyses of those 21 reports.
All the reports describe beatings: `indiscriminate' . . . `whenever questioned' . . . `to death' . . . `unconscious' . . .
Some of the synopses from those affidavits and information currently in the possession of the Human Rights Commission are as follows:
Kusho Chundak (abbot of Ganden monastery) was beaten continuously for two months on his arms and legs until broken.
. . . there were 400 prisoners . . . at Gurtsa, of which 98 per cent suffered serious injuries from torture . . . arms, legs and ribs broken, wrists dislocated . . .

By the time he arrived in prison, P. was unconscious from the beatings . . . placed in a tub of very cold water. When he regained consciousness he was pulled out of the water and beaten and questioned until he again lost consciousness.
Most of the nights I was beaten' . . . `I was handed over from one official to the other. In between, I was tortured and interrogated'
A man from Kham died in a cell behind mine. He was very badly beaten and they did not give him any medical treatment.
Many prisoners report being tied during beatings, or handcuffed and shackled.

`He had his hands shackled all day long. Frequently they beat him with electric batons. Sometimes he was made to lie face down in a ditch and when the water came in, the Chinese would force him down again with their feet.'
Nun B was beaten with an electric baton and wooden sticks. They stripped her and trampled her head under foot, they kicked her many times so hard that she could no longer move.
Two nuns for R nunnery are under treatment following insertion of sticks in their vagina while in detention.
Nun D is 23, they applied the electric baton first to her private parts, then to her mouth.

There are constant affidavits and so many substantiated reports that the questions of the total violation of the basic human rights of Tibetans in detention in Tibet, under Chinese domination, are just unarguable. It is a great tragedy that this sort of thing is occurring in this world. I commend to honourable members the 1988 Asian Watch report entitled Human Rights in Tibet and the report prepared for International Alert by the Rt Hon. Lord Ennals and Frederick Hyde-Chambers which was published in 1988. I think honourable members should familiarise themselves with those reports.

Environmental issues are touched on in part four of the plan. The Chinese are introducing new agricultural practices into Tibet and, in the process, destroying the forests and wildlife there. In addition, the dumping of nuclear waste in Tibet and the use of Tibet to develop and produce nuclear weapons are kept away from public scrutiny. This is a major problem and one that needs full exposure. Under the five-point peace plan these nuclear related developments would cease and full attention would be given to restoring the ecology of Tibet. There is evidence that a nuclear missile site has been established in Tibet and many reports that 25 per cent of the nuclear weapons of the People's Republic of China are stored in Tibet. The last point, the commencement of earnest negotiations on the future status of Tibet, is the key point in terms of giving reality to any part of the plan. The proposal states:

We wish to approach this subject in a reasonable and realistic way, in a spirit of frankness and conciliation and with a view to finding a solution that is in the long-term interest of all: the Tibetans, the Chinese, and all other peoples concerned.

Here is an opportunity for the People's Republic of China, which claims that it is opposed to colonialism, to come to terms with its own major example of colonialism. The situation in Tibet is desperate. More than one million Tibetans have died since military rule was established by China in 1950; two-thirds of Tibetan territory has been added to adjoining Chinese provinces; and more than 6,000 monasteries have been destroyed. I think the House should note that that figure is over 6,000. One report that I have indicates that a further 2,624 monasteries have been destroyed. Most of those monasteries were built before Christ. They have stood the test of time in a culture over 2,000 years old, yet since 1950 it has been well documented that over 6,000 monasteries containing priceless treasures and artefacts have been taken from the face of this earth. That alone should cause any reasonable thinking person to stand up in anguish and protest to the People's Republic of China at this gross vandalism of antiquity alone.

The Chinese are attempting to control and render powerless the Buddhist religion which remains at the heart of the Tibetan culture. The full story of the violation of human rights in Tibet is brilliantly presented by John F. Avedon in his book entitled In Exile from the Land of Snows. That was a vintage publication in 1986. I have a copy and I think honourable members should read that book as well.

In 1959, 1961 and 1965, the United Nations General Assembly called upon China to end violations of Tibetan human rights. Since then, there has been precious little response from the world community. This year, as a result of the demonstrations in Tibet, the United States Congress and the United States Senate passed resolutions condemning human rights abuses in Tibet. I might add that the motion now before this House is in almost identical terms to the motion passed by the United States Congress and the United States Senate. However, the United States Administration, intend on maintaining good relations with China, supported Chinese efforts to end dissent in Tibet which was very violently done.

The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, fled into exile in India in 1959 along with 100,000 other Tibetans. Since then he has been one of the world's consistent spokespersons for non-violence and for the self-determination of the Tibetan people. If we believe in non-violence it is incumbent on us in this House to support essentially non-violent struggles and not let the violence equals media attention equals world attention equation to be the driving force of our peace and justice efforts. A statement was issued by the Dalai Lama on 10 March this year which was published in the Tibetan National Day. That statement reads:

I have always felt that violence breeds violence. It contributes little to the resolution of conflicts. I, therefore renew my appeal to all freedom-loving people to support our non-violent struggle for the survival of our national identity, our culture, and our spiritual tradition, and to persuade the Chinese Government to abandon its oppressive policies.

The Dalai Lama and the Tibetans are not seeking to restore outdated political and social institutions. They are working, non-violently, for the opportunity for the Tibetan people to decide their own future and to be responsible for it. The five-point peace plan has much to commend it. It deserves our support and the support of the Australian people. Supporters of non-violence should help to put the world spotlight on this peace plan and encourage the commencement of negotiations on the future status of Tibet. Let us address the issue of Tibet before more violence occurs rather than after.

I am pleased to report to the House on the very recent visit of the Premier and of the Foreign Affairs Minister of the People's Republic of China. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), representing Australia, held discussions which included debate on what was occurring in Tibet. I understand from Senator Evans that Australia's position was clearly put to the Chinese delegation-that Australia and the Government view with concern the well-documented and unarguable acts of oppression and gross violation of human rights which are occurring in Tibet.

There are many problems in the world but perhaps the Tibetan problem is unique. It is a religious culture of great antiquity which, throughout known history, has been a culture primarily of non-violence, where Buddhist monks are educationalists, teachers of language and the preservers of the ancient culture. When one sees a unique culture like that being destroyed-and destruction is what it is all about-and being taken from the face of the earth so that such an antiquity will no longer exist, the world cannot remain silent, this Parliament cannot remain silent and no Australian can remain silent. I urge this House to support the motion and to support the freedom of the Tibetan people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to second the motion moved by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) on the question of Tibet and its relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC). I do so because I welcome debate and discussion on the question, although I might not agree entirely with the motion as drafted. It is important that in this Parliament we are able to debate the issue carefully and thoughtfully. We should recognise the relationship that this country has with the People's Republic of China but ask the Government of the People's Republic of China to realise that we believe that where there are human rights violations we have the right to raise those issues wherever they occur in the world, whilst not wanting to interfere in the internal management or affairs of the People's Republic of China.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great respect for the work that has been done by the Chinese leadership to restructure the economy, stimulate growth and improve the standard of living of the people of China. They are to be commended for that. The first aspect of the motion moved by the honourable member for McEwen reads as follows:

(1) commends the Dalai Lama for his past efforts to resolve the problems of Tibet through negotiation with the People's Republic of China and for dissuading the Tibetan people from using violence to regain their freedom.

I believe that the Tibetan people ought to be able to regain freedom. I think the Dalai Lama has to state clearly in the near future what he means by freedom. When the Dalai Lama administered the territory it was what is called a theocracy as opposed to a democracy. There needs to be a clear statement from the Dalai Lama on what he has in mind in relation to freedom. One does not want to replace one form of totalitarianism with another. I am not suggesting that he is going to do that, but I think there needs to be a clear statement on that matter.

I was not sure when the honourable member circulated the motion which proposal he was referring to in paragraph (2), which commends the Dalai Lama for his new proposal in his continued quest for peace. The honourable member stated that he was referring to the 1987 statement by the Dalai Lama. That is interesting. I think there has been a development since then, because whilst in 1987 the Dalai Lama put a peace plan before the United States Congress to convert Tibet into a demilitarised zone-which would in fact provide a buffer zone between India and China-and halt Chinese immigration to Tibet because of its human rights position, he has qualified that statement a little this year. That happened in a speech made, or certainly distributed, before the European Parliament in Strasbourg in June this year in which he proposed that Tibet should be an autonomous region and a self-governing democratic political entity in association with China. Commentators have said that the Dalai Lama was calling for `one country, two systems', which is an analogy with the Beijing policy and the agreement with the Thatcher Government over the future of Hong Kong.

That shows that the Dalai Lama has been prepared to make concessions. I hope, in the spirit of the concessions that the Dalai Lama has made, that the Government in Beijing will accept that and enter into serious negotiations with him. I know there have been discussions at lower levels between the PRC and the Dalai Lama. I know that the PRC would like the Dalai Lama to return to Beijing and live there. I do believe progress is possible, but there needs to be goodwill on all sides, particularly by the PRC. Probably concessions need to be made by both sides.

As I have said, I admire and congratulate the People's Republic of China on the restructuring of its economy. There has been a freeing up of the economy. There has been a recognition of the importance of the market-place in delivering an increased standard of living to people in China. I hope that the PRC recognises that that increased standard of living, that freeing up of the economy-the allowing of free markets so that people can produce their own goods for sale in the market-place-should occur in Tibet.

I congratulate the PRC on the development of special economic zones. I have visited at least one of those. The PRC, like the Soviet Union, has to face the question of what it does with autonomous regions and national minorities. I am far from being an expert on the history of China, but the histories of China and Tibet are obviously interwoven, as is the history of the provinces or autonomies, and the gathering together of power in a central region after the exploitation of China in the past by Western powers. They might seem fairly strong words, but it is the truth. The country has been through a stage of centralisation and we are now seeing a period of decentralisation in the People's Republic of China. It is only in the last few months that we have seen the rights given to provinces to negotiate directly with outside corporations and companies and to enter into joint ventures with those companies. One is saved the problem of having to go to Beijing and deal with bureaucrats there; bureaucrats, wherever they may be, in Canberra or Beijing, can raise difficulties. That is a welcome development. It has been welcomed by the Australian business sector, which, hopefully, can continue to contribute to growth, to the mutual benefit of both countries.

I return to the question of national minorities. Tibet is very much a part of that issue as far as the Chinese are concerned. We know that the Soviet Union is facing similar difficulties at present. I was interested to hear a report in the last few days in relation to demonstrations taking place in Estonia that Premier Gorbachev acknowledged-I think in a rather mature way-that it was an inevitable part of the perestroika and glasnost process; in other words, the process of restructuring the economy, and in so doing allowing greater freedoms.

The Chinese-and the Russians will not admit this-are ahead of the Russians in the so-called perestroika process, that is, restructuring the economy. I think they are at least a decade ahead in realising the importance of the market-place in delivering growth. Whilst the Russians are behind, the PRC could learn from what is happening in the Soviet Union. If one delivers economic freedom, it is obvious that people will want to exercise greater political freedoms. The question of how one relates to minority populations and regions is a serious issue facing both countries. As the honourable member for McEwen said, as there has been a Russification of the Baltic states, a Chinafication is going on in relation to Tibet. Whilst the PRC might say that workers are being brought to Tibet to work on new developments, to give growth, by the same token, if it is a political mechanism for swamping the Tibetans, it is something that is not very helpful and creates an equal or greater reaction-as we have seen in the protests in Tibet in the last two years. That is an issue that the People's Republic of China clearly has to face. I believe that it should stop that Chinafication as part of the goodwill in meeting the proposals that have been put to it by the Dalai Lama.

Amnesty International has issued a report on its concerns about detention without trial, ill treatment of detainees and police shooting of civilians in Tibet. Obviously there are excesses in the regime. I hope that Beijing treats this matter with concern and realises that Amnesty International has a right and a responsibility to point out denials of human rights wherever they occur in the world. I hope that the PRC will allow Amnesty International representatives into Tibet.

I heard this morning that a television program was shown in the United Kingdom in the last 24 hours, made by a woman who filmed in Tibet disguised as a tourist. She smuggled the film out of the country because the authorities would not have let it out. I am told that the film contained a number of interviews with monks and, I think, with five women who claimed to have been tortured. The honourable member for McEwen nods his head indicating that my recollection is correct. I ask the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China in Canberra to give an assurance that there will be no retribution or punishment in any way of the people who were interviewed in that program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, endorses that request. It is made in good faith. It is important for the credibility of Beijing that there be no retribution. It is important that it understands that the West is interested in the matter and that at the same time there is good will in the West towards the People's Republic of China. Perhaps we have all been a little sensitive about criticising the People's Republic in the past out of respect for the way in which it has handled the difficulties, perhaps caused by the Cultural Revolution, and in recognising the task it has in developing its economy. But a new maturity is needed. The People's Republic of China needs to understand that if people in this place believe there are human rights abuses they are able to say so freely-as people have said in the US Congress-without prejudicing our respect for what is happening in China. Parliaments and the world community need to be aware-notwithstanding relationships between countries-of the fact that we can criticise the abuses that take place, whether they occur in South Africa, in China, or in Tibet. I hope the Chinese authorities recognise that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are big changes taking place in Taiwan. They are great changes in a growing democracy and in many ways they are parallel to what is happening in the People's Republic of China. I hope that the authorities in Taiwan-the so-called Republic of China-are interested in human rights issues in Tibet. I understand that both the so-called Republic of China and the People's Republic of China have similar policies towards Tibet. I can understand that, for historical reasons. But there is the challenge of the human rights violations there.

I did not discuss this matter with the honourable member for McEwen before this debate, and I have not caucused with him, although I seconded the motion-as I said, I did not know whether he was talking to the 1987 Dalai Lama proposal or the 1988 proposal-but I would request the Chinese authorities to allow honourable members to visit Tibet. I would be prepared to go at my own expense. The honourable member is nodding to indicate that he would go, in a spirit of good will. We would also go to Beijing, if we were invited to do so, to see for ourselves what is going on, and be constructive and positive and not destructive. That is very important.

Finally, Tibet is entitled to a piece of the economic pie, the growth and development that is going on in the People's Republic. There is a need to respect the dignity of the Tibetan culture and people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House deplores the continuing high levels of personal taxation and the distortion which when coupled with assistance to low income families has seriously lowered incentive for people to reduce their dependence on fellow taxpayers.

One of the records this Government has gained since it came to office-one of which it is not very proud, although it continues to hold the record-is that it is Australia's highest taxing peacetime government ever.

TALK.START.PARA: —You say that every year.

—It continues to hold the record; it is doing it very well. This is leading to a growing feeling of frustration in the Australian community. Australians are continually complaining. I think all honourable members find wherever they go that the level of taxation is causing continued frustration and reducing incentive. I want to talk a little about that today and about what happens when we couple that with some measures the Government has introduced to try to combat the problems caused by high taxation. Unfortunately, no matter how often it is reminded, the Government continues to ignore the problems that high taxes are causing. Today I will show a small cross-section of some of those problems. As all honourable members should know, prevention is better than cure, whether it be high taxation, the effects of high taxation or any other area. Despite this, the Government continues to apply bandaid after bandaid in an attempt to cover up what are the unintended consequences of high personal taxation. Despite layer after layer of these bandaids, the wounds of high tax continue to break out in a way that brings shame onto this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I talk about poverty traps I will give a quick explanation of them. A poverty trap is a situation in which people find that despite working harder and despite trying to improve their lot, the loss of some targeted benefits, coupled with the progressive income tax scale, mean that there is no benefit for them. A paper was recently released by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) entitled `Income Support Policies, Taxation and Incentives'. The paper confirmed that many low income earners now face the highest marginal tax rates in Australia's post-war history. In other words, it is not just the highest taxing government; it is also taxing low income earners at their highest levels ever. It is important to contrast this record with that of the previous Government. The effective marginal tax rate, which I will come to in a little more detail in a minute, for a family with a dependent spouse and two children, earning 75 per cent of average weekly earnings, dropped-I emphasise `dropped'-from 35 per cent to 31 per cent under the previous coalition Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It dropped?

—That is right, it dropped. It shows very clearly that the coalition has a very good record in contrast to this Government's record. Who could ever forget the cruel and misleading election hoax of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before the last election? He said, `No Australian child will be living in poverty by 1990'. I say `cruel' because poverty under this Government has risen dramatically. The Government's response, of course, has been to apply more bandaids. It still has not looked at the cause of much of this poverty which is higher levels of taxation, particularly personal taxation. The Government churns out more and more welfare. As the EPAC paper pointed out so vividly, the net result is the creation of horrendous poverty traps. Unfortunately, what we find is that the Government applies these bandaids, which have a superficial benefit and which will obviously go some of the way to provide short term help-I am the first to acknowledge that. But they do not really solve the massive long term problem that we are creating-the one that should really concern all of us; it concerns all of us on this side of the chamber-in that there is enormous disincentive for people to get themselves off welfare benefits; in many cases there is no incentive for them to do so and it is better for them to stay as they are.

SPEECH.PARA: I give a pertinent example which I raised in this House on 11 October this year and which compares two families of husband, wife and three children, in similar situations and renting a house. In one case the husband earns $325 a week and in the other $525 a week-a $200 a week difference in gross income. But, when we look at the effect of the family allowance supplement and rental assistance and at the difference in the Medicare situation of the two families, we find that the family that does not receive the various additional bits of support goes from being $200 a week better off to being less than $10 a week better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hundred dollars disappears.

—Nearly $200 disappears. This is due in part to the bandaid cures but it is also due very much to the very high levels of personal income tax which have forced people into this position. Of course, more and more people are finding themselves paying higher levels of personal income tax. This is being brought about by bracket creep. The effect of bracket creep together with targeted welfare means that many families no longer have the incentive to reduce their dependence on fellow taxpayers.
—That is the core of it.

—That is the core of it. In the EPAC paper, which I will come back to in a minute, there are many other cases of people being very much disadvantaged because the combined effect of higher levels of personal income tax and the targeting of welfare has put them in an almost impossible position.

SPEECH.PARA: I have given a typical example, but there are also extreme examples where people face an effective marginal tax rate of over 100 per cent. In other words, people who try to reduce their dependence on welfare and try to get out and earn their own income are effectively taxed at over 100 per cent at the margin. Is it any wonder that this disincentive in our community is causing all sorts of side effects and all sorts of problems? The EPAC paper gives the case that a low wage sole parent, renting privately and working 20 hours a week, may face a marginal drawback rate of 62c in the dollar-62c in the dollar-when the supposed maximum marginal rate is 50.25c. There are many other examples where the effective marginal rate is well above 75c. There is the double problem of progressive income tax scales and the effect of the means test relating to welfare payments. According to this EPAC paper 15 per cent of sole parents and 8 per cent of people on the unemployment benefit face an effective marginal tax rate far above that of the top income tax level.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the poor and the needy.

—That is correct. As my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield points out, they are indeed the poor and the needy, and yet under this Government they face an effective tax rate higher than that of the highest income earners in Australia. Is it any wonder that there is a lack of incentive for people to improve their lot?

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect exaggerating these welfare traps, with effective marginal tax rates being so high coupled with high personal income tax, is that average and marginal tax rates have risen. This is more the cause than the effect. Average and marginal tax rates have risen more over recent years than they have in previous years. But they have risen more for taxpayers with dependants than for those without dependants. In other words, this Government has demonstrated quite clearly a bias against families in its present taxation and welfare systems. This is all documented in the EPAC report. These are not just my words; it is all in the report.

The EPAC paper gives example after example, all documented and with very clear charts, which show that people in various situations face effective marginal tax rates at some levels of income-all these levels, I might add, are well below average weekly earnings-which shoot well over 100 per cent. At page 39 of this report there is a table which shows the equivalent marginal tax rate for one-income couples with two children and in public housing as at the end of 1987. As their income moved from 50 per cent of average weekly earnings to 100 per cent of average weekly earnings, they faced an effective marginal tax rate of over 100 per cent. There is a similar example of a one-income couple with four children. This reinforces the point I was making that families are being hit harder than single people as a result of this distortion.

Page 47 of this report shows that a sole parent with two children and living in New South Wales public housing-assuming that he or she is on a wage of $284 a week, which is not a lot and is well below average weekly earnings-will find that if he or she tries to work overtime, that is, to work more than 55 hours a week, to improve his or her lot, again the equivalent marginal tax rate will go over 100 per cent. Also, a sole parent with two children and in New South Wales public housing who starts to work more than five hours a week faces an equivalent marginal tax rate of over 100 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the solution?

—I will come to the point that the honourable member raises in a minute. I also refer honourable members to page 53 of this report, which shows very clearly the change over the last two decades in the equivalent marginal tax rates for a one-income couple with two children and renting privately. If we look back to 1968 there was a steady progression in the chart from 50 per cent of average weekly earnings to 250 per cent. In fact, the highest rate of tax was less than 50 per cent. So at that stage no-one was paying more than half the income in tax. In 1978 there were fewer steps in the tax scale but the net result was still the same: nobody paid more than half of the extra dollars earned in tax.

SPEECH.PARA: But when we look at December 1987, last year, what do we find? With the various adjustments that this Government has made, the chart looks very different. In fact, the equivalent marginal tax rate for one-income couples with two children and renting privately goes over 100 per cent when the income rises to about 80 per cent of average weekly earnings. Also, when the income goes beyond that point and moves towards a little over twice average weekly earnings, they are again faced with an equivalent marginal tax rate of nearly 80 per cent. Is it any wonder that the system that the Government has set up has taken away the incentive for many families on low incomes to reduce their dependence on their fellow taxpayers?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are from the Government's Advisory Council.
—Yes, that is right. This information comes from the Government's own Advisory Council. Professor Mathews made it very clear in his observation when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the conventional wisdom was that high average tax rates encourage workers to work harder to restore what they lost through taxation. This could no longer be accepted: workers responded to high and discriminatory taxes either by seeking higher money wages for the same work, or by joining in the general scramble to avoid or evade tax.
Those are the words of Professor Matthews, a leading expert on taxation in this country.

In conclusion, I do not suggest that there is an easy solution to this problem. The Government continues to ignore the problems that it has created itself through high personal income tax, coupled with additional selective welfare measures which have been needed because of the effect of that high taxation. Having created so many problems in the first place, it is now trying to apply the bandaid. It is quite clear that reducing personal taxation rates must be a number one priority. It is also clear that there is a very strong case for splitting income between husband and wife, as is pointed out in the EPAC paper. Furthermore there is a very strong case for trying to reduce some of the welfare traps so that people do not lose the incentive to become independent of other support. All these ideas are supported by the EPAC paper, from which I wish to quote a couple of points. In the section dealing with policy implications it is pointed out:

Over the next few years the relief of poverty-ensuring that adequate support is available to all in need-will remain a priority objective of Governments. A key challenge for policy will be to devise ways of pursuing this equity objective without undesirable effects on the willingness or ability to work or save.
In particular, consideration needs to be given to:
(a) Reducing the severity of poverty traps and the range of incomes over which they operate . . .
It goes on to say that consideration will also need to be given to:
(b) Developing a structure of taxation that, consistent with the pursuit of equity and other objectives of government, minimises disincentive effects.

I think it is pointed out very clearly in the paper that the present tax system pays no regard to families and that the welfare system ignores the tax system. Means tests continue to apply to gross wages despite the existence of a progressive tax scale which, in itself, is a means test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government rejects the motion out of hand for the twaddle that it is. I am glad that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) referred to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) report because under a government of his persuasion a report such as that would never have seen the light of day. This report is testimony to the fact that this Government examines the problems of Australian society, not only at the taxation level but also at the personal level. We do generate reports such as the one on which the honourable member based his speech. The other point I make about the honourable member's contribution-and he admitted this himself-is that he did not have a solution to the problems. We in the Australian Labor Party have solutions and that is why we sit on this side of the House. We will stay on this side of the House because the Opposition has never had any solutions.
—There are more poor people out there now than there were when you came to power.
—The honourable member for Bradfield, who is at the table, dropped his retirement income policy on Monday and saw it disappear without trace. He is now interjecting.
—You must be blind.

—No, I am not. I saw the honourable member's policy on about page 38 of a few newspapers. That shows that nobody takes it seriously. One point that the Liberal Party of Australia raises continually is this glib, throwaway line that this is the highest taxing Government ever. But would we not expect taxes to rise in an expanding economy? The fact is that in 1982-83, under the Liberals, we had a shrinking economy. It would be a crime if, in a shrinking economy, taxation rose. But after putting 1.1 million people back to work, increasing productivity and increasing output in this country, we would expect to generate more taxation. It would be a sin if we did not. Of course we generate more taxation every year; every year the taxation revenue rises. So it should.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point the honourable member made was that we are a high taxing country. I have here the latest revenue statistics for Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) member countries. Of the 23 OECD countries we are the nineteenth lowest taxing country.
