That is, there are 18 countries in the OECD which tax more than we do. If we go through the range, from Sweden, which consumes about 53 per cent of its taxes expressed as a proportion of gross domestic product, down to the lowest, Turkey, which consumes about 22 per cent, we find that Australia sits on just over 30 per cent which is very much on a par with the United States, Japan, Portugal and Switzerland. There is not very much difference in the overall taxation take of those developed countries. As I have said before, if the Opposition wants Turkey's tax rates it will also get Turkey's social security provisions. Honourable members opposite are smiling and nodding their heads like golliwogs. They want the Australian people to believe that they can give them Turkey's tax rates and Sweden's social security provisions. That is all they have ever talked about. Opposition members always tell their audiences what they believe they want to hear.

The honourable member for Wannon talked about marginal tax rates. In the seven years that the Liberal Party occupied this side of the House it was happy to leave the highest marginal tax rate at 60c. It is now down to 49c because this Government lowered it. Likewise, the 48c rate which the Liberal Party was happy to live with is now down to 40c. In the case of the lowest income earners, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), as Treasurer, was happy to have the bottom tax rate at 30c, but this Government has now brought it down to 24c. As the nation knows, next year those taxes will be cut again. Because of the taxing regime of this Government, we are able to lower those tax rates. Professor Mathews, who was quoted by the honourable member for Wannon, said that under the sort of taxation system run by the previous Government paying tax was optional for many. And it was. We saw the sort of bottom of the harbour fiascos that developed under the Liberal Government. In my home State of Western Australia the Liberal Party was into tax avoidance up to its ears.

This Government has brought in measures such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, substantiation and all of those measures to make sure that the taxation system is decent. All the benefits of that have been given back to people in the form of lower tax rates. The process has been redistributive, rather than one that increases the total tax take. While we are discussing people on the lowest rung of society, the honourable member opposite talked about people who are unemployed. Certainly every day that the Opposition occupied the Treasury bench, when it was in government, an extra thousand people found themselves in this position. If one looks at the poverty gap that existed in 1983 when we assumed government, one sees that a single person on unemployment benefits was $23.40 under the poverty line designated by the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. Under this Government that person is now over the poverty line by $1.30, so there is a $25 turnaround. That is maintained all the way through, whether it be a single parent family, a one-child family, a couple with no children or a couple who have three children and no jobs. Under the Liberals these people were underneath the Henderson poverty line by $26.30; under this Government they are under by $10.95.

When I saw the motion on the Notice Paper today I was rather bemused. The honourable member seemed to be saying that because we are paying people on social welfare too much, they will not go out to work. We have heard all these crazy schemes, usually put up by members of the National Party of Australia, about working for the dole and all that rubbish. We have costed that particular proposal, and if it were ever implemented it would cost $700m. That is the sort of solution that comes from the opposite side of the House. Opposition members do not have any idea about how to tackle this problem.

The motion moved here today by the honourable member for Wannon was nothing more than just a whinge. There were no solutions and there was no hint that he had any idea-in fact he admitted himself that he had no idea-how to tackle them. I will tell him how to tackle them; he should just stay on that side of the House and leave the tackling of those problems to people on this side of the House because the Australian Labor Party is the only party that exercises its mind on the solving of those problems, just as it is the Party that put decency back into the tax system, got industry working again in this country and lifted education to levels approaching those of the OECD. John Hyde said it all on the weekend when he was commenting on his former colleagues. The fact is that the Opposition has no principles. It has no direction. We can all observe in this House that the Opposition has no leader. It is obvious to everybody in Australia that the Opposition has no hope either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104a. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Aviation Museum-Nuclear Power-Society's Standards-Members of Parliament-Proposed Sydney Airport-Service Stations-Deforestation-Mr Peter Sawyer

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a very proud aviation record and history. I am sure that this really came to the fore when, during this bicentennial year, we witnessed some of the most spectacular air shows ever seen at any time in this country. Indeed, I hasten to add that they were some of the most spectacular air shows ever seen anywhere in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I wish to raise in this grievance debate is that, despite the fact that we do have this history, this tremendous record, we do very little to maintain our heritage in that respect. One thing that has been referred to constantly in this House over the years is the establishment of a national aviation museum, probably in Victoria. For many years we have had small and dedicated groups of people around Australia who have been prepared of their own free will to try to salvage this heritage, with very little help from governments of both political persuasions in this place.

The matter first came to the attention of the Whitlam Government during its period in office when it held an inquiry into museums and national collections. At that time there were approaches from a number of groups, scattered throughout the Australian States, suggesting that we should be trying to put together some of our history. When one looks back over the years at the great names in aviation such as Kingsford-Smith, Ulm and Hinkler, at the great names of commercial aviation such as R. M. Ansett, Miller and Connellan, at the legacy of all that they did and the prominence they gave to Australian aviation, one wonders really what we have to show for it.

Probably one of the saddest examples I could give of this neglect is that in my electorate a used car yard has as its mascot sitting rotting in the middle of the yard, a DC3 aircraft with a very long and proud history in the United States Air Force and, I understand, with Qantas Airways Ltd. One can drive beyond Toowoomba and see a former Trans Australia Airlines Viscount sitting in a yard rusting to pieces. These aircraft were the great openers of the Australian inland, the great means of communication, yet we have let them fall into disrepair.

As I said, there are a number of organisations in the States which have been prepared to make some effort to maintain this heritage, without very much success or support from this Government. I suppose that one of the reasons for that is that Federal governments have always considered aviation history to be a State responsibility. When those groups have gone to State governments, the governments have failed to support their initiatives, principally because of the potential Federal involvement.

If we are going to go ahead with this national aviation museum, I wonder whether there has been any definitive study of what the cost of establishing it may be and what the cost of maintaining it may be. These things are very expensive. One of the things we have to be fully aware of is just what our responsibilities will be in terms of the Commonwealth's contribution. I contend that it would be a much cheaper proposition if we gave support to these groups, who often consist of men with very great skills, with very great experience, with very great technical expertise, who are prepared to give their time and effort and, indeed, quite often their money, to establish these museums in every Australian State so that every Australian has access in a real sense to this history and heritage.

One of the real regrets over the years, and one of the real reasons why successive Federal governments have not made this contribution, lies in the nature of the disposal of much of our equipment. There are a number of departments which are and should be involved in supporting this concept of maintaining our aviation heritage. For a start there is the Defence Department, which operates the equipment and declares it surplus with no consideration of preservation in terms of its location or condition. Once the equipment is at the end of its life the Department of Defence hands the matter over to the Department of Administrative Services, which disposes of the equipment. There is no differentiation between private buyers, scrap merchants, commercial enterprises and, of course, these genuine aviation museums that are scattered round Australia.

We have now the Department of Aviation and the Federal Airports Corporation, which have the airport land and many of the facilities that could be used to maintain some of this material. The home affairs, arts and heritage people also come in because they have responsibility for museums, but as yet nothing has been coordinated in terms of preserving this sort of heritage. Education departments, both Federal and State, should also be involved. There is a great deal of Australian history wrapped up in this matter and young people could be taught about our history by using facilities such as the museums scattered around Australia.

It might be argued that moves have been made to support some of the private museums, and I suppose that is true. On Queensland's Gold Coast there was a private museum-strictly a private museum-a money-making enterprise which has now gone into liquidation. The sad part is that some of its equipment has had to be sold off. I understand that some has gone interstate, some has gone overseas, and some has just been sold for scrap.

When we ask the Government what is happening with the Mirage aircraft which are being disposed of, some of the answers we get are amazing. We do not really know yet just how many of these aircraft will be retained. We do not know the real identity or details of the aircraft. We do not know whether any will be going into an aviation museum. We do not know about public accessibility to these aircraft if they are to be preserved for their heritage value. It is sad when one reads reports that aircraft such as these are being sold for scrap. I am not saying that the Government should maintain each and every one of the aircraft. However, I look at the case of the Neptune bomber that was given by the Government at a reasonable price to a so-called non-profit organisation. I think that was in 1979, and the Opposition was in Government then. The Department of Administrative Services now quite openly admits that what was supposed to be a non-profit organisation was a highly profitable one. That Neptune aircraft was sold in recent times for 30 times the price for which it was sold by the Government. In many respects that is an absolute scandal.

May I say that we do have a very livewire division of the Confederate Air Force based in Australia. A number of pilots every year make a pilgrimage to Harligen, Texas, in the United States and undertake flying displays there using vintage aircraft from World War II and all sorts of ex-commercial aircraft. These gentlemen try very hard to maintain an interest in Australia. It would be people of that calibre that could well be used in establishing these non-profit, community based aviation museums around Australia.

One can see what can be done in the preservation of aviation history at places like the Smithsonian Institution or, more especially, at Duxsford, near Cambridge in Britain, which I was privileged to visit in February of this year. In the case of Duxsford, the government gave a complete ex-RAF airfield to the society not only in order to maintain and preserve the military history of World War II in Great Britain-there are some magnificent aircraft in that field-but also so that the civil aviation areas could be preserved. There are examples there of all the great civil aircraft produced by the British aviation industry over the years, ranging from the Concorde right down to the Comet, the VC10 and other modern commercial aircraft.

My plea to the Government is that we have a bipartisan approach to this matter. There are people scattered around Australia who want to come together to make sure that our heritage is preserved, a heritage of which we can be very proud. I hope that there will be a bipartisan approach by all people in this Parliament and that we will not go ahead and allocate the huge amounts of money that may be involved in the national museum but rather create a sense of real cooperation, of real commitment by aviation enthusiasts in all States of Australia so that our young people can have access to a very proud history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate today to rebut some of the misinformation that is being spread by the mining lobby since the growing public interest in the greenhouse effect. I would like firstly to address the comments of Mr Hugh Morgan, head of Western Mining Corporation, who said recently, that the way to avoid the greenhouse effect is to support the nuclear industry, to mine, reprocess and export uranium as well as to establish nuclear power stations in Australia, especially on the eastern seaboard. It is interesting to hear such comments coming from Mr Morgan. After all, it is the mining industry, together with the petroleum extracting industry, which is mainly responsible for the greenhouse effect in the first place. Now that its current activities have led us towards global catastrophe and its profits are threatened by growing environmental consciousness, the miners want to channel the world's energy demands into another of their commodities-uranium. This is the equivalent of recommending the replacement of the use of alcohol with heroin.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two massive energy problems confronting the earth at the moment. One is the greenhouse effect. I will not go into unnecessary detail here, but basically the greenhouse effect refers to the blocking-in of the earth's atmosphere, of long wave heat radiated from the earth's surface towards space. The blocking-in of this heat is increased by the production of a number of gases, including carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and atmospheric methane, which act as a blanket or barrier preventing heat escaping from the atmosphere.

The other major energy problem confronting the world is the growth of the nuclear power industry. It cannot be denied any longer that nuclear power is an extremely dangerous form of power generation. In the era of the greenhouse effect we must be awake to any attempts by the uranium lobby to cover up the obvious dangers associated with its industry. The attempt has already started. The October newsletter of the Uranium Information Centre (UIC) devotes most of its space to telling us how environmentally and medically safe the nuclear industry is. This so-called information sheet contains many distortions. On page 2, for instance, it states:

While acknowledging the seriousness of the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the U.S.S.R., it is a fact that few accidents involving radiation have occurred in civil nuclear plants and only Chernobyl has led to direct deaths and any observable effects on the health of those involved. Under normal circumstances, nuclear power has considerable advantages in environmental terms compared with coal combustion and has been instrumental in saving a large number of lives that would have been lost during the extraction, transportation and use of equivalent amounts of fossil fuels.
Let us look at this statement more closely. It says:
. . . few accidents involving radiation have occurred in civil nuclear plants.

The authors must have forgotten about Three Mile Island. The Australian Financial Review of 3 November this year reported that a United States Government study reveals that this accident was far more serious than originally reported-45 per cent of the reactor's core, or 62 tonnes, had melted. The authors must also have forgotten about the Sellafield reprocessing plant in Great Britain, which is a joint civil and military plant. An inquiry in 1977 into the plant showed that there had been 194 accidents. A massive fire there in 1957 released up to 20,000 curies of iodine 131, and as much as 240 curies of plutonium 210. A University of Newcastle report estimates that as many as 1,000 people may have been affected.

This statement also ignores the fact that there is a strong link between the civil and military section of the nuclear industry. Each depends in large part on the other for their continuing long-term viability, and the health and safety record of the military nuclear establishments is appalling. My colleague the honourable member of Phillip (Ms McHugh) in her speech a couple of weeks ago pointed out some of the details and facts which have emerged recently regarding health and safety violations in United States nuclear weapon plants. The article in the Uranium Information Centre's (Victoria) newsletter sent us news of claims, `Only Chernobyl has led to direct death and any observable effects on the health of those in war.'

The problem here is obvious. The health effects of nuclear power are often not directly observable. The claims in the UIC newsletter are backed up by a table which purports to show that few deaths or illnesses are caused by nuclear accidents. No doubt these figures do not include high leukaemia clusters in children living close to reactors or cancers which appear many years later in reactor workers and their families.

An example of the invisible dangers of the nuclear industry is the town of Canonsburg in Pennsylvania. This town's association with radiation began in 1910 when the Standard Chemical Company began producing radium. A factory in Canonsburg processed the uranium which was used in the Manhattan project. In 1965 the factory began to close and the nuclear waste had to be disposed of. The owners bulldozed it across the road, tipped it into a pond and then covered it with shale. Later it was turned into a baseball diamond and used by the local children. The residents of this town have since discovered a large incidence of cancer among the local community.

I use this example because it proves that no matter how much the nuclear industry protests its innocence and says that nuclear power is safe, the nuclear industry is plagued and will continue to be plagued by poor management decisions, irresponsibility, greed and negligence. If it was possible in Canonsburg, it will eventually happen elsewhere. I quote again from the newsletter that `under normal circumstances' nuclear power is safer than coal. That is absurd. There is no way that accidents at nuclear reactors can be avoided. Due to the possibility of human error, accidents are inevitable. Chernobyl, Three Mile Island, Sellafield and countless other accidents show that nuclear accidents, when they occur, have far more profound consequences than corresponding accidents in conventional fossil fuel power generation. For example, extremely high levels of radiation still persist in parts of Sweden which were hit by fallout from Chernobyl, 1,000 miles away.

Nuclear power is not the answer to the greenhouse effect. The solution is not completely known at this stage as our understanding of the phenomenon is only in its infancy. However, a more rational approach would be to tackle the problem at its roots. A number of solutions should be considered, including research into alternative energy sources; more efficient use of fossil fuels; the stronger promotion of energy conservation; the development of more fuel-efficient cars and power stations; stricter controls on the emission of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, ozone and chlorofluorocarbons and reafforestation. Money spent on research into these measures could represent a much better allocation of funds than the enormous amount being sunk into ridiculous scientific fantasies such as synroc.

As well as leading to the proliferation of nuclear weapons, nuclear power is used for the production of electricity. Only 10 to 15 per cent of the world's processed energy is used in the form of electricity. Cars and trucks are among the biggest users of energy contributing to the greenhouse effect. Nuclear energy, therefore, can address only a very small part of the problem. I hope that people like Hugh Morgan will not start to advocate now the introduction of nuclear-powered cars to prevent the greenhouse effect.

In conclusion, I call upon the Australian people to reject the cynical disinformation campaign about nuclear energy as the solution of the greenhouse effect that is being propagated by the uranium mining lobby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The American journalist Walter Cronkite concluded each of his popular commentaries on current affairs and public issues with the words `And that's the way it is'. No doubt this phrase was designed to convey an impression of authoritative and credible insight so when Cronkite said `And that's the way it is', millions of people believed him and acted or reacted accordingly. They were challenged by his commentaries to look beyond the headlines and examine the wider meanings and possible implications of the important news stories of the day. In other words, Cronkite was more than a public opinion setter; he was a public opinion stimulator, encouraging people to think things through for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: All too often we are concerned, even alarmed, by what we see or hear or read but are not sufficiently interested or motivated to find out more or to actually do anything about it, except perhaps to give a cursory shake of the head and make a passing remark to anyone who happens to be listening that things are not what they should or used to be. The appalling things that are currently happening in and to our society are reflected by the issues which receive publicity in the Australian media. Our expectations have been lowered and we have accepted this downward trend.

I believe that in many instances the standards and traditions which used to be the norm within our community have been cast aside for no good reason other than that they are old hat and must therefore be defective, reactionary and irrelevant. In this context we should recall the words of another famous, influential and admired American, Herbert Hoover, who said:
The principal thing we can do, if we really want to make the world over, is to try to use the world `old' again.
It was the old things that made this country the great nation that it is.

There are the old virtues of integrity and truth; of incorruptible service and honour in public office; of economy in government, of self-reliance, thrift and individual responsibility and liberty; of patriotism, real love of country and the willingness to sacrifice for it.

If the ideals and concepts Hoover espoused are considered conservative, reactionary, old-fashioned or out of date, then I, for one, am happy to be regarded an an old-fashioned, out-of-date, reactionary conservative. Is it old-fashioned and reactionary to object to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) broadcasting obscenities and then attempting to justify its actions by claiming that the words in question are frequently used and can be heard in any school ground or bar? This is not a valid reason or satisfactory excuse for the irresponsible decision to include obscene and offensive words in prime-time programs. The fact that something is often said or done does not necessarily mean it is acceptable or correct or should be condoned. Furthermore, there is a significant difference between a private or bar room conversation and a public broadcast and the reasons for requiring a higher standard in the latter forum are obvious.

Sir Rupert Hamer, Chairman of The Friends of the ABC, summed the matter up very well when he said, `It is not for the ABC to lead the way downwards'. Whilst the ABC indulges itself in reflecting the apparent unfortunate decline in community standards in so far as the spoken word is concerned, some sections of the film and video industry are pursuing a similar though potentially far more hazardous path by promoting visual pornography and violence as a legitimate alternative art form. In a recent article in the Age, Neil Jillett discussed our current film censorship guidelines and the erratic manner in which they are applied by the Film Censorship Board. He states that he is a believer in a more liberal censorship of films available to adults and a tighter censorship to those available to children. But in the case of the particular film which he describes as graphically violent, sexually explicit, and hardly helpful to the anti-drug campaign, Jillett suggests that the Board may have defied its own guidelines by giving it an R certificate; that is, one suitable for cinema screening to adults. He commented:

Because of its sexual violence, this film strikes me as being clearly unqualified, according to censorship guidelines, for cinema or video release. There is also the question of whether it should be disqualified by the guidelines' references to drugs.

It is interesting to note that whilst Jillett describes this film as `a splatter movie of the goriest, most violent kind', the director of the cinema where the film is to be shown claims that it is `an entertaining romp, good of its kind'. Those of us who are reactionary and conservative enough to believe that explicit sexual violence is not the stuff of which entertaining romps are made should record our disapproval with the authorities who have allowed this film to be publicly screened. The time has come when decent, ordinary, old-fashioned people should join forces to ensure that those who are responsible for interpreting what are, after all, very lenient censorship guidelines are equal to the task. If not, they will have to be relieved of their duties.

The same applies to some members of the medical and scientific professions who are apparently prepared to sacrifice ethics on the altar of so-called technological development. According to Dr Jules Black, a Sydney obstetrician and gynaecologist, medical terminology and technology enabling men to become pregnant and carry children to term will be available and operating within the next two years. Are the reactionary conservatives the only ones offended by this depraved proposal? Dr Black says that men could even breastfeed a child by taking female hormone supplements.

He assures us that there would be no shortage of Australian men willing to be part of such a procedure. He says that transsexual couples, for a start, are crying out to have children of their own and that many men would also give anything to become famous. Almost as alarming as the prospect of childbearing men is the attitude of Dr Alan Trounson, director of the Monash University in vitro fertilisation program, who regards the prospect of inducing pregnancy in a man as `doubtful ethically'. Doubtful? I am astonished by Dr Trounson's choice of word. Such an unnatural concept is totally abhorrent. It is not doubtful ethically; it is impossible ethically. I urge other old-fashioned reactionary conservatives to register an immediate protest at this example of modern medicine gone mad. Hippocrates must be spinning in his grave.

Finally, let us consider what Hoover referred to as `the old virtue of incorruptible service and honour in public office'. The Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct has certainly dealt these old virtues a body blow of immense proportions. Those who are elected or appointed to public office have a sacred duty to uphold the confidence and trust which have been placed in them. It is despicable to betray the public trust; to actively and intentionally work against, rather than for, the best interests of the community one is meant to serve. To take advantage of one's position to secure some individual gain or benefit at the expense of the public good is under any circumstances unjustifiable and inexcusable.

While we are on the subject of public office, I believe it is about time that we all acknowledged the fact that politicians face particular problems when it comes to our collective public image. We all need to make an effort to regain the public esteem our predecessors once enjoyed. Respect, dignity and the confidence of the people cannot be demanded as a right or achieved by legislation, coercion or force. They can be earned only as the result of honesty, hard work, integrity and selfless devotion to duty. It does little to enhance our collective reputation if any one of us acts in a way which belittles the people and the institutions that we represent.

The magnum opus of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the conclusion of the Australian Grand Prix recently does little to convince an already disillusioned community that members of parliament know how to behave, or that their behaviour and presence deserve the respect of others. Can anyone imagine a Ben Chifley, Robert Menzies, Gough Whitlam or Malcolm Fraser cavorting around the presentation dais whilst being doused with champagne? It may be reasonable, or at least understandable, for excited racing car drivers to perform this traditional but nonetheless peculiar victory ceremony which invariably involves their colleagues and adoring fans, but to extend the gesture to include our Prime Minister is beyond acceptable standards. I doubt that the British Prime Minister, the President of France, the Chancellor of West Germany, or the United States President, or for that matter any other respected world leader, would have been subjected to or would have tolerated similar treatment.

Mr Deputy Speaker, my objective in canvassing these matters today is not necessarily to gain support for my own views about particular issues. What I have endeavoured to do is to challenge others to examine the issues for themselves, to consider the implications and assess the potential consequences. We should all exercise our right to make up our own minds and to take any reasonable and responsible action we may deem necessary or appropriate. Unlike Cronkite, I would not presume to suggest that my opinions on the issues that have been raised today are infallible. If the few examples that I have cited here are truly indicative of the way it is in Australia today, this great nation of ours is in deep trouble and the institutions, standards, traditions and principles which the majority of its people value and want to see preserved are under enormous and immediate threat. The challenge is there; it is the duty of every Australian to respond to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had thought that I would be discussing questions of the Northern Territory economy and would make that the main focus of my speech in this grievance debate; however, the comments by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) have attracted my attention. I was particularly intrigued by those comments which referred to the need for members of this Parliament-I believe he was also referring to the honourable senators who sit in the other place-to have the virtues of honesty, hard work and integrity and to undertake activities which did not belittle people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say to the honourable member for Casey that if there are any people in this Parliament who have demonstrated the capacity for a lack of integrity, a lack of honesty and a capacity to belittle people, they are the members of his own coalition. I will just point to one example, and it is the National Party senator from the Northern Territory. Over the last few weeks he has undertaken a campaign, along with his colleagues, deliberately to belittle people and has demonstrated a clear lack of integrity by using his position of privilege in the Senate in a way which I can describe only as jumping into the gutter of racial division and character assassination for cheap and cynical political point scoring.

He is someone, I might say, who professes a belief in the Christian faith. Yet without any apparent reference to the principles of that faith he has been prepared to use his privileged position in the Senate to vilify, denigrate and use smear campaigns against individuals and families amongst the Aboriginal community in my electorate; completely, I might add, without any substantiation. Not only has he done that; he has named wives and children of people in public life in a deliberate attempt to smear them.

I ask the honourable member for Casey, if he is honest and believes in integrity, justice and all the things he espoused in his speech, why is it that he allows his coalition party room to carry on with these antics? Why is it that he allows, particularly, members of the National Party to use the Senate committee system to shame people and to use that system as an attempt to assassinate their characters by smear and innuendo? Just tell me. Has he got a response? He clearly has not.

I invite honourable members to go through the Estimates Committee Hansard, to see the number of people who have been named and to see what they have been named for. In one particular instance a very good friend of mine has been named because she has the temerity to live with someone else; no other reason, but because she happens to live with someone else. That is what the Senate has degenerated to. That is what some senators have decided to use their position of privilege for; that is what he has done. The National Party senator for the Northern Territory has been elected-I might add, on the preferences of the Labor Party, unfortunately-to come down here to represent the people of the Northern Territory in the Senate. Approximately 26 per cent of the population is Aboriginal, yet what has he done over the last number of weeks? He has sought to undermine the community's confidence in the Aboriginal community; he has sought to attack people as individuals; he has sought to undermine organisational support, without any justification or substantiation.

Will he go back to the electorate and front those people? Will he make those statements outside the Parliament? He knows what would happen to him. He knows that he would be pilloried all over the countryside and that if he goes into those Aboriginal communities and organisations about which he has made these references and confronts these Aboriginal people, they will kick him out. Is it any wonder that the vote by Aboriginal people for his type of person, for the people who front with the National Party in this place, is what it is? Is it any wonder that the human beings, those civil libertarians on his side of the House, cannot stand it? Yet the honourable member has the temerity to get up here and preach to us about those issues, about the moral standards of Parliament. He does not know what moral standards are. He is not prepared to accept that people have the right to defend themselves. By the lacklustre performance of the Opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal Affairs, who seems to be falling into the pocket of this sort of tactic, there is clearly no idea on that side of the House of what integrity and honesty mean and how to represent the interests of the people of Australia in a fair and equitable manner.

I might just say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I did not intend to speak in this debate about that issue, but the galling statements made by the honourable member for Casey left me with no choice. I would say, however, to the honourable member for Casey, and to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) who sits there scoffing, that they might suggest to the honourable senator from the Northern Territory who sits with the National Party that if he wants to maintain the respect of the Christian community in the Northern Territory, or at least get some respect from those people in the community who believe in justice and fairness, he should desist from the sorts of attacks which his colleagues seem to defend.

Whilst on the sorts of attacks that have been made by the National Party senator for the Northern Territory, I might say that I was somewhat amazed to see the statements made by the Minister for Lands and Housing, Mr Manzie, in the Northern Territory on 22 November in which he blamed the ills of the Northern Territory economy upon Treasurer Keating and this Government's economic policies. Anyone who has any clear idea or just a little understanding of what the Northern Territory economy is about would realise that the problems of the Northern Territory are of its own making.

Eighty per cent of government receipts in the Northern Territory come from this Government, from the taxpayers of Australia. What we have seen in the Northern Territory shows that mismanagement is exemplified by this fact: in 1980 and 1981 capital outlays as a proportion of total revenue and grants received were 44 per cent. By 1987-88 they had fallen to 22 per cent. Is it any wonder that the population in the Northern Territory is on the decline? Is it any wonder that in the 12 months to June last there was a net interstate migration loss from the Northern Territory of 4,600 people. That represents a total population loss of 900 and it is the first time since World War II that the population has declined from one June to the next.

The unemployment rate is running at some 6.7 per cent as at October 1988 but, in fact, that relatively small unemployment rate is as a direct result of the fact that people are leaving the joint. It has almost got to the stage where it is a case of last one out turn out the lights. The housing vacancy rate at May 1988 was 18 per cent. In terms of building approvals, the total value of buildings approved in September was $11.2m or 79.7 per cent lower than in September of last year. This figure reflects the decreased public sector contribution towards the total of buildings approved.

However, lest we think that the Commonwealth is not pulling its weight, apart from the 80 per cent of the Northern Territory Government's revenue which is received from the Commonwealth in terms of budget outlays, we also see capital works programs funded by the Commonwealth outside of the normal Budget process as defence expenditure. Through grants made to the Northern Territory, for example, we have spent $250m on stage 1 of the Tindal project. An additional $170m has been allocated for further defence expenditure; $26.5m of that is to go to the Coonawarra project; $39m, or thereabouts, to Tindal; $4m to Jindalee; $60m to the Second Cavalry Regiment; $19m to housing; and an amount of money to Larrakeyah army base.

Honourable members will recall the debate in this place about housing and education. This year will see a substantial increase in the expenditure from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory in both those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss a matter of great concern to country people of New South Wales, particularly those living in the Parkes electorate and those who use the major airports there, namely, Forbes, Parkes, Dubbo and Cudal. I am raising this issue because of the imminent threat that many of the aircraft flying from country New South Wales, including those from the Parkes electorate, into Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will be forced by a deliberate decision of this Government to land some 25 kilometres west of Sydney at Bankstown, or even worse, some five or six years down the track from now, these people will be forced to land 60 kilometres west of Sydney at a small commuter airline strip that is going to be built at Badgerys Creek.
—It is ridiculous.

—It is ridiculous, as the honourable member for Casey says, because there is no need for it. Let me get one thing straight at the start: this proposal, this alternative, is totally unacceptable to country people. The Federal Government is aiming to do this by either banning these aircraft from landing at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport or by putting excessive charges on them which will be imposed by the Federal Airports Corporation, which is the owner of that airport. Unless this stupid proposal is stopped, I am told that it will be implemented very soon.

SPEECH.PARA: Country aircraft flying into Sydney have traditionally had a share of aircraft landing numbers there and they are entitled, I believe, to maintain that share. Let us not forget that 1 1/2 million people live in country New South Wales and something like a third of the aircraft movements into Kingsford-Smith come from country areas. If these people are going to be forced to go to Bankstown, let alone Badgerys Creek, we have to note a few things about Bankstown. It is already operating at near maximum capacity and would need a great deal of upgrading even to be able to handle these extra aircraft in the forms of terminals, runways, taxiways, radar and so on.

Let us not forget that there is no satisfactory public transport to the city from the Bankstown area. It would take one to two hours for the public to get in because there is no proper public transport system. People from country New South Wales who wanted to do business in Sydney and were forced to land at Bankstown, would have to stay overnight in Sydney. That would be a cost not only in time but also in money. Of course, quite a lot of people will opt, if this is forced upon them, to drive to Sydney instead of fly and up to a third of the commuter passengers could be lost. I refer to those flying from cities such as Bathurst and Orange who would probably opt to drive down; even from Forbes or Parkes, perhaps even from Dubbo. If this happens, the numbers using these services will fall. That will make the routes less economic than they are now so fares will rise, fewer services will be provided, and the companies flying these routes will end up using smaller aircraft; indeed, many of the routes will become unviable and some airlines may withdraw from the routes altogether or go bust.

This of course will lead to a lower quality of life for country people. I can tell the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) now that country people are not prepared to cop these alternatives. We will fight these proposals tooth and nail to the bitter political end and that will be the end of this Government at the next election.

Mascot has a theoretical capacity of about 220,000 movements a year which, when operational, is about one movement every two minutes, or one every four minutes even in rainy weather. It is very close to this capacity now, because in the last fiscal year it had about 212,000 movements in and out. Because landing fees are related to the weight of the aircraft, the Federal Airports Corporation wants to shift smaller aircraft-that is aircraft weighing less than 5,700 kilograms-elsewhere. That relates to aircraft from about the size of Kingairs down.

I tell the Minister that if these aircraft are shifted out, it will affect in excess of 50 per cent of the flights coming from country New South Wales. This would be in total disregard of the reasons for building the airport in the first place. One of the prime reasons it was built was to serve all the people of New South Wales. Let us not forget that Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is the ninth busiest airport in the world. Unlike the others, it is not a multi-runway complex. It has only two runways, the east-west runway and the north-south runway. What is desperately needed at Kingsford-Smith, apart from other things such as lifting of the curfew which would help a little, is a third runway parallel to the north-south runway. Everybody who has looked at the problem and every inquiry that has been held into the matter comes to this commonsense conclusion. It is the only logical way to go.

It would need a runway only about 1.8 kilometres long which would allow landings, but not take-offs, up to the size of the Boeing 737. Such a runway could be operational in 2 1/2 to three years. A more elaborate runway about two kilometres or more long could be built for an all-up cost of about $250m to $300m and that could be fully operational in five to six years. This option, if exercised, would allow an increase in traffic in and out of Kingsford-Smith of 40 per cent. Mr Deputy Speaker, that is an extra 90,000 movements. If that came to pass it would solve the immediate problem totally. I hasten to say, of course, that the coalition recognises that the Badgerys Creek airport must go ahead, but that is not going to be fully operational until something like the year 2015.

As we know, this Government opposes the third runway because of noise. It exaggerates the figures totally. The Air Transport Council says 78,000 people around that area are affected by noise. Let us not forget that they live there because the prices of houses are lower there because of the noise factor. So they buy them with their eyes open. The figure is 78,000, not a million as the Minister often tells us. That highlights, of course, the fact that the Minister has a direct conflict of interest in this area and is therefore not fit to hold his portfolio because of that.

Aircraft noise today is not what it was even 10 to 15 years ago with modern technology, much quieter engines and so on. The Minister is trying to ban small aircraft and replace them with larger aircraft. I wonder what the people who live in the electorate of Barton think of that, because larger aircraft are obviously going to make more noise than smaller aircraft. It will also mean, of course, more noise for those who live at Bankstown, too, as larger aircraft will be forced to fly in there.

This illogical and stupid paranoia with aircraft noise, leading to this Government opposing a third runway, is causing it to make the most extraordinary decisions. One announcement recently is that the Botany Municipal Council is giving permission for new buildings to be erected only about 200 metres north of the end of the proposed north-south runway, to a height of 51 metres, instead of the present 15-metre limit. This will mean, of course, that that runway could never be built, and that either the State Government would have to stop it by putting on restrictions or we would have to bulldoze them out of the road after we win the next election.

It will be a criminal act if these buildings go ahead and block that runway being built at some time in the future. I can say to the Minister that Qantas is totally in favour of the third runway, and Ansett and Australian Airlines are about to hold a Press conference to announce that they are in favour of the third runway. In fact, the entire industry is in favour of the third parallel runway. Sydney is in favour of it; New South Wales is in favour of it; country New South Wales is in favour of it; Australia is in favour of it; everybody is in favour of it except this Government.

It is a totally irresponsible decision not to build it and the Government is doing it purely to save the Minister's seat. Such a cynical, political decision is being made which will devastate country passengers from New South Wales. It will stifle international tourism; it was a major factor in Sydney losing its chance to host the Olympic Games. It will compromise safety; it is going to cost millions of dollars in delay and inconvenience and in longer commuter times and so on. If these discriminatory landing charges are applied and this runway is prevented from being built, I can tell the Minister that there will be a revolt in country New South Wales and elsewhere that will force this Minister and this Government into political oblivion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few months more and more service station lessees have been deeply distressed by treatment by oil companies which supply them; oil companies which are also their landlords. The recent shabby treatment of service station proprietors has affected not only those in Eden-Monaro. All over Australia intimidation, forfeiture of tenure, price discrimination and unfair lease premiums have occurred because of the actions of oil companies. For about 80 per cent of lessee dealers throughout Australia security of tenure provided through the Commonwealth Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 expires in September 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act itself does not expire, but oil companies will be unfettered in their ability to decide the fate of these dealers. Some dealers, it is true, will go because of unsatisfactory performance, or because of closure of sites. Most will be entitled to fresh agreements under the conditions set out in the Act. Some oil companies, in an understandable attempt to prevent a log jam in September 1989, commenced the introduction of their franchise agreements earlier this year and the remainder are expected to have announced their intentions by early 1989. This seems to be fair and commercially reasonable.

Unfortunately there are problems for dealers, problems which their associations have been struggling to resolve. Some of the unresolved issues are the subject of litigation and others are being discussed during an inquiry by the Trade Practices Commission. Service station association representatives and proprietors have told me of intimidation. Whether or not it has been condoned by oil companies, I am advised that field staff have been systematically threatening dealers, both explicitly and by implication, with non-renewal of agreements in 1989 if they do not agree to forfeit some of their independence.

Scare tactics have been used with threats of an uncertain future should dealers not accept the new agreement by the stipulated deadline. Legislation provides for security of tenure until at least September 1989. Three of the four companies which have released their intentions require dealers to accept and sign agreements before the end of 1988, thus forfeiting up to a year of their hard won tenure, while all too often the agreements are unacceptable. I ask the oil companies: Why should dealers have to set their future in concrete so soon? There are dealers who now contemplate walking out of their businesses and losing the goodwill that they have built up, rather than accepting these agreements. There are others who are in debt, who feel locked in to accepting the agreements, even though they know they will go further into debt trying to hold on to their assets.

Oil companies describe lease premiums as franchise fees, even though there is nothing to stop them being applied in return for the granting of a fresh lease. This seems to be a blatant attempt to get more money from dealers for little return other than the doubtful benefit of remaining on the site. The oil companies claim they want franchise fees in return for a true franchise relationship, but when I look at some of the agreements I see that most of the requirements for the oil companies would normally have been carried out anyway in the interests of the oil companies themselves.

Those obligations of the oil companies are rather few and most of the obligations in the agreement are on the service station operator. Normal elements of a franchise relationship, elements which apply to McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and firms such as that, are missing. Franchise expectations, exclusive territory, profitability expectations and mutuality of interest, all seem to be missing from the proposed agreements.

For the consumers, petrol users throughout Australia, particularly in country areas, the worst of their relationship with their suppliers is price discrimination. Much of the difference between country and city prices is due to policies of oil companies towards service station lessees who are charged the top price for fuel as determined by the Prices Surveillance Authority. The oil companies select service stations such as freehold customers and charge them lower prices for fuel. Some of those customers do not even carry the oil company trade mark, yet they are charged lower prices than a person in a franchise relationship.

It is no wonder that these franchise dealers are upset. Surely, if they pay franchise fees and comply with a great list of obligations, they should be offered the bottom prices from the oil companies. I do not propose to dwell on this issue, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I do not want to pre-empt the Trade Practices Commission recommendation. I do want to add my view that the agreements are onerous and appear to contravene the right of franchisees under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. Some of the agreements require a franchisee to purchase all fuel from one oil company, even though the Trade Practices Commission has given a ruling that service stations should be able to purchase 50 per cent of fuel from oil companies other than the lessor or franchisor.

I know that there are negotiations on this aspect. I also know that many differences remain unresolved. I do not know whether petrol buyers throughout Australia realise that if retailers become locked into unwieldy one-sided agreements, things will become worse for the consumer and it may well be easier for petrol companies to put up their prices.

Petrol companies are talking about the rack pricing system. I do have some concern with this proposal in that it may be a way of protecting oil companies from one another, rather than protecting consumers or service station proprietors or petrol distributors. I am rather sceptical that prices would drop in country areas under rack pricing and I am confident that they would increase in metropolitan areas. Rack pricing is alleged to set a price generally agreed to by oil companies throughout Australia. Oil companies would still have the right to sell to major customers below the rack price within the system.

It seems to me that we ought to extend the 50 per cent requirement so that distributors and service station proprietors have more freedom from the oil companies. I have not become emotional about this; I have not outlined the devastation produced within families, the prospect of people walking out of businesses with nothing for goodwill or the prospect of families feeling unable to get out because of their growing debt. They could become locked into hopelessness and despair and be unable to move. Consumers deserve a better deal and I know my colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who is in the House, through his consumer affairs subcommittee has, with me, been talking to service station operators. He has frequently expressed in the House his concern that consumers deserve a better deal, but it will not happen if petrol companies gain full control of all the aspects of marketing, wholesaling and retailing. It is very important that we look at this question and that we do have something to say, as I have, to the oil companies as they proceed to try to set these agreements in concrete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recent months have witnessed the national and international environment debate shifting to a more informed discussion about fundamental environmental issues. These include growing concern as to the pollution levels in the North Sea, questions of soil degradation, and the impact of deforestation as well as the problems caused by toxic waste disposal to the atmosphere which brings about an ozone layer depletion in the so-called greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.PARA: On a recent parliamentary delegation to the Philippines, the problem of deforestation was brought home to me as an important factor in the Philippines economy. The Philippines have a population of 58 million people, which is rurally based. The slow industrialisation has meant that population pressures on the environment are extreme. The excesses and corruption of the Marcos regime have added an exploitive element to the loggers and the commercial interests who see profit from removing valuable timber from the forested areas of the Philippines. Along with the slash and burn attitude of the traditional Filipino farmer, this has brought about a major devastation of the soils, climate and forests over the last two decades.

Images taken from satellites have indicated that the upland forests that covered most of the Philippines have fallen in land area from 75 per cent to 25 per cent. Some of the smaller islands, such as Cebu, are now virtually barren. My own personal observation supported this evidence that the removal of trees is one of the most difficult national problems facing the Government. President Aquino puts deforestation along with poverty and national debt as being the three major problems facing her government.

The problem of deforestation in the Philippines is exacerbated by the problems of land tenure. Changes to the more fertile areas often push those without land into mountainous areas where logging is profitable and some landholdings can be created after the trees are removed. The traditional agricultural method based on slash and burn, along with illegal loggers, means that there is a national cultural attitude against the maintenance of forest areas. Big profits can be obtained from logging in the short term, but because of the corruption and lack of government controls and timber removal and replanting, the devastation of the Philippines countryside is immense.

With the removal of trees and vegetation, soil erosion is becoming a long term problem with top soil being washed down the streams and rivers, which in turn pollutes the fishing areas around the Philippines islands. In the high tropical climate, once the process of deforestation and erosion takes hold, it is particularly difficult to re-establish trees and vegetation to restore the fertility of the land.

The average age of the Filipino population is between 23 and 30 years, which means that there is a potential for a major population explosion, putting further pressure on the environment because of the largely rural based villages and farming operations. The concentration of urban population in the major city centres with low standards of housing and living conditions brings a further focus on the total national Philippines environment. How will the Filipinos survive if their streams are polluted, their coastal fishing areas no longer operate and their agricultural systems are not sustainable in the long term because of the removal of forests and vegetation cover?

Whilst forests seem to be a problem far removed from the Filipino policy makers and city dwellers, their future could largely depend on reversing the traditional attitude of forest destruction and logging for short term profits. On the island of Borneo similar problems have become evident. In the process of developing the State of Sarawak the Malaysian Government plans to undo in the rainforest what nature has taken centuries to achieve by building a dam.

The proposed Bakun hydro-electric project will contain 4,000 million cubic metres of water and will submerge numerous farms and settlements. Hundreds of square kilometres of virgin rainforest with its wealth of flora and fauna will go under water. The dam, twice as high as the Aswan Dam in Egypt, will be the largest in South East Asia. It will transform a tranquil, unspoilt landscape into a region of heavy industrialisation. This devastation is to be carried out in the name of development, yet it seems that politicians and industrialists stand to gain more from the project than the people of Sarawak.

According to proponents of such schemes, the benefits of the dam to the nation outweigh the accompanying environmental impact. However, urban pressures, soil erosion and deforestation bring into question the long term ability of the population to exist in Borneo. The Aswan High Dam in Egypt is a perfect example of this. It has led to a steady deterioration in the fertility of Egypt's soils, causing significant problems for Egyptian farmers.

The same problems will no doubt become evident in Borneo with the construction of the Bakun hydro-electric project. In Brazil, the link between deforestation and development is so well entrenched that the yearly ritual of destruction by fire is difficult to prevent. In clearing the land, the general motto appears to be, `Flames can do what the hands cannot'. In 1987 180,000 square kilometres of land were burnt by farmers. Worried at the prospect of losing land as yet unused by them and fearing the Government would expropriate such land, they attempted to assert ownership by burning and clearing and thereby creating claims to ownership.

It is estimated that the fires in the Amazon Basin, the lungs of the world, are responsible for 10 per cent of the carbon dioxide in the world's atmosphere every year. Thus the deforestation epidemic has significant ramifications for the protection of the ozone layer, a matter which is much debated at the moment.

In preparing ski slopes in Europe trees and shrubs are removed from the upper mountain areas so that skiers can have clear and uninterrupted long runs. As a result of this commercial activity, deforestation and soil degradation have come under increasing scrutiny due to evidence which confirms the dangers of avalanches, mud slides and rock falls on the mountain slopes around villages in northern Italy near the Swiss border. Deforestation of ski resorts is now directly linked to such disasters which have displaced over 7,000 people and wrecked 50 towns, villages and holiday centres.

Deforestation varies greatly from country to country. Global destruction proceeds at approximately 0.6 per cent annually. In some countries, the rate of deforestation is as low as 0.02 per cent a year, while in other countries it reaches a rate of 7 per cent per annum. Closed forests which provide a self-sustaining environment of light and moisture and in which there is a delicate balance between the flora and fauna can easily be destroyed by man's greed and exploitation. It is estimated that these closed forests could disappear from the world environment in 25 years.

This is a sad indictment of our world's awareness of the value of such a resource. The livelihood of millions of rural people throughout the world depends on forest resources. Wanton destruction and degradation of forests have widespread implications for human society. Quite clearly the quality of life in the future depends upon responsible action for the re-establishment of forest areas on the planet. In Australia there have been extreme positions put on both sides about the maintenance of forest areas. On the one hand, the conservation movement has brought to the public's attention the dangers of unrestrained cutting down of trees throughout Australia, while on the other hand the responsible forest industries have developed a renewable program of timber harvesting and tree planting over a 30- to 40-year cycle.

Australia must maintain a position in leading the world and, more particularly, our Pacific neighbours in providing the balanced arguments that ensure the natural forest environment will help the largely urban populations of Asia and Australia to survive. It is clearly evident that the wanton destruction of forest resources has long term effects on the world's atmosphere that have not yet been calculated. In this grievance debate I have raised the awareness of these issues in the hope that future generations will benefit from a sensible long-term approach to protecting trees on this earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to use the last few minutes of this grievance debate to canvass an issue that I did bring to the attention of the House before. It relates to Mr Peter Sawyer and my entry into this debate is rather timely because we have seen his latest literary effort-some 36 pages-which have now been circulated throughout the country. Mr Peter Sawyer is the infamous prophet who prophesied doom throughout this nation. We ought to go back to some of the history because it is almost a year to this day that Peter Sawyer put out his November magazine last year telling of an Aboriginal uprising that would take place on Australia Day 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that he said that there would be thousands of people killed right across the nation; we would see the fall of the Hawke Government; an international peacekeeping force was going to come into this country in around May of this year; there would be a new economic structure because we would have a cashless society, an economy based on gold, and everybody who had anything would lose it all and we would have this dictatorship.

He said there would be no more pensions, no more unemployment benefits and instead we would have some sort of voucher system. All this would be changed. It would all result, he said, in a one world government that would actually reside in this Parliament and that there were mansions being built in the Australian Capital Territory where the world governors would reside. He also told us about the identification cards that would be brought in and the international and national surveillance system.

He told us of the hundreds of thousands of farmers who would be wiped out in early 1988; of economic collapse, of the country coming to a standstill because of the coal strike that was going to close down the nation. He said emphatically, `This will all occur by 1 May 1988'. It did not happen and on 29 June this year he went on the Haydn Sargent program on 4BC in Brisbane, with compere Greg Garey. He was asked why it did not happen. He said: `They are still doing all these things on what you might call a revised timetable. It is going to happen now in September and October'. He then went on to say, `Everything else we have talked about appears to be almost exactly six months down the track', and that is from May. So if we work it out, it is 1 November.

He actually quotes that date because he said, `They'-and I put in all Australians-`have to start lining up at the post offices with their identification from 1 November 1988'. So what he prophesied was doom and gloom, economic collapse, a dictatorship, an international peacekeeping force-all these amazing things. The fact is that not one thing he ever said, ever prophesied or ever accused this Government or the Opposition, the National and Liberal parties of, has ever been shown to be true.

It is understandable that in this 30-page diatribe that is now being sent to members he will not talk about those issues. He has attacked Senator Boswell, Gary Johns, myself and other members of this chamber who have stood up to him, to the League of Rights and others. The fact is that he has been discredited on every claim. If there is an international conspiracy it certainly does not revolve around this Parliament. It might revolve around some of his associates tied up with the Australian League of Rights, but certainly not here.

Just as those claims have been refuted, so has his claim about an international and national surveillance system coming from the Deakin Centre in Canberra. I thought, how do I beat that claim? I thought if he is talking about independent people there is one way of doing it. I asked Mr Trevor Perrett, who is the independent member for Barambah, Queensland, the man who took Joh Bjelke-Petersen's seat, to come to Canberra to see for himself. I have in my possession a letter from Trevor Perrett, MLA, who says quite clearly that the claims Mr Sawyer has made have no basis.

The regrettable part about this is that Mr Sawyer has done enormous harm. I have letters from people, from wives and families who have said how husbands have sold up property, how they have invested in gold when they sold everything they had, got rid of their assets because of what Mr Sawyer had said. I have had deputations of pensioners who have sat in my office and cried that they were going to lose everything that they owned, because all their pensions would disappear. I have had the same thing from farmers who did not know what to do because they had had that economic prediction of what they ought to do-sell their properties if they did not have a certain equity. He has done great harm.

Whilst he has lost a lot of his believers the man is still very dangerous. I think it is a pity that he is being used by others. I think he has been the tool of the neo-nazi pro-Hitler Australian League of Rights. I have said it before and I will say it again. It does not surprise me that he defends the League of Rights again. It is sad and it is rather pathetic that this has continued. I think we need to know now who is behind the man.

I noted in the Haydn Sargent report that he said that at one point they were distributing something like two million pieces of literature around this country. What say it was not two million, what say we come back to 100,000. He charges, as I have here in this document, $50 a time. So if it is not two million but 100,000 and it is $50 a time, we are talking about a base financial resource of some $5m. We ought to know what he does with the money. Who is behind it? I have heard him say publicly that he is on unemployment benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he paying tax?

—I do not know. I would like to know. Does he pay tax? The fact is that we are bringing his madness to the fore. Fortunately the churches and others who got with him in the early days have walked away from him and it pleased me. Just as we have had attacks on the Sawyer prophecies, we now have people like the Reverend Fred Nile coming out and talking about the attempts by the League of Rights and others to take over his organisation, Call to Australia.
—We could call it the Sawyer bean tax.

—That is not a bad idea. If there is a conspiracy, I know it does not involve this Parliament. It does not involve the National, Liberal or Labor parties. It certainly may involve the extremist neo-Nazi groups that do regrettably exist in this country, but they have a right to be here and I will fight for them to have that right. But the time has come to put an end to Mr Peter Sawyer. He has said a lot of things about me and I will sort that out in another arena; that is, if I can find his address. That is not a threat, that is a promise.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of this country need to contact their Federal members if they want to know the truth. Members of the Liberal, National and Labor parties have prepared material to answer these outlandish Sawyer claims. I have prepared a tape and I have already sent out almost 500 copies of it to people who want to hear the truth. I would suggest, just as Senator Boswell does the same thing with the churches and other groups, that members of Parliament ought to take upon themselves a special responsibility to ensure that Peter Sawyer is put in his place, that his mad, irresponsible allegations are shown to be what they really are. Only then will we have sensible debate about the future of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Peter Weygers-Imported Prawns-X-rated Videos-Mr Froud-Mr Ted Kenna, VC-Atheism and Agnosticism-South Africa-Girl Guides Overseas Visit-Child Care-Mr Justice Staples-National Science Strategy-Buy Australian

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this year I spoke about the action of the Western Australian Education Department in posting one of its grade 1 officers to serve in the remote Yilgarn district. This was done contrary to a finding of the Teachers Arbitration Tribunal in 1981. The Western Australian Director of Education first described it as a simple matter of a two-year posting. Lately, he claims it is a complex matter. Moreover, the period of the posting has already been stretched to three years with a fourth now possible. The officer of the Education Department of whom I speak is Mr Peter Weygers.

SPEECH.PARA: My particular interest stems from the fact that Mr Weygers is also the elected mayor of the town of Claremont, the town being in the heart of my electorate. Because of his country posting, his ability to carry out his mayoral and council duties is diminished. If the Australian Labor Party genuinely supports local government as one of its referendum questions would have us believe, it should take immediate action to ensure that Mr Weygers is able to carry out his elected duties unhindered and without detriment to his standing in the Education Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention something about the testing of imported goods, particularly pre-cooked prawns. Recently I received correspondence which has alarmed me, and I am sure it will alarm most members when they hear that, of 86 consignments, 17 when tested were found to be contaminated; that is, 20 per cent of those 86 consignments. Two of the contaminations were salmonella and the other 15 had high bacteriological contamination. But the most alarming thing is that these prawns were then allowed to be re-exported.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the correspondence I have, importers are given the option of re-export, that is for reprocessing, et cetera, or destruction of the product. It is understood that re-export is normally the favoured option. I think it is very alarming that we have not, as yet, got something in place that would forbid that kind of thing happening. Of course it concerns me that the re-export may be a process whereby the products are sent to be irradiated to try to clean them up, which is a process that is entered into in a number of countries which use the radiation process to clean up contaminated food and then put it back on the market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor's letter writing brigade are a busy bunch at the moment as they flood the Letters to the Editor columns of the national dailies. Labor's copout on the X-rated video question has allowed Canberra to continue as the national capital of pornography. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has flown in the face of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material which, after more than three years of research, recommended a ban on X-rated videos and their R-rated equivalents.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Mick Booth of Panania in New South Wales to write in the Australian today that he and his wife, and I quote his letter, `enjoy retiring to our bedroom, cracking a cheap bottle of bubbly and indulging ourselves with a video nasty, bluey or NVE, $25m a year says we are not alone'. Mick Booth might be surprised to learn that not all the $25m worth of video nasties is being watched by consenting adults.

Thirty-eight per cent of all video rentals are R-rated violence and the 12- to 25-year-old group are the biggest hirers of R-rated and violent videos. On 29 June this year, less than five months ago, all State governments in Australia recommended to the Hawke Labor Government that it place a ban on X-rated video material.

Every State in the nation does not want this rubbish, has legislated against it and has been inundated with it by mail order from Canberra. The Joint Select Committee spent three years receiving and examining evidence that this material engenders in the viewer a sexually callous and manipulative orientation towards women. It is quite obvious that the last thing we need is more time to look into it, as the Prime Minister said.

The Government has hit the rewind button while the rest of the country wants to change channel. If Canberra wants to watch this junk why should other States have their laws circumvented by mail order?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House the fact that a constituent of mine, a Mr Froud, celebrated his 100th birthday this week and, as such, joined in the Australian bicentennial celebrations. Mr Froud was born in England but came to Australia in 1909 as a merchant seaman. He tells me, and he believes quite categorically, that there are many Australians here who came via such ships and, of course, have made a very large contribution to this country. He served us proudly during the First World War and saw action throughout much of Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: He has become very much a proud Australian and, though he may have achieved his century, his brain is still active and he still actively participates in many of the political debates that are held in his district. His wife and children also are with him and I think it is important that we, as a parliament and as a government, acknowledge the contribution which people like him have made to our community. They are the sorts of people who make Australia great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week in my electorate in the city of Hamilton we honoured a great Australian. The people of Hamilton gave a fitting tribute to a great Australian and one of our war heroes-in fact, Victoria's sole surviving Victoria Cross (VC) winner-namely, Mr Ted Kenna. It was my privilege to organise the project, which culminated last week in the State President of the Returned Services League, Mr Bruce Ruxton, coming to Hamilton to unveil a portrait of Mr Kenna. This portrait was painted by the official war artist and famous Australian portrait painter, Sir William Dargie.

SPEECH.PARA: The generous support of many individuals in Hamilton and in the district and also the RSL sub-branches of my area in getting this portrait painted is very gratefully acknowledged. Private Kenna was awarded a VC in 1945 for bravery in the face of the enemy at Wewak in New Guinea. Hamilton now has a fitting tribute to one of its most famous sons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the presence of the Rev. Gil Duthie in the gallery. He was the Australian Labor Party whip and honourable member for Wilmot for many years. I hope he will not be too upset by my remarks. It is probably superfluous for me to point out that what I am about to say is a personal statement and I am not speaking on behalf of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In my teens, I changed my religious views from agnostic to atheist and have held to those views since then.
