However, over a relatively short period recently, a great number of persons flaunting their strong religious beliefs, including Jim Bakker and Jim Swaggart, the United States television evangelists, Bjelke-Petersen and his motley crew, Bruce Judge and Warwick Fairfax, have hit the deck. More recently, Fred Nile has been exposed as a charlatan and fraud and Iran has been defeated.

This conjunction of events can surely not be due only to good luck. I therefore admit that maybe there is some supernatural force at work and I may have to become an agnostic again. In passing, may I congratulate Mrs Janet Strickland, the former Commonwealth Chief Censor, on the success of her libel suit against Fred Nile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South African State President has justly granted a reprieve to the Sharpeville Six. The prison sentences imposed are heavy but some future government might reduce them, especially as very few informed observers believe that they are guilty of the offences with which they have been charged. To some extent the reprieves are a gesture to outside pleas but they are also partly due to pressures from within South Africa to reprieve four white policemen. Surely, if South Africa wishes to return to the civilised world it will abolish capital punishment altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: Meanwhile, I wish to pay a tribute to those white South Africans who have done so much to try to abolish apartheid. They have used whatever avenues were open to them and are undeterred by failure. Dozens of them are well known to those of us who study events in South Africa. Most are liberals with an unquenchable spirit. In particular I praise David Bruce, who was jailed in July for six years for refusing to help to impose apartheid while doing national service. We should all admire his great courage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this very brief moment available I would like to pay tribute to a group of girl guides and boy scouts who are going to Bangladesh in a couple of days to take part in a joint project between the girl guides and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), designed to give aid to that stricken and flooded country. The group comprises 18 rangers, who are girl guides over 18, and one rover whom one might envy, John McTier from my electorate, who are going to spend about a month in Bangladesh engaging in a joint project with UNICEF to provide immunisation, well digging and medical facilities in the wake of the floods.

SPEECH.PARA: One may well say that this is the sort of grass roots aid that Australia should be supporting more and I am very proud of these young people for what they are going to be doing. Most of the time they are going to be spending in Nakarli, which is a town of some 40,000 people in the south-east river delta, one of the areas most greatly stricken by the floods. They will be cooperating with the local girl guides to carry out this project.

The project they are doing may well be the subject of a Film Victoria documentary. They have received no Australian Government assistance and they require none. It seems to me that this is the kind of thing that young people do for which they ought to be paid great tribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bureau of Statistics, not content with arousing the wrath of the Australian people with its household expenditure survey, is now again riding roughshod over the interests of Australians with a survey of private child care usage, and the parent of every child attending a child-care or pre-school kindergarten in Australia will have to fill out this form.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is an invasion of privacy and an intrusion on the rights of parents to guide and care for their children. Complete and total confusion between child-care and pre-school is evidenced by question 4: `What was the main reason the child or children attended a child-care centre?' this was given out, by the way, to the parents of a child at a pre-school. It goes on: `Parents at work are looking for work, parent study, parents attending sport, parents shopping, parents and social activities and entertainment, give parents a break, parents engaged in community activity, parents visiting doctor, dentist, hospital, good for child-or other'. At the very last of the list is `good for child'. There is no mention of education, and that is what pre-schools are all about.

I would like to say that my constituent who alerted me to this tried to discuss the matter with the Sydney office of the Statistician and was treated very high-handedly. He tried to phone the Australian Statistician, Mr Ian Castles, was told he was unavailable, kept waiting on an STD call for 15 minutes while they searched for his secretary, who could not be found, and then when he tried to leave a message asking Mr Castles to call him back, was told by the switchboard, `It is not our policy to take messages'. That is a totally inappropriate and unacceptable way for any government agency to treat the people of this country, and I wanted to make the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to protest at the treatment meted out to Mr Justice J. F. Staples, Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I would like to quote from his own comments in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since early 1980 I have exercised the powers, jurisdiction, responsibilities of the office only occasionally, and since early 1986 not at all.
I know of no reason good in law that justifies what has been done . . .
De facto, the President of the Commission has cancelled the commission of the Governor-General.

It is not in the public interest that the Act should be administered with this result. The acts and defaults of the President invert the historical intendment of the relevant provisions of the Act . . .

The Act provides that I shall not be removed from my office except by the Governor-General, on an address from both Houses of the Parliament in the same session, praying for my removal on the grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity . . .
Only the Parliament can check the abuse that now rages.
I hope the Parliament will take that act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday we saw the first ever demonstration by scientists in support of science. Scientists have opened up an action front, a liberation movement for science, and I applaud them. They must speak up; the wimp tag must be relegated to the past. Concern at the calculated destruction of our human intellectual capital is now widespread. What we now lack is vision.

SPEECH.PARA: Where is the Australian Labor Party politician, for instance, who has the foresight to stimulate the search for the knowledge of space? Who in this Government will give that vision? It must come from the top. There ought to be in this country leadership, vision, energy, to achieve 200 years on. Instead we are starting to falter. It is not progress to see the best and brightest of this nation, the key to future economic prosperity, actively resorting to decibel democracy to make a point because leaders are too shortsighted to realise where our future really lies.

There is no leadership on the other side. Those who attempt to speak science, like Barry Jones, are ignored. As one of the different generation of rudimentary scientific literacy, but who has an abiding faith that as Australians we have the capacity, the initiative, the innovative skills, the drive to provide a better way, I join those scientists in calling for an urgent lead for a proper national science strategy.

We lack for one thing only-leadership with vision. That is the tragedy of this debate on science. It exposes so openly a failure of leadership and vision in a country that has so much to look forward to. Today's leaders are talking today and ignoring tomorrow. Be assured, history's judgment will be harsh unless there is a change of direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the few seconds left available before Question Time to call on all members of this House and all Australians, Madam Speaker, to buy Australian for Christmas. I believe it is important for us to remember as we make our Christmas purchases that whether it is a supermarket, motor vehicle or whatever, purchases of Australia-made goods mean jobs for Australians and mean cutting down on our imports.

SPEECH.PARA: Especially at Christmas time when people tend to look for little luxury goods, they should look for that kangaroo logo, the Australian-made logo, and make sure that they support Australian enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, will be absent from Question Time today on Government business. Questions normally addressed to Mr Bowen should be addressed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy. I also inform the House that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, will be leaving before the end of Question Time to meet a Government commitment.

—I address my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister in receipt of a brief on the findings of a special audit of Middar, a Western Australian cultural company, which disclosed a breach of a loan agreement with the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and a number of provisions of the Western Australian Companies Code, debts of over $450,000, and that it failed to properly account for public finding? Was the Minister further informed that in those circumstances the ADC could not fund such a body under the ADC Act? In October 1988 did the Minister, knowing these facts, then write to the ADC and ask that it reconsider its position with a view to continuing funding to Middar? Will the Minister table all relevant documents, including his letter to the ADC?

—Madam Speaker, I must say the source of these bits of information is exposing itself more and more. The question of the Middar organisation is an ADC matter. I did write, as I am often asked to contact the ADC-we have been down this track before. The ADC is a statutory body and, as has been the lot of previous Ministers when approached by a particular organisation, when one is asked to have the matter considered again by the statutory body, the ADC, one does it. As I understand it, the matter is properly before the ADC and I will address the question to it and I will report back to the honourable member.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the attempts by medical groups in Australia to introduce a new content based fee structure for general practitioner (GP) services from 1 November without prior consultation with the Government. Can the Minister inform the House as to what action he has taken to protect patients from the economic and social hardships which would arise due to the unilateral imposition of such a system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have shared the concerns of the honourable member for Scullin that hardships may result to patients as a result of a unilateral decision by a number of medical groups to impose a new fee structure. Therefore, I am very pleased to inform the House that last week the Royal College of General Practitioners agreed to ask its members to halt any imposition of the new fee structure pending discussions with the Government. We have agreed with the Royal College to set up a working party to examine and further develop proposed descriptions for a content-based GP fee structure. I am glad to announce that that working party will hold its first meeting next week.

ANSWER.PARA: The working party is to report by 1 March to develop descriptions of items and GP fee structures but not, of course, the fee levels. It will also look at the involvement of GPs in the provision of health promotion and preventive care services in this country, at quality assurance procedures and monitoring mechanisms, and at the incentives that can be provided for the provision of quality care, quality assurance, continuing medical education and vocation training for general practice. Any financial implications arising out of that working party would, of course, be a matter for Budget considerations.

I want to say that this decision by the Royal College is an historic decision. It will enable the Government and the College to work together on a package of issues, embracing not only fee structures but, very importantly, the quality of care provided and the continued upgrading of the skills of GPs. Let me say, because it has often been misrepresented, that my consistent position on this issue has been that the Government is not opposed in principle to a change from the longstanding time-based system to one which can be demonstrated to be better. However, conditions need to apply, and we have made this clear from the beginning of this debate. We would not allow changes if they were simply a back-door method of boosting doctors' incomes. The new system has to be shown to improve the quality of patient care and it needs to be capable of effective and proper monitoring and accountability, both in the interests of patients as well as in the interests of ordinary taxpayers.

I welcome very much the college's decision to participate in this process, and although a lot of hard work lies ahead I believe we can develop a GP fee structure which meets those criteria. I point out that the attitude of the college is in stark contrast to the attitude of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), which has simply sought a confrontationist position on this issue; it has refused to discuss these issues with the Government except under quite unacceptable conditions. Indeed, we might question whether the AMA is more interested in politics than in the interests of either GPs or of patients. Indeed, that is perhaps one of the reasons why the Royal College is increasing the number of GPs identified with it and the AMA is in fact declining. Let us put the AMA aside. It is increasingly becoming irrelevant to many of these health issues. Let me welcome very much that there will be this working party. We will be meeting with the college from next week. I believe that with hard work and good faith we can emerge with a system which not only improves issues for GPs but, much more importantly, improves patient care in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Is it a fact, as reported in today's media, that the Reserve Bank holds the view that mortgage interest rates should be pushed to 15 per cent across the board as a means of taking the heat out of the housing sector?

—I do not get up here-neither does any other Treasurer-and give views on what the Reserve Bank might think or might not think about a situation. The Reserve Bank supports the Government's view that monetary conditions ought to be appropriately firm, which they are. The interesting thing is that we keep getting these questions about mortgage interest rates. The Opposition is entirely unspecific about fiscal policy. The shadow finance spokesman is about tightening up interest rates.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I refer you to the question, which says, `Is it a fact that, as reported in today's Australian, the Reserve Bank holds the view that mortgage interest rates should be pushed to 15 per cent across the board?' The Treasurer apparently does not know that answer. He is about to launch into an attack unrelated to the question.
—Order! I am sorry, but how does the honourable member know what the Treasurer is going to say before he has even said it?
—Madam Speaker, I would like to be running the book on it.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Madam Speaker, apparently the Opposition thinks that Opposition policy should not be commented on by Ministers. I do not know of anywhere in parliamentary practice in 88 years where there is any substantiation for that view. That is just absolute bunkum. The shadow finance spokesperson believes that interest rates ought to be tightened up. There is no fiscal policy. So apparently the Opposition is saying that interest rates, monetary policy, should not be tightened. On the other hand, it will say imports are running too quickly. What does the Opposition want? Then it goes back to a question about living standards and declines in household disposable incomes coming from higher interest rates while at the same time it opposes every national wage adjustment.

—I take a point of order. Yesterday, I asked you, Madam Speaker, whether you would enforce the Standing Order on relevance. I refer you again to the text of this question and I suggest that there are only three possible responses: `Yes', `No', or `I don't know and I will find out'. The Treasurer has not uttered any of those words, so I do not see how his reply can be relevant.
—Question Time is a courtesy extended to the House by the Executive branch of Government.
—Under Standing Orders--
—Order! Will the Treasurer wait for a moment.
—When you are ready.
—Order!
—Order! That is quite enough.

—That is the constitutional position, and the Standing Orders are simply to facilitate the delivery of the courtesy. It is as simple as that. We see these crocodile tears about living standards when the Opposition has opposed every national wage increase since 1983. But then members opposite ask questions about the impact for interest rates-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shack

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order and persist with asking you, Madam Speaker, to enforce standing order 145, which provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: An answer shall be relevant to the question.

Despite what the Treasurer might say, there is ample precedent for the Speaker to rule on this debate, and I refer you to House of Representatives Hansard of 27 August 1981. The honourable member for Menzies, the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, was on his feet and departed from answering a question. He started to attack the then Opposition-the Australian Labor Party-and the then Speaker said:
Order! The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.
I believe that you, Madam Speaker, should enforce standing order 145 on this and every other occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chair is not bound by every decision taken by previous Speakers. The Treasurer was in order, but I suggest that he would assist Question Time if he did not make his answers quite so long.

—On the point of order: the process would be assisted if there were no disorderly interjections and points of order. Points of order which relate to relevance and which are themselves not relevant to the delivery of Question Time are disorderly; that is, the procedure of taking points of order is disorderly in this context.
—Madam Speaker--

—Order! The honourable member for Tangney will resume his seat. I point out to the Treasurer that it is incumbent on the Chair to hear all points of order. The Chair cannot rule on points of order until it has heard them.
—On the point of order, I accept that point, but if points of order are raised persistently--
—I have the right to raise a point of order, as well as honourable members opposite.
—Order!
—If points of order about relevance are raised persistently and they are rarely, if ever, accepted by you, Madam Speaker, the raising of these points of order is disorderly.
—Has the Treasurer drawn his answer to a close?
—No, I have not.
—The Chair urges him to do so.
—If I have an uninterrupted flow, I will answer the question. This Opposition has no fiscal policy; it has no monetary policy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shack

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I refer again to standing order 145 and I also refer to your ruling when you said that the Chair is not bound by every precedent of former Speakers. On 9 September 1981, an honourable member raised a point of order with the then Speaker Snedden and said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw your attention to the Hansard of 27 August. You ruled:
The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.
Madam Speaker, that member of Parliament was you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before you rule, Madam Speaker on that point of order, the question of relevance--
—You are debating it.
—No, one may take a point of order--
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders is not making the rulings in this House.

—One may take a point of order on a point of order that has been raised. Regarding that point of order, the question relates to relevance. Point one, that has always been broadly interpreted; point two, the question related to interest rates and throughout his answer the Treasurer has been discussing the basis of interest rates. I would have thought that that was evidently relevant.
—I have pointed out to the House on a number of occasions that very often relevance is a matter of opinion. The Chair calls the Treasurer.
—The Opposition will not stop me from answering questions. It is as simple as that.
—Order! The Treasurer will get on with his answer.

—The Opposition has no fiscal policy; it has no monetary policy. It has opposed every national wage increase since 1983, so there is no point in members opposite asking questions about the position of the Reserve Bank on interest rates if they have no consistency in any of the three major arms of policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Does the reprieve from execution of the Sharpeville Six indicate a significantly-

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Sydney will cease. There is far too much noise from my left. I cannot hear anything. I call the honourable member for Sydney.
—Does the reprieve from execution of the Sharpeville Six indicate a significantly improved prospect for reconciliation in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that the Government welcomes, as I hope all members of this House would welcome, the decision by President Botha to commute the death sentences of the Sharpeville Six. It would be well known to all members of the House and the international community that many leaders, including Prime Minister Thatcher, President Reagan, Chancellor Kohl and me, made personal appeals to the South African Government to spare the lives of the Sharpeville Six. Last month I also underlined the Government's interest in this case to Joyce Mokhesi, the sister of one of the six, when she visited Australia, and honourable members may be pleased to know that Joyce Mokhesi has just been in contact with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to thank the Australian Government for its efforts on behalf of the six.
—She has also been in touch with me.

—I never want to do an injustice to members opposite; they need every mercy they can get. I am quite prepared to concede, following the interjection of the honourable member for North Sydney, that he has also been thanked. I thank him, too, for his intervention. If it played some part, as I hope our intervention did, he is entitled to thanks as well. The Government-and I hope that the honourable member for North Sydney shares our position-remains very concerned that the Sharpeville Six, having been reprieved, nevertheless are still facing very long prison sentences, as I hope the honourable member for North Sydney appreciates, despite an admission by a key witness for the prosecution that he lied under oath because of police coercion. I hope that the honourable member is just as concerned about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The case against the Sharpeville Six, as you Madam Speaker would appreciate, turned on the application of the extraordinarily dubious doctrine of common purpose regarding individual members of a crowd who were not shown to have participated directly in the commission of an offence. Other South Africans are still liable to conviction on the same spurious grounds as were the Sharpeville Six. I can assure the House that the Government retains its concern on that matter and will continue to express that concern. It should be understood that the commutation of the death sentence of the six-which, incidentally, was part of a broader exercise of clemency that included the commutation of the death sentences of four white policemen-does not go to the root cause of violence in South Africa. Whatever else is said, it is crystal clear that the root cause of violence in South Africa is the evil system of apartheid and the continuing denial of political rights. Having said that the root cause of the problem remains and will continue, that there will be violence until the South African Government comes to the negotiating table, I repeat on behalf of the Government that we welcome the decision to commute the sentence of the Sharpeville Six.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Minister for Trade Negotiations expect to obtain support from the United States (US) for the liberalisation of world agricultural trade advocated by Australia and the critical General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) mid-term review in Montreal on 5 December when his colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has refused to support the United States objection to the non- scientifically based ban on growth promotants in livestock just imposed by the European Community (EC)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate the Leader of the National Party of Australia on his maiden question. The European Community and the United States, as the Leader of the National Party indicated, have been unable to resolve their differences over the Community's directive which effectively bans the sale of meat treated with hormonal growth promotants, and that directive comes into force on 1 January 1989. Its application to third countries was suspended for one year and will come into effect in 1989. Australia is concerned at the prospect of the intensification of bilateral trade disputes between the United States and the European Community which had led to the worsening climate in international trade, particularly in the agricultural area.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not heartened in Australia by the prospect of retaliatory and counter retaliatory measures which may result if the US and the EC are unable to reconcile their differences, which, as the honourable member indicated, appears to be the case at this stage. We are opposed to the ban on scientific grounds; nevertheless we are concerned to protect the interests of the Australian meat industry and its continued access to the European market. As honourable members would be aware, meat products exported to the European Community are worth about $130m a year, and Australian officials are holding discussions with the European Commission with a view to satisfactorily resolving this issue without prejudice to Australia's GATT rights.

In relation to the views expressed by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I do not know why the Leader of the National Party has the view that that in some way will conflict with the attempts of Australia to reach some reconciliation with the United States in attempting to bridge that gap which exists between the United States and the European Community on agriculture. It is a different issue. The premise on which the question was based is false. The issues can be separated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The United States wanted us to hold firm on this.
—The honourable member might get his chance to ask questions, if he is allowed, rather than interject at the time.
—You hope they can.

—Hopefully. Those discussions are taking place at the moment between our officials, the European Community and the United States. In relation to the other matters that the Leader of the National Party raised, we will be pressing on and we have been very active throughout the last two years in attempting to reconcile the differences between the European Community and the United States with the support of the industry, including the National Farmers Federation.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House about proposed capital works developments at the Macarthur Institute of Higher Education and the Government's overall program of capital works for higher education? Further, can the Minister advise as to the importance of the higher education contribution scheme in providing resources for the capital program and whether the Government considered any other options for alternative sources of funding such as up-front student fees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and his continuing interest in the Macarthur Institute of Higher Education. After Question Time I will be tabling a report which outlines the commitment of resources to higher education in the forthcoming triennium and in that it will be clear that the Milperra campus of the Macarthur Institute will be supported to the extent of $2.6m for a multi-purpose teaching centre. I am obviously aware that the institute, both at Milperra and the Campbelltown campus, has substantial capital needs for the future, particularly to support the very substantial growth it will experience over the next three years. It will be clear in the report that early next year I will be announcing the capital projects for 1990 and 1991 and the Government will support the projects necessary to accommodate the strong growth that will be occurring throughout the system during this triennium and beyond.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth pointing out that this is an historically high commitment of capital funds to the higher education system. In 1988 $78.5m was spent and by 1991 the figure will rise to $177m. This is in marked contrast to the commitment of our predecessors to higher education capital expenditure. In 1982, the last full year of the Fraser-Howard Government, expenditure totalled a mere $16.7m. Indeed, in one year that Government was able to fund only one new capital project, compared with the 48 new capital projects to start in 1989, including 13 new student residences. That does not include nearly $20m in renovation grants which are necessary to support the renovation of many of the older institutions which, as a result of the neglect of our predecessors, have many rundown facilities. That will provide the Government with an opportunity to concentrate on health and safety problems which exist in many places.

The honourable member asks about the way in which this capital support will be funded. As he points out, the new higher education contribution scheme will provide a significant amount of the funds necessary to support higher education in the future. The honourable member asks whether the Government looked at any other alternatives. The Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding did look at the proposal of up-front fees and it decided not to support such a measure because of the way in which such a system would constitute very substantial barriers to entering higher education, particularly for people from lower income and disadvantaged backgrounds. As opposed to that, our scheme will not constitute any up-front barriers. In that context it is interesting to look at the proposal reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today, which purports to be a preview of the Opposition's policy. There we have a re-run of its former proposal to involve the payment of very substantial--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have gone from a position of the Minister answering the question to him talking about the past practices of the Opposition when in government, and now to a point where he is talking about hypothetical matters reported in the newspaper for which he does not have any evidence of substance. That is going too far and he is wasting the Parliament's time.
—Order! I call the Minister.
—What is the ruling?
—The Minister will answer the question.

—I just happen to have a copy of the honourable member's question with me and he asks whether the Government has considered any other options for alternative sources of funding such as up-front fees. I am saying yes, we did consider them and yes, we did reject them because they constitute an unfair barrier to the entry of people from lower income and disadvantaged backgrounds. In relation to these other proposals, even if some scholarship or free places are provided the 75 per cent who do not qualify for such scholarships will be facing up-front fees of perhaps $12,000 and perhaps $30,000. That would be a crippling blow to all but the wealthiest people in the country and it is important to remember that merit-based scholarships would assist people from more privileged backgrounds, those who went to private schools and who are of more wealthy circumstances. So it is entirely inconsistent with any policy which tries to achieve greater access and greater equity. But at least this portends perhaps the disclosure of the Opposition's policy. I just want to say to members of the Opposition that there is no more time for procrastination or waffle. It is about time that they were as precise as we have been prepared to be in terms of our policies so that people can make a proper judgment of our policies versus theirs.

—The Treasurer will be aware that many Australians are finding the 1988-89 household expenditure survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics highly intrusive and have refused to respond to it. Is the Treasurer aware that, earlier this month, the Commonwealth Ombudsman expressed concern that the Australian Bureau of Statistics may have provided misleading or insufficient information to the Attorney-General's Department-information which resulted in a legal opinion that it was within the law to make the current survey compulsory to fill in? Has the Australian Bureau of Statistics yet responded to the Ombudsman's concerns? Has the Australian Statistician followed the Ombudsman's suggestion that he obtain the advice of the Attorney-General's Department on the legality of the retrospective tabling on 29 September of the household expenditure survey?
—I am not aware of the issues raised by the honourable member. I will put that question on notice where it should have been in the first place.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PURCHASE OF REAL ESTATE BY FOREIGNERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Is it correct that, since September last year, the Government has imposed a blanket restriction on the purchase of established residential real estate by foreigners? Has the Treasurer any information as to how prospective Australian home buyers might be disadvantaged if this restriction were removed?
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. I take it that this refers to measures that are contained within the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill which is before the Parliament to be debated today?
—Could the Treasurer give me some background to this?
—I think the question seeks information about conditions which were established by the Government up to 12 months ago.
—It is in a Bill before the House today.
—I do not intend to deal with elements of the Bill. I am just talking about conditions in the economy.
—The Treasurer will keep clear of the Bill. I call the Treasurer.
—It is correct that in September last year--
—That makes a farce of Question Time.
—The question is in order provided the Treasurer keeps clear of the provisions of the Bill.

—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: as you know, I am reluctant to enter into this sort of debate but I do say that it is intolerable to have the Leader of the Opposition saying to you that you are making a farce of the proceedings of this House.

—Madam Speaker, on that point made by the Prime Minister: yesterday you adopted an attitude towards the Opposition in relation to Standing Orders which was universally interpreted by members on this side of the Parliament as being unsatisfactory. You have been presented with a point of order and there is before this Parliament--
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order.
—The honourable member will resume his seat. I am hearing a point of order.

—The Prime Minister wonders why I interject in circumstances like that. Madam Speaker, when that kind of defiance goes on you have a classic example of why the Opposition feels frustrated by the conduct of the proceedings of the Parliament. The point of order raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was a very simple one. We have before the House at present a Bill which, inter alia, gives effect to an announcement made by the Treasurer affecting foreign acquisitions of real estate in this country. The point of order taken by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in relation to that standing order clearly brings to your attention the fact that the Bill before the Parliament gives effect to the announcement referred to in the honourable member's question directed towards the Treasurer. If that standing order is to have any meaning it must mean that the question asked is out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point of order: House of Representatives Practice, dealing with the question of anticipating debate before the House, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The principle established by rulings from the Chair is that questions seeking to elicit information about proceedings pending in the House are permissible provided they do not anticipate the discussion itself or invite a Minister to do so.

For example, in 1976, Speaker Snedden disallowed a question because it invited anticipation of the second reading speech and the arguments and principles upon which the legislation was based. However, he later permitted a question asking whether certain people would be disadvantaged under legislation then before the House.

The question that was asked of the Treasurer was not anticipating debate before the House but was asking whether persons would be disadvantaged, exactly in line with the circumstances permitted for asking questions by Speaker Snedden.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Spender

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. May I remind you that standing order 144 very clearly states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions cannot anticipate discussion upon an order of the day or other matter.

The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill is order of the day No. 10. It deals precisely with the matter about which the Treasurer has been asked. That question is clearly anticipating discussion-a very broad statement upon the Bill-which, incidentally, is subject to the guillotine process which means that we will not have a fair opportunity to put our own views on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has put his own point.

—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: clearly, it does not anticipate discussion. It is clearly phrased within the framework of that permitted question. Speaker Snedden permitted a question asking whether certain people would be disadvantaged under legislation then before the House. Quite clearly, nothing in that question invited him to anticipate debate on the matter. It went to that issue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order which relates in particular to the intervention of the Prime Minister. I draw your attention to page 856 of the Hansard dated 27 August 1981. The Prime Minister, who was then the honourable member for Wills, said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. What sort of double standards are you allowing in your ruling?
On page 857 of the Hansard the then honourable member for Wills, in addressing the Speaker, said:
You are allowing him to get away with murder.
The Minister has done it three times. There is a double standard in this House.
That is the standard of the Prime Minister, the hypocrite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Where is the point of order? I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. If he starts that again I will name him. The Chair has ruled the question in order. The Treasurer will keep away from specific portions of the Bill before the House.

—Before last year's announcement, purchases of residential real estate which were valued at under $600,000 were not examinable by the Foreign Investment Review Board. But the Government was concerned--
—That is exactly what the Bill is about.
—Order!

—That is right, but I am not canvassing the Bill. The Government was concerned that foreign purchases of Australian homes would be helping to drive up home prices without there being any significant offsetting benefit in the economy; in other words, we could see no advantage in permitting speculative purchases by foreigners. The Government, in making clear where it stood and, consistent with its foreign investment policy of welcoming foreign investment to Australia, allows foreigners to identify new residential housing--

—Madam Speaker, I take a further point of order. The Treasurer, in his answer, has identified the subject matter of the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill. It deals with urban real estate. He knows that it deals with urban real estate; it is the specific subject matter of that Bill. If these Standing Orders are to mean anything at all he cannot be allowed to continue.

—To that point of order: merely mentioning the title of a Bill does not anticipate discussion. He is not going to the substance of the Bill; he is dealing directly with the question of certain people being disadvantaged.
—The Treasurer may continue provided he keeps to that part of the Bill where certain people will be disadvantaged.

—Disadvantage would arise because, at the moment, the Foreign Investment Review Board is receiving about 400 calls per week from foreign persons or representatives of foreign persons seeking to buy Australian residential real estate. Were such a measure not to obtain--

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: the words that the Treasurer is using are repeated from his second reading speech on this Bill; they are almost word for word. I would suggest that he is transgressing in the way that was foreshadowed by my colleagues.

—Madam Speaker, the words that the Treasurer was using were clearly dealing with the question of numbers of persons potentially disadvantaged, or affected. That was in order as far as Speaker Snedden was concerned, but clearly those on that side of the House disagree with him.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Yesterday you ruled in relation to a similar point of order I took on this issue of canvassing debates in the current session. I add to the point of order taken by the honourable member for Curtin by referring to page 492 of Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice:

INTERJECT.PARA: References in questions to debates in the current session, concluded or adjourned, are out of order.
The Treasurer is clearly now referring to the debate in as much as he is referring to the second reading speech, and he is therefore out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is in order provided he keeps to the portion I have told him to keep to. If he is going to read us his second reading speech, he will be out of order.

—I am providing information to the House about the administration by the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Treasury of this particular provision. The fact is that were the restriction to be removed, there would be substantial upward pressure on existing house prices. If 400 inquiries turn into 400 purchases, we would have upward pressure on prices. But the Government sought to allow that pressure to go into developing undeveloped-that is, new residential-real estate by permitting foreigners to build and sell substantial residential real estate. I conclude on this point: if the measure is removed, there would be upward pressure on home prices by the up to 400--

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: When I raised this matter originally I simply put before you that the question was covered by the Bill. I sought not to argue it, because it was as plain as a pikestaff to me that the question was out of order. That has been shown now, with very wordy evidence, by the Treasurer. He referred to precisely what this measure covers. It is not a question of disadvantaged people; it is a question of the Bill covering the very ambit of both the September statement and what we are to debate tonight.

—Further to that point of order: the words that are being used by the Treasurer go precisely to the question of disadvantage, how that disadvantage occurs and what numbers are potentially disadvantaged, and that is what was covered by the precedent in the ruling from Speaker Snedden.
—I call the Treasurer, to conclude his answer.

—The disadvantage will be suffered by the Australian population at large and home buyers in particular, who will be under extra pressure from foreign purchasers who were formerly never registered, because we never took registrations of interest for properties under $600,000. Those 400 inquiries a week, if they become purchasers, will put upward pressure on prices. That is why the restriction should remain.

—Is the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support aware of the High Court's decision today which ruled that the Government's arrivals tax is unconstitutional? Will the Minister tell the Parliament how much was raised by this unconstitutional tax and what he will say to those who demand their money back?
—I thank the honourable member for his question, but it should have been directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and not me.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of reports that the Government is delaying making a decision on pay television until as late as the year 2000? Are these reports correct? What steps is the Government taking to develop policy on pay television?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that I am delaying decision-making on pay television. A press report a couple of weeks ago stated that I had referred a draft paper back to the Department. There is an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Max Walsh which condemns me for referring a paper back to the Department and says that I have effectively put pay television on the back burner. There is a remarkable press statement today by the Opposition spokesman on communications, Senator Lewis, in which he claims that I said in a recent speech that we intend to delay pay television until the year 2000.

ANSWER.PARA: I am rather surprised by these reports. The facts are as follows: firstly, I did refer a departmental paper on pay television back to the Department for further improvement because I believe it needed that improvement. It was not a matter of burying the issue; it was simply a matter of the Government making some input into a departmental paper and wanting various things that had not been raised at all or properly to be fully included in the discussion paper. It is a matter of the Government making sure that it has an input into these things and not simply accepting what comes from departments. To condemn us for that seems to me to be rather odd.

Secondly, my intention is-and I have already stated this but apparently it needs to be said again-to release that discussion paper early in the new year after it has been perused by Cabinet. We will then allow some months for public discussion before finalising the policy in the middle of next year. Contrary to Mr Walsh's impression that I am burying the issue, we are moving in a responsible way to develop a considered policy on this issue in the near future.

Thirdly, Senator Lewis has got things hopelessly wrong. Nothing in the speech I made last Monday week on pay television indicates an intention to postpone a decision on pay television until the year 2000-although I have no doubt that we will still be around at that time. What I did say was that we will be in a position to finalise policy on pay television well in advance of the expiry of the moratorium on pay television in September 1990; indeed, we will be able to do so a year or more before that.

The reference I made to the year 2000 was Telecom's intention to have completed its rewiring of the whole telephone network in this country by the year 2000. It will replace the copper wiring system, which currently brings telephonic communications into our homes and offices, with fibre optic cable which will not only give us improved telephony in this country but also the capacity for about 40 television channels. That will be completed around the year 2000 under the present intention of Telecom, and maybe sooner if pay television is agreed to.

What I also said was that other quicker alternatives could be used. There is at least one spare channel capacity in each capital city. The Aussat satellites that are launched at the end of 1991 and early 1992, will have transponder capacity for 14 television channels. We also have the possibility of pay television operators being licensed to lay down their own cables, as happens in the United States. There are all sorts of possibilities which could bring us pay television well before the year 2000. There are a lot of issues to be decided before we finalise the policy. The discussion paper will be available in the near future. Mr Walsh, Senator Lewis and anybody else who wants to read all about those issues will be able to do so in early January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I desire to put a question to you in respect of the conduct of the House. I refer you to the conduct of proceedings in the House yesterday when the honourable member for Grayndler, Mr Leo McLeay, was in the chair and the conduct of debate in respect of amendments to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988. I understand that the Opposition amendments were carried-if one listens to the tape that is made of the proceedings. First, will you examine this matter, Madam Speaker, to ascertain whether the committee passed the Opposition's amendments? Secondly, will you ensure that Hansard accurately records what happened when the Opposition's amendments were put and that the Votes and Proceedings accurately record the decision that was made?
—I will certainly take the question on notice and I will get back to the honourable member for Flinders after I have heard the tape.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The proceedings of a committee are not available to the House; they are the responsibility of the committee, and the only person to whom that question can be directed in the forms of the Parliament is the Chairman of Committees.
—Does the honourable member for Flinders wish to direct it to the Chairman of Committees?
—You said you would follow it up.
—I will follow it up.
—All I seek, Madam Speaker, is a statement of the facts. The matter may fall within your jurisdiction in respect of Hansard.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONDUCT OF THE BUSINESS OF THE HOUSE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I direct my question to you. You will be aware that Question Time is embedded in the practices of this House, that chapter 11 of the Standing Orders deals specifically with Question Time, and that its importance, as we know, is central to the whole business of Parliament and is summed up by Pettifer. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is fundamental in the concept of responsible government that the Executive Government be accountable to the Parliament. The capacity of the House of Representatives to call the Government to account depends, in large measure, on its knowledge and understanding of the Government's policies and activities. Questions without notice and on notice play an important part in this search for information.
Will you advise the House, Madam Speaker, whether it is correct to say that Question Time is a privilege extended by the Executive?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly take the question on board and will getback to the honourable member.

—In connection with the question that was raised about the passage of the Copyright Amendment Bill yesterday, I was the Minister at the table on that occasion. I recall that when the question was put the noes quite clearly were--
—Order! The Chair has taken the question on board and will have a look at it.

—I had intended to draw to the attention of the Chairman of Committees that it was possible that a mistake had been made. I understood, in accordance with the clear indication that was given by the House, that the record would be adjusted appropriately. I am sure that will have been carried out.
—The Chair will take the matter on board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.
