SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, for the information of the House, I present a report on higher education funding for the 1989-91 triennium.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Yesterday's Melbourne Herald carried a thoroughly inaccurate and disreputable reference to me in an article entitled `The might of the right'. The story alleges that I crashed a dinner of media executives. It then portrayed me as a supporter of General Pinochet in Chile. As to the first allegation, I refer to a letter written last night to the newspaper by one of my hosts at the dinner, Laurie Oakes. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Chris Wallace, in an article headed ``the might of the right'' (the Herald, Wednesday November 23) makes the outrageous claim that the Federal Education Minister Mr John Dawkins crashed a dinner of media executives at the Hyatt Hotel, Canberra, a few weeks ago.

Mr Dawkins certainly did not crash the function. It was a Nine Network dinner. Mr Dawkins and his wife joined in at my express invitation and that of my colleague Mr Peter Harvey. I might say that their presence added considerably to an enjoyable evening.
The conversation, of course, was private. Miss Wallace was not present.

As to the matter of the dinner table discussion, I would not normally have made public reference to it, given its private nature. However, because one of the participants has apparently facilitated this distorted report, I need to record my recollection of the conversation. The question of Chile was raised by one of the journalists employed by Bond media-not Mr Oakes or Mr Harvey-who complained of the acute embarrassment of having to work for an organisation whose chairman not only had commercial links with Chile but also extolled the virtues of General Pinochet's regime. The journalist went on to suggest that the Government should impose South Africa-type sanctions on commercial dealings with Chile. It was at this point that I disagreed, saying that the South African situation was different and that if governments started imposing sanctions on all obnoxious regimes it would be difficult to know where to draw the line.

The discussion was amicable and the report of my views by Miss Wallace, whom I have never met-or if I have I do not recall doing so-is thoroughly inaccurate. It is distinctly dishonourable for a journalist to report as facts events and conversations of which they have no direct knowledge without checking with those to whom they attribute quite offensive views and behaviour. A further gross distortion emerges as Miss Wallace tries to associate me with the New Right. Any half diligent journalist would know that in my Australia Day address of 1986 I was one of the first politicians to alert the country to the scourge of the New Right. I said then of the New Right:

There is emerging in Australia today a dangerous current-a so-called philosophy-that is a threat to the basic fabric of our egalitarian and liberal society. It would replace fraternity, equality and compassion with greed, indifference and self-interest. It threatens to undermine the principles of justice, equity and security that define the best in Australia. One of the worst and most offensive aspects of this movement is that it clothes itself in such traditional symbols as the flag, a borrowed and superseded anthem, and myths about enterprise and endeavour.
More specifically, as Trade Minister I said of Mr Copeman's actions in the Pilbara--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is now getting beyond his personal explanation.
—No, I am not, Madam Speaker. If you read the article you will see that there is a thread which tries to connect me first with the New Right and then with Mr Copeman.
—Sit him down. This is abuse.
—No. The Chair has always tried to give a certain latitude to those whom the press has maligned.
—You have been far more lenient to him than you have been to me.
—The honourable member will not argue when I am speaking. I fully remember when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had to make an explanation and I gave him a long time in which to do it.
—I am the Leader.
—Does that make a difference?
—Yes, it does. Certain indulgences, as I understand it, are extended to leaders on both sides of the House. This is going way beyond the indulgence given to anybody making an explanation.
—The Chair gives a lot of indulgence to leaders on both sides of the House and will give the same indulgence to a backbencher or anyone whom the press has abused.
—More specifically, as Trade Minister I said of Mr Copeman's action in the Pilbara:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not deal with work practice reform by taking the attitude of Charles Copeman. He instituted a lockout in one of our vital export industries, the iron ore industry. What do honourable members think was the attitude in Japan when the mining company decided to lock out the work force and suspend exports to Japan . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. This is an outrageous attempt to make a speech rather than correct a misrepresentation. Indulgence or no indulgence, it cannot be described as anything but that. I ask you, Madam Speaker, to sit him down.
—The Minister will draw his personal explanation to a close.
—Why don't you refer us to the page?
—I am quoting from Hansard; so Opposition members can look it up themselves. I despise--
—Then you don't have to repeat it.

—I am not quoting from Hansard now; I am making Hansard now. I despise the New Right. I despise brutally repressive regimes of the Left or the Right. I also despise slothful journalists who present their own fantasies, or the idle gossip of others, as facts. I have already taken up this matter with the paper's editor and I will send him a copy of this statement to assist with the publication of a suitable correction.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to act to halt the decline in Australia's Defence Force capabilities.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week there was a matter of public importance debate in this House on Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel wastage, and the Cross report, tabled last week, clearly documented the massive problem of Australian Defence Force wastage. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) did not appear in the House at that time and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) was delegated to take part in the debate. Once again the Minister dodged the issue, as he so often does. He sent her on an impossible battle which she lost and the myth that that side of the House has been peddling for at least three years about there being no problem with wastage from the Defence Force was blown apart by the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-the Cross report-which was tabled here last week. After last week the Government looked naked and very foolish as a result of the myth it had been perpetuating about Defence Force personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday at Question Time I asked the Minister for Defence whether there was a loss of capabilities in the Defence Force. He stood up and his first words were, `There has been no loss of capabilities'. The myth about the effect on personnel in the Defence Force has been exploded. The Government is now peddling another confidence trick about the state of the Defence Force itself and its capabilities. It thinks that it will get away with going around the country saying that there has been no loss of capabilities. Let us just look at the facts. The Minister claims that all his advice is that there has been no loss of capabilities. I will read some statements made by the Chief of General Staff, General O'Donnell, in evidence to the Cross report. He said:
Army's current high wastage rate has had and will continue to have adverse effects in the following areas:
a. Operational capabilities . . . High levels of wastage impact directly on Army's ability to meet government directed capabilities.
He went on to say:
At present the field Army is undermanned and underequipped.
And again:

There is a need for additional resources in both manpower and finance to reduce the workload . . . to equip ourselves to meet the tasks ascribed to the Army in the Government's defence policy . . . It is a fact that wastage is affecting Army's operational capability.
On and on it goes. That is one of the Minister's senior advisers. Let us look at what Vice-Admiral Hudson, the Chief of Naval Staff, said:

The shortage of both operators and maintainers is causing a high turnover in billets at sea which in turn is resulting in low experience levels and is affecting among other things, achievement of acceptable weapons practice standards.
Again it goes on:
Navy needs 1,200 more people across the FYDP or will have to stop some major activity in order to accommodate the capital equipment programme.
The Navy's submission to the Cross Committee said:
Experienced levels of personnel on sea postings are currently low. This adds to the likelihood of increased numbers of grounding, collisions and accidents at sea.
The Cross report said:
In 1987 half the active manpower of the submarine service was under training.

It is that low level of experience and the overcrowding on the HMAS Otama that caused, in part, the deaths of two submariners last year, according to the Chief of Naval Staff. The Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Funnell, said:
It may well be that we will have to cut back on the activities of the RAAF . . . we cannot continue operations as if we have pilots we no longer have.
The Cross report said of the Air Force:
High wastage has forced the RAAF to post comparatively inexperienced pilots into the QFI courses.
That is a reference to qualified flying instructor courses. The Acting Director of Air Force Safety, in his submission to the Cross Committee, said:

The first 6 months of this year have been the worst six months for accidents for 20 years. Inexperience has been a major factor in accidents. Young pilots are not supervised by older pilots because there are not any older pilots.
The Chief of the Defence Force said:
Firstly, there are no direct effects on operational capability.

But he did say that there has been a dilution of experience. Loyal as the Chief of the Defence Force is to the Government, I disagree with him and so does everyone else. Every second reference in the Cross report will indicate that dilution of experience has a major effect on operational capabilities. One has only to look at this dilution of experience in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) squadrons, in the submarine service and in the field Army to see the effect that this is having on the capabilities of the Defence Force.
After an exercise in northern Australia last year the commander of 1 Division, Major-General Jeffrey, said:

Heavy losses of trained manpower impinge heavily on operational effectiveness of the Division . . . A high wastage rate leads to lowering of the level of trained manpower, degrading effectiveness and the ability of the Division to train and deploy quickly to meet credible northern contingencies.
He went on to say:
The regular Army is undermanned to meet the Government's requirements. I estimate we are doing a 38,000-man task with a 32,000-man Army.
Just this week Colonel Dunn, the commander of 1 Division Artillery, the chief planner for Kangaroo '89, said:

The Army needs 4,000 extra men to sustain itself for any credible time. The high wastage of junior officers and NCOs is crippling Army operations. Six new 155mm guns are being mothballed because of lack of manpower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three senior colonels resigned last week.
—I will get to that in a minute. This week, RAAF officers, referring to the further cuts in flying hours for the Defence Force, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Front line squadrons will be unable to properly train their crews . . . This will lead to a dramatic decline in operational experience levels . . . The cut will not give the F111 squadrons enough hours to maintain their category C rating, let alone allow for any upgrading.
Finally, I will just put this myth to rest by quoting from the Cross report. It said:
The extent and magnitude of wastage in some of those areas is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.
The next decade! And that is if we start to do something about it now. It went on to say:
The effects of high wastage amount to a loss of operational capability . . . Capabilities will continue to diminish if wastage remains high.
My final quote from the Cross report is this:

The nation's senior professional single service military leaders have all acknowledged that the current high wastage rates have all reduced capabilities. These judgments were confirmed by the Chief of the Defence Force when he appeared before this committee.

In the face of all that evidence from the most senior Defence Force officers in this country, how could the Minister get up here as late as yesterday and maintain that there is no loss of operational capabilities in the Australian Defence Force? I presume that in a few minutes he will stand up and say again that there has been no loss of operational capabilities. Every time the Minister gets up and says that, the troops he is supposed to be commanding laugh at him. What is worse, every time the Minister gets up here and says that, the troops lose a little more heart. They say, `There's our commander denying that the problems exist. What hope have we got for any improvement?'.

If we look quickly at the Army we see that there are problems of low sustainability in the field; shortage of equipment, even in the Australian Defence Force; shortage of ammunition; and shortage of officers and non-commissioned officers. It came to my notice this week that two commanding officers of the only two battalions in the ADF, the 1st Battalion and 2/4 Battalion, resigned.

TALK.START.PARA: —They came to the end of their terms.
—Of course they had. They resigned because they did not want to come down here and soldier on.
—Like you.

—I resigned when the Whitlam Government was in power, for the very reason these two commanding officers have done it-because this Government is in power. The Minister should not give us that rubbish. The same thing is happening again.

SPEECH.PARA: The test for the Army is simply this: If we had to send a force to Fiji or anywhere else, as we did last year, would it be able to do the job? Honourable members should recall the fiasco in May last year when the ADF bounced around in a couple of frigates off Fiji. They came back and said, `Thank God we did not have to do anything because we had nothing to do it with-no vehicles, no helicopters, nothing'. If we were asked to go in to Papua New Guinea tomorrow would we be any better off? The answer is no. We can look at what has happened to the Navy in the last four years. HMAS Snipe, HMAS Ibis, HMAS Kimbla and HMAS Yarra have been decommissioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the new ones.

—Do not talk about new ships. Where are they? The test for the Navy is simply this: Can our Navy operate offshore on its own with any security? The answer is no. That is how the Navy has declined in capability. If the Navy had to force a passage through straits to our north which might be closed by a hostile power, could it do it in the face of land-based aircraft? The answer is no. And the same sorts of comments might be made about the Air Force.

SPEECH.PARA: One might ask why it has all happened. It has happened for a variety of reasons. The Government's promised funding has never come to fruition. The Government's great 3 per cent increase has never happened. The 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product this year is the lowest proportion of GDP on defence spending since 1950. The Government has maintained all its equipment programs at the expense of training personnel. It simply does not understand the fine relationship between personnel, training and equipment. It has allowed it to get out of kilter. The White Paper which will be the subject of another debate-the Minister's blueprint for the future-is falling into one big hole: surveillance, the air-sea gap and the defence of mainland Australia.

The Australian Defence Force is in serious trouble. The Minister either does not understand what is happening in the Defence Force or he does understand and will not face his responsibilities; or it may be both. As far as personnel wastage is concerned, the Minister has hidden behind the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel for the last 12 months, despite the fact that it is his direct responsibility. That myth has not been blown apart. As far as capabilities are concerned, the Minister has nowhere to go. The Minister has not faced the facts in the past. He would not face them yesterday. I will be interested to see whether he is going to accept some responsibility today. If he does not, we will continue to expose the myth he is peddling until we restore the Australian Defence Force to a proper level of capability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an example here of why this man-the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White)-cannot be trusted with a shadow Cabinet portfolio position. The level of immaturity of his analysis was brought out in his statements here today. He talked about operational capability, and I will deal with that later. During his remarks, by implication, he committed the Opposition to an extra 4,000 to 6,000 men in the Army. Give or take a few hundred, the Army is virtually the same size it was throughout the Fraser years. The Opposition spokesman has now committed the Opposition to another 4,000 to 6,000 men. He told us that what we ought to be doing is concentrating on exercises and on capability. He said we need another 4,000 to 6,000 men in the Army. He has just attempted to commit the Opposition to a cool $400m to $500m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: He then asked whether the Navy would be able to sustain operations distant from our shores against an air threat? There is only one possible conclusion to that position and that is that the Opposition is again calling for an aircraft carrier-the step it took away when it was in government. If it is talking about an aircraft carrier with substantial fleet coverage capability, it is talking about an aircraft carrier with a substantial number of fixed wing aircraft, not just helicopters. The honourable member has now committed the Opposition to $2 billion worth of additional expenditure. Failing to achieve that, he says--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the cost of an aircraft carrier.

—The honourable member for McPherson does not think that is the cost of an aircraft carrier. He should go away and do his sums again because that is what it is. The Opposition has a problem in comprehending the real nature of the defence debate-not what individual unit commanders may feel from time to time, but the overall balance of the Australian Defence Force; not an individual lobby position that might be put forward from time to time, but the overall balance of the Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Opposition fails to understand that means that it cannot develop a defence policy. We have been waiting for about one year for a defence policy to appear. Even if the Opposition got what it asked its shadow Cabinet for-3 per cent real growth ad infinitum-it would still not be able to fit into the defence program an aircraft carrier and another 6,000 soldiers. That is before we talk about what the honourable member for McPherson is asking for in terms of in-flight refuelling for the F111s, nuclear submarines, and a helicopter carrier for the deployment of ground forces. Before the Opposition did all of that, it still could not fit the program announced today by the honourable member into what his maximum demand is on the shadow Cabinet, let alone what it may be prepared to provide him with.

The fact of the matter is that if there is any impact on morale by the public statements of Ministers, shadow Ministers or other people in politics as far as the defence forces are concerned, the problem lies not with statements that I might make or that my colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) might make, it lies with the honourable member for McPherson. If the honourable member wants evidence of that, let me now present it to him from the Chief of the Naval Staff in his address to the Returned Services League National Congress. This must be unprecedented in a serving officer dealing with an Opposition spokesmen on defence. The Chief of Naval Staff said:

I quote a recent public statement with which I totally disagree: ``Australia's defence capability is becoming a sick joke to our friends and allies'' (Peter White, 4 August 1988). If I did not know better I could only assume that the author of that remark had no knowledge of where the truth lay; nor was interested in finding out.
There are, of course, difficulties such as the shortage in some areas of trained personnel. In other areas we are losing more than we can really afford; and no Chief of Staff will ever claim-
honourable members should listen to this; this man knows the politics of this business-

that his service has enough money for operating expenses; but while we may be relatively small, I have no hesitation in saying that the ADF is as professional as it has ever been. A realistic approach is being taken to the allocation of resources to ensure that the balance between capability, readiness and sustainability is maintained. As I have said before, we are not preparing for World War III. The balance that has been struck is sensible in terms of current strategic outlook and flexible enough that we can react to the uncertainty we could face in the future. So despite the criticism of the ill-informed, Australia does have a Defence Force with a capability to meet credible, I again stress credible, contingencies--
The Opposition does not understand that. That is why it goes on advocating another 6,000 full time men for the Army at a cost of $500m per annum. He continues:
. . . and the infrastructure to expand in response to higher levels of conflict.

The Chief of the Air Staff recently was so irate about comments that had been made on the capability of the Air Force that he sent me a note, requesting that I use it at some time. He wrote-and nobody on this side of the House would say any differently-as follows:

There is no argument that the RAAF is currently experiencing difficult times-as is the ADF generally-because of the increased rates of personnel separation. But to draw the conclusions he does, Mr White is drawing a long bow and, at the same time, taking a cheap shot at the professional competence of the personnel who remain to sustain and develop the RAAF's operation skills and corps capabilities.
Let me go on to something that was said by the Chief of the Defence Force in a recent public statement:

Australia has a coherent defence policy, an efficient and effective Defence Force and skilled service professionals in whom Australians can feel pride and confidence. Yet it has become almost fashionable in some small but vocal segments of the community to talk about the rundown of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and of our defences in general. Both propositions are demonstrably untrue. Unchecked, they are potentially damaging and run the risk of causing Australians to lose confidence in their Defence Force. Such propositions are also depressing for the ADF itself which knows that reality is otherwise. There are also more serious concerns if we are sending the wrong signals to neighbours and allies.

It was sensible diplomacy for me to maintain my silence regarding the sort of nonsense that the honourable member for McPherson talked at the time of the Fijian crisis about our capacity to do things there if the Government so decided. For me to have disputed that openly in public at the time would have been to create circumstances of crisis that any sensible government would be unwilling to let any Minister pursue. The decisions that were taken by us at that time not to deploy military force in that instance, and in a number of others, were decisions not taken by virtue of a lack of confidence on our part in the capacity of our defence forces to do the job. They were taken for sound political and policy reasons.

There was no doubt whatsoever in the mind of the Government at that time that if a direction had been given to the Australian defence forces to protect the lives of Australian people in that country, should the circumstances have arisen where their lives were under threat, our armed forces had the capacity to do the job. It is unfortunate that the circumstances at the time did not permit me to defend the honour and the capabilities of our defence forces against the type of mindless assault delivered by a number of people in the press at that time and by the honourable member for McPherson in his speech 10 minutes ago. But I can do it now. I will defend the honour and effectiveness of our defence forces against the persistent attack that the honourable member has made on their capacity over the last three months.

The honourable member's problem is that he is a totally immature Opposition spokesman on an important area of policy. That is why he is still a junior Minister. That is why he has been given another junior Minister to run in competition with him. That is why, at the back of the minds of the coalition parties, if ever they were to resume office, there is not the slightest possibility that they would give the job to him. The fellow who is totally bored with the question of international trade and who finally managed to struggle to his feet to ask one question here would be, in those circumstances, the Opposition's defence Minister.

The honourable member for McPherson cannot be trusted with the defence forces because he does not have an understanding of how to formulate a defence policy. What he has, based on his past experience, which was of great, honourable service, is a capacity to comprehend what a unit commander feels at any point of time and, when taken to the nth degree, what he would require to sustain himself in all conceivable circumstances of high and low threat. He does have an understanding of that. That is how one competently commands a unit, as the honourable member did, but unfortunately it is not how one competently conducts oneself as a Minister for Defence. What one is obliged to do, and what the Chiefs are obliged to do is, in the end, to achieve a balance. In peacetime there will never be the capacity of any government in this country-there never has been-to provide absolutely every capability that every sound professional judgment will say that we ought to possess. That is simply commonsense.

The question is whether one is getting one's balance right and ought one to adjust one's balance if one sees in some circumstances that one is not getting it right. We have a continually open mind on that subject. There may be a requirement in some circumstances for extra operational expenses to preserve capability. But let me assure honourable members straight away that we will never define a requirement that operational capability requires another 6,000 men in the Army, more than Malcolm Fraser was prepared to sustain in the Army. We will not arrive at a judgment that a maintenance of capability requires that. Some highly capable professional men would urge us to do so, but we would not arrive at that judgment. However, we are prepared, from time to time, to arrive at a judgment for compromised trade-offs on operational expenses questions versus capabilities.

Increasing amounts of money are going to the operational areas. The question is whether it is enough. The question also is what priorities do we assert to choose among them. One of the difficulties being experienced by Army units at the moment is the question of whether the resources will be there for a series of exercises it has been used to performing. For Exercise Kangaroo 89 next year we are suspending a series of exercises that we would normally do, or running them down, in order to be able to put resources into Kangaroo 89, which is a test of the whole Government's defence strategy. Is that commonsense or is it not? It will impact in a way that concerns some people in some units, obviously. The combined cost of the exercises that have been cancelled or reduced constitutes $25m less than we are going to spend on Kangaroo 89. So, in effect, we are going to spend more on that operation than we would on the exercises that have been cancelled.

Obviously, if one has a budget-which as I said, unlike the rest of Commonwealth outlays, has increased slightly in real terms over the last year-one has to operate within it and establish priorities within it. As one establishes priorities, there will be some satisfied and some dissatisfied people. In the case of operating expenses of the Air Force, where there is an increased training requirement, as we have as we experience pilot losses, which every other country in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is experiencing, we have to put more into those training areas than perhaps we would put into other Air Force operations.

The honourable member does not understand that that is the sort of thing governments have to do. If the honourable member were sitting in my place and I were sitting in his, it would be the same case. He would be making decisions about priorities in these areas within a budget the same size as ours-as he has batted in front of his shadow Cabinet. It can give his shadow Cabinet no confidence in him that when he stands up in this place he displays no facility for the capacity to make policy in that regard and throws gratuitous insults which have caused him to lose the confidence of the senior defence advisers in this country. The quotations I have outlined demonstrate that. It will give the shadow Cabinet no confidence to hear the honourable member attempt to commit it to what would require 7 to 8 per cent real growth for five or six years to get anything near the sort of equipment and manpower levels that he is asking for.

The honourable member is not a competent Opposition defence spokesman. He insults the Services, which perform great tasks in great difficulties for this country and he is where he should be-a junior shadow spokesman, and that is where he is going to remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to rise this afternoon to support this matter of public importance in the House. I say that not simply as a backbencher whose turn has come around to debate something as important as this issue, but as somebody who until eight months ago was one of the senior officers under the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I notice that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is disappearing out of the House. I wish that she would stay and listen to what I have to say, as it deserves to be heard. I say to the Minister for Defence that I am appalled at what I have heard him say here this afternoon. What he has done in half the time allotted to him has been to put up a great smokescreen about Opposition defence policy. We are not about Opposition defence policy this afternoon; we are about discussing the decline in Australia's operational capability.
—Under this Government.

—Under this Government, I agree. What the Minister did was to resort to personal castigation of the shadow spokesman. I deplore that and I am sure that everybody in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) would do likewise. I think he also questioned the professional integrity of some very senior officers in the Defence Force. I note one in particular that he referred to-the Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Hudson, for whom I have the highest esteem and who has the highest integrity, et cetera, of anybody in the Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet what did the Minister say? He said, `He knows the politics of the game'. In my view, that has hit the nail right on the head: `He knows the politics of the game'. In this place on 30 August I made a comment about my resigning from the Defence Force, as I did in March, in which I said that I was absolutely appalled at the increasing politicisation of the higher echelons of the Commonwealth Public Service and the Defence Force. The Minister has come into this place this afternoon and admitted that. `He knows the politics of the game' is what the Minister said. That is appalling and it reflects on the integrity of the Defence Force members, who must remain apolitical if we are to be truly effective.

As far as the decline of capabilities is concerned, which is the subject of the matter of public importance before us this afternoon, the Minister completely disregarded the facts. I draw attention to one or two facts that relate to the Royal Australian Navy. I am sure that some of them will apply to the other two Services as well. I do not want to regurgitate the argument over the aircraft carrier decision and operating fixed wing strike aircraft from an aircraft carrier, even though the Minister drew that as a red herring in the debate earlier this afternoon. First of all, I have to say that the decision of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) to take up that fixed wing training support for the fleet has not been completed. The FA18s and the Macchis are just not able to complete those tasks. There are not enough pilots in the RAAF. I think we all agree on that. But, more importantly, they do not have the experience and they do not have the qualifications. Therefore, the Navy, in particular, is unable to exercise in the way it should. That is very important for operational readiness. The Minister can posture about operational readiness; but let there be no doubt about it: the Defence Force has suffered a reduction in its operational readiness.

The next point I make is in relation to the loss of a number of commanding officers of our front-line ships. Over the last three years 10 to 12 senior commanding officers have been lost forever. Ten to 12 does not sound a very large number. But they are absolutely impossible to replace. We have to look at the fact that those senior officers would have moved on to drive the desks in Russell and Campbell Park and to determine the operational capability for the future. Those officers have been lost.

I also refer to the loss of expertise generally. In the Navy it is generally known that rank and skill levels are being manned at below the optimum rank. That simply means that we do not have the right people for the right job. Therefore, a lot more time has to be spent on training. Of course, that whole training scene is compounded by the restrictions on fuel. We heard the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) talk about restrictions on fuel both for ships and for aircraft. In naval terms, the fleet commander is just not able to meet his operational readiness targets.

The projects area seems to be a preoccupation of the present Minister. I have to say, as I said in this place on 30 August, that he has forgotten about people. When one talks about a loss of capabilities, one is really referring to people. Therefore, we have to look very closely at the Cross report, the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which was tabled in this place only two weeks ago. What are the facts? In 1987-88, 13.2 per cent or 9,327 people left the Defence Force-the most to leave in a single year for more than a decade. There has been an increase over the previous year in four successive years. In 1986-87 the wastage rate amongst critical personnel, such as engineers, computer specialists, project managers and pilots, was also the highest for 10 years. In 1987-88, 3,839 or 41 per cent of the 9,327 total personnel leaving the Defence Force departed despite the fact that they were not eligible for pension benefits. More than 25 per cent or 18,246 people have left the Defence Force in the past two years.

We find government spending on personnel dropping from 49.9 per cent of the total budget in 1982 to 43 per cent this year. In 1987-88, 123 of the ADF's 820 pilots left the Force, compared with a 10-year average of 47. In 1986-87, 107 pilots quit the Defence Force. I have to remind the House that to train a pilot to graduation costs in excess of $1m. To convert a pilot to fly an FA18 costs a further $700,000. Flying hours and knowledge of operational skills costs nearly $1m per year per pilot. The pilot bonus scheme, which Minister Kelly has commented on in this place and which was instituted by her Government to retain Defence Force pilots, has failed to dissuade pilots from leaving and in fact has caused resentment among other key personnel, such as electronics and communications engineers, who are also being lost to private enterprise.

Members of the Defence Force are being regarded as second class citizens. Some service families now supplement their income with the family allowance supplement or social security income because they live below the poverty line. That is appalling. In relation to housing and education, 61 per cent of 5,133 servicemen surveyed advised the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works that they were less than satisfied with current living-in accommodation.

I think what I have said this afternoon clearly demonstrates that the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel do not have a feel for what is going on within the Australian Defence Force. Clearly they are out of touch and, as I said in this place on 30 August, both Ministers continue to tread a very fine line between management indecision and maladministration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance the terms of which state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to act to halt the decline in Australia's Defence Force capabilities.

There are a number of aspects to that. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) spoke mainly about the operational aspects, and that is one part; but there are a number of other aspects. The operational aspects were discussed by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) today in a very fine contribution to this debate.

A number of red herrings have been floated by the Opposition today. Indeed, it will be interesting to see, on 4 December when its marvellous manifesto comes forth, what is the Opposition defence policy. This Government has been in office for nearly six years, and I have been involved in defence debates for that long on this side of the House. The Opposition's defence policy changes not only from month to month but from week to week and sometimes from day to day, depending on which speaker is on his feet. At one stage the previous member for Denison-before we got rid of him; before the last election-said that he wanted another $7 1/2 billion for defence. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) said today that he wanted another 6,000 men for the Army. The Minister for Defence, quite rightly, said that the Army is basically operating on the same number of men as it has been for a long time. The Opposition should not forget that it was in government for seven years and before that for 23 years. It has spent three decades in government. The previous speaker talked about housing, education and a number of things. What did the Opposition do in housing and pay when it was in government for three decades? Absolutely nothing! The Defence housing was in a disgraceful state until this Government's spending of $750m over 10 years, a program which has been hailed by everyone concerned as a very good program to bring the defence housing up to a respectable state. Why did it get to that state? It got to that state when the Opposition was in government. It got to that state because for the last couple of years under the Fraser Government, the Opposition's Government, hardly anything was spent on defence housing. Honourable members opposite talk about defence personnel and looking after personnel, but the troops were treated like third-class citizens and families by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —And tonight you are cutting out new enlistees from defence service home loans.

—I will not bite with that nonsensical interruption from the honourable member for Farrer. We come into this House with yet a new Opposition defence policy being announced today. I wonder what it will be on 4 December. Six thousand new men costing half a billion dollars per annum has been put forward today. We look at the old forward defence again, because we are going to have aircraft carriers. The Minister for Defence said that would cost about $2 billion. I think Australia would be lucky to get out of it under $3 billion. Unlike the Opposition's Defence Minister, who said, `We are going to have an aircraft carrier', the honourable member was going to put helicopters on it. Whoopdedoo! That is what Mr Killen said. Aircraft carriers with helicopters. That is no damned good. Decent fixed-wing aircraft are needed, as the honourable member knows, and in this day and age that costs a great deal. We are looking at probably $2 1/2 to $3 billion, and some experts would say, `It is no good getting one aircraft carrier; you really need three. And even if you did have one, you would need a number of other ships, destroyers, to escort it. You are looking at billions of dollars'.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone on this side of the House, in a euphoria land, would say, `That is wonderful. Let's have three aircraft carriers. It would be terrific. We can have 40,000 men in the Army, too. It would be terrific. Let us have 20 submarines'. But the trouble is, who is going to pay for them? The Opposition knows it cannot pay for them. It will never come back in. The Opposition in fact had already made the decision in late 1982, early 1983, not to go ahead with the aircraft carrier. It did not tell anyone. Then its former Defence Minister, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), when in opposition straight after, when we carried that decision out, said, `What a dreadful thing'. He forgot to tell the people of Australia that he had already come to the same conclusion just a few weeks before when he was the Minister. That is absolute nonsense.

The Opposition talks about housing and a pay freeze. We are not perfect on this side of the House. A report was quoted and I was a member of the committee that brought that report into this House a few weeks ago. It raised a number of very important matters, which the honourable member for McPherson brought up today. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has welcomed that report. But let us not forget that on a number of occasions the report states quite clearly that the Committee welcomed a number of the initiatives that the Government had already taken. It will take anything from six to 18 months to see the final result of those initiatives that have already been taken.

The Minister for Defence pointed out-I think it was at Question Time today-the wastage rates in other air forces and in the United States; in fact, the turnover in those air forces was higher. It is not a perfect world. There are problems, particularly in the Air Force, because of all the other competing pressures. We are living in 1988 and not 1958. The people in the defence forces are highly trained, in very good jobs, and are subsequently able, if they resign from the defence forces, to obtain excellent jobs outside, and to receive very good money, and they can live very well. This was not always the case in 1948, 1958 or even 1968. However, in this day and age-and it is here now forever-because of the very high quality of the training, people in the defence forces are being grabbed by industry day after day.

So I think probably the reality is that there will be a higher wastage rate than has historically been the case. It will become lower than it is now. I am not suggesting it will stay as high as it is now, but I think the level will be higher than it has been historically, for all the reasons that I have just mentioned. Not the least because a person can lead in some respects a better life. A serviceman gets married; his wife has a couple of children; he is in his thirties, and after being shifted half a dozen times because of promotions or whatever, his wife says, `Look, we are not going to put up with this any more. You can get a good job outside with good money. We can live in a three- or four-bedroom home in a city we like, and we can live well'. That is a real pressure. We will have to put up with that to some extent.

The recommendations of the Committee have been gone through with the Government. The Ministers, in particular, will be looking at those very closely, and I am quite sure they will be looking to implement a number of the recommendations of the Committee to assist our defence personnel as much as possible.

In conclusion, as I said, there are a number of aspects to this matter of public importance. One is the operational side in regard to personnel and the second is the capability side. On the capability side we have heard today how we should be spending more money on personnel and, at the same time, we should be spending more money on capability. One cannot do both unless one is going to blow the budget out or virtually cut the education or health department portfolio in half. It cannot be done. I believe that the Budget brought down by the Minister is well balanced. It was brought down for a very good purpose-to serve Australia in peacetime. Australia will have very good capability, including submarines and frigates as well as FA18s in the not too distant future. We will have a Defence Force much more capable and reliably targeted than was the case several years ago when members opposite were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

—I am indebted to you, Sir. Perhaps I should say that this is the first opportunity I have had of making this personal explanation. I was misrepresented by a spokesman for the Attorney-General who was reported in the Age yesterday, 23 November. Perhaps by way of an aside, I should say that, in view of the Speaker's remarks about misrepresentation in a newspaper, I am not suggesting for one moment that I was misrepresented by the newspaper, rather that it had reported, presumably accurately, what the spokesman for the Attorney-General said.

SPEECH.PARA: This spokesman said that it was `absolute nonsense' for me to have suggested that the Special Investigations Unit was interrogating people before the War Crimes Amendment Bill had even been passed by the Parliament. I was misrepresented by the Attorney-General's spokesman, as is shown by the following two facts. The first is that in the particular case I referred to in my press conference, two Federal Police officers interrogated a suspect, without cautioning him, about alleged offences under the War Crimes Bill. The second fact is that the Special Investigations Unit has interviewed and questioned numerous people in Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra about their alleged involvement in offences under the War Crimes Bill. Finally, whatever the spokesman for the Attorney-General may say, before the Bill has even been passed, this Government and its agents have been trying to enforce it in breach of every principle of law and justice this country is based upon.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL(No. 12) 1988SALES TAX BILL (No. 12) 1988SALES TAX BILL (No. 1a) 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1988 concurrently with the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 12) 1988, the Sales Tax Bill (No. 12) 1988 and the Sales Tax Bill (No. 1a) 1988. That being the case, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition parties do not oppose the Bills. However, as I shall explain in detail shortly, I will move committee stage amendments tightening up certain wording in the Bills so as to remove unnecessary ambiguity and uncertainty. A second reading amendment has also been circulated to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1988. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(1) the Keating/Hawke Government presides over a ramshackle wholesale sales tax system which abounds in anomalies and inconsistencies;
(2) the sales tax system is made incredibly difficult to understand and administer by ambiguous legislation;

(3) the Australian computer software industry, an increasing supplier of exports, has especially suffered from ambiguous and confusing sales tax legislation, and as a result vital export income that could contribute to the paying-off of Australia's huge net foreign debt of $89 billion has been lost; and
(4) the proposals contained in the Bill are a further indication that Government taxation policies are creating substantial inequities in the effect of taxation upon individual Australians'.

Under the present sales tax law, computer programs, whether developed for a single user or for a number of users are subject to sales tax where the programs are embodied in goods and are imported into or sold in Australia. As announced in the August Budget, the broad purpose of the four Bills is as follows: first, to remove sales tax on computer software programs developed for a single user, except to the extent that the programs contain programs or parts of programs for multiple users; and, secondly, to extend the sales tax beyond multiple user computer programs embodied in goods to multiple user programs delivered by electronic transfer as well. These changes follow two years of dispute between the Government and the computer software industry. First, the Bills attempt to rectify the apparent taxation of software services. In the 1986-87 Budget, the Government extended the application of sales tax to the production of computer software. In announcing the 1986-87 amendments the Treasurer said:

Avoidance of sales tax occurs through the device of selling only the discs and tapes on which the computer software is embodied and licensing the consumer to use the software itself; sales tax is then payable only on the value of the discs, which is a small fraction of the total price. The sales tax law is to be amended . . . to ensure that the taxable sale value of the computer discs on tapes encompasses the software on them.
He then went on to note:
The production of `in-house' software will not be affected by the changes . . .
More clearly, in a 1986 memorandum to the deputy commissioners of Taxation in each State, the Australian Taxation Office in Canberra stipulated:
The amendments are not to be interpreted as authority to collect sales tax on the mere supply of computing services.

Indeed, the relevant November 1986 taxation ruling from the Commissioner of Taxation made it obvious that, where a software consultant was engaged to develop or install a computer software service that might otherwise have been developed in-house, it would be exempt from tax. It was obvious that the Government's stated intention was that software services were not to be taxed. Only the manufacturers of a product for multiple users would be taxed. However, as is often the case in this area, the stated intention was not matched by the actual practice of the Tax Office. The perennial problem arose that the Tax Office reinterpretation resulted in a draft ruling in May 1988 that effectively taxed the provision of services as well as the manufacture of goods. Therefore, taxation by stealth again reared its ugly head under this Government.

Honourable members will be aware that, as a general principle, the wholesale sales tax system applies to goods that have been produced and not to services provided. Effectively, the extension to services would mean the introduction of, pretty much, a broadly based consumption tax, something that we know the Treasurer in this country personally supports strongly but, of course, virulently attacks publicly. We all know that he was a great advocate of the consumption tax until his tax cart hit the brick wall at the fiasco of the National Taxation Summit-the tax reform summit, as it was euphemistically called-in 1985. Nonetheless, after extensive consultation with interested groups and in particular with the Australian Information Industry Association and the Software Services Industry Federation of Australia, the Government has backed down. It has given the Tax Office a slap in the face and has introduced this legislation to ensure that where a service is provided to a single user it will not be taxed.

Unfortunately, things are never as simple as they first appear, and in all areas of tax legislation we must begin to worry how much ice is being left for the Tax Commissioner to skate on. Unfortunately, the current legislation is still ambiguous. Its definitions lack clarity. Simply stated, the software industry is genuinely concerned that the changes introduced in these Bills will be as ambiguous as the existing legislation and, therefore, they will inevitably result in a Tax Office ruling or rulings that again encroach on the area of services.

In recent times disquiet about the various rulings of the Tax Commissioner and his office has increased. The taxation bureaucrats have been sailing very close to, and many people will say far beyond, the limit of their responsibility. Their job is to administer the taxation laws in a non-partisan and objective manner. They must not suppose that they can infringe on the role of the Parliament or on the role of the judiciary. The Tax Commissioner possesses very wide discretionary powers. It is imperative that he uses them circumspectly. His duty is to raise taxation revenue efficiently; his duty is not to impose his own morality on whether or not individuals and companies should strive to minimise their tax burden. Very few individuals and very few companies in this country can be considered tax cheats. The overwhelming majority are honest taxpayers who are suffering from the crippling burden of high tax rates and the need to interpret over 3,500 pages of complex and sometimes enigmatic tax legislation.

A particular concern with the Bills is the definition of `computer program', which has been altered to include part of a computer program. This means that, depending on the interpretation of the Tax Office, this legislation can be used to tax all the various codes and sequences used in the development of a customised software package if they have been used previously. In effect, a service may become taxed simply because the computer consultant relies on various parts of his past work and experience to produce a customised computer program. I will therefore move in the committee stage amendments to clauses 4 and 7 of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill to tighten up the definitions used in that legislation.

The second object of the Bill is to remove the distortion and avoidance opportunity that has arisen, whereby software packages delivered in the form of a good, let us say a diskette, is taxed, while that delivered electronically, for example down the telephone line, is not. The latter will now be taxable. We do not oppose this decision. However, we do oppose the way Australia's high technology computer software industry has been treated so shamefully by the Keating-Hawke Government. This story has been repeated right across the manufacturing sector as well and, no thanks to the Government, the computer software industry has grown as an export earner from around $16m in 1984 to an estimated $150m in 1988. However, the software industry has been continually kicked and beaten by this Government. Its growth has been severely jeopardised by blundering tax administration, more intent on raising revenue than putting into effect its own rhetoric about `levelling the playing field'.

When Australia faces a gross foreign debt of about $115 billion and a net foreign debt of about $89 billion, the Government sets policies to penalise investment. Export industries right across the spectrum of the economy have been restricted by the lack of appropriate domestic restructuring. Micro-economic reform, the so-called agenda of this third Hawke Government, has not materialised and it is hard to spot any micro-economic reform at all. Typically, all we have seen is a Treasurer who has overseen the deterioration of the sales tax system into a ramshackle mess full of anomalies and inconsistencies. There has been no tax reform in this country; there have simply been tax increases in one form or another. The four Bills being debated today will produce a revenue gain of about $30m in 1988-89 and $50m or more in the years thereafter.

It is interesting at this point to stop for a minute and think about this Government's record with indirect taxation and what one might call consumption taxation, particularly sales tax. The Budget for this year provides for a 14.4 per cent increase in sales tax collections, which is almost three times the Government's forecast inflation rate for this year. It is double the rise forecast in the Budget for private consumption spending and it is an even faster increase than the huge rise of $5.7 billion in personal income tax.

The second comment I make is that the increase of $1 billion in sales tax revenue this year will lift the Hawke Government's main consumption tax to $8.6 billion, 2 1/2 times higher than what it was under the Fraser Government, despite the repeated Hawke Government promises that it would not introduce a consumption tax. It has been quietly broadening the consumption tax base in this country behind the scenes. How else can one explain that in the six years of the Hawke Government, including this financial year, there has been a 147 per cent increase in sales tax revenue, three times the rate of inflation over that period? That hits hardest the lower income earners, particularly families. The tax system has impacted on a whole host of things as basic as orange juice, ice-cream and flavoured milk, snack foods and so on, on which this Government for the first time has imposed a consumption tax.

Finally, it is worth recognising that sales tax revenue now makes up nearly 10 per cent of total Government revenue compared to only 6 per cent of total Government revenue under the Fraser Government. So it is another hidden attack on the pockets of the average Australian. This Government has said consistently since 1985 that it does not support a consumption tax and does not want to introduce a new consumption tax, and we can see why this Treasurer, despite his rhetoric, has been wandering around the country boasting about the merits of his tax reform while in the meantime his tax boys back home have been quietly issuing and changing rulings and broadening the tax base, the sales tax base in particular, to raise that phenomenal increase in sales tax revenue-147 per cent over the life of this Government, three times the recorded rate of inflation over that period.

By contrast, the Opposition has made some very clear-cut statements of its position on indirect taxation and on taxation generally. We have given a clear commitment to reform and to rationalise our quite ramshackle indirect tax system. Individuals and the self-employed should be able to read the Income Tax Act without needing an army of tax experts. Reforming the complex legislation like that which we are debating today, together with tax cuts, will provide genuine tax relief. That relief is needed now, and it is only the Opposition that is prepared to provide it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support these important sales tax measures before the House. I believe one has to place these four sales tax Bills in the context of the Government's whole taxation reform program. It is fair to say that this has been a tremendously reforming Government in relation to taxation, and the key aspect of that reform has been recognising the unequal burden assumed by ordinary taxpayers. That is why we have already moved to reduce marginal rates of taxation significantly. We have got rid of that 60c in the dollar marginal tax rate that the Liberal Party had. It is a continuing source of disappointment that, despite all the rhetoric from the Opposition, in its seven years in office it was unable or unwilling to do anything about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important aspect is that we have removed the rorts and ramps in the taxation system that were permitted and tolerated-I will not say encouraged-by successive Federal Treasurers on the Opposition's side of politics and, more particularly, by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he was Treasurer for an extended period in the Fraser Government. Those were very significant reforms, and when we look to the future we find that the Government is already committed to furthering that process by reducing personal income tax on 1 July 1989.

This is sales tax legislation and another area where the Government has moved to equalise and rationalise the tax regime. Even though the shadow Minister for Finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), made some criticism during his speech, we have to ask: What is the Opposition's position in relation to a consumption tax? Is it in support of a consumption tax or is it opposed to a consumption tax? I suppose that the real question on this issue is: Can the Opposition be believed anyway? I think it is fair to point out that the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Elliott, certainly is in favour of a consumption tax. Although he is prepared not to enter the Parliament at the next Federal election, clearly he has a great deal of influence in the Liberal Party and he is an unreconstructed advocate of a consumption tax.

As far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned, we had the options paper presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at the National Taxation Summit. We arrived at our position; that is, we rejected the concept of a consumption tax and everyone on this side of the House supports that position. The people of Australia have the knowledge, the surety, that we will be totally opposed to a consumption tax. They need have no doubt about that when they come to decide whose tax policy they will vote on. On this side of the House we are opposed to a consumption tax. We are not sure about the other side of the House. Some are in favour of it, some may be opposed to it, some may worry about the electoral consequences of it, but that multimillionaire President, Mr John Elliott, is an unrestricted advocate of it.

As the Treasurer said in the House earlier today, it is a pity that we cannot debate these Bills in the context of an overall taxation policy that also incorporates the Opposition's position on sales tax and on a consumption tax. When we in the Government and the people of Australia have the privilege of learning what the Opposition's taxation policy is, we will be able to debate it, we will be able to argue about it but, most important, we will be able to add up the figures. Whether it is on the personal income tax side, on the sales tax side or whether it is on consumption tax, business tax or any other area of taxation, we will be able to add up the figures. Certainly we will be able to have a look at the cuts that the Opposition is proposing. I sincerely hope-I feel that I speak for all members on the Government side-that there will not be any mathematical boo-boos in it because certainly it will undermine the credibility of the Opposition, as it did so damagingly at the last Federal election.

We are in a difficult position when we come to debate these Bills because we just do not know, as the people of Australia do not know, what the Opposition's policy is. There is talk of an election next year. Certainly one is due before August 1990; that is the latest we can go. I sincerely hope that the Opposition will develop its policy. I understand that some policies have been released. I have checked with the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, but unfortunately the Opposition's taxation policy has not been released.

Sales tax is a very important area of taxation and there have been some outstanding anomalies in the sales tax area. I am very pleased that the Bill removes the sales tax on computer software. As chairman of the Caucus small business policy committee, as it then was, and in my involvement in the transport and communications area, I have received a number of letters from corporations such as Paxus Professional Systems Pty Ltd and Fujitsu Australia Ltd and a number of people involved in computer software, pointing out how anomalous the tax was. I am very pleased to see that this Bill removes that anomaly, and has totally fixed up those concerns of the computer companies that I mentioned. In fact, I regret that the letters I have on this matter are back in my electorate office otherwise I would be very pleased to read out not only the concerns that those companies expressed to me but also the delight that they had in relation to the Government's response to them.

I have talked about a number of areas of taxation in trying to look at the big picture of taxation reform. Of course, in talking about businesses I regret that I did not mention one of the most significant reforms we have undertaken on this side of the House=mthat is, imputation, or the removal of double taxation on dividends. There is no doubt that this has had a profound effect on the share market, on the equities market. It has given a new incentive for those companies which have fully franked dividends; it has added a new lustre and attraction to them. Of course, the imputation system that we have introduced in this country has been seen by all reasonable observers as being one of the most far-sighted in existence in any country. I suppose that we have been keen to fix up the whole area of taxation and to provide the proper incentive and encouragement to business to go out and earn a dollar. Imputation was a very important reform and the lack of imputation distorted investment decisions.
