24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

We have had to make a significant reform in the capital gains tax area. When I say that we introduced a capital gains tax, a capital gains tax was always in existence but that was only for transactions or sales where the particular commodities or goods were owned for less than 12 months. But we have put in a sales tax regime which just does not tax the nominal capital gains but also the actual real gains; that is, the profits that are made are discounted for inflation. Once again the lack of capital gains tax was an area which distorted investment by businesses when they were looking to make management decisions about where they would apply their funds. I think it is a very important social equity issue that this Government has tackled the capital gains tax.

Notwithstanding the hype and hysteria of the Opposition in responding to the Government's initiative, most commentators today would say that capital gains tax is now an accepted form of taxation and it is largely accepted by the business community and its representatives. When we look at the whole sweep of government reform in this taxation area-it has meant that the Government has had to produce many Bills before this House, including these sales tax Bills which, once again, rationalise sales tax-we can see the quality of the Government's performance. It has had to take hard decisions, but it has had to take necessary decisions. Sometimes the Government has done this in difficult circumstances but, almost uniformly, without the benefit of a bipartisan approach by the Opposition. If there is one thing that I regret it is that we have not had the bipartisan support of the Opposition or a bipartisan debate on the whole area of taxation. I understand how difficult the role of an opposition is. Often oppositions are encouraged to be noisy or negative and, when they take bipartisan positions, they do not get the credit that they deserve for it. But the whole of this taxation reform has been done without the bipartisan support of the Opposition.

To sum up my position on this legislation, I support the Bills as they are important and they fit into the whole fabric of taxation reform. As regards tax avoidance, we have cleaned up a $7 billion industry. What that means for average, ordinary taxpayers is that they were carrying the burden. For every dollar that was not paid, Mr Joe Blow, wage earner, or his wife and children, or small business, were picking up that burden. We have cleaned out those ramps and rorts.

We have lowered marginal taxation rates, and next year we are going to do so again in a significant way. We have introduced a fringe benefits tax that was long overdue. Who can forget the debate about entertainment expenses? The removal of the tax deduction was going to crush the restaurant industry. Hundreds of thousands of people were going to be thrown onto the streets. The reality is that that did not happen, and people accepted the equity of entertainment expenses not being tax deductable, thus stopping some senior management people taking out their families for lunch, for example, and claiming it on entertainment expenses. The workers never had that kind of opportunity.

Dividend imputation is a real boon for the business community, one that has been widely accepted by it. The advantages and opportunities presented by dividend imputation have certainly been seized by the business community. I refer also to the capital gains tax, substantiation of expenses, and general action against tax evasion and tax avoidance. It is with pleasure that I support this legislation. I commend it to the House. I am sure that it will be accepted not only by the House but by the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak in particular to the amendment, which I seconded, to the motion for the second reading, which deals with the Opposition's concern about the application of taxation by this Government, in particular the inequities it is imposing, especially on smaller individuals. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) chose to range very widely on the subject, and I welcome the opportunity to respond to some of his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will, hopefully, correct some anomalies and remove some of the burden of sales tax. But we have to recollect that sales tax is a huge burden on working people, wherever it is applied. Through this legislation it is being applied to home computers. That is what it was originally aimed at-computers that people are buying to give to their children so that they have the skills to enter the work force of the future, a future which will be very much linked to computers, even in the trades area. I was in a joinery shop the other day and the owner said to me that he needed, above all else, people who had computer skills. We are dealing with sales tax on computer programs. The Government has recognised at last that it is doing damage in that regard and that it should reduce the tax burden, although not in that particular area.

The honourable member for Chifley spoke about sales tax, capital gains tax and many other matters. He also talked about tax avoidance and said that there was some advantage to Joe Blow in catching up with all these people. The Opposition does not support tax avoidance or tax evasion, but I would be surprised if the people in the western suburbs of Sydney can identify where they have had a refund with regard to that $7 billion. The reality is that the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) advised the Government the other day that 30 years ago a family with two children on three-quarters of average weekly earnings was paying 3 per cent of their income in tax. They are now paying 15 per cent. That has occurred over that 30-year period.

The honourable member for Chifley also mentioned capital gains tax. It is interesting that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) chose also yesterday to speak about capital gains tax when, in my view, he launched an attack on small business-the people who will pay this sales tax on computer programs when they purchase them. For some unknown reason he referred to them as `commerce'. I always thought that commerce was an honest word, but to hear the Treasurer speak about it on Tuesday this week, one would think differently. He said-and I quote from Hansard:

I suppose that it has never entered the minds of the Leader of the Opposition or his people on the front bench-people out there supporting the person who buys the local fruit shop or the small office block opposite, sits there doing nothing for four or five years, finds that its value has moved up or doubled, then cashes it in and walks away with a tax free gain . . .
He was clearly very critical. He went on to say:

The Opposition thinks that that is what one does-because those people are the people in commerce. It is commerce to go and buy the local fruit shop, to do nothing with it for five years, and then to cash it in. It is commerce for the suburban solicitor-
another small businessman-
to eye off the two shops opposite, buy them, sit there for four years and then cash them in.

The Opposition amendment today refers to the inequities in the tax system. We believe, in our capital gains tax policy, in the rights of small business to profit from a long term investment; not from a short term investment in property but from a long term investment, like the greengrocer, and like the suburban solicitor who is prepared to go for the longer haul over five years. During that time they will be paying sales taxes of the type mentioned.

I would like to give an example of just how this is working to the disadvantage of poorer people. In the Australian Financial Review of 22 November 1988 there appears a large display advertisement for the auction of a residential Sydney property. It is expected-and I say this because I have inquired of the auctioneers; I had a personal interest when I first saw the advertisement and that is what causes me to bring it to the House's attention-to bring about $1m and the capital gain to the owners under the present capital gains tax law will be free of tax. I do not know how much gain there will be, but I do know that the adjoining identical property cost the present owner $225,000 five years ago. In other words, if the adjoining identical property was on sale next week, the owner who has, to quote the Treasurer, sat there doing nothing for five years, would have a tax free gain of $775,000.

The property for auction-the one that is advertised in the paper-is at 27 Roslyn Gardens, Elizabeth Bay. The adjoining and identical property, No. 25, to which I have referred, is the property of Paul Keating, the Treasurer, who apparently, when the value is established by auction next Tuesday, will be, on paper at least, $775,000 richer on a property on which, to use his words, he has sat and done nothing with. He bought it in 1983 and for exactly five years he has sat on it and done nothing. We know that the property is not occupied by him. He lives in Canberra. There have been previous arguments relating to the fact that he nominates that property in Elizabeth Bay as his principal place of residence, and that, of course, makes it his home. Under the Treasurer's law on capital gain, his home is free of capital gains tax. It is quite clear that the Treasurer is about to make a $775,000 tax free profit, if only on paper. He has done exactly what he has accused other people of doing-that is, to use his words, to sit there for five years and do nothing. That, as far as I am concerned--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I recognise that this is a fairly wide-ranging debate, but I think that at present the honourable member is straying beyond the realms of relevance.

—I would argue with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on that point. I listened to the honourable member for Chifley, and if he missed any part of the taxation procedures of this place, I would like to know what they were. He talked about marginal tax rates and everything else and he was not interrupted.
—Order! I have just asked the honourable gentleman to be relevant.

—Very well, Mr Deputy Speaker; I will come back to the legislation. As I said, the sales tax will be imposed on the kind of computer products that are sold to families who cannot afford million dollar houses but who are being required to pay $100,000 to $200,000 for houses which we would once have considered worth barely $20,000 to $30,000. When we add to that the present level of interest charges we can see that these people are struggling. The honourable member for Chifley seemed to imply that these people have problems, yet we have this continuously growing taxation burden.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer tells us day after day in this place that the Government has evidence from its Forward Estimates that government spending is reducing. He always gives it as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). We know that one can produce statistics to support any argument one likes. He chooses to present a percentage of GDP. GDP has grown rapidly in this country. In the Treasurer's first couple of Budgets it grew at 7 per cent and 8 per cent, fired up by government deficits which also happen to be 5, 6, and 7 per cent of GDP. In other words, we have had a debit led recovery; we have fired up the GDP. Consequently, the Treasurer's claim that he is maintaining expenditure and, one would assume, taxation within the limits of a certain percentage of GDP is not having the same effect on taxpayers. When we get down to the dollar values we find that the last Fraser Budget raised $44,000m; the current Keating Budget raised $88,000m. The working people, for whom the Treasurer cried crocodile tears today, have to cope with inflation and bracket creep. The Treasurer talked about the effect of foreign investment on the price of housing. He cried crocodile tears for people in my view. He might want to sell his residence in Elizabeth Bay for, say, $400,000-half price-and set the example!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not ignore the directions of the Chair. I ask him to remain relevant to the Bills under debate.

—I certainly will come back to the matter before us. I will close in a minute. I do not want to take too much time as I have a colleague who wants to make a contribution to this debate. The sales tax provisions, although somewhat improved, will cause many problems for people because a sales tax is still being imposed on the information process. There is still a large amount of sales tax being collected on computer programs. These are the things the nation needs for the development of industry and the minds of our young people. In that regard there is still a problem. I reject the remarks made by the honourable member for Chifley. I am certainly entitled to do that as he made so many remarks about different things. I do not think the Government's tax policy has got much to recommend it. It has hurt many people. People, according to EPAC are paying five times as much tax, as a percentage of their earnings, as they were 30 years ago. Anybody who looks at the growth of taxation will see that it has occurred principally under two governments: the Whitlam Government and the Hawke Government. The other matters I have raised show the Government's hypocrisy, particularly that of the Treasurer who, despite making the remarks he did, is using loopholes within his own tax law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill, the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 12), the Sales Tax Bill (No. 12), and the Sales Tax Bill (No. 1A) I would like to say how horrified I am that these days, every time I come into this House it is to speak against more taxation from this Labor Government. There Bills are the same. There will be a $50m increase in taxation. There is a new 20 per cent sales tax on the transfer of electronic information. Computer programs transferred electronically will be subject to sales tax of 20 per cent. It will be retrospective, of course, to 4 November 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I was amused to hear the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) say in a speech on the economy how the Labor Party Government has increased the size of the economy and increased revenue from taxation. He was trying to put up some spurious argument that because the economy is growing we should be paying more tax. I have never heard anything more ridiculous. If the economy is growing, we should be paying less tax as a percentage. We are not seeing that under this Government. The economy is shrinking. If we take into consideration the Government's borrowings and debts we will see that the economy has shrunk substantially. The Government is placing us in a position in which our children will have to continue to work to pay back these horrific borrowings. Apart from working and sweating they will have to continue to pay the high taxes that this Government is imposing every day in this House on fellow Australians. There is no doubt that this is the highest taxing period that this nation has experienced. Our economy is not growing; it is shrinking. One has only to look at the balance of trade situation each month to see that it is the worst in our history. It is continuing that way. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) comes in here using rhetoric, speaking rubbish, when the economy is not growing to the extent that it ought to be.

Currently, sales tax covers only those programs embodied in storage mediums and imported or sold in Australia. Computer programs transferred within Australia will be subject to this new 20 per cent sales tax. The sales tax payable on computer programs transferred from overseas to a person within Australia who is not registered for sales tax purposes excludes programs embodied in goods. It means people have to register if they are now receiving electronic information, or receiving a computer program that they wish to use to help boost business. The Government is continually taxing business. If people want to install a new computer program and earn some income they will be taxed for the privilege. The buyer of programs not already registered must lodge a sales tax return and pay the tax within 21 days from the end of the month when the program was transferred.

Under the software related services, programs developed for single users in certain circumstances are free from tax. This means that once a program one has developed personally goes 20 per cent beyond private use-for instance if it is used for business-the 20 per cent sales tax will apply. People can develop their own programs but once they start using it in their private businesses beyond 20 per cent they will be expected to pay the new tax. The sales tax provisions also include computer programs transferred internally by electronic means. Transfers made free of charge will not be affected because the sales tax is placed on the cost of the charge made for the transfer of the program. Of course it requires the recipients of the programs transferred from outside Australia to lodge sales tax returns which I mentioned previously. The legislation package is expected to produce $30m in revenue in 1988-89 and in subsequent years the Department of the Treasury estimates that the revenue will be $50m.

There are some very grey areas in the legislation as to where the tax should be levied and at what stage people are exempt from sales tax. I have a very large number of coal mines in my electorate. I have recently been to Blackwater to look at some of the mines. I have kept in touch with the people and the management who are working the mines. The Currah mine is using the largest drag line in operation in the southern hemisphere. It is an 84 cubic yard drag line. This new piece of equipment cost $50m. A lot of computer software is used in the mining industry. Long wall mining of coal is taking place at the Cook underground mine with enormous pieces of machinery which are hydraulically and computer controlled. Most of the computer functions of this generation machinery are built in and are not subject to the new tax. However, there is a grey area between where sales tax is paid and where it is not. If people in mining and agriculture purchase machinery to create wealth and develop a resource it will be exempt from sales tax. But in the goods department, the ordering department, or the accounting department at head office the mining companies are very much subject to this new tax. The other mine in the area which is affected by this new tax is the South Blackwater mine. The miners are greatly concerned about the rapid increase in the value of the Australian dollar. They wrote contracts in Australian dollars when the dollar was worth 70c or 75c. They borrowed large amounts of money to build up their mining operation and to invest capital and now they find that the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Government are forcing up interest rates which, in turn, is causing the dollar to escalate rapidly. We now see it selling at somewhere around 86c or 87c. So the dog continues to chase its tail.

The rapid rise in the dollar, which the Treasurer thinks might help some sectors, is disadvantaging primary industry-particularly primary industry exports such as wool, beef and coal from the mines in the electorate that I represent in south-west Queensland. The Yarrabi mine is a small coal mine that is operating east of Blackwater. As I have already mentioned, the Blackwater South mine has borrowed a lot of capital recently. It is very concerned about the rapid escalation of the dollar, and the escalation of all taxes that are being imposed by this Labor Government.

I do not wish to speak for much longer. As I said, we now have large-scale use of computers by school kids across the country. My children badger me to buy a computer. I am not too sure what they are talking about half the time, but I am expected to give them one for Christmas. Computers are becoming very useful tools, certainly for the generations to come. I wonder why we should place regressive taxes on electronic transfers from one computer to another. I have much pleasure in supporting these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make just a couple of comments in response to some of the matters that have been raised and in particular to the amendment that has been moved. There have been indications that amendments will also be moved at a subsequent stage. I want to emphasise that the Government quite clearly has made concessions and given consideration to people who are engaged in the computer software industry in Australia. I am sure that both honourable members who have just spoken recognise the fact that amendments of this kind are not made in isolation, but all governments of any political persuasion enter into, as they should, sensible discussions and arrangements with people engaged in economic pursuits in the community and in the economy generally who have an interest in the issues under consideration. Any additional concerns that any of those interests want to bring to the attention of the Government or the Minister will, of course, receive consideration. There is a responsiveness on the part of the Government in connection with this issue as there has been in connection with all issues and as there will continue to be. There is no need for any of these amendments at all and the Government rejects them.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 2, lines 8-18, omit paragraph (a).
(2) Clause 4, page 2, at the end of the clause add the following paragraph:
(c) by inserting in subsection (1) the following definition:

`` `module', in relation to computer programs, means a product licensed or sold in its own right as a separate and standard existing unit comprising either a single computer program which performs a self-contained function or a group of computer programs which together perform a set of integrated functions;''.
(3) Clause 7, page 3, line 20, omit ``computer programs'', substitute ``modules''.
(4) Clause 7, page 3, line 23, omit ``programs'', substitute `'modules''.

As I foreshadowed in my speech during the second reading debate, the Opposition is moving amendments to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill. The amendments are an attempt to clarify the application of sales tax to the computer software industry. Just to pick up a point made by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), I understand that these problems have been discussed by the relevant industry groups with the Government and the Government has still chosen to ignore them.

The irony of this Bill is that it is an attempt by the Government to improve the existing legislation, which has been ambiguous and unclear. However, there remain genuine concerns that the Government's amending legislation will be just as vague and ambiguous. When tax laws are vague it is incredibly hard for business to operate effectively. Not only efficiency but also equity goes out the window. Because suppliers are required to remit sales tax within 21 days of the end of the month in which the transaction took place, they have little opportunity to raise an objection without facing severe penalties if they disagree with the Australian Taxation Office's ruling.
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

It is important that the law is clear right from its introduction. A particular concern with the Bill is the definition of `computer programs', which has been altered to include `part of a computer program'. This means that, depending on the interpretation of the Australian Taxation Office, this legislation could be used to tax all the various codes and sequences, the basic intellectual property, used in the development of a customised software package if they have been used previously. In effect it may end up that one of the principal reasons that the Bill was introduced-to stop the taxation of services-will be defeated. A service which is not normally subject to tax under the wholesale sales tax system may become taxed simply because the computer consultant relies on various parts of his past work and experience to produce a customised computer program.

I am therefore moving amendments to clauses 4 and 7 of the Bill to tighten the definitions used in the legislation. Basically, the amendments will introduce into the legislation the definition of a computer module. A module, in relation to computer programs means a product licensed or sold in its own right as a separate and standard existing unit comprising either a single computer program which performs a self-contained function or a group of computer programs which together perform a set of integrated functions. This definition will give the Tax Office a better guide for determining what are those parts of a program that are simply the building blocks and, in effect, what is the taxable product when those building blocks are put together into a discrete usable item.

The Opposition believes that these changes will facilitate the application of the tax. They will hopefully stop further `unintended consequences' in the application of the sales tax to this industry. The Government fails to realise that simple and understandable legislation is just as important for genuine tax relief as lowering the level of taxation. The Opposition is aware of this and will again attempt to fix badly drafted legislation from the Treasurer (Mr Keating).
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill facilitates the transfer to the Corporation of joint owner airport facilities throughout this country where the Commonwealth has an interest in aviation activities that take place upon them. The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) already runs 17 aerodromes, airports, throughout this country. I regret to say there is very little evidence to suggest that it is doing a very good job. It is for that reason the Opposition has proposed, in an amendment which will be circulated in my name, that there be an inquiry into the FAC and its activities. We think this is particularly appropriate before the Federal Airports Corporation is given responsibility for any more than its current 17 airports.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of areas which cause considerable concern to the industry, airport users and travellers throughout Australia. I propose in the few minutes that are available to me-probably, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as a privilege extended to the Opposition by the Executive-to address my remarks to the concerns of the industry. The operations of the FAC are quite controversial. They certainly do not have a harmonious relationship with a large section of the industry, in particular general aviation. There have been complaints about the attitude of the FAC and the fact that there has been little consultation. I cite a reference by the President of the Airport Owners and Operators Association with respect to the level of consultation that goes on between airport users and the industry. He talked about meetings held throughout the country for the purpose of discussing the plans of the FAC and pointed out that at Moorabbin Airport there were five people who were consulted and at Essendon there were little more than 15. These discussions were with respect to the FAC's proposal to introduce what is known as a GAIT charge, or general aviation infrastructure tariff. I will be making comments about that charge later. I think the discussions are indicative of the FAC's failure to honour its obligations and its responsibility to consult with those people whom its activities directly affect.

It is important to understand that the FAC has been created as a monopoly. In fact, it is a site monopoly which it is impossible to avoid. If one wants to use an airport that has been transferred to the FAC one has to deal with the FAC. Unfortunately, the FAC has recognised the power that this monopoly gives it, and I will be citing some of the consequences of this power and the reactions to some of the proposals of the FAC.

The level of charges is also quite controversial. The aviation industry is already at the 100 per cent full cost recovery level which was recommended in the report of the Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery. I will be talking about that at a later time also. I have mentioned the power of the monopoly supplier of a service which is afforded to the FAC and its approach to business. I will also make some remarks about its perceived commercial competence. Let me just allude to the fact that the Trade Practices Commission has already said that the FAC is in breach of the Trade Practices Act in some of its dealings. The FAC's reaction to that is, I believe, something that does not reflect credit upon itself or the Government. It is something that is beyond the pale. It is also appropriate to examine the role of a monopoly supplier of services in an industry that the Government claims it is deregulating.

In recent days there have been reports in newspapers about concerns among people who aspire to take advantage of the ending of the two-airline agreement to become domestic airline operators throughout Australia. May I just digress for a moment and say that the way the Government went about that was quite curious. The FAC came into being on 1 January. Prior to that, the Government had already entered into lease arrangements with the major domestic airlines. It was not done by the FAC, the statutory authority, the Corporation that is responsible for running the airports; it was done by the old department. Even more curious was the way the whole leasing agreement was approached by the department. To begin with the consultancy for the drafting of the lease agreements was not let to public tender. It was simply given to a former employee of the department. One may say, `That's fine, the person obviously has some considerable expertise'. But I wonder whether one would say that if one knew that that person's prime activity with the department prior to his retirement and taking up this consultancy was not in the aviation area. I am led to believe his expertise was in the roads area.

For something as significant and sensitive as the letting of major lease agreements to the two domestic airlines, at the very least the tenders should have been public. If the Government were fair dinkum about giving the FAC responsibility for running the airports, it might have let it go ahead and negotiate the lease agreements. Perhaps one could argue that the negotiations had to go on and could not be delayed until the Corporation came into being, and that is a reasonable argument. But the Government could have delayed actually signing the lease agreements until a few weeks later because the agreements were signed on the eve of the implementation of the FAC. The FAC was handed a fait accompli.

Let me make some reference to the concerns of the industry about these agreements, and there is some considerable concern, which has been published in the newspapers. Mr Bryan Grey, a former owner of East-West Airlines Ltd, has an ambition to establish a fourth airline in this country to be known as Compass Airlines. He is extremely concerned that the terms of the lease agreements given to both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines will preclude his ability to develop terminal facilities which will enable him to establish his airline. The Government talks a lot about establishing competition but when it comes to putting these words into action it is very reluctant to act.

We saw recently the acquisition by TNT Limited, an interest associated with Ansett Airlines, of East-West Airlines. The matter went to the Trade Practices Commission, which said that it was concerned about this acquisition, it believed there should be some restrictions placed upon it, but it was not in a position to pursue the action because it did not have the resources. This Government talks about competition, deregulation and commitment to an expanded deregulated economy. Yet it is not prepared to provide the resources to back up a Government instrumentality when it says there is a problem. It is disgraceful when the Trade Practices Commission of this country, the authority that is charged with the responsibility of ensuring that trade practices are in fact fair and equitable, says, `there is a problem; we would like to pursue it but we can't do it because we don't have the money'. The Government has the money to spend on cutting the price of beer, but when it comes to something as significant as ensuring competition among airlines in this country it does not have the resources to spend on it.
The FAC has some 1,200 people working for it. I would like the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) to explain exactly what those 1,200 people are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Each of them separately?

—Yes, I think it would be a very good idea. Let us see some job descriptions for these 1,200 people and find out what they are actually doing. Most of them came from the Department. I wonder whether their job descriptions are relevant any more. Airports are run by the people who work at them. The only evidence one sees of the FAC when one goes into an airport these days is a big sign that says `Welcome to the Airport-Federal Airports Corporation'. If that is not a waste of money, I do not know what is. Who cares who owns the airport? What people are really worried about is whether they catch their planes on time. But these days we have money to spend putting up signs.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister is going to take an interest in this debate, let me tell him that the staff of the FAC have just received pay increases. What is more, they have new cars. They have new offices and new office equipment to go with them. They have these new signs, also. When the Government announced the CAA-FAC package, it said, `We are going to reduce the costs to the industry'. Immediately it started to spend a lot of money. The consequence was that charges went up incredibly.

I have referred to the Bosch report. Let me consider what the Bosch report said. The Minister has been talking to me about the costs of the Department. Henry Bosch, Chairman of the Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, handed down his findings to the Government with suggestions on implementing 100 per cent cost recovery. Bosch recommended:
If major reductions in departmental costs can be achieved, cost recovery can be attained by 1995.

The Government has obtained in excess of 100 per cent cost recovery in two years-a long way short of 1995. But what it has not done has been to go along with the other half of the Bosch equation, and that is, reduce the costs to the industry. The costs have probably increased. The Government has not been fair dinkum with the industry. It has taken a typical Labor Government approach-`We will rip the money off the people but let us not worry too much about cutting back expenditure'. It falls into line with the Treasurer's approach, which we have seen in so many other areas-increasing taxes as a substitute for reducing costs. Let me quote from an editorial that appeared in an industry magazine under the heading `Farcical Aviation Charges'. The acronym will not be lost on many people in the industry-FAC, Farcical Aviation Charges. The article states:

In point of fact, the aviation industry is being grossly over-recovered, as the Government collects some $400m in taxes from aviation fuel, which goes into consolidated revenue and is not attributed to aviation. The same is true of import duty and sales tax on aircraft and aircraft parts. Nevertheless, even under its restricted definition of cost recovery, the Government acknowledged in 1987 that full cost recovery had been achieved.

On January 1 of this year, the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) came into being. Their task is to improve the efficiency of the 17 capital city primary and secondary airports, apply sound commercial principles, make airports self-sufficient and reduce costs.

I will refer to some of the sound commercial principles adopted by the FAC in a moment. Let me make a few remarks about the so-called general aviation infrastructure tariff, known as GAIT. Again I quote from an industry magazine, which states:

The FAC proposes to introduce a General Aviation Infrastructure Tariff (GAIT) at all FAC airports (excluding capital city primary airports where landing charges would remain). They propose to sell stickers which would allow use of FAC secondary airports for a period of one year for . . . $1 per kg based on maximum take-off weight.

That translates roughly into about $1,050 per annum for a Cessna 172, which is a fairly small, light aircraft; about $1,300 for a Cessna 182, and for a Beech 36, about $1,600. This is the Government that is going to reduce the costs to the industry. It is also relevant to talk about the commercial practices of the FAC. We should remember that it is a monopoly supplier of services at these 17 airports. The Bill before the House proposes to give the FAC access to additional airports throughout this country. This was reported in a journal which is circulated widely throughout Australia called Inside Canberra. It talks about the way the FAC went about letting the tender for a facility at Sydney's international airport. I will read directly from Inside Canberra. It states:

The terms and conditions were so onerous and inequitable that interested parties complained to the Trade Practices Commission that the Federal Airports Corporation was abusing its position of market power. In a letter to the FAC dated 1 June the Trade Practices Commission said that indeed the terms and conditions attached to the concession appeared to contravene section 46 (misuse of market power) and section 48 (resale price maintenance).
That is, of the Trade Practices Act. The journal goes on:
The tendering procedure was halted while the FAC considers its position.

Let me tell honourable members what the FAC did. It withdrew its tender and relet it without putting it back to tender. I quote from a statement by my colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), the shadow Attorney-General, about the tendering processes of the FAC. He gives three examples which are worth noting carefully. They are not three isolated examples. As the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, will remember, I asked a series of questions in this place earlier in the year of the responsible junior Minister. All he could do was throw his hands up in the air and say, `I will get you answers'. I am still waiting for the answers. My colleague the honourable member for Menzies gave the example that, firstly, there was the granting of a new three-year contract for the duty free shops at Sydney international airport without putting the contract out to public tender. The duty free shops are a very lucrative facility, and yet the contract did not go to public tender.

Secondly, when inwards duty free shopping was introduced, the Government handed out these lush contracts without putting them out to tender. The FAC may not have been directly responsible for that. But this is relevant to this whole debate today. The conduct of commercial operations from a monopoly position like that should be above question. There is no possible justification for putting out such a concession without putting it out to public tender. How can that be justified, when one of the objectives of the Corporation is to comply with normal commercial guidelines, which are to maximise profits?

My colleague referred to the short-lived contract for removing duty free dockets at Brisbane airport. I will explain to honourable members what that process is. When one goes through the Customs barrier someone takes the docket off one's duty free package. There was a contract for that. This arrangement was cancelled when the honourable member for Menzies raised the issue with Senator Evans, who brushed it off as a `misjudgment by management'. That is the standard of FAC administration in regard to tendering processes. As I have said, I raised a number of issues in this place in questions to the Minister and I am still waiting for answers.

Is it any wonder that a new pressure group has been established to deal with the FAC? At FAC-controlled airports an organisation has been established known as the Federal Airport Operators and Tenants Association. It is a direct response to the difficulties that people who work and operate their businesses at airports have with the FAC. It says that it is going to tackle some of the current prickly issues as a matter of urgency. These include the method of charging landing fees by the FAC at Coolangatta, Essendon and Launceston airports and the need for the industry to pay additional charges when the Bosch report recommendations of 100 per cent cost recovery have already been exceeded.

I said that I would talk about some of the commercial arrangements of the FAC. Let me quote from some of the correspondence that people in the industry have sent to me about what the FAC is doing. I quote from a legal opinion given by a reputable firm, Bowden Stokes and Jones, to a general aviation firm. I will not name the firm, but I am sure that the Department and the FAC know which firm I am talking about. The legal opinion states:

In fact the Lease (Clause 5 (a)) requires the tenant to carry out all repairs and maintenance as required to the improvements as required by the Airport Manager which without any provision to the contrary would mean all structural repairs of any kind. Further, clause 4 gives FAC absolute control over any alterations or additions which may be required by the tenant, even extending to the payment of the fees for FAC's architects who would require to approve any plans and supervise any of the works undertaken. In short, the proposed Lease is extremely one-sided and far more onerous on the tenant than any normal commercial lease.

That is what people think about the approach of the FAC to negotiating with its clients. It is obviously exploiting a monopoly position. I quote from other correspondence I have received from people who have to deal with the FAC:

We believe that the rent increase as indicated in your proposal, which we calculate at more than a 35 per cent increase, is contrary to both Federal and State government policy of keeping price increases within the CPI and has the distinct possibility of driving small business such as ours out of business.
It should also be noted that up to May 18th 1987 the rent was only $250,000, therefore, the latest increase represents an increase of over 56 per cent in just 14 months.

Furthermore, we cannot understand the justification for the requirement for us to insure the premises for an amount of $52,405, without any improvements, when only five months ago you required us to insure the same premises for an amount of $20,000-an increase of over 160 per cent.

Obviously, we are getting to a situation where the FAC is either picking numbers out of the air or it is playing games in order to generate additional revenue. Of course, similar comments are made about the GAIT charges.

The FAC had transferred to it certain airport properties and they were given a value. In the Senate Estimates process an attempt was made by some of my colleagues to get answers on the value of these assets and some other detailed information about the FAC operations. This monopoly supplier of information has yet to provide those answers. There is just a determination on the part of the Government, which is arrogant and out of touch, and the FAC, to keep everybody in the dark and to say, `Take it or leave it: pay the money or get out of business'. Of course, when one is in the aviation business one does not have too many other options, and many people are in fact leaving the industry. We shall see a situation, particularly in Victoria, where people will move from Essendon to Moorabbin, and then further and further out, because they will just be moving to get away from the FAC. It is something that really should be questioned.

We have a high and rising level of charges at present. Let us look at what will happen in the future. The assets of the FAC, which were Commonwealth assets, were sold to it by the Government. They were sold to a statutory corporation of the Commonwealth. It is an interesting transaction. If they had been sold to a private organisation, one could understand the Government, perhaps, wanting to be paid the way it is.

The Government provided the finance for the acquisition of these assets, but it is a very interesting finance package. It is not fully commercial at this stage. It is only one-tenth commercial and we are already seeing escalating charges. Over a 10-year period the package of finance goes completely commercial. What is the level of charges that will be imposed on the industry at the end of 10 years when all the debt is at commercial rates of interest? I wonder whether the Government has realised whether there will be an aviation industry and what will be the cost that is passed on to the users of airports.

Let me make a few comments about the FAC and its inadequate response to the problems of aviation right throughout Australia. I guess the most pressing problem that the industry faces in this country at present is Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I am sure it would surprise every member of this House to know that the FAC has yet to develop a master plan for the development of Kingsford-Smith Airport. We have the absolutely ridiculous policy of the current Government of not building a third runway, but surely the FAC should know what it is going to do with that airport. It is the premier airport in this country. It is critical to our tourist development; it is the hub for our domestic traffic. And the FAC does not have a master plan!

That is not unique. There is in fact a master plan for Perth Airport. I have spoken at length with the people who are responsible to the local government authority in that area. They quote the master plan and they tell me it was done in 1985 and it provides for a parallel runway and the development of the facility right into the next century. Of course, the FAC is busy allowing leases for the development of new domestic terminals. A close look at what these lease proposals are shows that they are in direct contradiction to the master plan, and in fact it limits the ability to implement the master plan. So we do all the work. We look at the need to develop the Perth Airport facility. Then the FAC, probably in its never-ending hunger to gain revenue to meet its interest charges and fulfil its obligations to the Government, is busy leasing land which is supposed to be in the middle of a runway or something else and is in fact going to limit the ability to develop that Perth airport facility. What is more, local government cannot even get an answer from the Government on what is going on. The Government will not respond to the local government's inquiries as to what its intentions are for this airport. No wonder there is a proposal to develop a private airport at Perth because this Government has lost control of what is happening.

We have problems with Brisbane Airport. The terminal facilities are hopelessly inadequate there and the Government will not act to provide an international terminal that is adequate to cope with the growing tourist traffic and certainly it has no hope of coping with the immense number of tourists who will be coming into Brisbane International for the 1992 Lions Convention.

One can go on at length about the FAC's activities. Everywhere one turns one finds it to be wanting and totally inadequate. The major concern that the industry has is that the FAC is not soundly based. For that reason we have moved an amendment which deals with a number of areas that we firmly believe should be reviewed. There is even some question as to whether the FAC has a sound legal basis for imposing some of the charges it is seeking to impose at present. For that reason we will move an amendment that reads:
That the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report with particular reference to the following:
(1) The powers and responsibilities granted under the Federal Airports Corporation legislation . . .

Of course, that is very germane to the point I have just made; whether it has in fact the power to impose the charges that it is imposing and whether those powers are in fact appropriate, or perhaps even excessive, because there is a real concern throughout the community with monopoly, although this Government seems quite content to deal on very close and friendly terms with big business, one or two big businesses in particular, and perhaps it has plans down the track for what it is going to do with the FAC.

We also believe there is a need to inquire into the value of assets transferred by the Government to the FAC. Many of these assets go back some considerable years. They were in fact given to the Department after World War II and the previous administrative arrangements provided for a full cost recovery program. The previous department, in setting charges imposed on the industry, in some cases, although not all, ran a full cost recovery program. It was levying charges, which were raising money, which were imposed on the basis of full cost recovery. Those charging regimes ran for some years. So some of the assets have in fact been paid for to a considerable extent in the past, and yet with the transfer to the FAC they were valued and then a new cost recovery program was implemented. So they have been paid for twice. Again it is just another grab for money.

The other aspect of the inquiry that we propose is that the Corporation's plans for developing its airports, and in particular, Sydney, Brisbane and Perth, should be reviewed in detail and as a matter of urgency, because there is nothing more critical to the future development of aviation in this country than the airport facilities and there is nothing that has been done by the FAC to the present time that inspires confidence. There is nothing that has been done by this Government that inspires confidence in its ability to deal with this growing challenge. It has a classic case of policy paralysis. It cannot come to grips with what is obvious to everybody else. There was a situation today where both domestic airlines had a joint press conference calling for the development of a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Qantas Airways Limited, the Government-owned airline, had previously called for that. The New South Wales Government is in favour of it. The Opposition is in support of it-yet because of one member, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), a marginal seat-holder, the whole aviation industry in Australia is being held to ransom. Air fares are going up and the economic benefit of tourism and the growth in aviation to Australia is being reduced. Those are the sort of priorities that this Government has, and they are deplorable.

We also believe there is a need to examine closely the Corporation's approach to its commercial activities. The short references I have made here to some of the major contracts for facilities at international airports and small lease agreements for general aviation operators indicate that, at either end of the extreme, the competence of the Corporation should be called into question and that there is an urgent need to look at the way it does its business and whether it should retain the power it has at present.

We also think that it is about time the Government had an open inquiry into establishing a Government-run monopoly in what is supposed to be, in a very short period, a deregulated, competitive industry. If we are going to do away with the two-airline agreement, if we are to have an open skies policy, if we are to have some competition in domestic aviation in this country, what is the logic in creating site monopoly? Why do we not say `Competition is good; let us have competition right throughout the industry'-and not have the Government trying at arm's length to maintain control and regulate the industry. The FAC will be the determinant of the success of a deregulated aviation industry in Australia. If it is not possible for new airline operators to get terminal space, they cannot fly. It would be a brave new airline that came in to an industry with a massive investment on the condition that it had to be a tenant of an existing airline. That is exactly the situation that is likely to develop under the arrangements proposed by this Government and its so-called independent statutory authority, the FAC.

It is a disgrace. The Government is making a mess of aviation. I believe that the FAC does not have the expertise, nor has it been given a proper brief to undertake its charges. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia believe that there is a need to break up the FAC monopoly, to provide genuine competition in the supply of services at airports, and to provide an opportunity for private industry to become involved in this area. For that reason, we propose that this Bill be referred to a parliamentary committee for inquiry so that the Australian public will know exactly what sort of mess this Government is making of its aviation industry. I move:

That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: ``the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report with particular reference to the following:
(1) the powers and responsibilities granted under the Federal Airports Corporation legislation;
(2) the value of assets transferred by the Government and the basis for financing the Corporation with particular reference to the implications for charges imposed by the Corporation;
(3) the Corporation's plans for developing its airports, and in particular its proposals for Sydney, Brisbane and Perth airports;
(4) the procedures adopted by the Corporation for its commercial activities with emphasis on requirements and procedures for calling tenders and letting contracts;
(5) the implications of the Federal Airports Corporation monopoly position for the aviation industry, in particular general and sports aviation and non-scheduled airline and charter operations;
(6) the appropriateness of the Federal Airport Corporation monopoly position in a deregulated aviation industry;
(7) the legislative basis, financial structure and corporate objectives of the Corporation; and
(8) the Corporation's organisation, structure and staff numbers''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment with great pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill and I oppose the amendment. Whilst I found the contribution of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) interesting, I am afraid that I am unable to agree with the basic premises on which he proposed his amendment. Indeed, I would say that, if the amendment were carried, it would frustrate development in civil aviation in Australia, particularly in my own electorate of the Northern Territory. I will refer to that matter later. I remind the House of the background of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). The Corporation was set up as a government business enterprise, established by and incorporated under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. On 1 January 1988, the FAC assumed responsibility for the ownership, management and development of Australia's major airports and for the commercial activities on the airports, including arrangements with airlines and other operators for the use of airports and for leasing of property and the letting of business concessions. Like any business, the Corporation is required to be financially self-supporting. It has been established with a capital base and a debt-equity ratio determined by discussion and negotiation between the Commonwealth, States and Territories and the FAC under the FAC legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The current amendments arise from an announcement in the Budget that the Government intended to transfer ownership of the civil aerodromes at Alice Springs, Mount Isa and Mackay to the FAC. It also announced that responsibility for the civil aviation facilities at the Defence owned aerodromes at Darwin, Townsville and Canberra were to be transferred to the FAC on conditions to be agreed between the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, the FAC can operate as Federal airports aerodromes that are situated on land which the Corporation owns. Because of the legal impediment to ownership of land in the Australian Capital Territory it would not be possible for the FAC to take over the civil aviation facilities at Canberra Airport as the Act stands. It is therefore necessary to amend the Act to allow the FAC to operate aerodromes on land that it holds on a leasehold from the Commonwealth.

The Bill is also designed to cover circumstances in which the Corporation assumes responsibility for the operation of part of other Defence owned-that is, joint user-airports. The legislation will empower the Corporation to enter into arrangements with Defence relating to land tenure and operations on the airport. That is of particular importance regarding the Darwin Airport. The purpose of the Bill therefore is to amend the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. That Act provides the legislative framework for the Corporation. As it now stands, the Act requires that, where land owned by the Commonwealth becomes a Federal airport, or a part of a Federal airport, ownership of that land is to be vested in the Corporation. The amendments for which the Bill provides will allow the Federal Airports Corporation to operate Federal airports on land which is leased from the Commonwealth by the Corporation or on land in respect of which the Corporation has entered into arrangements for joint use with an authority of the Commonwealth.

I now refer to some of the amendments that have been proposed, as they clearly identify the purpose of the legislation. Clause 2, relating to definitions, will be amended to provide a definition for `joint-user aero-drome' and `jointly used area'. Clause 3 relating to functions of the Corporation will amend section 6 of the principal Act to provide for the functions of the Corporation to include participation in the operation of joint-user areas. Clause 4 refers to the extent of functions of the Corporation and will amend section 8 of the principal Act to provide for the functions of the Corporation in relation to a Federal airport to extend generally to a jointly used area except in relation to disposal of land. Exclusion from the Corporation's functions of the matters relating to the control, by persons engaged in air traffic control, of vehicles on manoeuvring areas at Federal airports is extended to jointly used areas.

There is an important amendment under clause 5 dealing with powers of the Corporation. This clause amends section 9 of the principal Act by specifying that the Corporation has the power to lease from the Commonwealth land at a federal airport that owned by the Commonwealth. It also gives the Corporation power to enter into arrangements with the Commonwealth for use of land at a Federal airport that is owned by the Commonwealth. It allows the Corporation to enter into arrangements for the joint use by the Corporation and an authority of the Commonwealth of land at a Federal airport that is owned by the Commonwealth. The Corporation may also enter into arrangements relating to the operation of jointly used areas and it may lease land from a person for the purposes of the principal Act.

There are two other aspects of the amendments to which I would like to refer briefly. Clause 10 deals with airports and business concessions. This clause amends section 71 of the principal Act by excluding the whole of an airport from the Airports (Business Concessions) Act where part of the airport becomes a Federal airport. Clause 11 deals with the Defence aerodrome. It inserts a new section in the principal Act to retain the application of section 20 of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 to the part of a joint user aerodrome that does not become a Federal airport.

All these amendments are important, particularly in the case of Darwin Airport. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that the then responsible Minister, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) stated in this House on 23 August this year that the Government had taken a decision in principle that the Darwin and Alice Springs airports should be transferred to the FAC and that detailed arrangements were being negotiated. It was expected that the transfer would take place by the end of the year. The Federal Airports Corporation indicated at that stage that, upon finalisation of mutually satisfactory financial arrangements for the transfer it would immediately commence planning for the redevelopment of civil aviation facilities at Darwin, and that included a new terminal. The terminal and the associated works had a projected cost of about $65m. In addition, the Alice Springs Airport was to be upgraded initially at a cost of $1.3m. With the final development of an improved terminal at Alice Springs, the cost increased to $20m. These improvements-the relocation of the terminal at Darwin to the north side of the aerodrome and the redevelopment of the airport terminal facilities at Alice Springs-are sorely needed and long overdue.

I will illustrate this by pointing to some interesting statistics. Alice Springs, although it has a small population of around 25,000 people, has the tenth busiest airport in Australia, with more than 500,000 passengers passing through the terminal in 1988. Between 1986 and 1988 passenger numbers through the terminal have increased by some 30.6 per cent. By contrast, passenger numbers in Darwin have increased by some 10.1 per cent. I will give some indication of the increasing number of passengers going through the Alice Springs terminal and the consequent increased volume of air traffic. In 1986 passengers uplifted and discharged at Alice Springs totalled 387,359. By 1988 that figure had increased to 506,037, thus the 30.6 increase. In Darwin the figure in 1986 was 342,234, while by 1988 it had risen to 376,755. In 1987 passenger movements through the Alice Springs terminal increased over and above the national average by 11 per cent and in 1988 by 2 per cent, while in Darwin the numbers increased over and above the national average as well.

It is important to recognise why these terminals are needed. The saga of the redevelopment of the Darwin Airport has been a long and sorry story. To the bitter experience of a number of people involved in the aviation industry and in the tourism industry, promises which had been made in the past failed to materialise. However, this Government has made a commitment to upgrade the Darwin Airport and there are clear indications that that commitment will be met. I am confident that the negotiations between the Federal Airports Corporation and this Government will be finalised in the very near future.

As a further indication of the importance of Darwin Airport, I point out that although its passenger throughput is somewhat less than that of Alice Springs, it must be recognised that Darwin is an international airport that receives a lot of traffic from South East Asia. Most of the traffic from South East Asia is carried by the various airlines that have landing rights in Darwin, besides Qantas Airways Ltd. They include Royal Brunei, which was granted landing rights in 1983; Garuda, granted rights in 1969; and Merpati, granted rights in 1982. That reflects the importance of Darwin not only in terms of tourism from South East Asia but also its importance to South East Asia as part of our trading associations.

Overseas visitation contributes a significant proportion of income derived from tourism in the Northern Territory. In 1983-84 only 10 per cent of Northern Territory tourists came from overseas whilst by 1986-87 that figure had increased to 18 per cent. In 1986-87 overseas visitors contributed 21 per cent of tourist expenditure in the Northern Territory, or $61m. When people come to visit the Northern Territory they come to see some outstanding natural features such as Kakadu National Park and Uluru National Park, which are administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. This demonstrates the increasing importance of the airports at both Darwin and Alice Springs.

In 1982 the number of visitors to Kakadu National Park was 48,500 and by 1987 that figure had increased to 195,000. In 1986 the figure was only 129,000 and the percentage increase over that 12 months was some 51.2 per cent. That demonstrates the sort of pressure that has been placed on facilities at both the Darwin and Alice Springs airports. In 1987 visitations to Uluru National Park numbered 188,351, and although both Kakadu and Uluru National Parks are important attractions we must recognise that a large proportion of tourist traffic to arrive in the Northern Territory does so by aircraft. Some 18 per cent of the visitors in 1986-87 came from overseas, and invariably the travelled by plane.

As an airport serving international destinations, the Darwin Airport is by any stretch of the imagination appalling and needs to be upgraded urgently. It will be transferred to the north side of the airport, leaving the south side of the airport for the use of the Royal Australian Air Force who will eventually take over the terminal facility. It is difficult to describe the pressure on the terminal at Alice Springs as a result of the increased number of passengers passing through. As a person who regularly uses that airport, I have great admiration for the people who work there because the working conditions are appalling and the sufferance they have to undergo as a result of their working conditions needs to be addressed rather quickly.

The amount of $1.3m was to be spent upgrading the Alice Springs Airport and the work was to have commenced by October, but the developments between the FAC and the Commonwealth in relation to the ownership of the airport and the attitude of the two airlines, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, about the redevelopment of the airport have led to the delay in the project. I was hoping, as was my colleague in the Northern Territory and as is this Government, that the transfer of both the Darwin and Alice Springs airports to the FAC would have been finalised by now so that work could commence, so the handicaps which people are experiencing at both Darwin and Alice Springs airports could have been alleviated, and so that there could be an increase in tourist visitation. I do not doubt that people who visit those airports realise there is a significant need to upgrade the facilities.

The transfer arrangements have proved to be more complex than first anticipated. In particular, these issues have required additional time to resolve determining with the FAC on agreed valuation for the airports; tenure arrangements at the joint user airfields; legislative amendments necessary to permit the FAC to operate Federal airports on land leased from the Commonwealth; and lease arrangements to apply at Canberra Airport and for the existing civil aviation facilities at Darwin Airport. These, as I understand it, are close to completion.

It had always been proposed by the Commonwealth that the transfer of Darwin Airport to the FAC would involve the Corporation accepting responsibility for the existing civil aviation facilities in the interim period while new facilities were being constructed on the north side of the aerodrome. As I understand it, the FAC has agreed to the leasehold proposal and preliminary negotiations involving the FAC and the Department of Defence, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Administrative Services are under way. This amendment to the FAC Act will permit the transfer of the existing civil aviation area to the FAC under leasehold from the Commonwealth, and that is one of the reasons why this legislation is important. If we were to accept the amendments proposed by the Opposition, there is no doubt that there would be endless frustration of the ambitions of the people in the Northern Territory who require new facilities at both Darwin and Alice Springs.

Alice Springs, as has been acknowledged, has been the subject of overcrowding for a number of years, and as I pointed out earlier it was decided initially in the context of the 1987-88 Budget that provision would be made for some limited expansion at a cost of $1.3m. Unfortunately that development was frustrated by the failure of the airlines to agree on space allocations within the proposed redevelopment. As I have said, that delay in development has caused frustration not only amongst travellers and general users of the airport, including the tourist industry generally, but also amongst the work force at the Alice Springs Airport. Once again I commend in particular the staff of Ansett and Australian Airlines at the airport. When 578,000 visitors come through the airport each year it is very difficult to issue those people with tickets when there are only two desks. As a consequence, luggage handling becomes a nightmare. It is of the utmost priority that this matter is settled as quickly as possible. I am looking forward to that happening with in the coming weeks. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill may I say that the amendment moved by the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has my full support. Before I comment on that amendment there are a couple of matters that I would like to take up with the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). He has my full sympathy in terms of his support for the further development of the Darwin and Alice Springs airports. I am sure that he would agree with me that the Northern Territory Government deserves the utmost support and congratulations for the magnificent job that its Tourist Bureau has done in promoting the Northern Territory in the last few years.

SPEECH.PARA: While the honourable member for the Northern Territory mentioned three airlines that operate through Darwin I think there is already another Asian airline in the form of Singapore Airlines going into Darwin at the moment. Another airline has indicated that it wants to start operating into Darwin next year. The demand there will be great indeed. But the honourable member for the Northern Territory did not mention that, if he is not careful, events might pass them by because a major international carrier is already talking about operating direct international services into Alice Springs. The honourable member for the Northern Territory would want to be fully aware of that to make sure that those facilities will be there and to make sure that he does not suffer the embarrassment and the humiliation that we in Queensland have been forced to suffer by virtue of the tin shed that presently operates as the Brisbane international terminal. I will come to that later.

I speak in this debate with the belief that, throughout the aviation industry in Australia there is a feeling of frustration and anger over what has been developing in the last few months especially since the institution and the coming on stream of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). I refer particularly to what is happening in the general aviation industry. The phone and the fax machine in my office run hot with complaints about some of the propositions that are put to some of the operators in that general aviation industry by members of the Federal Airports Corporation. There is a very real concern within the general aviation area about some of the charges that have been devised by the FAC.

We set up the FAC as an independent statutory corporation to be operated on commercial principles with a view to privatising it further down the line. One of the requirements was that it had to pay for itself and it had to produce a profit. But one wonders just what will happen in the general aviation industry if these things are not done carefully. The operators at the secondary airports in particular are expressing a great deal of concern. One of the things that really worries me is that there appears to be a move afoot within the general aviation industry for many of the aircraft operators to move right off the secondary airports.

If we are not careful we will see-maybe this is a good thing; maybe it is not, but I rather think it is not a good thing-private airports being set up all over the country because the general aviation operators just do not think that they can meet the present charges that are being imposed. I think that is a very real threat. If that happens one of the great difficulties might be that some of the safety controls over general aviation might not be available. At the moment I guess that we have one advantage with the secondary airports. There are facilities to make sure that inspections that are going on, and the maintenance being undertaken on behalf of general aviation are certainly up to standard. We would want to protect that. As I have said, there certainly seems to be a move afoot where a number of the operators are saying, `We will not cop this any more. We will get out and we will set up our own private airport'. I think honourable members should be aware of that.

The other thing that is causing some concern is that charges are being levied on some of the contractors at FAC airports. One case came to my attention this week-I have made ministerial representations on it-of an aircraft engineer who has been told that he now has to pay some outrageous sum to operate at Archerfield Airport in Brisbane. I really wonder just how the FAC comes to determine what some of these charges may be. I think we should be very careful of that.

I read with interest the Hansard record of Estimates Committee B undertaken in the Senate on 13 October 1988 when the whole area of the FAC and the Civil Aviation Authority came under the very close scrutiny of members of the other place. I am afraid that I agreed with the shadow Minister when he expressed some concern at the fact that, as yet, we do not have answers to some of those very real issues that were raised at that Senate Estimates Committee. One thing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) should do at the moment is ensure that we get some of those answers back as fast as we possibly can because there were issues relating to the operation of the FAC, to some of the charges imposed and to some of the future intentions of the FAC that, frankly, we just do not know about.

I mentioned a little while ago the situation that faces Brisbane Airport. Of course, we have a magnificent new domestic terminal there and a new runway-admittedly in the wrong place, but we have a new runway that can take all sorts of equipment. Sitting next to it is the old Eagle Farm Airport. It would seem, from reading the Hansard documentation of the Estimates Committee that, at the moment, the Federal Airports Corporation does not have a clue about what it will do with that old airport facility which is sitting there derelict. A lot of the buildings there could be available and made quite serviceable for a number of other organisations. But, as yet, we have had no answer on what the story is. Yet legitimate people such as freight forwarders and customs agents, would love to be able to get space at airports to establish their businesses. They are being denied that opportunity. The other thing that they are concerned about is what the costs might be if they go onto those airport sites. That just does not relate to the Brisbane Airport; that relates to a number of other airports around Australia. We know what a farce Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is at the moment. We know of the capacity, especially for the burgeoning air freight industry. We know what restrictions there are at that airport and the very real restrictions that are being applied to new international or would be international air freight operators.

I will dwell on the Sydney Airport situation briefly because my colleague mentioned it and it was discussed in the other place. It is fascinating that we have an arrogant Government and a Federal Airports Corporation that really have not come to the party to provide for the real needs and aspirations of Sydney people in relation to Sydney Airport. It is fascinating to go back through the newspapers of the last few days. The headline in the Weekend Australian was, `Airlines condemn plan for airport'. Both Australian Airlines and the Regional Airlines Association of Australia made very great criticism of the decision of the Government not to proceed with the third runway. In the Courier-Mail on Monday, 21 November, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), made a statement about that third runway. In the Daily Commercial News, one of the voices of the industry, on Monday, 21 November, we find the headline, `Sydney airport light aircraft ban mooted'. That might be well and good but we read further in that story of the very real frustration that is being experienced. Hot off the press today, Thursday, 24 November 1988, we find in the Daily Mirror from Sydney not one story but two. In the first story we find:
A third runway must be built immediately at Kingsford-Smith Airport or Sydney will face massive flight disruption, Australia's two major domestic airlines warned today.
Ansett and Australian Airlines, furious at congestion-caused delays which are already up to 30 minutes long, said work on a new strip should begin at once.
Both carriers say the third runway is the only answer to the city's mounting aviation woes-and both reject the Federal Government's idea of building an entirely new airport at Badgerys Creek.
So that story goes on. The interesting thing is that, at the end of that story we find the following:
A spokesman for Mr Punch-
that is, the Minister-
said that by the time it was finished, air traffic would have increased so much that Badgerys Creek would be needed anyway.

That is debatable, but that really is a terribly arrogant statement when people are screaming out for extra assistance. In the same newspaper, this afternoon's Daily Mirror from Sydney, the headline on page 13 is `Hotel Boom Gloom'. The article reads:
