Sydney's thriving hotel industry is headed for disaster-unless radical improvements are made to the airport.
There are 47 new hotels on the drawing board but already industry leaders are predicting doom.
George Bedwani, general manager of the plush Southern Cross Hotel, warned that Sydney did not have the facilities to cope with more tourists.
And without them the additional hotels could not survive.
`If new hotels are to succeed the government needs to solve many problems with the airport,' he said.
`As it stands Sydney airport cannot take any more people or planes.
Of course, he is quite right. Later in the same article he appeals for that third runway.

What are we doing? At a time when about the only growth industry we have in Australia is the tourist industry, when Sydney is handling 58 per cent of the traffic and when it is the major hub of Australia, we have this complete and utter arrogance, this political decision not to go ahead with the third runway at Sydney Airport. It is the only solution. If we really think that Badgerys Creek is going to be operating in time to take international traffic, when we know that the number of international tourists to Australia will double by the turn of the century, we really do not know what we are all about.

The only solution that has been provided in reports ad nauseam is that we must proceed immediately to build another strip at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is true that aircraft are getting bigger, and that may relieve some of the congestion, but the sheer volume, pressure and build-up of the number of tourists coming to Australia and the number of tourists flying domestically in Australia will require that we build that third runway as soon as possible. There is no other option, and as soon as the Government-or the Minister-wakes up to it, the better.

It is fascinating that yesterday the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) made a public statement that he was very concerned about the future of tourism growth into Australia and in particular into Sydney due to the restrictions of the present international airport. That should be taken on board by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support because there he has one of his own power brokers from New South Wales making the statements that we all know about in this place to the effect that the only solution for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is to proceed with the third runway.

It is with great pleasure that I support the second reading amendment that has been moved by the shadow Minister. It is essential that, with the doom and gloom that seems to abound within the aviation industry, with the very real concerns that are being expressed about the general aviation industry and particular developments, we try to find out what is happening.

There is concern about other airports. Yesterday it was announced that $2.4m of improvements would be made to Adelaide Airport. Yet in those great growth airports such as Brisbane very little is being done. I am horrified, disgusted and sorely distressed at the attitude that is being taken by the Federal Airports Corporation in terms of the future of Brisbane's international terminal. Time and time again propositions that could virtually solve the difficulties at the Brisbane international terminal within 18 months are being put and are being totally rejected.

Yet another bandaid solution is being put up for a further extension to the tin shed that poses as the Brisbane international terminal. That is always rejected: no proposition for a new international terminal will be looked at for at least another three to five years, despite the growth factor at the Brisbane international airport, despite the fact that the convention traffic next year into Brisbane will be greater than it has ever been, and despite the fact that in 1992 Brisbane will host the Lions Clubs International convention. Can you imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker, 36,000 people travelling through Brisbane in one weekend? Thirty-six thousand people will pour off Boeing 747s into a shed with five gates, no airbridges, restricted room for the immigration people to work in and horrific conditions for Customs. Despite that, the Federal Airports Corporation says, `No, we're not really interested in that', just as previous governments were not interested in the development that occurred during the Commonwealth Games, just as they were not interested in what happened at World Expo 88, and just as they are not interested that every Friday morning aeroplanes from Singapore Airlines, Japan Airlines and Philippines Airlines are all waiting for a bay at the Brisbane international terminal. We have people in positions in this Government who really do not understand what is happening in the tourist industry in Australia. We have departments which will not intermingle and which will not refer to others to find out what is going on. Frankly, that is part of the reason why we have this overloaded aviation disaster facing Australia at the moment.

It is time that this Parliament had a good look at what is happening in aviation. Whether it concerns Brisbane, Sydney, Townsville or Darwin, or Alice Springs in the future, we have to make sure that there is adequate planning. It is all very well for the Government to talk about five million international visitors by the turn of the century. That figure will be achieved much sooner, having regard to the present growth rate.

The news this morning was that we still have the second highest growth rate in international tourism, of all the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. The only member country that is ahead of us is Turkey. We are out there getting this business, yet we are doing everything we possibly can to make sure that that expansion does not happen; that that growth is restricted; that we make it as uncomfortable as we possibly can for international arrivals and that we make it as hard as we can for new international airlines to come to Australia due to the lack of slots and all sorts of restrictions, such as curfews at some airports. It really makes one wonder why the Australian Tourist Commission goes overseas and works so hard to bring visitors here when, because of the bureaucratic nature of this Government and the sheer arrogance of some of the members of this Government, everything is done to stifle that kind of growth and development.

I hope that there is a realisation in some of the electorates in the western suburbs of Sydney that all the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support is doing is depriving young people in those western suburbs of Sydney of new jobs. Airports are huge employers of staff, and we are stifling the job creation role which can be undertaken in the airport development at Kingsford-Smith. That has all gone west. We are not taking full advantage to ensure they get those jobs in aviation and tourism. We seem to have a completely blinkered approach at the moment in terms of development and in terms of having a commercially minded organisation running the airports. We seem to wear blinkers in terms of opening it up to commercial enterprise. In Brisbane where there are five or six consortia which say, `Please, give us the opportunity to develop a new international terminal for Brisbane. As long as we can build a hotel and a shopping centre, we will make a go of it, and it will not cost the taxpayer or the airline users one single cent'. The Government says, `No, we are not going to look at that for three years'. In Brisbane we even have the State Government virtually saying that it will organise it and will pick up the tab for it. But we are not getting anywhere.

Time is restricted. I would love to demonstrate how well an international air terminal can work as a commercial proposition. As I have said in this place before, I wish that Qantas Airways Ltd would give a handful of free tickets to members of the Federal Airports Corporation and drop them off at airports in Manchester, Copenhagen, Amsterdam and throughout the United States and say to them, `This is how it is done; this is the way you make a profit; this is the way you don't cost your taxpayers anything; this is the way Australian aviation should be developing; this is the way we should be building our terminals'. Until we take those blinkers off, this country can never reach its full potential in terms of tourism growth, because it is going to be cut off at the throat, at the international gateways of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in this debate and express my concern on behalf of the tourist industry of Australia at the way in which airports throughout this country are being operated and managed. There is no doubt whatsoever that there is universal concern within the industry that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Government, which is the ultimate owner of it, are not up to the job of meeting the growth in demand in our fantastic tourism industry. The Federal Airports Corporation, since it was first established in January this year, has been the butt of a great deal of criticism. It has seen tremendous rises in the charges that it places upon the industry. It has been criticised for not consulting the aviation industry before it establishes costs and provides the sorts of services it does. It is overseeing a totally and utterly inadequate facility for the tourist industry in Australia today. At the same time the FAC has been lumbered with some fairly unusual lease arrangements that were signed prior to its being established. At the end of the day, the FAC has come into a tremendously difficult area. It has, according to members within the industry, not performed as people expect. The Government has not helped it in one single area to assist in providing better services to the aviation industry and the tourism industry, and to the general public.

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, we are looking at and discussing today one of the greatest shambles that this Government oversees. If we can do something to improve our airports we will do a tremendous amount to promote tourism to Australia. We have bodies such as the Australian Tourist Commission. We have organisations such as the Australian Tourism Industry Association. Individual owners and operators of tourist facilities in this country go out each day promoting tourism in Australia, and taking Australia to the rest of the world saying, `For goodness sake, come to the most exciting tourist destination in the world. We've got it all here'. But when they come in their droves, as they are doing at present, tourists find that their first experience is an absolute shambles.

One has only to go, as so many people now know, through places such as Sydney international airport, which is the best example of the chaos and disaster that exist in the industry, to realise what a bad first impression international visitors to our country encounter. They experience considerable delays, I am told, of two or three hours at a time. They have to walk around building sites. The signs are not adequate. There are not sufficient trolleys. I was coming through the Sydney international airport earlier this year and I had to wait 20 minutes before a trolley appeared on the scene so I could take my luggage out of the place. There were probably 150 people standing at the baggage collection area waiting for a trolley. One of the basic elements of running an airport is to ensure that people can get their baggage out of the place and not add to the delay experienced by international visitors. Fortunately, this is not the case.

The Airports Corporation is not doing its job. The Government is not helping it. As a consequence, all the efforts of the tourism industry to promote tourism to Australia are being downgraded by the fact that when tourists come here they experience shocking conditions at our airports. I am ashamed to think what they go through. They have a bad first impression which will last a long time. The industry, the hotels, the bus companies, the restaurants, the resorts, and the tour organisations will have to do a lot of hard work to make up for the damage that our tourist industry reputation suffers from the time visitors arrive at our airports. This year 2.2 million to 2.4 million people will visit Australia. Sixty per cent of them will come through Sydney Airport which is why the honourable member for Fadden and the honourable member for Richmond spoke extensively about the inadequacies of that airport. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in the last day or so finally admitted-he has been slow off the mark-the inadequacies of Sydney Airport. Yesterday, 23 November, he was reported as saying:
. . . the development of Australia's tourism industry could be severely hampered unless airport infrastructures was expanded and passenger processing improved.
He went on to say:

This position will deteriorate as the growth in tourism continues unless there are significant improvements in the efficiency of passenger processing and a substantial expansion of airport infrastructure.
He made some specific criticisms. He said:

Major problem areas are lack of terminal space, peak passenger movements regularly exceed terminal capacity, inadequate baggage handling facilities, poor passenger information, trolley and coach parking facilities, and congested airways.

At long last the Minister responsible for tourism, Senator Richardson, having been in the job for nearly 12 months, has admitted to the people of Australia that our airport facilities are inadequate. Sydney Airport is the chief reason why Senator Richardson and the entire industry say that airport facilities are inadequate. We have so much potential to be generated from tourism if we can do it right. Tourism these days is earning Australia about $25.5 billion. It employs about 6 per cent of the Australian work force. That is about 430,000 people. It is predicted that by 1991 there will be 630,000 people employed in the tourism industry. It is one of our largest export earners-I think the third largest. Wool and coal exceed it slightly. It has the potential to create more jobs than any other industry. It is the shining light on the economic horizon, but the one stumbling block along the way is our airport facilities.

The honourable member for Fadden particularly highlighted the broad array of inadequacies of our airports. We do not have to go to Sydney to find the inadequacies. We can go to Darwin Airport. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) spoke of the problems in the Northern Territory. Even though he is a member of the Government he made some fairly damning criticisms. Darwin Airport is a national disgrace. I was up there not so long ago. If one wants to stand in a crowded spot I suggest one go to Darwin Airport. I have never seen anything more crowded, more uncomfortable or more inadequate than Darwin Airport.

The Alice Springs Airport has had a huge growth in passenger traffic. In the last couple of years it has had in the order of a 30 per cent increase in passenger traffic. People have to stand in the carpark because there is no room for them to stand in the Airport while they wait to get another flight, to be picked up, or to check in. There is hardly a check-in facility at all. Often there will be five or six major aircraft parked on the runways as thousands of people disgorge from them to something that is totally inadequate.

The Brisbane Airport has a magnificent runway, but the international terminal building is locally described as the hayshed-I inspected it earlier this year-and it is a very adequate description of it. I witnessed a 747 coming from Japan disgorge its passengers. There was just one aircraft at that time. It took no more than five minutes for a queue of people to work its way outside of the general waiting area and back up into the aisle from where the aircraft passengers were initially disgorging. People were being delayed for lengthy periods just because that facility is totally inadequate.

The Perth Airport, admittedly, was badly designed from the outset, but it is now very much in need of upgrading. The Coolangatta Airport needs increased radar facilities. In fact, it needs radar facilities-not increased radar facilities. Cairns is in the same position. I think its radar facilities consist of a pair of binoculars held by one of the people in the air traffic control tower. That is totally inadequate for large airports such as Coolangatta and Cairns airports.

The Melbourne Airport needs expanding. The Government has a huge responsibility, not just to agree to do these things but also to provide the funds for them. Qantas Airways Ltd has to double its number of aircraft in the next five years. Australian Airlines needs a massive capital injection. Qantas also needs a huge capital injection. All sorts of government statutory organisations need massive amounts of capital. The Government does not have the physical ability to deliver the capital in order to provide those services for the future. Yet private enterprise is prepared to do it. As the honourable member for Fadden pointed out, a number of private enterprise groups in Brisbane would be willing to build a new world class international terminal tomorrow morning if the Government would allow them to do it. The same situation applies in Darwin where the Northern Territory Government and private enterprise are prepared to work together to build a new terminal building for both international and domestic traffic. The previous Liberal-National Party Government was in the process of doing that, but then this Government came to office and stopped it. The Northern Territory Government and private enterprise in the Territory were both prepared to work together to take over the job of building terminal buildings at both Darwin and Alice Springs. That would have saved this Government a power of money, yet it would not let it happen.

This highlights the political problem existing in the tourism and aviation industries in Australia today. This Federal Labor Government is totally opposed to any concept of privatisation, and it is totally opposed to the building of any new runway facilities at Mascot for the sake of the seat of the honourable member for Barton and Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch). It is sad to see the whole growth of the Australia tourism industry being held back by this Labor Government for the philosophical reason that it does not like privatisation and for the purely political reason that it is frightened of losing the seat of Barton. Therefore, the employment opportunities of hundreds of thousands of young Australians are being held back by a government wholly and solely for political and personal reasons. This is totally inadequate.

We hear constantly from the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support that Badgerys Creek will be the saviour of us all. Badgerys Creek will be a saviour in 15 or 20 years' time. That is how long it will take to develop it properly. In the meantime, the number of international visitors to this country increased from 2.2 million to 2.4 million this year and will probably increase to seven million or even eight million by the year 2000. That is what the industry now expects. Badgerys Creek will not be operating fully by the year 2000. The number of international visitors coming to this country will almost treble, and on the present ratio 60 per cent will come through Sydney Airport which currently cannot cope with its 60 per cent share of 2.2 million. The situation will get worse. That is why the industry, elements of the Federal Airports Corporation and so many people throughout Australia say that the only reasonable, decent decision that this Government can make is to build that extra runway at Sydney Airport. That could be done for about $300m and work could be completed in about six years. That would be a huge boost to the tourism industry and it would ensure that Australia did not develop a bad reputation in the international tourist market.

At the same time, international airlines have been hit not only by increased charges from the Federal Airports Corporation, which is nicknamed the Farcical Aviation Charges group, but also by huge increases in Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) charges. I shall highlight how international airlines are suffering from huge increases imposed on them by the Civil Aviation Authority over the past 12 months. En route navigation charges have increased by 303 per cent, fire rescue service charges are up by 50 per cent; and terminal navigation charges have been increased by 43.3 per cent. In fact, international airlines this year have been hit with an extra $105.5m as a result of this Government trying to do nothing more than turn tourism into a means of gaining tax revenue. In the process it is hurting the tourist industry by putting up costs of services and airlines tickets. Of course there was a great example of this in the High Court of Australia this morning when it was revealed that the Government was totally out of place in imposing the arrivals tax earlier this year. In fact, the Government now has to pay back the money to those people who paid their $5 tax. That indicates that the FAC, this Government and the CAA are turning tourism and aviation into a milch cow in order to raise more revenue. I think that that is an incredibly sad situation for Australia's tourism industry today.

At the same time, because of the inadequate services being provided at our airports most aircraft leaving Sydney Airport are experiencing delays. In fact, 90 per cent of international flights are being delayed due to the lack of runway space and terminal gates. As a result of this in the last week or so Qantas Airways Ltd has said that unless more aircraft can be accommodated at Sydney Airport the growth of inbound tourism will be restricted. At the same time the industry has revealed that for several hours each day there is no room for even one extra jet at the three mainland east coast capital city airports. That is a chronic situation which cannot be sustained. It highlights the inadequacies of the approach of both the FAC and this Government to the management of our aviation and tourism industries.

Unless the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation support and all those people in the Government who have the responsibility of seeing that Australia's full potential is reached can ensure that those people who want jobs in tourism can get them, unless we have Ministers who are prepared to reach those sometimes difficult decisions, I am afraid that Australia will be very much the poorer. There will be many thousands of people standing on the end of unemployment queues unless this Government does something to fix up our airports. It has to build the third runway at Sydney Airport, it has to allow private enterprise to develop terminals throughout Australia and it has to ensure that it does not treat the aviation and tourism industries as a means of raising tax revenue. Unless the Government does all those things Australia will be much the poorer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of my colleagues, particularly the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), on the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill. I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for helping to facilitate the speaking arrangements as I had a commitment a moment ago which delayed my entry into the chamber. I strongly support the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond because it highlights many of the problems we see with this legislation and with aviation generally in Australia today. We see the need to refer the Bill to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure-a committee on which I happen to serve because of my long-standing interest in aviation policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways aviation in Australia is in crisis as a result of neglect of the decisionmaking process of governments of both political persuasions at both levels, Federal and State. The grid lock occurring regularly along the east coast of Australia and elsewhere at some times, to which other members have referred, is creating congestion and hence levels of frustration which place life in jeopardy. This is not something which should be deemed to be an elitist problem-a problem which affects only those who fly around this country regularly. The employment of countless thousands of people depends on a viable aviation industry. Many people who are employed directly and indirectly in jobs associated with the aviation industry may never fly. So we are not just defending the rights of fast-moving people who have to fly as part of their jobs; we are defending the right to provide positive infrastructure in this country for the 1990s and beyond. We are providing a basis for aviation to cope with the massive increase in traffic. We will see a much greater increase with the deregulation which is proceeding. Also, with the growth in retirement incomes, and the increased proportion of retired Australians, traffic will increase as certain airline companies, such as East-West Airlines Ltd, pitch a budget approach at prospective passengers to facilitate group travel to tourist resorts around Australia. This approach is particularly designed to meet the budget strategies of elderly people and other categories of group travellers.

In terms of the crisis situation-and it is a crisis situation-the clock stands at about five minutes to midnight in the aviation industry in Australia today, not only because of the congestion problem but also because of other more subtle aspects for which the Government is to blame. I refer in particular to two areas: Firstly, modern radar and the problems that have been encountered along the way with the installation of upgraded radar systems around Australia; and secondly, navigational aids for the main runways at our capital city airports.

We have a situation where for a period there was an improved radar system installed just to the east of Perth to control air traffic in the Perth area and over much of Western Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be interested to know that on the radar screens displayed for the air traffic controllers, the call sign of the aircraft, the flight number and the altitude came up alongside the bleep on the radar screen. It was a logical process in tracking the movement of the aircraft and is happening in France, Europe and the US. However, for several years there was a specific instruction from the then Department of Aviation that air traffic controllers were to ignore the information on the radar screen as to flight call signs, altitude and so forth and proceed by more manual and antiquated procedures. That went on for an extraordinary length of time before it was resolved when additional improvements were made to radar systems elsewhere on the eastern seaboard. Again it was a case, to some extent, of too little too late.

In terms of instrument landing systems it has to be said that Garuda Indonesia and certain other airlines have from time to time got it awfully wrong over Melbourne. Part of the reason these airlines have got it awfully wrong is a special set of circumstances where an aircraft is turning right base to land into the north and suddenly it has lined up with the Essendon south-north main runway instead of the Tullamarine south-north main runway. On making some inquiries about that one finds that at that time there was no instrument landing system on two of the four runways at Tullamarine. Are we fair dinkum about providing the right infrastructure for aviation in Australia today, or are we getting by on a bandaid approach which has been exacerbated by governments in the past at both State and Federal level?

Clearly we want to see the right infrastructure and the right control structure provided to bring about the sort of breakthroughs that we need to provide safe and economically dynamic aviation in the future which will service not only the capital cities and the international tourist flights but also, more particularly, the provincial cities in the States-cities such as Albury, Mildura, Wagga Wagga, Dubbo and Tamworth in New South Wales. Those cities are essential ingredients of the economic infrastructure of this country. If their flights are to be squeezed out of the capital cities because of this crisis congestion that simply is not good enough. I strongly support the thrust of the comments and the amendments moved to this important legislation by the honourable member for Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), I strongly support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). I again support in the strongest terms his comments about the infrastructure needs of the Australian airline industry. It is not good enough to think solely about capital cities. We also have to think about the regional airports.

SPEECH.PARA: In my particular case in the electorate of Cowper, Coffs Harbour has an airport recently upgraded to jet standard. It is a very satisfactory airport but it is on the verge of needing to be upgraded again. Even more important than that, Port Macquarie, with 48,303 passengers in 1987-88, desperately needs to be upgraded to a jet airport. Something will have to be done to upgrade Port Macquarie's facilities. These days transport is becoming more and more important to the tourist industry. As you know so well, Mr Deputy Speaker, Port Macquarie is one of the great jewels of the tourist areas of Australia and its airport must be upgraded to jet standard.

Kempsey, a little further to the north, needs upgrading with a non-directional radio beacon. This has been on the move for years with the Department of Transport and Communications and with previous Ministers. Now that we have had a change and Eastern Airlines is servicing the airport and the valley the need is even greater. Passenger numbers are now 9,600 per annum and it is anticipated that before very long the number will grow to 15,000 per year. Operational requirements for Kempsey Airport right now demand that a non-directional beacon should be installed. As well as passenger services there are general aircraft and a commercial flying school, and an aircraft engineering firm, Premier Air Maintenance, has recently established itself at Kempsey Airport. It is no good just saying that we can go ahead and do what we must at Brisbane and Darwin airports and elsewhere and neglect the regional airports. I again emphasise that there is a desperate need in the very near future to upgrade the Port Macquarie Airport to jet standard. At the very least Kempsey must be given a non-directional beacon.

If we do that, however, and I am sure it must happen, we get back to the other side of the coin, which is that there has to be a third runway at Sydney Airport. I do not think anybody in his right mind can argue with that proposition. Almost invariably, when I fly to Sydney from Coffs Harbour or from Port Macquarie the aircraft stooges around somewhere over Gosford or the Central Coast, turning round and round in circles because of the congestion at Sydney. Blind Freddy can see that there must be a third parallel runway.

It is absolutely disgraceful that this Hawke Labor Government is so remiss in its response to the needs of the aviation industry that it can hamstring and restrict the growth and development of air services purely out of regard for one marginal seat, the seat held by the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), who is the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. One seat is totally destroying the future of airlines flying into Sydney. In connection with tourism, I make the point that it is vital that we get some immediate action to improve Sydney's facilities. Australia is looking at receiving two million overseas visitors this year, 3.3 million in 1995, and five million in the year 2000. Overseas visitors to Sydney currently number 1.2 million. The figure is expected to be 1.8 million in 1995 and 2.8 million in the year 2000. We already have 30 airlines flying into Sydney. There are 35 expected by 1995 and 38, at the vest least, by the year 2000. Believe it or not the number of passenger movements through Sydney Airport at present is 6.2 million. By 1995 it will be 12 million and by the year 2000 it will be 18 million.

It is not good enough for this Government just to think about putting its airport out at Badgerys Creek, fluttering around like bogong moths and attempting to solve the problem by saying, `Yes, we will advance the Badgerys Creek airport'. There is no point in putting it way out in the scrub without a fast transport system. That will solve no problem at all. In fact, people in areas such as Dubbo and Orange will find it quicker to drive to Sydney rather than catch an aircraft, fly to Badgerys Creek, and then have to drive or get to Sydney by some other means.

It is time this Government took the bit between its teeth and made the right decision, which will be applauded by all Australians except the honourable member for Barton and some of his constituents. They will realise that with modern aircraft the noise is not nearly as bad as with older aircraft. The realities are that the more modern the aircraft the quieter it is. I am positive that 99.9 per cent of all Australians will support the move for a third strip at Mascot.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join the debate on the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill. Many Opposition members and Government members have contributed in a sound way to the debate. I would like to raise a few matters which concern me. Naturally I want to say something about Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I have always been interested in the airports throughout Australia, particularly the international airports. They are important to the future of our nation. The legislation before the House gives more flexibility to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and provides for land to be vested within the Corporation. I have no objection to that. I think the setting up of the Corporation was not a bad idea. It took airports out of the hands of the Federal Department of Transport. There were problems. Both the Government and the Opposition appreciate the fact that it is not easy to keep up with the facilities that are required for our airways.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been a member of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for five years, I have always been concerned about this matter. We held hearings regarding most of the major airports of Australia and their need for advancement and extension. It concerned me greatly that there was inadequate planning by State and local councils for airports. We can pinpoint not only the Sydney area but also Perth and Brisbane. The councils in those areas allowed the extension of residential areas right up to the airports. That was a great shame. In regard to the Williamtown airport in New South Wales, which is a dual airport, serving the Royal Australia Air Force (RAAF) and civil aviation, there were certain extensions of residential areas. The Minister would be well aware that those extensions were allowed to take place there. As a result, my electorate office takes phone calls nearly every day from people objecting to noise in the area. In those days the State did not cooperate with the local councils-it is not the same today-to undertake the proper planning of the areas concerned. So there are problems throughout Australia in relation to airport noise.

The Bill indicates that the FAC now has a commercial charter. It has had a commercial charter from the start. In other words, the FAC is supposed to pay its way. That is a good thing. As the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has emphasised today in this debate, the important thing is the efficiency with which the FAC undertakes its work.

While we are looking for efficiency and for the FAC to pay its way, there are certain aspects of the FAC's operations that I would like to say something about this evening. They are important to those of us who represent country electorates throughout the continent and who are so dependent upon airways to give the service to our people. Australia has been reasonably fortunate. All of the States have an international airport. We have three international airports in Queensland. We would have four if Customs were operating at Coolangatta Airport. The airport can take a jumbo jet. The north of Australia is being opened up. There are international airports at Darwin and Alice Springs. Darwin Airport is particularly important now that the RAAF has moved down to Tindal which I think was an excellent move. We want the north of Australia opened up to the tourist potential that this great country has.

Unfortunately, previous governments did not foresee the progress that would take place. So now there is a lot of catching up to do if we are to cope with the volume of traffic mentioned by honourable members during this debate today. Up to eight million or nine million tourists a year will be visiting Australia in a few years time. The tourist industry may be our greatest money earner. So it is important that we now address the problems with our airports. I hope that the FAC will work to a long term plan and that it will cater for Australia's future needs-not only the needs of our own people to travel from State to State and intrastate but also the needs of those people who will visit this lovely country of ours. One could almost say that our infrastructure is underdeveloped. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) knows that only a fortnight ago we spoke about the state of our roads. I spoke about the Pacific Highway and the importance of doing something about the state of that highway. I spoke about the railways. I feel that it is important that the States and the Commonwealth do not neglect the railways. They are important, particularly in regard to the carriage of cargo throughout the country. There are also the airways. In the modern world it is important that we have the necessary airways facilities.

I will confine the remainder of my remarks to Sydney Airport. I do not suppose that a member of this House has said more about the need for extensions and work at Sydney Airport than I have. Commuter aircraft travel from my electorate of Lyne into the city. I am very aware of the importance of these small passenger planes to other parts of the State. Unfortunately, the Government has scrubbed the plan to build a third runway at Sydney Airport. This is a calamity. It was on the drawing board years ago when I was a member of the Public Works Committee. It was being discussed then. The then Minister for Transport may actually have approved the north-south runway at Sydney Airport. It is essential. We have no objection to the choice of Badgerys Creek. But it is about 60 kilometres from the centre of Sydney.

What transport will be provided for travel from the airport to the city if international aircraft, or indeed any aircraft, are diverted to the proposed airfield at Badgerys Creek? They will have to be diverted there if the Government is planning to go ahead with the airfield. What planning has been done and what discussions have been held with the New South Wales Government in respect of the availability of suitable transport, whether train, expressway or other forms of transport, to get people into the metropolitan area? If one has travelled, one's thoughts turn to cities overseas which have been forced to put their airports many miles from their centres but they have provided expressways or trains to get people into the centre.

It is important that the Government and the FAC give every consideration to the ability of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to cater for the increase of over 3 per cent, practically 4 per cent, in landings and takeoffs that will occur. I ask the Government not to divert Eastern Australia Airlines, which runs to Taree and serves the important area of Forster-Tuncurry and the rest of the district. I ask the Government not to divert those passengers into Bankstown or anywhere else. Bankstown is 25 kilometres away. Very little transport is available to get people into the city from there.

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—As the honourable member says, it is true. Every time there is an opportunity I take that opportunity to plead with the FAC and the Government to please consider the needs of Sydney Airport closely and to realise their responsibilities. The situation is costing the city, the State and this nation considerable amounts. If we get a bad name, those people are diverted elsewhere, because there is not only Australia in this world. There are many beautiful places around the world which offer many packaged trips and much joy to the people who wish to travel. We want our share of this. We want our share of this. We do not want the Kingsford-Smith Airport to continue to be a blight on the economy. The Minister is a sensible fellow. He should keep in mind that if there are delays in the air and delays in getting off the ground, in turn that will cost the travelling consumer money; nobody else. The airlines have to account for that. It will cost those people extra money in fares and that is not very fair. I appeal to the Government to look at this with the FAC and make sure there is adequate planning of Sydney Airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There were just a few matters that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) asked me to refer to in summing up. The first thing that he asked me to do was to thank honourable members for their contributions--
—What happened last time?

—I am complimenting some of the honourable member's colleagues for the concern they brought to the debate. There were a couple of observations that the Minister also asked me to refer to. He asked me to say that the FAC in the first place has moved quickly to address major airport infrastructure needs. I think most of the members who have contributed to the debate are aware of this. The FAC has, for example, announced a major extension of the Sydney Airport international terminal building. It has also announced its intention to develop a new international terminal building in Brisbane within five years, as well as modifying the existing terminal building to cope with growth during the interim period. It has announced further development of the Adelaide international terminal building. It will also be providing substantial supporting infrastructure to enable the expansion of domestic terminal facilities at a number of capital city airports.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for us to recognise that the Government established the Federal Airports Corporation in the first place with a view to putting the operations of Australia's major airports on a proper commercial basis. The assets that were transferred to the Corporation were valued in accordance with normal business principles. I know that that has been one of the matters raised during the debate. But I want to emphasise that the valuation procedure was in accordance with normal principles. In valuing the assets, careful assessments were made of the FAC's ability to earn an appropriate rate of return on those assets. The Government also paid attention to the need to avoid burdening the FAC with a debt structure which would lead to substantial additional costs on the aviation industry.

It is worth mentioning that the Corporation currently has, as the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) mentioned, a total staff of about 1,200. That is a major reduction from around 1,550 staff who previously worked on the same functions in the former Department of Aviation. When the FAC was established on 1 January last, there was no increase in aeronautical charges and the charges continued at the level that had previously been levied by the Department of Transport and Communications. Subsequently, the charges were increased by 6 per cent on 1 July 1988, but that increase was simply in line with inflation. The discussion that has taken place has been very useful, and of course, the Government fully recognises the importance of Kingsford-Smith Airport. My colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), recently released a report prepared by a joint Commonwealth-State task force which examined the airport needs of the Sydney basin. This report identified a number of measures for improving traffic management at Sydney Airport as well as options for longer term development of additional airport infrastructure, and of course, the Government will be addressing this report in the near future.
