DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 8. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —These two fairly technical Bills, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, are certainly not being opposed by the Opposition, although in one particular respect we shall endeavour in another place to refer a section of one Bill to a Senate committee. The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill contains a series of changes to legislation, five different changes, and I shall briefly refer to each of those.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, the Bill proposes to change the method of measuring beer for the purposes of customs and excise duty. So using old-fashioned measurements such as the kilderkin is something that is now, Madam Speaker, you will be sorry to hear, of the past. New rather prosaic and technical measurements will be used in their place. I assure the House that that does not bring the wrath of the Opposition down on the Government. That is a matter about which we are extremely relaxed.

The second change that the legislation makes is to simplify the export procedures for exports of defence equipment. Under this legislation, exporters in future will not need a licence for every individual consignment of exports from Australia. The purpose of this is consistent with the Government's desire to promote Australian defence exports, to facilitate those defence exports, in order to help us in Australia to build up some sort of effective defence industry which has some export potential. Some people I know in the community are a little sceptical about the potential we have to do that. I certainly do not share that scepticism. I think Australia has every opportunity to create an effective export oriented defence industry. There are other countries with comparable populations which have succeeded in doing that. Sweden, for example, comes to mind. It has been enormously successful in building up a defence industry, and I see no reason why in this country, with the manufacturing know-how that we have, with the capacity to develop technology that we have, we cannot achieve great steps forward in developing an export oriented defence industry. Some of that work, of course, will involve joint ventures. It will come about through purchases that we have made and offset arrangements we have been able to enter into. Through those offset arrangements we may in turn be able to develop further export potential. Let us hope that that happens. This legislation will, in a very technical way, and probably not in a very significant way, help to facilitate at least those particular exports.

It is important that I mention that there is some opposition to these changes-for example, from people in the community who describe themselves rather euphemistically as `peace groups'. These people, who run around telling us that nuclear war is about to rain down on the heads of our young people in the next few days if we continue to talk with the United States, are concerned that these changes will mean the Government will allow a whole flood of weapons of death to flow out of Australia and will be contributing to some sort of global arms race in a massive, irresponsible and immoral way. I think those views, like all the views of those sorts of people, are massively exaggerated and massively overstated. There is an international arms industry. It is important that the West retains strong defence and continues to ensure that that strong defence is modernised and is technologically advanced. If we do that, in the future we will be able to defend ourselves against contingencies that we cannot predict.

That means that there will be an arms trade among western countries, and I see no reason at all, given that that arms trade will take place in any case, why our country should be completely excluded from it, as is the desire of some peace groups. It is also important to point out that in spite of the changes that the Government proposes the schedule of permissible exports will remain in place, so that there will still be countries to which exports of Australian defence equipment are banned. I note that the east European countries and South Africa are on that list. In addition, the Minister can prevent certain kinds of defence equipment from being exported. I see no problem whatsoever with these changes. I know that my colleague the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), welcomes them and he would like me to put on the record that he is a strong supporter of proposals to promote exports of Australian defence equipment.

The third change that this legislation makes is to facilitate duty free entry of goods from Christmas Island so that the local content requirement of goods manufactured on Christmas Island that enter duty free will be reduced from 75 per cent to 50 per cent. Again, we have no objection to that proposal. It puts Christmas Island on the same par as Papua New Guinea and the forum states, and I suppose, rather heroically, the Government hopes that that will be some help to development of the Christmas Island economy. It may assist, and it is worth a try, let me say. Perhaps the casino proposal, which has generated a lot more interest than this amendment to the Customs and excise legislation, would make a bigger contribution. I do not know what manufacturing potential on Christmas Island the Government has in mind, and perhaps the Minister will take a couple of minutes to let us know, because that may be of community interest.

The fourth change is the clarification of the consequences of false and misleading statements resulting from the outcome of the Murphy v. Farmer case in the High Court. That was a quite extraordinary and interesting case, and I recommend it to honourable members as an interesting exercise in the progression of Australian law. Again, these Government changes have the support of the Opposition. The Government has retained the statutory defence provisions under which, if someone can demonstrate that he did not know or could not have been expected to know that a statement was misleading or false, there is a satisfactory defence. The fifth change is that government instrumentalities will be subject to excise duty. Because of the limited time allowed for this debate I will not say anything about that matter because members on this side have commented on that Government initiative on previous occasions. However, while I am talking about the timetable, let me make the point that I very much regret that the Government has guillotined this debate so that there is not really an opportunity for my colleagues to discuss many of the important issues raised. I will keep my remarks as brief as I can.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) is being debated cognately with the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill in general but we have some reservations about it. First, this Bill, basically, implements the tariff changes that were announced in the May economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We on this side of the House certainly welcome the reduction in the level of protection that those changes foreshadowed at that time and, therefore, we support that aspect of this Bill. Let me say, however, that if we are to reduce levels of protection in this country, as we should and as is perfectly rational on the part of the Government, it is a pity that the Government is not prepared to take other measures that are equally rational to assist in particular our manufacturing industry but also a whole range of other industries.

It is worth recalling that the fiscal cost of capital for companies, according to the Business Council of Australia and other sources, has actually increased over the past year or so. Australia, among the countries surveyed by the Business Council, has the second highest fiscal cost of capital after New Zealand. That is hardly a way of ensuring that Australia has a productive, rapidly growing and profitable manufacturing sector. When we reduce tariffs and, at the same time, increase the cost of capital to companies, we are not really doing something that makes an awful lot of sense. The Government should be moving in the other direction in terms of the cost burden on our companies.

Let me also remind the House that the level of productivity in this country is not rising; it is declining. From 1983 to 1984 the level of productivity in Australia increased. Of course, that was before the Government's policies could have very much effect in its first year of office. Let me say that that increase was almost certainly a result of the policies that the Fraser Government introduced in its 1982 Budget. But in 1985 productivity output per man hour stabilised, and since then productivity in this country has declined progressively. That is of great concern to all Australians. How on earth can we be competitive as a nation if the productivity of our industries is declining? We can have all the rhetorical debates in the world about living standards-the fundamental human side of this problem-but at the kernel of the issue is the declining productivity of our industries. I note that the Minister, very defensively, says, `But it is declining in the United Stated as well and people are being locked up in the Soviet Union too'. That does not mean that it is a good thing just because productivity is declining in another country. It is a bad thing if that is occurring in the United States, but we are not administering the United States, we are administering Australia, and that decline is a tragedy for Australia. We must become more competitive and work to raise our level of productivity, and that includes making substantial changes in our industrial relations system and work practices in this country. Enough of that because time is very short.

The changes that this Bill makes relate also to the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industry. In the past couple of weeks I have had brief discussions about these changes with the industry in Melbourne, and I believe that the debate has been pretty much played out. The industry is living with the changes. Let me say, as I have said many times before in this sort of debate, that the Government must have a predictable plan for industry. There is no point in changing the plan in the middle of its duration and expecting industry to respond effectively. Industry has a right to some degree of predictability. I plead with the Minister, when he sums up in this debate, to give us an assurance that there will be no more unexpected changes to the Government's various industry plans, in this case to the textile, clothing and footwear plan.

My final point is that this legislation imposes a duty on sugar imports from 1 July 1989 when it is proposed that the embargo on the import of sugar will be lifted. Let me make two points about that. My colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) will enlarge on this point. We have many concerns about the hasty way in which the Government has made these changes to the sugar industry. The Government has proposed a whole raft of changes. There has been inadequate consultation with the industry. We made clear when debating previous legislation on the sugar industry in this House-and I repeat in the context of this legislation-that we will refer that legislation to a Senate committee; We will also refer this part of this Bill to the same Senate committee for proper examination and consideration. The Government will not sneak through changes to the sugar industry in a 488-page Bill in this way; we actually managed to spot the changes. The provisions will go the same way as the previous legislation-to a Senate committee. The industry can then be properly consulted and we can work out an effective sugar plan, in particular for the people of Queensland and the industry in that State. As I said, my colleague the honourable member for Dawson will enlarge on that issue.

Let me raise one point that strikes me as quite irrational in relation to these changes to the sugar industry. A tariff of 35 per cent is to be imposed on imports of cane sugar and a tariff of 10 per cent is to be imposed on imports of beet sugar. Beet sugar overwhelmingly comes from the European Community where there are subsidies and artificially high prices under the common agricultural policy to encourage production. When they have finished with their production, they export it with their notorious restitutions.

The Minister may be able to explain, and the Senate committee will find out if the Minister does not tell us, why the Government is proposing to impose a 10 per cent duty on beet sugar from the European Community, where its production is subsidised and its export is supported by the notorious system of restitution, yet cane sugar attracts a 35 per cent rate of duty. I do not know why, and I look forward to hearing an explanation.

I know many of my colleagues would like to speak in this debate as they have many important things to say on these issues. The Opposition does not oppose these Bills but we will refer the provisions of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) which relate to the sugar industry to the Senate committee that will be established to examine other legislation pertaining to the sugar industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), was concerned about the living standards of Australians and was critical of the Government's position. I suggest that he speak to the one million people who now have jobs as a consequence of the policies of the Government since 1983. He was also critical of the sugar industry. As the only sugar cane farmer in this House, I am certain that the only sugar the honourable member for Mayo has ever seen is that in his cup of tea.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 institutes amendments concerning the removal of the import embargo on raw and refined sugar on and from 1 July 1989. These amendments impose protective customs rates of duty from that date. The Government flagged this decision in the May economic statement. The National Farmers Federation, along with many other primary industry groups, has been calling for an easing of the tariff protection for secondary industry and it was conceded by the NFF that some protection given to primary industries would also have to be eased. Allow me to quote from a speech given by Mr Rick Farley, the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, to the Beef 88 conference at Rockhampton on 12 May 1988:

The farm sector also has some decisions to make. If we want reduced protection internationally, and within Australia, we have to be prepared to accept reduced assistance ourselves, even though it's already at very low levels. That's going to entail some pain for individual industries, and for individual farmers, but the overall benefits to agriculture far outweigh the costs. The May Financial Statement is going to cause some rumblings within the farm sector, but our responses should acknowledge the benefits we'll derive from a more competitive economy, and from added momentum in the international trade debate.

So the May statement decision on agriculture was well understood by the NFF. It appears that in the dust gathering around the debate on the sugar embargo the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia is out of touch with the NFF's approach to reduction in assistance. The journalist Sarah Sargent, in the Australian Financial Review of Thursday, 26 May 1988, examined the effective assistance available to a number of primary industries. She pointed out that agriculture received effective assistance amounting to 16 per cent in 1986-87 compared to 19 per cent for manufacturing. I quote her:
There are pockets in which assistance is high-179 per cent for dairying, 34 per cent for citrus and 36 per cent for dried vine fruit in 1986-87.

The May statement included reductions in manufacturing protection. These measures alone will save the agricultural sector $350m. All exporters, including sugar producers, gain the advantage from this, and I can attest to that because, as I said, I am the only sugar cane farmer in this House.

The Queensland Government, perhaps trying to find any issue to talk about rather than face up to the corruption exposed by the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, has attempted to stir up violence on the tariff issue. The Queensland Premier said the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) would need a police escort when he came to Queensland to discuss the sugar issue-a clear incitement of violence rather than a rational look at the issue.

From July 1989 the sugar import embargo will be replaced by import tariffs of about 35 per cent for raw sugar and 25 per cent for refined sugar. These rates will be phased down to 15 per cent by July 1992. The export rebate will continue until 1992. There is no clear commercial reason why the sugar industry should supply the domestic market ahead of the export market. The choice between domestic and export disposals should be dictated by commercial realities, not political direction. As this occurs, the maximum price-which exceeds the average price-on the domestic market will come to be set at import parity plus the tariff. The tariff to apply in 1989 is similar to the current level of price support so there is no reason for an early fall in any domestic price. If world prices rise, returns from the domestic market could actually rise as a result of the tariff decision.

The industry has undergone a fundamental change since the embargo was introduced. At the time of the original Commonwealth-State agreement in 1923, much of the sugar was produced for the domestic market. Currently about 80 per cent of sugar production is exported. Of the domestic production of sugar, and I stress this, approximately 80 per cent is consumed by the food processing industry. The new arrangements will also assist those manufacturers in the food processing industry who will become more internationally competitive with their products and as a consequence we will have greater value added industries. On May 27, the Confectionery Manufacturers of Australia sent me a release which said:

Our industry had expressed concern to the Federal Government about the situation and we are pleased with its decision to deregulate prices. This announcement (the embargo decision) should begin a new era for the Australian sugar industry which will ultimately benefit consumers.

It matters little how we sell our sugar, whether we sell it in soft drink cans, whether we sell it in Europe as Bundaberg rum or whether we sell it as confectionery, provided we sell it. We have to get out of the old protected days of narrow vision that we have had to exist under for the last 30 years under the surprisingly socialistic attitudes of a State National Party conservative government. In essence, then, whilst protection for all industries is being reduced, the manufacturing industries associated with the sugar industry will substantially benefit from the decision.

The other fact is that, under the current domestic pricing arrangements, the industry has subsidised consumers as often as not. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that, in real terms, the annual average subsidy between 1971 and 1986 was $7.3m to consumers. The largest transfer to producers of $86m in real terms in 1985 was well below the transfer to consumers of $256m in 1975. The days of producers subsidising consumers are gone forever. As a result of the tariff, there will always be a net transfer to the industry which means greater assistance in the future than in the past.

The 15 per cent rate of tariff to apply in 1992 will be the same maximum applying to most other tariffs; in other words, we will have an equal playing field. This will provide more assistance to the industry than the current arrangements when the world price is more than about US11c a pound. I recognise that we have to wait and hope that the United States attacks its deficit. I acknowledge also that the United States should take a lead from Australia in free trade. We are leading the world in that now. We are leading the world in breaking down protection and that is something that everyone else in the world should be envious of. Any adverse effect will be offset by the lower costs arising from the general tariff cuts.

The National Party in Queensland, led by Senator Boswell, has tried to play upon fears of imported sugar as a result of the tariff decision. Any exporter trying to dump subsidised sugar in Australia will face two things. First, he will face the Government's powers to stop subsidised imports through the anti-dumping laws. Just as the Government acted against fertiliser and European cheeses being dumped, the Government can act to stop subsidised sugar being dumped. Fundamentally, any dumper will face the commercial strength of the Australian sugar industry. The industry operates against corrupt prices on world markets every day.

Fears have also been raised about imports from Thailand and Fiji. Such imports could occur only if the transport cost savings from those countries exceeded the protection provided by the tariff. They could occur only at very low world prices and, even then, the Government's coastal shipping policies, along with increased international freight rates, are narrowing the gap between coastal and international rates.

Unlike the Queensland National Party, the sugar industry is realistic about its future. It is prepared to accept the removal of the embargo, preferring instead to negotiate on the level of tariffs. I urge the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to examine carefully the industry's proposals. I am well satisfied that the industry is making a positive attempt to face the future.

For its part, the NFF has shown no great political courage in criticising the Queensland Government over its stance on the sugar problem. Apart from Mr Farley's commendable speech, it has allowed Mr Harper and Mr Ahern, Mr Randell and Senator Boswell to wander around in a time warp ignorant of facing up to a confident future. The NFF released figures which showed that the announced tariff reductions will mean annual cost savings of more that $2,400 per year for every farm in Australia. So it is extraordinary that a so-called free enterprise government in Queensland is ratting on the sugar industry by rejecting these initiatives.

Senator Boswell said in a report in the Bundaberg News Mail on 14 November that the sugar industry faced a loss of up to $300m annually. He and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) are now calling for a Senate inquiry into the changes. Before any inquiry is held, Senator Boswell should be aware that the entire domestic market of sugar amounts to the $300m that he believes the industry will lose. The Leader of the Opposition has run around trying to champion less government involvement. His own actions in Queensland show that he will abandon this policy, as he has tried to abandon every other decision he made when he was Federal Treasurer. A Senate inquiry would do absolutely nothing but create uncertainty in the industry. The industry accepts the decision on the lifting of the embargo. It is time that the Opposition in this place abandoned the line of the Queensland National Party and stood squarely behind the attempts to give the entire sugar industry an internationally competitive position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad moment when I have to criticise the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) for being an apologist for the Government and for getting only half of his facts straight in this regard. I must tell him, although he must know already, that it is the industry that requires a Senate inquiry, for one reason only-that the matter be fully discussed and that the industry conditions be fully examined. I am so sorry that he is now leaving the chamber and is not prepared to face up to the results of what he has said.

SPEECH.PARA: I also regret the haste with which this legislation is being introduced and the lack of time being given to debate on it. I do so particularly on behalf of the sugar industry. It is probably one of the most important measures that face the industry. While there has been a lot of public debate, there has been little Government acknowledgment of the reasons for the measure, and there will certainly not be any parliamentary debate. I also make mention of the fact that neither the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) nor the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) who, along with me, represent seats in the sugar growing area, appear on the speakers list and they are certainly not in the chamber at this stage.

I also question the Government about the sequence of presentation of legislation. Although the legislation removing the embargo was introduced last month, on 12 October, it has not yet been debated and apparently will not be debated this session, whereas the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3), dealing with sugar tariffs, which was presented only last week, is on the agenda for debate tonight and debate on it has to be curtailed because of the guillotine arrangement.

We also have the difficulty that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is not here-and not even in Australia-to face the charges. I believe the sugar industry has responded with great responsibility to the removal of the embargo when one considers the provocation it has faced from the Minister and this Government since 1984 when this Government reneged on its election promise to underwrite the sugar industry and prices and launched its policy of deregulation-in the midst of the worst droughts and disasters which have faced the industry, and certainly the worst prices ever experienced for sugar.

The Government's timing is really appalling because, during the period of deregulation, many people have been forced to quit the industry because of the high interest rate policies of this Government, the bad crops because of the drought-which still persist in some sugar growing areas of Queensland-low world prices and, as I mentioned before, the lack of the promise of support. In spite of the reversal of seasons and the low prices, there has been a revived industry that has had to discipline itself to these measures and has survived through pure efficiency and productivity. Price support for the 1985 season, half of which is rendered by the State, is the only assistance given by the Commonwealth, which promised much and delivered little. There has also been a belated interest subsidy on loans and grants towards the amalgamation of mills in certain areas. After all that, this embargo is to be removed.

What we have now is a very efficient, lean and productive industry now forced to accept this change. Of course, this change was mentioned in the May economic statement at the time when the industry and the State were setting about renegotiating the Commonwealth-State agreement by 30 June 1989. Minister Kerin came in here and announced the arrangements in the May economic statement. No notice was given to the industry. There were no negotiations and the industry was immediately notified that the embargo would be removed by 30 June 1989. Perhaps this is the Government's final response to an industry that has proved itself capable of producing for Australia and producing great exports.

There has been an acknowledgment by the industry and by the Minister that, over the last 15 years, the embargo has given stability of price to the consumer and stability of production to the industry. Yet the embargo has been removed without a trade-off in the 1992 negotiations for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. We are left with no negotiating position. I have just come back from Europe and have to say that the 1992 plan for the European Economic Community (EEC) will mean nothing for our exports. A ceiling has now been put on the subsidy, which is encouraging overproduction. The lifting of living standards in Spain, portugal and Greece can be done only by further overproduction in these nations of some of the products that we are talking about at the moment. The Government gave away a wonderful negotiating weapon by removing this embargo.

I have said that this was a provocative move and that there was a lack of consultation. In all of this, the industry, the millers and the growers behaved responsibly. Discussions between the industry and the State Government have gone on since the embargo removal was announced. Discussions have gone on between millers and growers in the different regions-all of this at a time when the seasons are still bad in some places, prices are low leading to liquidity problems, the dollar is rising and we have rising interest rates. Despite all this, they have had discussions with the Minister, who said that he would respond. The manner in which he has responded has been to push this legislation ahead of the other legislation.

All I can say at this time is that the legislation is ill-considered and ill-prepared. I say that it is ill-prepared because, while the documentation suggests that the tariff will be 35 per cent for raw sugar and 25 per cent for refined sugar, the same schedule contains a 10 per cent tariff on beet sugar. This means that beet sugar will be allowed into Australia from the most corrupt of the overproducing nations, those of the EEC. The EEC has been described as corrupt by the Minister. There will be an advantage in the case of beet sugar.

The item on which we gave away our negotiating arm, beet sugar, will be allowed in at a rate of 10 per cent. I said that the legislation was ill-prepared and hastily prepared. I want an answer from the Minister as to why that element remains in this legislation-why it is introducing higher tariffs for raw and refined sugar, but beet sugar will be allowed in without any problems. In this regard, I particularly refer to item 68 and items 1701.12.00, 1701.91.20 and 1701.91.10. I think the Queensland Canegrowers' comments should be read very carefully. What they are looking for is some correction of this rate of 10 per cent and also a better definition of what is required in that part of the Bill. They state:

Raw sugar is defined as having a pol of less then 99.5 per cent. The Sugar Board standard for Direct Consumption raws ranges from 99.0 per cent to 99.7 per cent, although most sugar is produced at 99.2 per cent to 99.4 per cent pol. However, it would be theoretically possible for a sophisticated producer such as South Africa to import raw sugar washed up to 99.55 per cent as white (to take advantage of the lower tariff) and then have it refined as if it were raw. The definition should not be based on polarisation, but on whether the sugar has been produced as a food or for further reprocessing.
It is possible for the import of say EEC Beet white as raws (below 99.5 per cent) for the lower tariff and then marketed as refined without any further value added.

The Queensland Canegrowers go on to make several other comments which, unfortunately, I am prevented from reading into Hansard. This means that the corrupted EEC sugar will be at a considerable advantage in this new tariff arrangement. This haste to legislate has given major advantages to our worst competitor who, I understand, up until a few years ago was subsidising sugar at the rate of $400 per tonne. Again I mention that we have given away all negotiating rights on that.

The industry has examined these matters and voiced its concerns with the Minister. The Minister has said that he acknowledges some of them, yet this legislation will be introduced without the benefit of any of the suggested amendments. At this stage the industry proposes that beet sugar should be treated in exactly the same way as raw or refined sugars from cane. Definitional changes previously suggested that the specific duty rate should not apply at the same rate of the ad valorem tariff but at a rate that protects the industry, up to a stage where the price of sugar is US12c a pound because after that the tariff equalises the rate. When the price falls below that-that has been the consistent level for the last three or four years-the industry wants a specific rate of duty.

Fiji should be treated in the same way as other sugar exporting countries and in this way Fiji could probably gain free duty access. Mixed with that benefit would be the cross-subsidised sales to Australia from the Lome convention and the higher price sales to the EEC. As far as Fiji is concerned that could be easily done by putting sugar on the exempt list. The 5 per cent preference for developing nations could mean that we will face a threat from Brazil and Cuba. Again we have this reduced tariff benefit for those countries.

In the anti-dumping area there is a requirement to be looked at to give us a quick trigger to react immediately so that we do not have the delay that we had with sugar. This has to be done immediately and the Government has to stop these double standards where it is prepared to accept, in some cases, that the manufacturing industries should get greater protection than other industries. All these matters are before the Minister at the moment. Where is he? He is overseas doing nothing about it.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, acknowledged this embargo. It has been discussed with the Minister but, in every respect, nothing has happened. As at 30 June 1992 the industry knows that the embargo will go. Industry is not arguing for it; in 1992 it is prepared to accept that, but it wishes to deal with the matter on the basis of the proposals that it is now putting forward. I believe that the Government has a lot to do in order to correct this situation. Therefore, we are not embarrassed in any sense whatsoever-because this legislation is not required until 1 July 1989 and because it is not a Budget measure-to ask a Senate committee to examine this proposition to remove the embargo so that it will give the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, who is at the table, an opportunity to explain what has happened and to tell us why beet sugar was not lifted to the 35 per cent level. It will also give the Minister an opportunity to acknowledge and recognise the difficulties of the industry by legislating in this House.

We are very pleased to see that because defence exports have been a grey area for many years. One of the problems has been the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade who has now moved on to higher things, for which we are grateful. We want to see guidelines for these defence exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important for this country that our defence exports are liberalised in conjunction with all our exports. We badly need some guidelines for Australian business. I think the main problem area has been covered before in this debate. It is all very well to liberalise defence exports amongst other exports but we still have to get our productivity down so that we can sell these goods overseas. I was very pleased to see that a defence mission has been sent to South East Asia this week. Until we get our productivity up and until our productivity improves in this country our chances of exporting the products from our defence industry, which are growing almost month by month in this country, are nil. No-one who has any interest in this area who sees the future of Australia in productive positive terms could but agree that, until we ease up the labour market in this country and get our productivity up, there will be no future for defence exports or anything else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very little has been said about the fact that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988 writes into tariff law the tariff changes proposed in the May mini-Budget. They amounted to a general reduction of tariffs of the order of 20 per cent spread over four years. I think it is important to note that that is an extremely modest change. Honourable members might think back in history and remember the 25 per cent change in one fell swoop in 1973 under the previous Labor Government. But this is a very modest change. I want to recognise that it is part of a whole program of structural reform, structural adjustment and increased market efficiency-so-called micro-economic reform-to which the Government pays a great deal of lip service but does very little. Such a program would embrace movements on many fronts as well as this attempt to improve efficiency through reducing tariffs in this way. It would also embrace the combating of restrictive work practices, reform of the country's transport infrastructure-things such as the waterfront and coastal shipping, a sensible program of deregulation and privatisation, a general program of reducing other business regulation and, above all, reform of the country's inflexible and centralised wages system, to which my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) referred a moment ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to this ever so modest reduction in the general level of protection, I want to stress that one of the reasons why it cannot be bigger than it is-though honourable members might say, as Dr Johnson commented on his friend's dog walking on its hind legs, `The wonder is that it happened at all'-is that, where the Government does not accept its reciprocal obligation to free up the wages level and reduce the cost and regulatory burdens on industry, nothing much can be done.
