DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 is an omnibus piece of legislation dealing with a diverse range of subjects, some of which are not related to my own shadow portfolio of health. The proposed amendments also impact upon the areas of housing and nursing homes, and my colleagues the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), respectively, will comment upon these areas=mif time allows. I add that comment because it is outrageous that the Government has not allowed sufficient opportunity for this legislation to be fully debated in this chamber. Debate on the Bill is subject to the guillotine and will be cut short at 10 o'clock. In light of that fact, I would like to foreshadow an in-principle amendment, which will be moved at the appropriate time in this debate, and further amendments which we will be forced to move in the Senate because of the lack of time in this chamber. The in-principle amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its concern about deficiencies and inequities in the Medicare health care system;
(2) deplores the way in which Government policies have had, and continue to have, a negative impact upon health insurance funds; and
(3) calls upon the Government to ensure that its policies are conducive to fostering the delivery of the best possible health services to the people of this nation'.

In the Senate we will move amendments to oppose clauses 12 and 13 of the Bill which propose amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 to remove Australians' entitlement to Medicare rebates for medical and pathology services received overseas. As my colleague the honourable member for Dawson will tell the House, we will also in the Senate oppose clause 29 relating to requests for the review of the decisions on nursing homes made under the National Health Act 1953. The fact that we are not planning to oppose the amendments to clause 7 (3), which redefines the terms `hospital treatment' and `nursing home-type patient', cannot, however, be taken as a sign of our blanket endorsement of them.

These amendments have been precipitated by the decision of some Victorian health funds to question their legal obligation to pay benefits to around 250 of their contributors who are nursing home-type patients in private bush hospitals. We deplore the big stick approach which the Government has taken to deal with the health funds' very legitimate concerns about their ability to continue to cover such expenses. After all, if these patients lived in the city, they would be supported by the Government either in a nursing home or in a public hospital. But the fact that these country people have no ready access to either of these facilities means that both they and their private health funds have been placed in a very difficult situation. This is a disgraceful state of affairs which was not helped by the initial reaction of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in which he branded the funds as `callous' and described their action as `unacceptable'. What the Opposition, and I suspect the vast majority of Australians, finds really `unacceptable' is the speed with which the Minister was willing to blame someone else for a problem of his own making.

Almost since the first day it took office the Hawke-Keating Government has endeavoured to centralise and socialise the delivery of health care. Over the last five years its policies in relation to the private health care sector can be likened to a classical military campaign based on the slow but sure destruction of supply and support for `the enemy'. In the Government's view the enemy is the medical profession and the private health funds.

The first shots in this campaign were, not surprisingly, fired at the health funds; their sin being that they were a party to supplying both doctors and patients with an alternative to government funding. Within days of Labor assuming office the Health Insurance Commission had a blueprint for Medicare on the Minister's desk. Using this as ammunition, the Government acted swiftly and decisively to cut off the principal source of doctors' revenue. This was achieved by making it illegal for anyone-other than the Government-to provide insurance for medical expenses. So, in one fell swoop, the Government effectively cut the medical professions' principal supply line. By giving itself a monopoly in relation to insurance for medical costs, it took the first steps towards making members of the medical profession reliant upon it, and to a lesser extent their patients, for their income and support. It had fired its first broadside at the health insurance industry in this way.

Just before Medicare was introduced the Minister was telling everyone that the cost of private health insurance under Medicare would be no more than $5 a week. That this has not proved to be the case is glaringly obvious to anyone who knows anything about private health insurance. The overwhelming majority of those with insurance are currently each week paying around $9 per person, or $18 per family, for their cover. This is almost double what the Minister said would be the top rate. The reason for this massive rise in contribution rates is the Government's socialised health care system-better known as Medicare.

By promising that Medicare would deliver universal free medical and hospital services the Government removed the incentives for people to take out private insurance. But, not content with this encouragement strategy, it then went on to the second stage of its campaign against the private health funds. In a series of raids, it set about creating real disincentives for people to remain in the funds, or to join them in the first place. By way of a number of actions the Government contrived to impose greater and greater burdens on the health funds and their contributors.

Time in this guillotined debate does not permit me to list each and every one of these actions, but let me put forward a few. In 1983 the Government slashed its contribution to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund from $100m to just $20m. And, I might add, it has continued to savage the fund, to the point where in the current financial year it stands at about $1m.

In 1984 the funds were forced into holding two months contribution income in reserve. In 1985 they were made responsible for the cost of prosthetic implants previously paid for by the state. Insured patients admitted to public hospitals were automatically classified as private, and therefore a liability for the funds, unless they specifically opted to be treated as a Medicare patient.

In 1986 the Commonwealth bed-day subsidy to private hospitals was abolished. This forced the funds to lift their rates to raise the same amount as the previous subsidy. A further $7.2m was added to the funds' expenses by charging repatriation patients holding health insurance as `private'. In 1987 the medical gap was increased to 25 per cent of the schedule fee, without any `cap', costing the funds, and their contributors, an estimated $105m.

Furthermore, the funds were forced to pay basic table benefits for 42 and 49 days respectively for psychiatric and rehabilitation patients, and to increase the basic table benefits for private hospital patients. The total extra cost to the funds of these last two actions has been estimated at $95m. Now, in 1988, we have these moves incorporated in this legislation to legally bind the funds to provide benefits for long term nursing home-type patients occupying hospital beds.

All in all, what these actions on the part of the Government add up to is much more expensive health insurance. Contribution rates are constantly rising, membership rates are declining, and the proportion of high risk members is on the up and up as the funds try desperately to keep their heads above water. Small wonder then, that they should start to question their ability to continue to pay benefits for the hospital expenses of nursing home-type patients and continue to question their legal obligation to do so.

That we are not opposing the amendments compelling the funds to support these people does not, however, mean that we have joined the Government's fight against private health interests. Instead, it is due to our appreciation of the fact that these nursing home-type patients are the innocent victims of both the long running war which the Government is waging against the funds, and of its failure to provide an adequate supply of nursing home beds for what we know to be a rapidly ageing population. These people have already been caused a great deal of anxiety and uncertainty about their position. We will, therefore, allow the passage of the amendments so that they need have no further fears about their future care. In doing so, however, I would like to remind the Minister that on 9 November he told the House:
The Government is prepared to work with the funds and the State Government on particular problems involving aged and long-stay patients . . .
I ask the Minister to keep the Parliament informed about the commencement and progress of these negotiations.

I turn now to part III of the Bill which, among other things, seeks to remove Australians' entitlement to Medicare benefits for medical and pathology services received overseas after 1 January 1989. As I said before, this is a move which we will oppose at the committee stage in the Senate. We will do so because we believe it to be patently unfair for the Government to slug taxpayers 1.25 per cent of their income for the compulsory Medicare levy, while at the same time denying them access to rebates. I am not arguing with the Government's view that people should protect themselves with travel insurance because of the extremely high cost of health care in many other parts of the world, but I do not accept and we do accept, that those Australians who pay their taxes, and their Medicare levy, should lose their entitlement to the Medicare rebate simply because they had to seek medical attention in another country. Nor do I accept that reciprocal health agreements, as they currently stand, are sufficient compensation for lopping off people's claims under Medicare.

After all, as the Minister said in his speech, there are only four such agreements in place-with the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta and Italy, and two more, with Sweden and Portugal, are close to being finalised. While making no great claims about the extent of my knowledge of geography, I nevertheless believe that it is fair to say that even when Sweden and Portugal enter the scheme of things there will still be many places in the world not covered. Indeed, there are probably a great number of them which will never be covered, including the United States where health care costs are very high. So, it is patently arrant nonsense for the Minister to claim that reciprocal agreements are a more `appropriate and effective means of providing health care cover for Australian travellers abroad'. Undoubtedly, there are many instances where the Medicare rebate does not go anywhere near the actual cost, nevertheless it represents some form of cover or reimbursement to which payers of the levy are clearly entitled. Its removal will place those Australians who go overseas for extended periods of time at the greatest disadvantage. I ask the Minister to take for example people on a six to 12-month academic exchange program, or those who are posted overseas by their employer. They will still be paying their taxes on their Australian wages and still having the Medicare levy ripped off them, but they will derive no benefit from it whatsoever. Of course it could be argued that even if one stays at home there is not much benefit to be gained from Medicare. As Des Keegan wrote in last Saturday's Weekend Australian:

So we have Labor's `free' health scheme, whereby we must have private insurance to put a foot on a hospital bed in sickness. Labor holds illusions in its magic gift, including `free' health for 1.25 per cent of our gross pay. Labor voters on average wages get paupers' beds.

The only way one can be certain to get immediate access to medical and hospital treatment under Medicare is to pay and pay. To have private insurance on top of the compulsory Medicare levy is, in effect, double taxation. What Australians who travel abroad have now is the prospect of triple taxation-the Medicare levy, private insurance and travel insurance-just so they can be reimbursed or compensated in some way for going to the doctor overseas. This is patently unfair, and a far cry from the all-encompassing health care system we were told we would get under Medicare.

In the final analysis what it all gets down to is cost. The Government must face up to the reality that its own grand design has simply proved to be too expensive. But, rather than admit that it has got it wrong-that Medicare is the disaster many predicted it would be-the Government is intent on propping it up by tinkering away at the edges. Fiddling with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the schedule for pathology rebates, the rules governing eligibility for Medicare rebates and so on, will not solve the problem-nor will a continuation of the Government's campaign against the private health funds.

It is high time that the Government and the responsible Minister realised that trying to keep health care costs within affordable bounds, while maintaining Medicare, is like fighting with one hand tied behind one's back. What we need is a better health care system, one in which costs are more fairly shared, where the delivery of services is fairly shared and where Australians can have immediate access to the highest quality attention, treatment and care. There was a time when this was the sort of health care system which we had. That this is no longer the case is due to the misguided policies of this Government and for that it deserves the strongest possible condemnation. It can continue its battles against the private health interests for as long as it likes. But, if it does, it should be prepared not only to lose a few minor skirmishes, or the odd campaign, but at the end of the day the whole war and government office as well. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its concern about deficiencies and inequities in the Medicare health care system;
(2) deplores the way in which Government policies have had, and continue to have, a negative impact upon health insurance funds; and
(3) calls upon the Government to ensure that its policies are conducive to fostering the delivery of the best possible health services to the people of this nation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many very serious health issues facing this country. If I can have your indulgence for half a minute, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will have one small swipe at the media. In the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday of this week there was the headline `Relax sex laws and abort AIDS babies: Government paper'. I am sure all honourable members who heard the tabling of the Government's paper on its proposals for the treatment of human immunodeficiency virus in this country will understand that that headline in no way outlines the very serious problems or the great extent and depth of the Government's paper. I suppose it is a further example of the sort of discussion we have in the newspapers on health care in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We find ourselves tonight, after 5 1/2 years in government, with the fifth Opposition spokesman on health, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), and still the Opposition does not have a policy on health care and still it has no proposals as to how it would go about delivering health care. There is never a word of encouragement of any suggestion that in some way we have been successful. All we get is carping criticism.

The Opposition sheds crocodile tears because nursing home patients in private hospitals are experiencing difficulties with health insurance in Victoria. The Opposition expresses concern about these people and about the Government's treatment of them. But we must understand that it was a Liberal government that established the category of nursing home-type patients in private hospitals. That system has been in place for 10 years and the health funds have been delivering payment for those patients for 10 years. Now they are trying to renege on that responsibility. That category was introduced by a Liberal government, it has been in place for 10 years and we have supported it. Now the Opposition is supporting its removal. I find that unbelievable. The Opposition spokesman talks about a monopoly being created by the Government in health insurance. The effect of that was to save the Australian taxpayers something like $100m in administrative expenses. The removal of duplication of a number of health insurance funds and services was desirable. The centralisation of statistics and the improvement in the functioning of the system have been readily endorsed by a number of surveys which have shown that patients and taxpayers in his country support the Government's action.

The Opposition also sheds crocodile tears about the fact that the doctors' source of income has been reduced to income from the Government only and that in some way this means that they have been disadvantaged. But we have a whole raft of professionals-chiropractors, dentists, psychologists and all sorts of other people-who would love to be in a situation in which their incomes were underwritten by the Government. Day after day I receive requests from such groups that they be considered for access to Medicare. I cannot accept the Opposition's criticism because we have provided access, equity, universality and simplicity. We have also provided something which is just as important and which every government must consider, and that is accountability and cost containment. That is very important. When we look overseas we see, for example, that the United Kingdom is restricting access of people to kidney dialysis machines. If one is more than 55 years of age, one is not eligible. If one wants a hip operation in the United Kingdom and one is more than 65 years old, one is not eligible. Those restrictions are anathema to our system. This Government would not consider them. But clearly, very serious constraints have to be provided on the public delivery of health care. In this country we have been able to contain costs and provide a service which covers everyone.

Again we see crocodile tears being shed by members of the Opposition about the fact that this Government proposes that when Australians travel overseas they should take out private health insurance. At the moment only 50 per cent of Australians who travel abroad take out private health insurance; the other 50 per cent believe that they are covered. However, when one compares health costs in Australia with those in the United States of America one realises that there is a massive difference. The Medicare rebate which is payable to those people who have procedures performed in the United States is totally inadequate and if people are not covered by private health insurance they will suffer. After 1 January, when this legislation is in place, most people will know exactly where they stand and Australians travelling overseas will take a more responsible attitude. They will not believe that they are covered when they are not. Clearly if someone has a problem of a long term nature or a pre-existing ailment, his or her option is to return to Australia and have it dealt with by our system. But for emergency care-and this is why we take out travel insurance, for things that happen while we are on holiday and which cannot be anticipated-private health insurance is a perfectly reasonable expectation by this Government.

Concern has been expressed about that, but when one looks at the situation in the United States one finds that it costs as much as $2,000 a day for health care in that country. If one is in hospital for 10 days as a result of, say, appendicitis or a car accident, one is looking at a bill of $20,000 or $30,000. Clearly anyone who travels overseas and does not take out health insurance is risking the cost of that bill. There is no way that those expenses would in any way be covered by the Medicare rebate because in Australia our system is much cheaper. We have contained costs effectively because our system is not open-ended like that in the United States. Because we do all that and cover everybody, we are very fortunate. We should understand that, and clearly most health professionals do so.

One of the other purposes of this Bill is to define who is eligible; and we will restrict the eligibility of Medicare benefits to persons residing in Australia on a legally permanent basis. Again, this is something that was overlooked in the initial legislation. In that, the entitlement was for all people resident in this country. Thus we have had an anomaly in the system since the legislation was introduced in 1984. The amendment may create problems for overseas students and visitors from countries with which we do not have a reciprocal agreement. It may also cause problems for those who are illegal immigrants, pending consideration of their cases. I suppose that in that regard there needs to be some consideration given to providing within the health care system-perhaps through the private health funds-some sort of special hospital and medical cover for those people. I understand that the Department of Community Services and Health is already looking at this. It is certainly something we need to consider because there will be a group of people who will be left out of the system.

Another concern of mine is one that we often have as members of Parliament. This arises when an elderly person wishes to come to Australia as part of a family reunion program. Quite clearly we are concerned about the costs that an elderly person might accrue against our health budget. It is unreasonable for Australian taxpayers to be expected to take up that cost. I believe there needs to be consideration of some way in which those who wish to sponsor elderly relatives from overseas can have a special benefit or some means of covering those elderly relatives.

The legislation covers a large number of areas of Government policy. We have already heard about the nursing home aspect and I do not intend to follow that here except to say that by providing for exempted nursing homes we will be able, in some way, to defray the costs and make those who are very fortunate in their old age and who are able to pay a higher cost in some nursing homes look after their own considerations in that regard. I am sure that in some way that will improve access to nursing homes for more people.

Finally, I wish to mention a topical matter-the contents-based Medicare service schedule that has been put forward by the Australian Medical Association (AMA). From my experience I have found that general practitioners usually work very hard for their money. They deliver services on a fee for service basis, so they have to see a large number of patients if they are to make themselves a reasonable income. The majority are dedicated, sincere, caring and competent doctors. I think it is rather exceptional to find a greedy, unprofessional doctor. While some of the procedural specialists have probably floated on the coat tails of technological advancement and have therefore done quite well for a while, those concerned have been addressed by this Government and are continuing to be addressed. The AMA's advocacy of a contents-based proposal was clearly badly timed and overzealous. Concern for patients was completely lacking. It is interesting to note that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners has now come together with the Government to establish a group to look into a contents-based schedule-something which the Government does not disagree with in principle, but which needs more work and consideration. Indeed, its hasty appearance and introduction by the AMA was unnecessary and uncalled for.

I suppose only a few of us will get the opportunity to speak tonight but I take this opportunity to support the legislation. I reject the Opposition's amendments. I reject its criticism of the Medicare scheme. Clearly it is a scheme that patients and the majority of doctors are comfortable with. Clearly it is something that in this country has provided us with a very efficient health care system of which we should be very proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), complained about the lack of people participating in this debate. May I say that he has only his own Government to blame. This is a major piece of legislation where major initiatives could have been taken. We are limited to one hour for debate and in that time very few speakers will be able to address this important question affecting the health and well-being of every Australian. So if the honourable member does have a complaint he should take it to the door of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples).
—I would have spoken longer but you rang my office.
—You were on for 10 minutes and you went over your time. You did not say anything in any case.
—Order! The honourable member for Dawson will direct his remarks through the Chair.

—There was very little involved in his 10-minute or over speech that really faced up to the issues that Australians are looking at. I understand that I am limited to 10 minutes. Because of that I can deal with only four areas relating to the nursing homes section. I again note for the second time in a debate tonight that the responsible Minister, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, is not here, and I think that is a shame. The four items I wish to mention are nursing home beds and their relationship to the private hospitals; respite care; the exempt home situation-members of the Government think this will be the best thing since sliced bread for the private operators; and the cost of appeals.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to examine the situation of nursing homes throughout Australia. I have with me a press clipping from the Border Morning Mail newspaper of 28 October headed `Nursing homes ``Face big cuts''.' It reads:
Victorian nursing homes face staff cuts of up to 30 per cent because of changes to Commonwealth funding, it was claimed yesterday.
The president of the Voluntary Care Association of Victoria, Mr Brian Moss, described the cuts as an exercise in mediocrity.
I can only suggest that in saying that he is attributing the fall in standards to the Government's reaction to the problems. The article continued:
He said funds were based on 18 hours of nursing and personal care for each resident.
`My nursing home has an average of 28 hours,' . . .
Mr Moss went on to say:
They are pushing us down to a level, the level has been set too low.

The nursing home operators say that there is great secrecy, that there is no way in which they can determine the workings of the Department and how the care aggregate module (CAM) calculation has been made up. I understand that freedom of information efforts have failed because the Government says that these figures were projections and that, even though the projections were for last year, they cannot be applied for under freedom of information. The Border Morning Mail has hit it right on the head. In Victoria particularly the standard of care is being lowered and, by implication, the standard of living of all residents.

The health insurance funds have seen a dramatic decline over the past nine years. They are now insuring nursing home patients. I understand that in 1979 an arrangement was worked out with the insurance funds that this would be the case. One must consider that over the nine years of the Labor Government we have seen the financial health of the insurance funds decline dramatically. They have no reserves; they are not allowed to have them. They are being asked now to insure patients who should be in nursing homes. Because of the lack of facilities, those patients are in bush nursing homes, not at public expense but at private expense, and the funds are being asked to pick up the cost.

This raises the matter of the great lack of nursing home beds in Victoria. The Bush Nursing Association is picking up those people in their private hospitals but they are not covered by any State grant because of Medicare and they are being refused the funds that are normally made available to nursing home operators. We have seen a change from deficit funding under the old Act, which I will admit indicated in many cases that, on a cost plus basis, there were not the necessary disciplines applied within the operation of those funds. We have turned to a completely different situation where there is a lack of disclosure, particularly in relation to the calculation formula under the standard aggregate module (SAM) and CAM. The situation in Victorian and South Australian nursing homes is that they have been set standards of care by their State governments. There is no way the Commonwealth will fund up to that standard, so there is a conflict between the two governments and the nursing home operators are caught in the centre. One group which operates in the charitable area said they are fast ceasing to be volunteer carers in the community and are becoming economic survivors. All the volunteers do now is scratch from one moment to the next in order to keep the establishment open on the lower scale of fees.

Complaints are also rife within the community about the resident classification instrument, which is set, I understand, on a five-scale model. Category one, which is the highest subsidised area, is calculated at only 10 per cent of the total residency of the nursing homes. The geriatric assessments team goes around making assessments on these five categories, obviously with the intention of getting more patients up into the higher end of the categories and fewer at the lower end, where they would attract a greater subsidy. This is duplication in its own way because the nursing homes have resident doctors who make these assessments all the time to make sure that they fit into the right slot as far as the standard of care is concerned, and they are the ones who would know best.

I have already mentioned the changes that were made to the funding of nursing homes in 1979 by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) when he was Minister. There was open competition for funds at that time. I also mention that the Commonwealth's contribution to the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund has decreased from $100m to $1m, without any reserves.

I have already mentioned respite homes. May I complain about the use of esoteric terms by this Department. We have the classic `resident classification instrument'. Even a Rhodes scholar would not be able to describe what that was. As to the definition of respite home, it took six months in my city, and I believe right round Australia, for people to appreciate what a respite bed was. Of course, this appears in the Bill solely because of the drafting errors in the Bill passed earlier this year. Section 49aa was inserted into the National Health Act 1953 in June. It will be replaced by a new section, the objective being to provide for new arrangements on respite care to be prescribed in detail by regulation. The Government is looking at two respite case places per 1,000 persons within hostels and nursing homes. It is interesting to see the calculation whereby the Government intends to have 4,000 places available by 1995. In June 1987 the number of aged residents in Australia aged 70 and over was 1,147,238. The provision of nursing home and hostel beds at the rate of two beds per 1,000 people would mean that there is a requirement right now for 4,588 beds; yet by 1995 the Government hopes to reach only 4,000. That is not the main object of this legislation.

I shall now deal with exempt homes. The honourable member for Perth, who spoke for the Government on this Bill, said that allowing those people who can afford to pay to do so would be a great way for the Government to reduce the demands on the funds. It is interesting to look at the second reading speech and to consider the massive government controls involved. It is doubtful whether there would be an opportunity for anyone to take any financial advantage from the exemption, particularly as it is only a 12-month licence. Where an operation changes to an exempt home, a person who cannot afford the fees is exempt for six months and then in 18 months has to find alternative nursing home accommodation, which runs well over the 12-month licence period. We look forward to seeing whether that can operate effectively in the community.

The measure we are complaining about to a large extent concerns the appeals related to fees charged by nursing homes. A memo went out to nursing homes well in advance of this legislation being tabled in this House notifying them of this measure. It results from the mess-up which has resulted from CAM and the intention to harmonise subsidies by 1992. Because of the difficulty in getting records for substantiation purposes, nursing homes that have had a claim have been submitting these appeals, which no doubt have flooded the Department. The Department is really judging Caesar on its own terms. We believe that it is the Minister who should make these decisions. He should make available the calculations regarding how CAM is really meant to work. The responsibility for the appeals should rest on his shoulders. We see the initial $500 fee for the appeal submission and the $500 fee per half day after that as being a blatant attempt by the Department to frighten off anybody who might want to make a claim. I believe that has already happened in many cases because of a lack of response.

We have an Administrative Appeals Tribunal which can intervene directly in matters between people and the Government. A limited cost applies. We wonder why the fees are set at the amount prescribed in the legislation in such a unique situation. If time for debate had not been limited, in the committee stage we would have opposed that aspect of the legislation. We will certainly do so in the Senate because we believe that the responsibility should be directly with the Minister. There are many things I would have liked to have said but cannot do so because of the shortage of time. I hope that after 12 months operation of these new terms, particularly those concerning the exempt nursing homes, the Department will review the situation to see whether a change is necessary. Again, we do not like the heavy-handed attitude of the Minister in bringing down the legislation in the way he has done. The legislation treats every private operator as a cheat and a thief. The second reading speech reveals massive discrimination against private operators. I would have liked the Minister to have been in the House to respond to the limited addresses we have been able to make to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before us tonight, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), is an omnibus Bill which makes various changes in the area of the community services and health portfolio. Amongst the schemes that have minor amendments made to them in this Bill is the first home owners scheme. Amendments are made to the definition of `Australian residents' under the Health Insurance Act. The Bill contains provisions in regard to the cost of medical services incurred overseas. As alluded to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the Bill makes changes to the treatment of nursing home-type patients. The proposed amendments in this area remove a technical anomaly in the legislation which is now being exploited by some health funds for the first time since the legislation made provision for nursing home-type patients in hospitals in 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous speaker, who spoke in his capacity as the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, talked his usual nonsense about the subject. He excused the behaviour of the private health funds towards nursing home-type patients on the grounds that the private health funds were unhealthy. He said that private funds were not permitted to have reserve funds. That is complete rubbish. The honourable member should be aware that, as of June 1987, private funds had some $660m in reserve funds. By June 1988 this sum had increased to $812m. So, contrary to what the honourable member said, the health of the private funds is quite good. If the honourable member needs further evidence, perhaps he could look at Australia's Health-the first biennial report by the Australian Institute of Health. A table on page 142 of that report indicates the number of contributors to hospital funds. One can see how it is levelled off, despite the universal nature of cover under Medicare. The figures given in the report dispel the nonsense that private health funds are in any way at present unhealthy.

I want to comment mainly on the changes to nursing homes. The section of the Bill that relates to aged care is one of a series of amendments which have been or will be introduced to implement this Government's comprehensive reform of the nursing home and hostel industry. The amendments to the National Health Act 1953 contained in the Bill before the House should be seen as a part of this comprehensive reform process. The aim of the Government's reform has been the introduction of a fairer and more equitable system for the aged in our community. These reforms will put aged care services on a rational and integrated basis that will serve the needs of Australia's rapidly growing aged population in the next decade and beyond.

This strategy is underpinned by some basic principles. Firstly, aged people should as far as possible be supported in their homes and in their communities. Secondly, aged people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs. This clearly reflects the community's preference. As the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has indicated, Government research has shown that older people much prefer to retain their independence, living at home for as long as possible. That is the norm. As people get older they much prefer to be in familiar surroundings, in the neighbourhood in which they have established their home, to go to the same shops, to relate in the course of normal daily living to the things they are used to.

The Government's home and community care (HACC) program has been successful in providing necessary support services to people at risk of entering residential care which allows them to remain in their own homes. Where older people are in need of residential care, the Government has been determined to ensure that it is affordable, efficient and of the highest possible standard. For many years it has been recognised that nursing home and hostel services in this country need a substantial overhaul. Nursing home funding arrangements were hampered by excessive regulation. There was no incentive to use resources efficiently. There was a percentage of fraud and abuse of the system. As a consequence, the taxpayer, the resident and his family were faced with unrealistically inflated costs.

The Government has indicated its firm resolve to ensure that this system is reformed. The standardisation of fees in non-government nursing homes will ensure that by 1991 no resident shall be required to pay more than 87.5 per cent of his pension plus rent assistance. The impact of these reforms will be to bring the Government's social justice objectives in the area of aged care within reach.

All aged people, regardless of income, will have reasonable access to care. This will see an end to discrimination against those less well off. It will represent a major step forward in bringing some much needed relief to the families of those needing residential care who are currently required to top up unaffordable fees. It will go a long way to preventing the present situation, where those who have enough money can buy their way into nursing homes at the expense of those who cannot. It will ensure a security of tenure for our frail aged in homes. It will mean that access to care is determined on the basis of need and that people can plan ahead for an ageing family on the basis of known costs. Since the early 1970s numerous reports and investigations have demanded reform of the aged care system. The Hawke Government is the first government to act on this matter to the benefit of all Australians. Perhaps it is another area in the general concept of those areas that may or may not be open to expenditure cuts if people like the shadow finance spokesman, who is in the chamber at the moment, had his way with the review of Government outlays. Again the shadow Ministers responsible should be sitting down and talking with him to see whether their pet areas are the areas which will go under the knife, because certainly in the overall economic rhetoric of those opposite, where they talk about the need to contain Government expenditure, one always has to wonder where exactly any of these cuts that are suggested will occur. So it is another of those areas where we have to wait and see whether the Opposition is able to grasp the nettle and take the necessary action to put before the Australian public any opposing policies to the present Government that can stand up to rigorous contemplation before going to any future elections.

As I said, the provisions before honourable members in this Bill are further steps in the major review in many areas, as the Minister put it in his second reading speech, of provision of human services. They are areas of which this Government has not lost sight. Often there is some reflection on whether this Government has lost sight of what its traditional base is looking for. In the portfolio of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) we have made definite efforts to improve the lot of those less fortunate. We have gone a long way to tackling the provision of services which will go towards the social justice objectives of the Government. I have no trouble tonight in supporting this legislation and I congratulate the Minister and his colleague the Minister for Housing and Aged Care on their progressive implementation of the policies under review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the aspect of this legislation that compels the health insurance funds to pay hospital benefits to nursing home patients who are in hospitals. It has come about by a decision of the Health Benefits Council of Victoria to withdraw health benefits cover from long stay patients in country hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is supporting this legislation out of concern as to the effect of this decision on many elderly and infirm patients around Victoria. However, the Opposition does not agree with the assessment of the situation by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The Minister has stated that the funds have a legal and moral obligation to pay the benefits. Perhaps we could examine this situation a little more closely.

First, the legal obligation seems somewhat hollow if the Minister is now having to introduce legislation to compel the health funds to do as he wishes. However, more important is the moral obligation. The Minister states that the health insurance funds have looked after such patients since 1979. This is quite correct. However, the Minister conveniently omits several points. He omits to say that starting in 1979, the Federal Government also made a decision to help fund nursing home-type patients by substantial contributions to the reinsurance pool, initially, to the value of $50m raising it to $100m in 1981.

The Minister further neglected to say that the then Federal Government's contribution to the reinsurance pool replaced its provision of a system of accounts which attended to the payment of benefits to long stay patients. Hence, the coalition Government had accepted a share of the responsibility-a moral responsibility-for the finance of nursing home-type patient costs in hospitals from well before 1979. The Minister finally neglected to say that it was the Hawke Government that in 1983 withdrew substantially from this responsibility when it cut the $100m contribution to $20m and in subsequent cuts to the present token $1m.

However, this sad and pathetic situation has not just come about because of the Government's total lack of moral obligation to elderly Australians via the reinsurance pool. There are five other factors that have caused this situation. The first is the Government's lack of action on the longstanding shortage of nursing home beds in Victoria. Victoria has the lowest number of nursing home beds per head of aged population of any State in Australia. This is particularly critical in country areas. It has been exacerbated by the Government's new residential classification instrument that effectively seeks to put frail, aged people in arbitrarily deemed categories 4 and 5 out of nursing homes.

Secondly, the Government's policy since the introduction of Medicare has led to a decline in the proportion of Australians covered by private insurance from 72 per cent in 1982-83 to just over 47 per cent today. This is the lowest level of coverage since private health insurance statistics were first taken out in the mid-1970s. Tragically, for the funds and for elderly Australians, it has been the fit, young people that have been leaving private health insurance funds and leaving the funds to cope with an ever-increasing burden of looking after aged people.

Thirdly, the Government has enabled Medibank Private to transfer profits from Victoria to other States to effectively undercut established health funds around Australia. This option is not available to other health insurance funds and this special treatment and uneven playing field has contributed to the crisis that we face today.

Fourthly, the Government has specifically prevented funds from accumulating special reserves for long term hospital patients, and then it complains when the funds have difficulty in meeting those obligations. They are not general reserves, as the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) referred to them; they are special reserves.

Fifthly, the Government has added a burden of $500m on Australians with private health insurance in the last five years. Specifically the Government has abolished the Commonwealth subsidy to patients in private hospitals, costing the funds $140m. The Government has reduced the Medicare benefit for medical services for privately insured hospital patients from 85 per cent to 75 per cent of the scheduled fee, lifted the $20 cap, and cost the funds $105m. It has required the health funds to pay for prostheses and it has determined that insured patients in public hospitals be deemed private. All this, plus the $99m reduction in the reinsurance pool, has added a $500m burden directly onto Australians who have health insurance and has directly caused this sad and sorry mess the Government is now attempting to remedy.

The Minister has said that the health funds have a moral obligation to pay these long stay patients' costs, because they have taken premiums for 20 to 30 years. Of elderly Victorians who must find nursing home accommodation in private hospitals, the average length of stay is 636 days at a cost to the health funds of $83 a day. The average cost per patient is $52,800. At a current health premium rate of $7.10 per week, it would take 142 years to recover such costs, and that is even without any other claims being made of the health funds. The health funds could afford to do this when a large number of healthy young people had basic health insurance. But, as we have seen, the Government's actions have driven these people out of the health funds and created the mess we see today.

In looking at the state of our health insurance industry, I wish to read from the report of the committee of inquiry into the operations of the voluntary health insurance scheme. Its conclusions were:
The operation of the health insurance scheme is unnecessarily complex and beyond the comprehension of many.
The benefits received by contributors are frequently much less than the cost of hospital and medical treatment.
The contributions have increased to such an extent that they are beyond the capacity of some members of the community and involve considerable hardship for others . . .
An unduly high proportion of the contributions received by some organisations are absorbed in operating expenses . . .
The cost of illness may include, in addition to hospital accommodation, treatment and medical services, a wide range of other services which have never been covered by the health insurance scheme.

That was from the Nimmo report of 1969. Nothing has changed. After four years of Medicare we still find the health insurance system facing the same problems that it had 19 years ago. So much for reform!

Finally, in attempting to compel the health funds to finance long stay patients, the Government is itself failing to address the central issue of nursing home-type patients-namely, whose responsibility are the aged and the chronically ill in society? The Government's actions have clearly shown that it believes that the responsibility does not lie with itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst Opposition members welcome the changes to the first home owners scheme that appears in this legislation, we have very deep concern about the way the Government has been reducing funding very substantially to that particular scheme, particularly at a time when first home owners are being crippled by rising housing costs.
