SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill. The theme I will develop is one that focuses on the hypocrisy, arrogance and intellectual dishonesty of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). However, before I do that it is important to recognise the economic background against which we consider this Bill. We have just seen a balance of payments deficit for October of about $1.7 billion, which included a record trade deficit of $681m and, in my view, a structurally weak and deteriorating balance of payments position. Any piece of legislation that deals with foreign investment against that sort of background is worthy of careful consideration, especially when it sets out to impede certain parts of the necessary investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition parties do not oppose the Bill; however we oppose those clauses in the Bill that enable the Government virtually to ban the foreign purchase of urban real estate. As a result, in the committee stage I will move amendments to strike out those relevant clauses. It is our view that the pre-September 1987 foreign investment guidelines on urban real estate, which were already fairly restrictive-and I emphasise that-are more important to the economic conditions of Australia and so we support them as opposed to what we see as the Treasurer's fairly knee-jerk ban. To be clear, we are not for open slather, as the Treasurer has tried to suggest on several occasions; we support the pre-September 1987 position, and I emphasise that point.

The Bill provides a number of changes to the treatment of foreign investors. Indeed, most of the changes actually relax the restrictions on foreign investment. None the less, the key point of the Bill, to my mind, is that it puts into place the mechanisms for the implementation of the Treasurer's announced ban on foreign purchase of developed residential real estate, that is, a ban on access to urban housing. What the Bill actually contains is the legislative requirements for foreign purchasers of urban real estate to notify the Treasurer of the transactions. The Treasurer is also given the power to stop the transaction if he considers that it would be contrary to the national interest. The Treasurer will decide the national interest based on guidelines laid down in a press release of 29 September 1987.

Briefly stated, the Treasurer believes that the national interest is best served by this sort of knee-jerk ban. Approval for the foreign purchase of developed residential properties will not be granted except in three very limited circumstances-Australian citizens living abroad, intending migrants who have received approval to take up permanent residence in Australia, and foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives resident in Australia. As I said previously, the new guidelines replace more relaxed and yet fairly restrictive rules that allowed the acquisition by a foreigner of a property or a number of properties when the cumulative total of the foreigner's purchase did not exceed $600,000 since June 1978. Subject to this and a few other exceptions, prior to the introduction of the ban in September last year acquisition of developed residential real estate for investment purposes was normally not approved.

I want to make several comments about this Bill. As I said, my theme will draw the attention of the House to what I consider to be almost unbounded hypocrisy, unbounded arrogance and unbounded intellectual dishonesty on the part of the Treasurer in dealing with this issue. Let me say a few words to begin with on intellectual dishonesty. There is no doubt in my mind that this Treasurer is quite happy in most circumstances to economise on the truth, but in this case he has conceded that there is no hard evidence that foreign investment has pushed up our house prices, although that is one of the principal reasons he claims to have taken the decision to impose a ban. Whatever investment there had been when he took the decision, foreign investment into our real estate market had clearly been at the top end, and the Treasurer conceded as much in his press conference on 27 September. There are a number of points that I could quote in that regard. I begin by citing the conclusion of one of the journalists who attended that press conference. I quote from the Financial Review of 30 September. The journalist stated:
The weakness of the Government's position was the lack of hard evidence.

At his press conference yesterday, Mr Keating could provide no facts and figures to back the decision. Nor could officials produce them later. The Treasurer admitted the evidence the Government did have, that foreign money was distorting the urban residential markets was ``inconclusive''.
He conceded that the Government relied heavily on ``anecdotal'' evidence.

If we look at the transcript of that press conference we see that a couple of specific questions were put to the Treasurer about the evidence on which he had taken that decision, and I will bring a couple of those questions to the attention of the House. A journalist asked:
Do you have any figures Mr Keating to show just what level of buying has been done by foreigners in residential real estate and what it's done to prices for the overall view?
The Treasurer's answer was `No.' Another question was:
What was the Government's assessment about the possibility of future capital inflow in these sort of residential areas . . .?
The Treasurer's answer was as follows:
Well we had not made such an assessment . . .

The Treasurer was quite explicit. He had no evidence on which to base his assessment of the so-called impact of foreign investment on residential real estate in Australia. Clearly, if we speak to anyone in the real estate industry, in particular in Sydney, the basis to which the Treasurer referred on a number of occasions, we find that many people gave evidence that is contrary to the Treasurer's view. For example, Mr David Collier, the Director of Colliers International said:
It is a very badly thought-out piece of legislation, prompted by recent scaremongering and irresponsible reporting in some sections of the media.
I might also quote Neil Collins, the Managing Director of Richardson and Wrench, one of the largest real estate firms in the country. He said:

. . . overseas investors have been buying only a very small percentage of the market and while there have been some spectacular purchases these investors were not major players in the market. I think it will make very little difference to the market.
He went on to say:
Out of the last hundred inquiries in our Double Bay office-one of the largest turnover residential offices in Australia-only three out of 100 were Asian buyers.
I might similarly quote Tim Mansfield from Colliers who said:
I am only aware of four Japanese who have bought in the eastern suburbs over the last four months and all were executives employed by Japanese companies operating in Australia.
Finally, I refer to the statement made by Mr Robert Bevan, President of the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales, who was quite astounded by the move. Mr Bevan said:

It is a decision taken for purely political reasons to support the fallacious argument that foreign investors in the $1m plus residential market are making it hard for first-home buyers in the $80,000 to $90,000 market. If there were any way the REI could be convinced that stopping foreigners from buying into the upper end residential market would stop the price spiral in the mid to lower end residential market we would applaud the Government's move.
The fact is that the decision was taken without any evidence whatsoever. No work was done; no data was looked at. There is no hard evidence available.

It was entirely a political decision based on short term political motivation and the concern, of course, was the impending fate of the Treasurer's mate in New South Wales, Barrie Unsworth. There is no doubt in my mind that the Treasurer's right wing faction in New South Wales lent all over him to do what he could to help Barrie. It was nothing more than a cosmetic gesture on his part and it was certainly not based on any significant analysis of the situation.

Equally, we can look at some of the economic arguments that the Treasurer has advanced, either on that occasion or more recently, to defend his position. Perhaps his most famous economic argument is that foreign investment can only add to the housing stock through building housing and not the purchase of existing housing. Surely the purchase by foreigners of existing houses from Australians provides resources for those Australians to build houses if they want to do so. In the longer term the effect of the sort of ban that has been applied could very much reduce the stock of housing. The Treasurer also alludes to the fact that these foreign investors have been pushing up residential real estate prices in Sydney. The ban has been in effect since September 1987 and it is fascinating that prices in Sydney after that ban, the magic solution, actually went up 60 plus per cent in residential real estate across the city as against 30 per cent, for example, in Brisbane.

What disturbs me most about the economic arguments we hear is that the Treasurer has the view, and it should not be forgotten that he is the one who consistently claims to be a great economic reformer and that he more than anyone else has deregulated the financial system and improved the efficiency of financial transactions and so on, that he can be selective about foreign investment in Australia. I put it to him that the the sort of economic beggars we are becoming in international markets as a result of the way he has run our economic policy really cannot choose where the investment comes from or in what form it comes. Once a country starts down the path of being selective it can end up being counterproductive. If a country wants to continue to run huge balance of payments deficits month after month and wants to live with an international debt level of $115 billion gross and $89 billion net, it must be prepared to lay itself pretty much at the mercy of international capital markets. If those international capital markets have taken a long, hard look at a country and downgraded its credit standing as well, it should not become too complacent about how difficult it might become. But not this Treasurer. He, for short term political reasons, has certainly started to try to be selective. From his point of view some investment is good and some investment is bad. He seems to have a funny concept of good imports and bad imports and good investments and bad investments. The fact is that he would not know if his backside was on fire when it comes to looking at the economy.

The simple economic fact is that if we do not take the investment in the form of housing, foreigners will have to buy other assets, or we will have to finance our continuing balance of payments position by increasing our debt. The Treasurer, more than anyone else, is to blame for the current state of our balance of payments and he more than anyone else is also to blame for the substantial movement in the exchange rates that may have kindled a foreign interest in buying real estate in Australia. The Government's policy has produced the weak currency but the Treasurer will stand up and say, `Yes, but we have recovered our level against the United States dollar'. He should not be too enthusiastic about that because the Australian dollar is down about 40 per cent against the yen and the deutschmark and 30 per cent against sterling. It is this Treasurer more than anyone else who has provided that encouragement to foreigners to the extent that it is an encouragement, to buy assets in Australia by running the sorts of policies that have resulted in such a weakness of the Australian dollar against the yen, the mark and sterling, to cite three examples. It is the Treasurer more than anyone else who has built up our balance of payments deficit and he more than anyone else who has presided over the quadrupling of our international debt, and so he more than anyone else must live with the consequences of his economic mismanagement.

The ban that is implicit in this Bill simply attacks the symptoms and has nothing to do with the causes. Over and above that there are some other disturbing features of this sort of behaviour. It is possible to start to frighten the horses. We rely very importantly on continued international confidence in Australia. It will not be too difficult with this sort of behaviour to start to frighten the international horses. International investors will at some stage become particularly wary of us, and the Treasurer should think about that. He was mucking around with our monetary targets in 1984 and abandoned them in early 1985, and the foreigners voted with their feet soon thereafter. Since then, on a number of occasions, he has frightened the horses and shaken their very confidence. I quote one leading property expert in Sydney, Jeremy Lewis from Schroders, in the aftermath of this decision:
Foreigners, in general, will wonder if this signals a change in Government policy. This is the first major change in financial deregulation and may have implications for other financial markets.
No other major western democracy has such draconian restrictions on the ownership of residential real estate by non-residents.

He points immediately to the fact the foreigners can lose confidence in our currency and in our economic management very quickly. There are many others that I might cite that have a similar point of view. For example, Greg Hywood in the Australian Financial Review said:
Labor must hope that Japanese institutions are not flighty, take the wrong signals and squeeze funds to Australia during a period when the external account is so badly out of adjustment.

We know that on the very day that this decision was announced the Financial Review summarised the position in the headline, `$A dips on new property rule'. The first paragraph in an article by Stephen Hughes states:
The Federal Government's move to curb foreign ownership of residential property yesterday sent foreign exchange markets reeling.

The case rests. International perceptions and confidence in our currency and in our economy are very fragile and they are easily influenced by irresponsible behaviour by the Treasurer. This is not the first time that this Treasurer has frightened the horses. I mentioned the example of 1984-85, concerning monetary targets, and the House will also remember the time the Treasurer flip-flopped on the interest withholding tax in the middle of 1986. I was in a Tokyo dealing room at the time and saw the Australian dollar fall 4c before lunch as a result of that sort of stupidity. The Treasurer's flip-flop on negative gearing is famous. Foreigners can be forgiven for thinking that our Treasurer does not know what he is doing, and I think that is a pretty reasonable assessment.

I want also to talk about the Treasurer's hypocrisy, and here I have much more evidence than I did on the other matter even though that evidence was not inconsequential. This Treasurer more than anyone else would stand in the international financial community as an unbounded hypocrite. To begin with, a couple of days after he announced this ban on residential real estate he left the country to go to New York to try to encourage investors to put their money into the country. That is the sort of hypocrisy one comes to expect from this man. One can imagine that he did not spend a lot of time drawing attention to that sort of decision on that trip to New York. He also left behind quite a lot of disarray in his Department. I have here a quote from the Times on Sunday and an article by Murray Hogarth:

When Mr Keating departed for New York, he left mini-chaos behind him. The small staff remaining in the Treasury's FIRB section was besieged for days by a flood of telephone calls from Australia and offshore seeking explanation of the new policy. In one week Mr Keating had interfered with the free market forces he is renowned for espousing and presided over the further stripping of the body which he expects to administer the new ban.

That is a classic comment on the hypocrisy that is identifiable with this Treasurer. Honourable members will remember that today, in Question Time there was an abortive attempt by the Treasurer to explain himself, following yet another dorothy dixer. He does not come in here to debate the issue. He got another dorothy dixer to try to put it on record that the Foreign Investment Review Board is being flooded with phone calls. Here is one good reason why it is being flooded with phone calls: nobody has a clue what this bloke is doing. There will be other reasons that I will draw attention to in a moment. The second piece of hypocrisy is in the Treasurer's second reading speech:
Honourable members may think that at first sight it is incongruous that the Government is strengthening sections of the Foreign Takeovers Act, while at the same time liberalising other parts of it.
This bloke shows an acute sensitivity; he always wears his heart on his sleeve. There is never any doubt what he is on about.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hasn't got a heart.
—That is right, he has not got a heart. He wears something on his sleeve. The word is not `incongruous'; it is a euphemism for hypocrisy again.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have been sitting here listening to this tirade against the Treasurer--
—There is no point of order.
—Yes, there is, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member has made a number of offensive personal comments against the Treasurer and I ask that they be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.

—The point I was making concerned the blatant hypocrisy of the Treasurer. He is also blatantly hypocritical in another part of his second reading speech where he says, in his words, that he will `provide a test for the Opposition parties'. He is a great one for providing tests. Honourable members will notice how many times he uses that analogy. I would have loved to have had this bloke in one of my economics classes and given him a few of those tests. But his test is to see whether we will go along with him and change our minds about what is the right thing to do about foreign investment in this country. He has made a mistake; he has changed his mind for short term political gains and he wants `to provide the opposition with an opportunity to clarify its position on these issues'. Our position has never changed; it is his position that has changed. It is blatant hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: The third level of hypocrisy in this debate associated with the Treasurer has to do with his frequent trips overseas marketing this country and encouraging foreign investment into this country. The trip that comes to mind most particularly is the one in the middle of last year when he went to Japan. In the course of his performance in Japan he made a number of speeches. I happen to have some key quotes from one speech, which I think makes the point, to the Australia-Japan Business Cooperation Committee. He makes this statement:
We were in the vanguard of the world-wide move to sweep away inappropriate regulation in the financial sector.
Australia's financial system is now among the most competitive in the world, with considerable depth and sophistication.
This process of deregulation has also extended to our foreign investment policy, which has been extensively liberalised from the restrictive structure we inherited from our predecessors in 1983.

We recognise that foreign investment is a positive force for progress, as it not only provides investment funds which otherwise would not be available, but also opens up the Australian economy to ideas and concepts from abroad.
I stress that our policy on foreign investment is non-discriminatory between countries and, consistent with our close trading relationship, we welcome long-term Japanese investment.
The Government particularly welcomes the contribution that Japanese interests are making to the expansion of Australia's tourism industry . . .

The point is that the Treasurer goes through the foreign investment policy in some detail and he forgets to mention that there is a ban on foreign investment in residential real estate. Indeed, in one quote in the Australian Financial Review associated with that conference he said:
. . . we welcome wholeheartedly Japanese investment in our economy.
He also said:
We regard Japanese investment in Australia entirely favourable and no less so in real estate.

He gives one story offshore-Jekyll and Hyde stuff-and a different story onshore. He gets people to come to Australia and invest. No wonder he is getting 400 or 500 phone calls a day in the foreign investment section because people cannot figure it out. People have heard him talk in Japan and they come out here and get a thorough dose of it.

The key points I wanted to make over and above that are that this Treasurer got us into the fundamental mess we are in at present. This Treasurer more than anyone else is responsible for the sort of balance of payments deficit that we have. This Treasurer overheated the economy over the last couple of years and frittered away the benefits of a commodity price explosion. This Treasurer comes and parades himself in here and in the rest of the world as the great micro-reformer and his action does not match his rhetoric. Here is a decision in this Bill that is completely contrary to that reputation.

The only way he will solve those problems is to go down the route that we have been advocating-very clear cut micro-economic reform. He has to deregulate and decentralise the labour market; he has to start tying wages to productivity; he has to embark on a privatisation path-an area that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) would know something about and lives in fear of for no good reason-he has to cut protection and reform industry policy; and he has to embark on a genuine process of taxation reform. There is a whole host of other things too, such as getting our wharves in shape, dealing with coastal shipping, getting on top of the transportation system and so on. Until this Treasurer starts to go anywhere near his rhetoric with his action we are destined to oblivion in international financial circles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I congratulate the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) for his contribution tonight. I think that what we have actually heard is not so much a contribution on foreign investment; essentially it is the first salvo in the next challenge for the leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia and he is trying to demonstrate some of those credentials which people in the Press Gallery are starting to suggest he has-not to mention some of his colleagues on the back bench; and I notice one or two of them in the chamber tonight. The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill, which is before us tonight, is consistent with announcements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) some time ago. All of the changes that have been announced are consistent with the general thrust of this Government's foreign investment policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government seeks to balance two important interests. The first is the natural desire of the Australian community that local people should have a dominant influence in our economy-I do not think anybody in this chamber would disagree with that-and the second is that productive foreign investment is very much welcomed because of the significant benefit that it brings to Australia. From what the honourable member for Wentworth was saying, I understood he believes that, for example, in the residential market, simply by stopping foreign ownership of that resource will in no way effect the general outcome of Australia's economic well-being. Of course, the Government does not see that as being the case. I just wonder whether at the bottom of this concern that he has about levels of investment in Australia is a more deeply routed concern for the foreign debt question and how one comes to terms with that.

Interestingly, this whole question about foreign debt is glossed over by members of the Opposition. It glibly runs off their tongues as if this total public debt has been accrued by government, in particular this Government. The honourable member for Wentworth well knows that 60 per cent of it is private debt and it has come from those people with whom he freely mixes who have borrowed from overseas and internal sources to finance takeover bids in those halcyon days we saw prior to the stock market crash and for which Australia is still paying the bill. He might seek to acquaint himself with what people from the National Party of Australia, particular those in Queensland, think about investment from foreigners, such as Asians, in their State. As I understand it, from the Premier right through the Cabinet, a great deal of concern has been expressed by the National Party in that State about the level of investment in real estate, whether it be commercial real estate or just residential real estate. We have already seen some examples of what happens where that gets out of hand, where public meetings are called and people express concerns about it and say, `We are being taken over by foreigners', and so on. Those people are average Australians.

I ask the honourable member for Wentworth whether he is suggesting that, in order to eliminate the foreign debt in this country, we should start to sell off more of Australia to foreign investors. Is that really what is being suggested? I do not think so. I would certainly hope not. I just ask that, at some stage in the future in another contribution about his ambitions to the leadership, he might be able to make some comments on that.

The honourable member referred to the question of tests being proposed to people on his side of the House by the Treasurer. I well remember one of those tests that he put to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) prior to the last election to cost and to show where all the promises that he had made to the Australian people would work and what effect that would have on Australia's deficit. From memory I think it has been shown that those costs would have increased our deficit by some $9 billion. To this day the test results still have not come in from the Leader of the Opposition. He has still not shown where he would make necessary changes to economic policy to enable his government-if the Opposition were ever to get there-to pay for those announcements that he made during the election campaign. He has surely failed the big test in that respect and there are many other examples that I could go to.

The Bill, as I have indicated, is an attempt by the Government to draw together the natural desire of the Australian community that local people have a dominant influence in our economy and that productive foreign investment is very much welcome. The Government stands by that. In drawing this balance, our policy is at total odds with the free market approach being advanced by the Opposition parties, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). In a press release that he put out on 29 September 1987, following the Treasurer's announcement on this matter, he totally rejected the Government's position with respect to foreign investment policy on residential real estate, describing it as `a knee-jerk reaction adversely affecting long-term foreign investment in Australia'. Clearly, that has not happened. Foreign investment in this country is continuing to grow and is being carefully monitored by this Government. One has only to look at the level at which foreign investment is occurring within the mining industry, hotels, the tourist industry, and so on, to see what worthwhile benefits there are. If anything has the tendency to affect levels of foreign investment in this country, it is the divisive stance taken by some members of the Opposition in respect of the immigration debate. We have seen evidence time and time again, particularly from our Asian neighbours, who have rejected those kinds of comments and said, `We will continue to invest in Australia provided that that policy of bipartisanship and the general multicultural nature of immigration policies, is adhered to'. I do not have to remind the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) of some of the comments made recently by visiting foreign dignitaries about comments that his leader has made.

The Bill is concerned with those issues of productive foreign investment that would come from continued interest by overseas countries. As I have indicated, there has been a concern for quite some time that houses were being purchased by foreigners who had no intention of taking up residence in this country, and, therefore, who had no real effect on the settlement pattern or the future economic well-being of this country. There has been some evidence, contrary to what has been said, that the price of Australian real estate was being driven up because of that fact. Distinct from most forms of foreign investment, the Government sees these purchases as providing little or no real benefit to Australia. Consequently, the Bill provides a legislative basis for the decision that the Treasurer announced in September last year to prevent such acquisitions.

Under the guidelines that have applied since that announcement was made, and given legislative effect by this Bill, all foreign acquisitions of urban real estate are examinable, regardless of the size of the purchase. That is somewhat important, because the $600,000 limit has now been abolished. Purchases of developed commercial real estate are still approved, subject to flexible guidelines for 50 per cent Australian equity, with approvals for 100 per cent foreign ownership being guaranteed if Australian equity on reasonable terms and conditions is available.

The amendments will provide a statutory power for the Treasurer of the day to examine foreign acquisitions of interests in urban land; to prohibit proposed foreign acquisitions of urban land that are adjudged contrary to the national interest; and to order the disposal of interest in urban land that is purchased by foreign persons without prior notification under the Act and which is determined to be contrary to the national interest.

I do not think that any member of this House could object to those points in the rationale for this policy. Australia's national interest is something that requires protection, whether it be in real estate or in investment in industry generally, investment in Australia's resource base, or whatever. This whole issue of the effect that it has on real estate markets is something which cannot be underestimated. One has to look at what is happening in Australia's major cities at the present time in respect of real estate. Prices are being forced up to unrealistic levels. I can give one example within my own area in Wollongong. Some land has been serviced and made available. Originally, under the Unsworth Labor Government in New South Wales, the land, which was owned by the Housing Department of New South Wales, was to be developed to provide public housing, which was most needed. Unfortunately, however, the decision was taken by the incoming Greiner Government not to proceed with public housing; rather, to hand it over to the Land Commission to enable it to be sold simply as land with development taking place that was controlled by the State Government.

What we have seen is land of that nature being sold for upwards of $80,000 a lot. In the Wollongong real estate market, that is quite considerable. The effect that that is having, contrary to what the Housing Department's Land Commission was supposed to do, is outrageous.

I recognise that there are limitations on time in this debate. I believe that the legislation that the Government has introduced is worthy of support. It will certainly rectify an anomaly in the system that has existed for some time and has been of concern to the Government. I urge wholehearted support for it tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation really takes the cake. It demonstrates the utter hypocrisy of the Government in claiming credit for deregulatory and free trade policies. Whatever progress has been made in that direction over five years of Labor Government has been very limited indeed. The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill is itself highly contradictory, proposing to free up some foreign investment guidelines, whilst harshly clamping down on others. The Bill shows no application of principle, no understanding of economics, and no scruples in appealing to the worst possible type of economic populism.

SPEECH.PARA: Any commentator or business group which in the future thinks of congratulating the Government for its liberal attitude to the running of the economy should remember this Bill. It matters little that this rabid interventionism takes place in the context of great fiscal responsibility by the Commonwealth; the long run effects will be the same as they have been in the past. Remembering these recent events, those who congratulated the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for his fine economic achievements should hang their heads in shame.

It is probably worth noting that the would-be Prime Minister, the present Treasurer, finds his greatest fans amongst the ranks of political commentators rather than economists and economic analysts. If anyone who has shown up his shortcomings, it is the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). The second reading speech of the Treasurer when presenting this Bill is particularly illuminating. It makes it quite clear that the Treasurer does not really believe in any form of economic rationalism or any policy of non-intervention by government in private business affairs. The Treasurer portrays the economy not as a dynamic process resulting from the actions of millions of Australians every day, but as a mechanistic apparatus which can produce a different product, with technical alterations by the Government. Thus, he presents urban real estate as a separate part of foreign investment which can be isolated from all other economic influences.

He criticises the Liberal Party in opposition for an excessive zeal for market forces to be unrestrained in this area. So much for the new, reformed Australian Labor Party which he so desperately wants to lead. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is one of the Labor members who will make sure that he never does. It is another sham public relations exercise designed to cover up the reality that those few Ministers who have a genuine desire to free up the Australian economy can no longer carry the day in Cabinet in Caucus or in the Labor Party. They can talk about free trade but they cannot do anything about it.

This legislation, unfortunately, makes Ministers like the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and his colleague the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) look absolutely stupid when they travel overseas to talk about removing barriers to international trade. The Government says to people from overseas, `We'll sell you our agricultural produce, minerals and manufactured goods. We love your investment in anything which we think you should invest in, but don't think of buying residential property. Don't think of buying homes'. That position does not make sense. It gives potential investors no confidence that the Government might not in the future make even more knee-jerk reactions to restrict foreign investment in other areas. If it did, I have no doubt that we would still hear the same emphatic rhetoric from the Treasurer and the honourable member for Calwell that they have used in the past and that the Treasurer has used in proposing this Bill to plead that the restrictions deal with a special case. From experience, it is obvious that the so-called special cases are just the beginning of much worse to come, if accepting the special pleadings of some, means abandoning an important principle such as that which we are debating tonight.

The Treasurer suggests that this legislation is an attempt to balance the acknowledged benefits from foreign investment against the vague notion that people want Australians to have the dominant influence in the Australian economy. The purchase of houses by a few foreign nationals will hardly challenge the pre-eminent role of Australians in the Australian economy. If the Treasurer is so preoccupied with foreign investment in Australia, what on earth does he mean when he refers to `the crucial requirement that we internationalise the Australian economy'? What will this measure contribute to the internationalising of the Australian economy? If nothing else, the balance of payments problems which the Treasurer simply has not been able to do anything to redress, necessitates a high level of domestic debt or foreign investment. There is no other choice. There is nothing in what he is doing or in what anyone on the other side of the House espouses.

If people investing in Australia are consistently investing in real estate that is an interesting commentary on what people think of the desirability of investment in Australian industry. That is the judgment of the marketplace. The honourable member for Calwell can wobble his beard all he likes but that is the commentary, that is the judgment being placed on the Government. In the long run, returns on investment in real estate are steady but they are not spectacular. However, with Australia's high levels of taxation and regulation and its sclerotic labour market, investment in productive enterprises is simply not seen as being competitive with other investments. That is a product of the economic management of this Government and its Treasurer, the would-be Prime Minister.

We cannot isolate people's desires to invest in housing from wider issues of investment and general economic policy. The so-called level playing field, which is part of the jargon the Treasurer loves to use, and which he refers to so often, demonstrates his misguided administration of the tax system and how his outmoded thinking is to be thrown out the window with respect to foreign investment. The economic arguments against the parts of this legislation which tighten foreign investment guidelines are clear. They are the same arguments which the Treasurer has used on other issues but obviously has ignored or not understood.

The most important objection to this Bill is that it infringes on the rights of Australians to trade. It will no longer be possible for Australian citizens to sell their property to the highest bidder if that bidder happens to be a foreign citizen. It is not just foreign citizens to whom this Government will dictate but to many Australians as well. Many Australians will be denied the best price available to them for their property. If any single measure of this Labor Government marks the point where it lost its nerve, it is this Bill. It is a classic measure of the old school protectionist Labor Party, which the honourable member for Calwell represents, with its fear of markets, its fear of business and its paranoia about foreign corporations. The honourable member for Calwell was there boots and all when the Government was going crook about General Motors-Holden (GMH) reaping profits and taking them out of the country through United States shareholders. We hear not a word from him these days because GMH is not doing too well. It is not taking any profits out. The honourable member does not come along and say, `Perhaps we should dip in and help GMH'. That would be the natural corollary of the cases he once advocated and I think still does. The Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have argued that domestic demand is too strong, using housing demand as one of their primary excuses for an overheating in the economy. Surely this strong domestic demand, which the Government is using very high interest rates to stop, is the explanation for the cost of urban residential real estate.

The recent economic policies of the Government demonstrate that it does not really believe that foreign investment is the cause of high housing demand in Sydney or in any other market. The only explanation for the new restrictions in this Bill is that the Labor Party is appealing to the xenophobia of some, for blatant electoral reasons. This policy was first announced just in time for the New South Wales election. Yet again, the Labor Party under the guidance of the would-be Prime Minister the present Treasurer, has demonstrated that it is willing to sacrifice the economic future of the country to further its narrow political ends.

The ALP clutches at the power, which is slowly but surely slipping from it, even if it means ignoring economic reality and the liberty of Australians to trade with whomever they want. If people really object to the foreign ownership of Australian real estate they have the option of doing something about it themselves. They can refuse to sell their own land to people from overseas and can voluntarily purchase local land from those who will sell it to the highest bidder.

Finally, it is likely that the boom in housing prices in Sydney will end in the near future, but that will not be because of the measures contained in this Bill. It will have a lot more to do with the exorbitantly high interest rates which the economic irresponsibility of the present Treasurer has engineered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Please, not the same speech.

—The honourable member should be quiet. He was not even here for the debate. I want to address my remarks to the comments made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) in his first attempt to show us that he knows something about economics. The honourable member for Wentworth's dream run in pretending to know about economics is over because his ridiculous New Right economic philosophy will be exposed for what it is: a fraud and a sham. He abused the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He used the term `hypocrisy'. This goes to show how much intellectual substance there was in his comments. He used the term `hypocrisy' about 20 times when trying to describe the Treasurer's position. If he had not been so repetitive he might have been able to tell us something about the substance of the issues before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one central and crucial question at stake. The Opposition is very clearly in favour of selling off Australian land and real estate to foreigners, no matter to what degree or to what extent. That is the point Australians need to recognise. The Opposition is not interested in the national interests of this country in relation to the sale of land, real estate and property. We have heard some very strange and fallacious arguments in the debate on the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill. First of all we were told that we were trying to prevent people investing in Australia. What rubbish! People can invest in a myriad of companies and corporations and in a myriad of areas of the economy. We are saying that land and residential properties have a particular place in the sovereignty of any nation and, therefore, we should protect them. That is all we are saying. If foreigners want to invest in Australia they can invest in Australian manufacturing industry, services, tourism, agriculture and a whole variety of areas. The Opposition is saying that there is no problem with that; however, the foreigners all need to invest in real estate. They need to buy houses and property which should be owned by Australian citizens. Opposition members have the gall to come in here and present a whole set of rhetorical arguments, but the basic point is this: notwithstanding all the intellectual jargon of the honourable member for Wentworth, he is not prepared to stand up for his country and defend the basic right of property. That is fundamental to this issue.

I warn the honourable member for Wentworth that the old Liberal Party of Australia is finished. The Liberal Party that once had some sense of decency and some belief in the sovereignty of this nation is finished. What we have now is a group of incompetents who, in trying to win power, are prepared to put out a policy to sell this nation down the drain. That is what we are debating in this Bill.

Then we heard the Opposition making accusations against the Treasurer for taking an honourable stand to protect this country. We know what has been happening. Instead of investment coming into the areas of production, manufacturing industry and services, what have we had? We have had foreigners coming in and going for that important area of residential property. Opposition members collectively should be ashamed of themselves. Instead of supporting our putting a limit on this investment-and I point out that it is not a blanket limit-they are saying that the Government has no right to limit this matter in any way, not even when foreigners come here and buy huge chunks of residential property for their own purposes. This means that they will make Australians tenants and they will be the landlords. But that does not matter to honourable members opposite. It does not matter if those investors are not prepared to invest in a single factory or new service for this country. No, they only care about the fact that people are prepared to invest in land and residential property. What a nonsense! After defending such a shameful position, they have the gall to come in here and accuse the Treasurer of hypocrisy. If ever there has been a group of hypocrites, it is honourable members opposite. Also I must tell the honourable member for Wentworth that if this is the best performance that he can put on in this House, if all he can do is simply abuse the Treasurer personally, in the way that he has done, he has a long way to go before he can claim the mantle of any kind of leader for the Opposition.

This Bill is a moderate measure. Its aim is clear. The Treasurer will have the right to examine-and that is all; not to reject-these proposed acquisitions and to determine whether they are in the national interest. That is the crucial issue. The Treasurer will simply have the right to examine the acquisitions. There is no automatic rejection. If there is a special case to be put forward, it can be put forward. There may be a case where a foreigner wishes to purchase residential property or land because he wants to go into production or open a factory or start a manufacturing industry. He may wish to help create jobs in this country. If that is so, he can put up that case. We are saying that there should be no automatic right for the purchase of property and the selling out of this country. That is all.

I stress that we are talking about foreigners; we are not talking about people who want to come and live in this country. We are not talking about immigrants; we are talking about foreigners. If people want to come and live in Australia they will have all those rights. The honourable member for Wentworth accused the Treasurer of hypocrisy in relation to people investing in Australia. If any damage has been done to investment in this country, it has been done by Opposition members, particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), undermining the business migration scheme. He has undermined business migrants coming to Australia and bringing their money to invest as Australian residents and citizens. He has undermined several hundred million dollars of investment with his comments about the racial basis for immigration. His comments have done us much more damage than any proposed limitation on the purchase of property. Let us make that perfectly clear. The Opposition has been responsible for the withdrawal of potential investment in Australia, both by foreigners and by people who want to come and live here, because of what it has done to the overseas perception of Australia-fallacious perception-as a racist country.

As the chairman of the Caucus immigration committee, I have had a number of submissions put to me about the disgraceful behaviour of the Leader of the Opposition. Members of different Asian groups in Australia have spoken to me about this matter and the damage which has been done to Australia in Asia. The honourable member for Wentworth talked about the Treasurer's visit to Asia-particularly Japan. He said that the Treasurer was hypocritical because he only told the Japanese that they could invest in everything else; he did not tell them that they could not invest in residential property. If there is anything hypocritical it is the Opposition's position in relation to the immigration issue which has undermined our relations with Asia, particularly in relation to investment by people from Japan. These are the facts of the matter. In his comments the honourable member for Wentworth made it clear that he and the Opposition generally stand for the selling out of this country by the giving up of our sovereign right of land and residential property, which is important to any nation. We totally reject that attitude and I think it is shameful that the first major speech we have had from the honourable member for Wentworth on these matters should be one that defends selling out our national sovereignty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that everyone would agree that we have heard a most extraordinary speech from the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who raved and ranted on the issue of foreign investment without understanding the way in which this Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill contradicts itself. On the one hand it is legislation which encourages foreign investment in so many different fields, yet on the other in one clause it discourages that investment. This legislation is aimed at Japanese and Hong Kong based investors in the Sydney property market. It tries to blame those people for increases in Sydney property prices. That is being racist. It is saying that we blame the Japanese and Hong Kong Chinese for the massive increase in prices in the Sydney property market. The Government is playing on the sentiments of Sydney people; it is playing on the racist sentiments of a minority of people in that city, building them up and trying to capitalise on them in order to win votes. Everybody knows that this part of the legislation in relation to property is irrational. Everybody knows it is completely inconsistent with Government policy. That is clear to anybody. It is simply a political ploy first designed to win a few votes for poor old Barry Unsworth, and he will not be getting any votes any more.
—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired.
—Order! The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.
