PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are at 11.00 o'clock at night on the third consecutive day of very lengthy sittings, about to consider an extraordinary piece of legislation, the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill, otherwise known in parts of Australia as the Westpac-ing Bill. Let me point out to the House just how extraordinary this Bill is. It contains some draftsmanship the like of which has never been seen in this Parliament since Federation. I refer, of course, to the fact that there are clauses in this Bill that say that if the Parliament dares to amend the Bill in any way, shape or form, within two days that amendment will be sent to Westpac Banking Corporation and it will decide whether it will accept, reject or otherwise deal with that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reached the stage where the ability of the Parliament of this nation to amend legislation in a proper way is being severely restricted by the draftsmanship of this Bill. I sound a note of warning to the Government that it can expect a rough passage in the debate on this Bill, restricted as it is, both in this House and the Senate, because of the draftsmanship associated with it.

I also point out to the House that Parliament has been pre-empted in another way in respect of the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. We are resuming the debate on the Bill just one week after the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) introduced it in the dead of night on Thursday of last week at 10 p.m. But what has been going on in the meantime? I will tell honourable members what has been going on. The Government has said, `Do not wait for Parliament. Do not wait for the House of Representatives debate or the Senate debate. Let's have some letters sent out to thousands of defence service home loan holders, under the official nomenclature of the Defence Service Homes Corporation, even before the Bill has been passed through the Parliament, saying, ``Just be advised that Westpac is taking over this scheme. A letter is enclosed from Westpac with some of the arrangements associated with this matter''.'

The Government has totally pre-empted the will of Parliament in an arrogant and out of touch manner. I add, to be fair, that contained in these letters are the phrases `pending legislation', `pending passage of enabling legislation' and so forth. We should leave that to one side because that by no means covers the circumstance where the Government has set an impossible timetable for the implementation of the defence service home loans scheme under the Westpac arrangements-the new scheme provided for by this legislation and operated by the Westpac Banking Corporation.
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

Honourable members have had hundreds of calls and letters expressing concern over the Government's letters, which are circulating far and wide, even before Parliament has passed this Bill. I warn the Government that its legislative package on this matter is trailblazing in more ways than one, and not in ways that are conducive to the strengthening of parliamentary democracy in this country. I condemn the Government for the structure of the legislation and its draftsmanship, which almost holds a gun at the heads of members and senators as to whether or not they can amend this Bill.

It could have been done another way. The structure and draftsmanship of the legislation could have been done in such a way that we were not subjected to a gun at the head approach. I realise that an agreement had to be reached with Westpac. I realise that Westpac is entitled to have some protection with regard to the passage of this legislation. But it should not have been to such an extent that the ability of Parliament to amend the legislation is effectively traduced. I register a strong complaint about that dimension.

The Westpac-ing of the defence service home loan scheme is a classic case of the Government, in another sense, stealing the coalition's policy. The Government is in fact privatising a significant government activity. The defence service home loan scheme started earlier this century. It has had very little upgrading since but it has provided a vital leg of assistance to veterans of World War I, World War II, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam, along with peacetime service personnel who enlisted between 1972 and 1985 who are eligible for the $25,000 home loan. The new scheme will eliminate the 10-month delay, which has been causing enormous difficulties for many service personnel, whether they be at Sale in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) or in the Albury-Wodonga military area or elsewhere.

I recognise that there are advantages conferred by this Bill. Improvements to the operation of the scheme are conferred by the negotiated arrangements. I give credit and recognition where it is due. However, let me say that on the fundamental point of a $25,000 loan at a blended rate of 6.85 per cent, in many ways the House is considering the defence service caravan loan scheme rather than the defence service home loan scheme. The reason for that is clear enough. The coalition Government in 1980 increased to $25,000 the fundamental loan associated with this scheme at the concessional interest rate. There has been no increase in the eight years since. What has happened in, for example, Sydney since that time is that we have had an 84 per cent increase in the median price of established dwellings. In Melbourne there has been a 131 per cent increase and in Adelaide a 104 per cent increase. What has happened to the defence service home loan basic amount? It has remained at exactly $25,000, and under this incredible legislation it will continue at $25,000. So in many ways legislation ought to be renamed the defence service caravan loan scheme. It is barely giving service personnel a start along the path to owning their own homes, the vital objective of the scheme.

I say to the House and indeed to the nation that it behoves the Government to address this matter as quickly as it can. Whilst there are improvements conferred by the Westpac-ing of the defence service home loan scheme, the legislation is so constructed that the $25,000 amount remains the same and the 6.85 per cent concessional interest rate up to that $25,000 also remains the same. So there is no betterment factor associated with those aspects of the legislation.

In respect of that aspect of the legislation, there is provision for those who need to borrow more than $25,000. That is almost everybody, unless the person lives in Pooncarie in my electorate at Rufus River or some other remote place. Most people will need to borrow more than $25,000. One of the additional advantages of these new arrangements is that there is a one-stop shop, one set of administrative charges, for those who want to get their additional borrowings also from Westpac. If they want to go to the ANZ Bank, to the National Australia Bank Ltd or to any of the building societies to borrow the amount they need over and above the $25,000, they are free to do so. They are not bound to borrow their entire housing loan from Westpac. That is important. It is the decision of the eligible person, once he gets his certificate under the provisions of this Bill, as to which financial institution to borrow from. Clearly, there will be many advantages in staying with Westpac for the full package and getting the benefit of the one-stop shop, the one set of administrative charges. But equally, the Bill is in the interests of people-some of whom have written to me in the last four days-who resent the fact that they are being forced into some arrangement with Westpac. They will now be able to go elsewhere for the topping up benefit associated with the loan.

The House is being invited to consider the special agreement which has been reached between the Government and Westpac Banking Corporation and which is embedded in schedule 1 of the Bill. I want to focus on some aspects of the legislation flowing from schedule 1. I want to do two things, firstly, to deal with the provisions relating to amendments and then to move on to the new enlistee situation and highlight to the House the coalition's amendment relating to the sunset provision in clause 5 of the Bill. The provisions are so incredible that they are worth reading into Hansard. Clause 6.1 of schedule 1, `Amending Act being passed by Parliament', states:
This Agreement is binding on the parties . . .
The clause goes on to say that the Bill has to be passed in the form of the draft bill initialled on behalf of the parties involved. Clause 6.2 of schedule 1 states:
In the event that the Amending Act passed by Parliament should contain any amendments from the Draft Bill referred to in Sub-clause 6.1-
that is, of the Defence Services Homes Amendment Bill-

the Commonwealth shall within two (2) days of the passage of the Amending Act give notice to the Bank of the amendments together with such information relating to those amendments as it wishes to provide.

Clause 6.3 of schedule 1 states that if, in the opinion of the Bank, such amendments do any of the things in paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e) and are unacceptable to the Bank-forget about the Parliament; it is whether the amendments are unacceptable to the Bank-`the bank shall notify the Commonwealth of such opinion . . .'. The Bank will then have a complete let-out under the agreement of the Bill. This incredible legislative draftsmanship is further sabotaging the role of the Parliament. The role of the Parliament is being sabotaged by those who would have us address this legislation at 11.00 p.m. at the end of a long sitting week. It is in that context that the Opposition has responsibly examined a series of amendments to this legislation. The Government also examined a series of drafting amendments, but it was able to exercise the provisions of the Standing Orders and the Minister's pen to bring about proper changes to the first reading draft print copy Bill so that it did not have to face the difficulty-

TALK.START.PARA: —Embarrassment.

—So that it did not have to face the embarrassment of going into committee to move its own amendments and then face the worry of the trigger mechanism it inserted in its own Bill to give Westpac the way out. This legislation is extraordinary for all those reasons. I now turn to clause 5 of the Bill. What does clause 5 say? It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Regular Serviceman

5. Section 4aaa of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of subsection (1) after paragraph (1)(c) `but does not include a person whose first service in the Defence Force began after 14 May 1985.'
This provision excludes hundreds of young sailors, soldiers and airmen from any eligibility under the defence service home loans scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—It is a specific exclusion, and the result of a Government decision. It was a Government decision to exclude them from the negotiations with Westpac and under schedule 1 of the Bill. That little measure, that little dimension of the Bill, is of vital importance to many young service personnel who are reaching the age when they are starting to think about housing, are marrying and are qualifying under the six years consecutive service provision. They now find that if they joined the Army, the Navy or the Air Force after 14 May 1985 they are second class citizens. What could be more destructive of the morale of those in our Army, Navy and Air Force, more divisive, than to have one set of eligibility criteria for one lot of service personnel and a second set of eligibility criteria-a harsher criteria-for those who joined the Services after 1985, the so-called new enlistees? The new enlistees will be second class citizens. Embedded in the legislation is clause 5, which specifically maintains that exclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now take honourable members to a document tabled 12 hours ahead of this legislation arriving in the Parliament. I refer to the famous Cross report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. Recommendation No. 33 is clear-cut. It is a very significant recommendation. I would have thought that for once the Government would have thought ahead and anticipated what the Cross report would have to say, coming up with a sensible recommendation to overcome the housing crisis. What happened? The Government forgot about the Cross report. It has so delayed this legislation that it faces the embarrassing situation that we are debating the legislation on the same day the Cross report is brought before the House-its recommendation No. 33 unanimously recommending that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) approve eligibility for defence service home loans for post-May 1985 enlistees. The Cross report says, `Put these new enlistees, these young soldiers, sailors and airmen, into the coverage of defence service home loans, and then, 12 hours later, the Bill comes along, excluding those same new enlistees. It is an absolute contradiction. How the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross), the Chairman of the Committee, the other members of the Committee and the members of the sub-committee on defence-the Labor party members including Senator Maguire and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay)-can vote for this legislation, which cuts right across the Committee's key recommendation No. 33, I do not know.

I think we have caught the Government red-handed. We have certainly caught the Government failing to anticipate the inevitable recommendations of the Cross report. I say to both the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel that they have an obligation to get on with the job of adopting recommendation No. 33 of the Cross report and seeing that this legislation is satisfactorily altered. The agreement with Westpac should be altered to pick up the new enlistees-and not until 1991. It should be announced well ahead so that the morale of service personnel will not be affected and so that they can plan ahead for eligibility for housing under the defence service home loans scheme. It is with that in mind that I advise the House that should I be permitted to do so-this is how parliamentary democracy sausage machine legislation processes work; I may not be permitted to do so because of the guillotine-I will seek to move an amendment in the committee stage, copies of which I have furnished to the Government and to the table. The amendment would read as follows:
Clause 5, page 4, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:

``(2) On and after 15 May 1991, the words added to section 4aaa of the Principal Act by subsection (1) are omitted from that subsection and, subject to subsection (3), the Principal Act has effect as if subsection (1) had not been enacted.

``(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (2), the Secretary shall not issue a certificate of entitlement in relation to an advance to a person whose first service in the Defence Force began after 14 May 1985, and no such person may exercise any right under that subsection, unless and until a new or amended arrangement, concerning these persons, is negotiated and endorsed by the enactment of legislation.''.

Let me explain to the House that what that clause seeks to do is apply a scapel sunset to clause 5 on new enlistees. All it sets out to do is say to the Government that the Government has said it is going to fix up the new enlistees and their housing. I recognise the statements made by Ministers in recent days on that matter. But we are not going to leave it to their Ministerial statements-not yet made in this House, I might add. Perhaps there might be an opportunity in this debate to do that here, or in another place. All we are saying is that if that matter is not fixed up by the time these new enlistees become eligible on or after 15 May 1991, then in fact the mechanism is there to trip them back into consideration for the defence services home loan scheme. However, we are even saying there that we are not going to force the hand of the Government or load it onto the existing arrangements without further negotiations with Westpac Banking Corporation because, of course, there would be additional entitlements and additional payments afforded by the increased clientele being made available to Westpac and also the need to adjust in the light of further developments consequent upon the passage of this legislation.

So I put it to the House that this scapel sunset clause is a very responsible approach to take in terms of this legislation. It has not been easy to draft, I freely concede, and the reason it has not been easy to draft is that the right of this Parliament to amend this legislation has been reduced by the incredible agreement and phrasing of schedule 1 in the Bill, which says, `Don't you dare amend this Bill or it has to go straight back to Westpac and it will give Westpac the right to cancel out'.

It is a very sad day that we have reached the stage of considering legislation on the basis of that structure. But I commend this scapel sunset clause to the House. I hope to have the chance to move it in Committee. I believe that as it is now worded the two sections of the amendment must be taken together; that there is no cross-referencing to phrases elsewhere in the Bill which might misinterpret the objective of the amendment. I state again, the clearcut objective is to be absolutely neutral to the schedule 1 agreement and the current agreement which has been reached between the Government and Westpac, but to provide that if the Government has not addressed the situation of the new enlistees effectively by 15 May 1991, then there is a basis to make progress towards putting those new enlistees back into the existing type of defence services home loan scheme. That is what the Returned Services League in the House Magazine of this week, Wednesday, 23 November, has in fact called for in its column, and I quote:
The current Bill-that is, the Defence Services Homes Amendment Bill should be amended to bring in post-May 1985 enlistees with a realistic level for interest subsidy.
Black and white! That is what we seek to do by this sensible, responsible, scalpel sunset clause which has been extraordinarily difficult to draft because of the overall structure of the Bill.

I conclude by saying that, yes, there are improvements conferred by this new scheme to be operated under the Westpac Banking Corporation. Yes, the coalition fully supports privatisation. It is a step in the right direction. It has taken the Government three years and six months to get to this stage, because this matter was originally announced on 14 May 1985 in that famous mini-Budget by Treasurer Keating. Finally we get there, and suddenly, right on the death knock of this Budget session, in an incredibly tight timetable, we get this extraordinary Bill with all its limitations, with its incredible contents, and with its incredible restrictions on the right of Parliament to amend. I reiterate to the House that whilst the Opposition supports the Bill overall, it quite responsibly advances its scalpel sunset clause to clause 5 to protect the rights and the morale of the new enlistees who do not deserve to be treated as second-class citizens in our armed forces today and who even the Government ought to recognise it needs to treat as first-class citizens to lessen their resignation and wastage rates and to ensure a boost in morale to our armed forces who so desperately need it. I commend the amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, of course, reject the amendment and support the Bill. I really wonder whether the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), as an ex-Army officer, does not somehow prefer that nice cocoon of regulations, rigidity, procedures and delays and all of those sorts of things to the choice which this Bill offers to service men and women. The choice to take out loans. The choice to build up on top of their subsidised loan, from either Westpac or another bank, a decent mortgage arrangement; the choice to change that loan from one house to another. That is what the service men and women have been telling the Government: `We want the choice. We do not like the delays. We would like to top up the current arrangements for loans, and we would like the freedom to transfer those loans between different houses'. After all, service men and women do have, from time to time, to shift their residences-that is one of the difficulties of being in the services-and here the Government is able to provide that.

SPEECH.PARA: So despite the cry that the Opposition makes that somehow it applauds the movement to privatisation, I suspect it would be more comfortable without it. The notion of privatisation, of course, is misleading in this case. The Government has been able to arrange that the home loans portfolios are indeed picked up by Westpac, at some considerable cost initially to Westpac, and at some considerable saving to the Government and therefore to the taxpayers. What we are able to hold in the hands of the Government are the essentials: the subsidies to the interest rate, so the interest rate never varies to the serviceman, to the person who takes out the loan. All of the insurance arrangements never vary. The security is held in the hands of service men and women. That is the key; that is what they want-flexibility, cheapness, and security, and that we have been able to offer. So it is a marvellous arrangement.

So we slip into the second criticism that the shadow Minister makes of the Bill. He does lend himself to some exaggeration when he talks about there being the poorest draftsmanship since Federation. The fact is that the Government has had to make a contract-if we can call it that-with Westpac, and obviously Westpac maintains the right or an expectation that the terms of the contract will be adhered to by the Government. That is most important to a commercial operation-Westpac. After all, Westpac put up $1.38 billion for the loans portfolio and another $100m for the premium. So it is not an exceptional case that Westpac should say, `Look, if for some reason this Bill is changed on its way through the House'-that is, with all of the elements attached to this House, its will imposed on the Bill, its ability to change it, to amend it-`should the Bill be amended, then Westpac maintains the right to renegotiate the situation'. Obviously it cannot write a contract, have the Parliament change the terms of the agreement, and then be locked in. Maybe it blows its money. That would be unfair to Westpac and ultimately, of course, unfair to service men and women who desire this new flexible arrangement.

I cannot accept that we are talking about poor draftsmanship; we are clearly not. What we are talking about is a delicate situation where a government has had negotiations with the private sector-with a bank-and we have been able to say to the bank, `You handle the loans portfolio. You do what you do best'. We can remove from the Government the weight of the raising of loans and the interest that has to be paid. We can remove from the Government the whole business of administering loans. But we cannot remove from the Government the responsibility of holding those loans and interest rates at a fixed level, to hold prime conditions for service men and women such as the marvellous insurance provision. That remains the Government's responsibility. I must say that this Bill issues in, to my mind, a new era of negotiation between the private and public sectors whereby it is possible to achieve full public sector control over essential elements of a service to one section of the community while allowing the private sector to do those things that it does well so that overall the package is the cheapest possible for that section of the community and also for the taxpayer. I commend the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Government for that negotiation and for their ability to put together the best of both possible worlds.

As for the accusation that we are stealing Opposition policies, first, it is simply not true that we are talking about privatisation; we are talking about the merging of public and private sector interests in the interests of the constituent. For some years we have given notice to the Opposition that we are looking for more flexible arrangements for home loans. That is the key, and we have been able to deliver. The point is that, although the negotiations have taken some time, they are now coming to fruition and we have achieved what the service men and women have asked us to achieve.

Again, the Opposition decries the fact that there is a limit of $25,000 on a loan. Of course, we understand that house prices have been increasing all too quickly in the past couple of years, but it seems to me that the key element of the loan is that the interest rate-the cost of the money that we can make available-is pegged at 6.8 per cent. Therefore, while the cost of homes has been increasing, the cost of borrowing money in order to purchase those homes has also been increasing on the open market. But the cost will not rise for defence personnel; it will be pegged at 6.8 per cent. I might say that that figure looks very healthy in the current climate of interest rates that are rather too high. We all understand that high interest rates will prevail for some little time, but that will not worry the defence personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long?

—I am sorry, I cannot predict. No-one can do that. But it will not worry defence personnel, because they will be saved and protected under this Bill, I might say for all time. The cost of the package is protected for defence personnel. In addition, they can negotiate add-ons. They can negotiate with Westpac or some other bank a top-up loan at reasonable interest rates. I do not believe we will see the situation that exists at present in which defence personnel obtain a defence home service loan and then have to apply for expensive bridging loans. They can do all their business at the one place, probably, but not necessarily, with Westpac. They can obtain an overall cheaper deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of the influx of post-1985 people applying for home service loans has been handled poorly by the Opposition. I guess the aim of members opposite, while acknowledging that they have been outgunned by this Bill, has been to say, `All right, the new people will get nothing. There has been a trade-off. Somehow the Government has traded off the ability to provide a magnificent arrangement for those who are already in a scheme but has knocked out future applicants.' That is not so. What the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) have been saying is that we are already working on negotiations and arrangements for the post-1985 group. But we do not necessarily want to lock ourselves into an arrangement with Westpac, for instance; we do not necessarily want to lock ourselves into a loan arrangement. Other choices may be available, so why should we not keep our options open? Why not ensure the ability to find even better ways of providing this excellent service for service men and women?

In the past couple of days, today in particular, I have received a number of calls from people in my electorate, especially from the suburb of Albany Creek, an up and coming suburb that is fairly close to Enoggera Army camp. The presence of that camp means that many Army personnel are settling in Albany Creek and those people are concerned about some of the statements made by the Opposition. They are also concerned about the change in the procedures, wondering whether they can maintain the current interest rate. They are wondering also whether they can maintain the most important elements of the service, such as insurance and so on, under the new arrangements. I can tell those people that, most definitely, all is well. They will maintain their current monthly repayment, and that is what concerns them most, I suspect, in the whole fog of changes through which they will have to work. The clearest statement is that their monthly repayments will remain the same; there will be no change to the amount of money they have to spend to cover their mortgage month after month. They can plan ahead knowing that those mortgage payments will be held. I believe that is a significant victory. The Government has arranged for a new flexible operation of the mortgage scheme but has held the cost for defence personnel.

One of the problems with the amendment moved by the honourable member for Farrer is that if it were passed-and thank goodness that will not occur-it could negate all the current generous arrangements which, for instance, provided for interest rates of about 6.8 per cent. If the new arrangement did not come into operation, we would lose the whole deal. That amendment would tie the Government's hands in looking for new and perhaps even better arrangements. Westpac-

TALK.START.PARA: —To keep you honest.

—We are honest. There is no problem there. We have done the right thing. Westpac has paid out $100m in premiums and $1.38 billion for the loans portfolio. That was a healthy decision not only for the Government but also for defence service personnel. Why should we leave Westpac, in a sense, unattended for all time? We might like to allow Westpac to face competition in relation to the post-1985 group. Therefore, we are still keeping in hand the fact that there may be future, better, more flexible and more acceptable arrangements, although I doubt whether we will achieve much better than this. It is a tremendous scheme, but we will not lock ourselves into an existing position. In any case, Westpac may not wish us to do that. This leaves open the post-1991 period, two years hence, when new people will be coming through. We may be able to make even better arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me sum up. The key elements of the Bill are those elements that service people required and asked of the Government. They did not like the 10-month waiting period. It is difficult to plan to buy a home knowing that there will be a significant wait before the mortgage is approved, and we all understand that. No-one likes sitting and waiting for the money to come through when house prices are rising. We have been able to solve that problem; the waiting period has been slashed. There will be access to a limit of more than $25,000. People will receive a subsidised amount up to $25,000 but they will be able to build in, probably with Westpac but perhaps with some other financial institution, new moneys on top of that subsidised loan without the excessive expense of bridging finance, as has been the case.

Thirdly, all the terms and conditions that currently apply to these loans will be preserved. That must be understood by the people of Albany Creek and all the defence service people in this scheme. All the rights, terms and conditions will be preserved. Of course, most important and most imminent is that the next monthly repayment will be held to exactly the same amount. We are not charging any more. There is no greater call on their limited incomes. They can plan ahead, knowing that the monthly repayment will be held down.

One of the key factors in the loan arrangements is that the new loans will be portable, and we are talking about a group which does tend to move home. They are shipped from State to State. Sometimes they might maintain a home in a State of origin but there will come a time when these families want to change home, either to shift interstate or simply to upgrade as many of us hope to do during the course of our lifetime.

Those are the five essential elements that this Bill seeks to introduce. I think we have done it well and I think all honourable members should congratulate the Ministers at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel for their excellent job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988 has been about to be introduced for over three years. It was in May 1985 that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that it was the Government's intention to arrange for private institutions to provide defence service housing loans for defence personnel. It was at that time also that the Treasurer said that the Government would eliminate the 10-month waiting period for such a loan. Tonight, some 3 1/2 years later, we finally have the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I am speaking on this subject tonight on behalf of my colleague the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), who is absent from the House on parliamentary business but who was very anxious to speak on this Bill. He has in his electorate of Macquarie the Royal Australian Air Force base at Richmond and he has provided me with material arising from his continuing dialogue with defence personnel at that station.

The coalition does support the thrust of this legislation but as the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), has indicated, we have a lot of concern about certain clauses in the schedule 1 agreement between the Commonwealth and Westpac Banking Corporation, and especially clause 6 of that agreement. Subject to that, the Bill is important and indeed welcome, at least because it removes the uncertainty that has prevailed in this area. Apart from the promise of 3 1/2 years back, in the 1987 Budget a great deal of confusion was introduced because the Treasurer said he intended to replace the $25,000 low interest loan with a $10,000 grant. That proposal has now been abandoned, but not before it fuelled considerable perceptions that conditions in the services had been further eroded, and with the lack of consultation that was seen as characteristic of an insensitive leadership. At any rate, the outcry over that proposal saw it scrapped in December and now, after another 11 months, we have this Bill to enact the privatisation and updating of the scheme.

Overdue as it is, it is welcome because it removes the uncertainty but it still contains two glaring inadequacies. The first is that while under the Westpac arrangement home buyers will be able to borrow more than the $25,000, and that is welcome and will involve a one-step deal, only repayments on the $25,000 will be subsidised by the Government. That figure of $25,000 has not been increased for some eight years, a period over which there has been a Consumer Prices Index rise of 75 per cent and of course house prices have risen even more than that. The real value of that loan has fallen very significantly indeed. When it was last increased it represented about 55 per cent of the national median price of a home but $25,000 now represents about 27 per cent, and of course in Sydney it is a laughable amount to contribute towards a home. As the honourable member for Farrer said earlier, we can now talk about the defence service caravan loan scheme, and there is some merit in so characterising it.

The second glaring inadequacy of the Bill is that post-May 1985 personnel are not covered by the scheme, and so large numbers of young soldiers, sailors and airmen are precluded. What scheme will they be covered by? After three years the Government still has not worked that out. My good colleague the honourable member for Macquarie would have me draw the attention of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) to recommendation 33 of the report on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which was tabled this month. Recommendation 33 urges the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to:
a. consider increasing the concessional interest DSH loan to $35,000, and then indexing that sum to CPI increases;
b. approve eligibility for that loan for post-May 1985 enlistees; and
c. examine an alternative DSH scheme based on the following framework:
(i) a substantial cash grant in the order of $15,000 to assist with the deposit on a home, and which should be indexed to CPI increases,
(ii) the payment of a continuing mortgage subsidy as long as the member remains in the ADF,
(iii) that subsidy to be reduced when an owner is not occupying his house, and
(iv) the subsidy to be portable (para 7.142).

I do not know how the Government can relate that to the Westpac proposal. Perhaps further negotiation is needed there. At all events, as I have indicated and as the shadow Minister has indicated, the Opposition supports the Bill overall but it needs supplementation, particularly to deal with the situation of post-May 1985 personnel. I support the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Farrer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the courtesy of giving me the opportunity to speak on the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988. I know it is unusual to have two Ministers speaking on a piece of legislation such as this, and I thank the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) for the courtesy of allowing me to speak on this measure. The Bill itself is so important, and particularly for my constituency in the Defence Force, that I think it is appropriate that I make a few comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I would like to comment briefly on the speech of the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who just spoke. He mentioned the need for a loans scheme such as that proposed and talked in a grandiose fashion about the need for that to be extended, but at no stage did he outline to this house what the Opposition's policy was on the extension of this scheme. How much will the defence forces out there be saying the Opposition is prepared to give in this loans scheme? Will it increase it? We have not heard anything about that. What is the Opposition's policy? Again a great mystery exists within the Opposition. It has no idea what its policies are on any area of defence or any area that affects defence conditions. However, that is not the case with the Government.

I want to congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who is at the table, for his successful negotiations in this very important area=msuccessful and important because it adds enhanced conditions of service for members of the Defence Force. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) explained just what they are. I would like to go through them because they are very important for members of the Defence Force. Prior to these loan provisions being inserted in the legislation before the House, for many years members of the Defence Force would have appreciated a loan such as this at a reduced interest rate of just over 6 per cent over 25 years. There has always been a catch-22 situation. This catch-22 has meant that most Defence Force personnel have not taken out this loan. One wonders why when it was so cheap. Primarily because there was a 10-month waiting period. If people who bought a house had to wait 10 months to get finance, they had to obtain bridging finance. Of course, the interest on that was so horrendous that it was just not worth while. The other major problem was that there was no portability. It is the nature of the Defence Force that personnel move a great deal, much more than I think is necessary so for many of them it was absolutely useless.

We have introduced these very important components: first of all, the 10-month waiting period will be eliminated from the time this legislation takes effect, which I hope will be in early December; secondly-I think this is very important as it means that the value of this loan is worth a lot more than the old one-the Westpac Banking Corporation has agreed to issue the loan with the rest of the money that needs to be borrowed on a house, because it has been rightly pointed out that one cannot buy a tent for $25,000 these days, on a first mortgage interest rate basis. Of course, that will vary from time to time but we guarantee the $25,000 at the 6.8 per cent interest rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 6.75 per cent.

—At 6.75 per cent. Of course, the rest of it will be based on the first mortgage interest rate. So it then makes this a much better package. Added to that is the portability, so that all new loans entered into will be portable. That means that families in the Defence Force can buy their homes very early in their career-that is one aspect that I encourage-and they can then sell that house, buy another house and take the loan with them. So these three very important aspects make this a very valuable package.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the Opposition moved an amendment to the second reading stage of this Bill? I understand its support for the legislation but we have a few problems with the amendment. Our primary problem with the amendment is that, like lots of legal clauses, it does not really say what the Opposition wants it to say. I am very sympathetic to the Opposition's position on this and I know that there has been a lot of goodwill in relation to this but, unfortunately, from the legal advice that I have had, the amendment does not achieve what the Opposition wants it to. If we proceeded with this amendment and accepted it we could negate all the very positive things about this new arrangement.

I just want to put on the record because I know this will be debated in some detail in the Senate that the legal advice that I have had indicates that the revised amendment of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) does not meet the objectives spelt out in subclause 5.2. The operation of subclause 5.2 would have the effect of including the post-1985 group within the terms of the overall Bill. Thus Westpac would be entitled to include them in the population to which it can offer the subsidised loan and, therefore, Westpac would get a free kick; it would not have to pay any additional premium with this windfall. I know that that is not the intention of the Opposition's amendment. I appreciate that; nevertheless, the legal advice that I have had indicates that that would be the effect of this amendment. Under the terms of clause 6 of the agreement with Westpac-this can be seen in schedule 1 of the Bill-Westpac would be able to withdraw from the agreement if the Commonwealth then sought to obtain such a premium or to provide for a different form of home ownership assistance for the post-1985 group. Unfortunately, the addition of the proposed new subclause 5.3 does not overcome the problem either. Effectively, it then seeks to undo the effect of subclause 5.2 but again it would fail because of the operation of clause 6 of the agreement. Put simply, subclause 5.2 would give Westpac the extra business with subclause 5.3 then purporting to take away that business. Clearly, such a course of action would be detrimental to Westpac and it could invoke clause 6 of the agreement. Further, there is considerable doubt whether subclause 5.3 would have the necessary quarantining effect. The terms `subsidy' and `agreement' which are used in this--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have now pulled out of that.
—That is good. Okay, we will leave that.
—What assurances will you give?

—I will go into that. As I have said, we have looked at the positive benefits, we have looked at the Opposition's amendment and I have indicated the legal views that I have had on that. We have other lawyers in the chamber who can have a look at the amendment and give us their interpretation. But there is a major problem when amendments such as this are introduced and when there are these different interpretations, particularly on a piece of legislation which, as I have said, is so critical to the Defence Force and to the veteran community and which offers such a benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The third area is the area of the post-1985s which I know is the spirit of the Opposition's amendment. I have been concerned about this area. I have already stated that we are looking at all sorts of options for the post-1985s. I have given a commitment that there will be a home ownership scheme for these people. In fact, on Tuesday this week I put out a statement which I would like recorded in Hansard because it is a guarantee that the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it.

—I will go through various parts of it because it is very important. The Government is considering a range of options for housing assistance for those who joined the Defence Force after May 1985. I state in this House that the housing assistance needs of those members who have joined the Defence Force since 14 May 1985 have not been forgotten and will not be forgotten. What I am really doing with those people is considering not just this type of funding for them but also a wide range of alternatives, including the provision of housing grants, forms of interest, subsidised loans and a combination of these. In fact, I am following the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am having a look at the implication of recommendation 33 in that Committee's report. It would not be appropriate for me at this stage to agree to an Opposition amendment which would give the post-1985s the same benefit as the pre-1985s. A committee of this House has stated that we should have a look at this question to see whether we can come up with an alternative scheme based on a framework of a cash grant, a continuing mortgage subsidy while people are in the Defence Force, and a subsidy to reduce when an owner is not occupying his house. That is exactly what I am doing. I think it would pre-empt any serious consideration of this report if the Government were actually to agree to the Opposition's amendment. So I reiterate that the needs of these post-1985s will be met. There is no need for the Government to be forced into making a decision on this tonight because there are a range of options--
—Or ever.

—The honourable member for Farrer said, `or ever'. That is not correct. In 1991 these people will become eligible. Until that time they are not eligible so it is important that they are given time to consider all the options that are available to them and so that I, as their Minister, can offer them the very best option that is available at the moment. I am not sure at this stage whether exactly the same benefit as that given to the pre-1985s is the best for them, but I can give a guarantee that a form of home ownership will be offered to them and that it will be a very generous benefit. At the very minimum, honourable members can be sure that those people will be looked after. Again, I thank the House for its tolerance in this matter. Finally, I reiterate that guarantee and thank the Minister at the table for his efforts on behalf of veterans and the serving members of the Defence Force.

24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
Friday, 25 November 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) at the table. We have heard about the odd couple and that Nero was fiddling while Rome burned, but these two Ministers sitting at the table, without even a ukelele between them, are singing a song of sympathy for members of the defence forces. I am disgusted, because I have just heard the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel say that she wants time to consider the options for service people. She wants to look at the 43 recommendations of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. She wants to look at the options of cash grants or subsidies of mortgages. She wants to look at the range of options. This Bill before us tonight, the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988, pre-empts her consideration of those options.
—Not for the post-85s.

—Not for the post-85s, but this is where the Minister is wrong. She looks at the statistics, the numbers, the subclauses and the clauses. What we are really looking at is 130,000 loans; that is, 130,000 Australian defence service personnel families. This Bill is being rushed through. There has not been enough time for consideration. On Tuesday 10 Bills were debated in this chamber. On Wednesday there were 13. Today, 11 were listed. It has been rushed through, yet the Minister says that we need time to consider the options. I agree entirely. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), speaking a little earlier--
—Petrie.
—I got the name from some of the honourable gentleman's colleagues. I asked two of them and they both told me it was the honourable member for Lilley.
—The member for Lilley wears a skirt.

—I am sure the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) does not-otherwise he would be part of an even more odd couple than the odd couple we have got. We have considered over 30 Bills in three days. I do not think it is appropriate that this should happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Petrie, referring to the loans, said that they would be portable. It has to be stressed that the existing loan holders do not get portability under this Bill. What happens to them? We have a loan ceiling of $25,000, with no increase since 1980. The honourable member for Petrie said, `House prices have been moving up all too quickly in the last few years. Interest rates are rather too high'.
He also said, `We all understand that interest rates will rise for some time'. That is not going to be of a great deal of interest to the 130,000 families affected by this Bill.

I particularly support the sunset clause proposed by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), because many concerned constituents have written to me or telephoned me. They are very upset by the suddenness of this measure. We have become used to government by press release, but Westpac Banking Corporation is capitalising on a situation, reaching out for captive customers. What is distressing to many people around Australia is that the Government has already passed over to Westpac personal and confidential details. The bank has tried, before the legislation has been, passed, to solicit business already. I quote from a letter from Westpac sent to one of my constituents:
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
Your assistance in completing and promptly returning the attached form is essential for us to effect the smoothest possible changeover from the Defence Service Housing Corporation to Westpac.

Westpac quotes the ex-serviceman's file number. It has the ex-serviceman's name and address. Westpac possesses personal financial details even before the legislation has passed through both Houses. I believe that this is a serious breach of confidentiality. One of my constituents has written to Westpac in the following terms:
I will not recognise your bank in any way in this matter until the enabling legislation is duly passed by Parliament and, if and when that occurs-
and it will occur-
I will expect to receive a proper form of notice of assignment of the mortgage.

It is all very cavalier, all very casual; no legislation; no decision by Parliament; yet the Government has passed the information to a private bank which then writes, `Right, we are taking you over.' The constituent's letter went on to say:
I will expect to receive a proper form of notice of assignment of the mortgage.

There has been no notice of assignment of the mortgage so far, but the bank has already sent a letter. I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that the timing is very bad. My constituent's letter continued:
At that stage, I will recognise your bank as mortgagee in place of Defence Service Homes Corporation.

I make the point very strongly that even if everything is shipshape and above board, like Caesar's wife, it has to appear to be so, and at the present time it does not, because the Parliament has not passed the legislation. The Minister has handed over the private details, without the authority of Parliament, to a private bank to make contact with 130,000 loan holders in this country. My constituent also wrote to the Defence Service Homes Corporation as follows:

By what right or power do you pass over to a private financial organisation my name and address, my file number with your corporation and, no doubt, details of the state of my mortgage and my record of payments?

That was private information. It was passed over without legislative permission or approval. That is not a satisfactory way of doing business in a corner store, let alone in the Parliament of Australia.

The other point that has to be made is one that I have had raised with me by many of my constituents. Many of them are not young any more. We have talked about the post-1985 people. We know that some are not going to have the benefit of portability. We are talking about men who served in World War II, in Korea, and in Vietnam. As always, where there is change, there is fear, uncertainly and unsettlement. Because of the rush I have not had time to investigate the Bill as thoroughly as I would like. The Minister can blame me if he likes. I do not know what guarantees have been built into the legislation. How do the 130,000 loan holders in Australia know? They have not been informed. The Minister has not written to them. The bank has only written to say, `We want your business; nominate the branch you want.' Nobody has said to the loan holders `You're protected, you're guaranteed. Don't worry, the bank is not going to rip you off tomorrow. The interest rates won't rise.'
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

The Minister knows that I have affection for him, that I like, respect and trust him; but he must do better. He cannot take it for granted. Australians cannot take it for granted either. It comes back to the responsible Minister-and he is a responsible Minister; I say that with sincerity-to make it very clear to those 130,000 families that they will not be done like a dinner. They do not know what to expect and they are fearful and concerned that Westpac will raise the interest rate at its pleasure. Safeguards must exist. They are concerned at what might happen with bank fees and charges. Nobody has told them. All they have got is a letter from big brother government and big brother bank which says to the ex-servicemen or current servicemen or to one of the 130,000 Australian families, `Don't you worry about that'. And we have heard that before. It says, `We'll look after you, just sign it'.

I say to the Minister that it is not good enough. What about the ex-servicemen who have not yet taken up their eligibility for a loan? Are they protected in the future? Will they be subject to negotiation in the future?

In conclusion, I repeat that it is not good enough to do it in this particular way. It is not good enough to hand over confidential personal records to a private bank without the authority of the Parliament. I suggest that the responsibility lies on the Minister to ensure that those 130,000 Australian families will not get done like the proverbial dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will not take too long tonight as I know everyone is anxious to get home. I can see the Opposition Whip running around in a hurry to make sure he also gets home. Being a former Whip I know the pressures put on Whips. However, I must take time to respond to my learned colleagues the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) who is the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and our famous professor, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). It is good to see him taking part in this debate.
—What about the Minister who is sitting on the front bench?

—I will come to our side in a moment. I was a little disappointed in the Opposition's contributions. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Cowper said that he had not read the legislation properly. I forgive him for that and I appreciate his sincere concern. I do not believe that any Opposition members have read their policy and that includes the shadow Minister. I will read some of it out in a minute. I suggest it is compulsory reading for all Opposition members. I point out to honourable members that there is a dud in the first paragraph of the Opposition's policy. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Veterans will retain their once only access.

Do honourable members know how many times we will allow veterans to have access to the scheme? It could be up to three times, but the Opposition is cutting it back to once only. It is in its policy, and there have to be special circumstances to get an extra opportunity. The Opposition has cut them back. We will let the veterans and war widows know that. The Opposition has also been talking about the post-May 1985ers. Can we see anywhere in its policy mention of the post-May 1985ers. They are not mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that their latest policy?
—It is the Opposition's policy. I give the Opposition credit for having a policy. All the good parts in the policy we have already implemented for the veterans.
—You pinched them.

—No, we did not pinch them. The honourable member for Cowper must read the Opposition's policy. The policy is to sell off the Defence Service housing scheme. That is the coalition's policy. The honourable member for Cowper has spoken a lot of nonsense tonight. The shadow Minister is very capable of and very good at skulduggery. He stirs up a bit of fear amongst the veterans community. I give him credit for that. All Opposition members should read their policy. It says the Opposition would sell off the scheme. To whom would the Opposition sell it? Would it do the same as we did? The honourable member for Cowper said that the Westpac Banking Corporation is terrible.
—We did not say that at all.

—Yes, he did. He said that Westpac want to increase interest rates. I ask the honourable member to read the second reading speech and the letter that we sent to veterans. He should read the letter Westpac sent to veterans. It said in its letter that the scheme related to the pending passage of the legislation. The honourable member said that Westpac and the Government were usurping the powers of the Parliament. That is absolute nonsense. We have guaranteed the veteran community that veterans will not be subjected to any increases. The Commonwealth will pay the extra charges if interest rates go up. If the Bank put them up of its own free will we would pay the extra. Veterans will not be disadvantaged in any way. We keep the insurance scheme. We have to assess the veterans and say who is entitled to loans. We still have those functions. I can give honourable members a total guarantee that the veteran community has nothing to fear in relation to this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: 24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

Westpac and the Government sat around the table. The veteran community was represented by none other than Sir William Keys, and other very highly distinguished Australians were on the negotiating committee. It was all worked out properly. Opposition members are all preachers and protectors of the free enterprise system. When we do a deal-it may be a deal with the person across the road-do they not think it fair that we should stick to it? The Opposition is saying that we should change the rules and the deal and that the bank should not be allowed to say, that is not the deal to which we agreed'. The honourable member would not want to agree to a deal with me, allow me to change it, and forgo the right to say, `No thank you'. If he went to a secondhand car dealer and said, `I will give you $5,000 for that car. There is $1,000 deposit' and when he went back, the dealer said it would cost $5,500, would he pay the extra $500? The answer is no. Once a deal is made we must stick to it. Nobody is usurping the powers of the Parliament. I know that the shadow Minister wants to move an amendment. I will not take too much longer.

I make the point to the House that there is nothing to fear. The veteran community has nothing to fear. As I said, Opposition members should read the policy and read the legislation. They will see that the guarantees are there. The shadow Minister is very capable of stirring. Apparently, he has got to Opposition members in the party meeting; he has even got the professor worried. All the shadow Minister has been talking about is the post-May 1985ers but there is nothing in the Opposition's policy that deals with them. It says, `when financial resources are available, when the time is right, we will do these things. We cannot do them until we have got the money'. That is all in the policy. I ask honourable members to read it. It is an absolute nonsense. It is a great effort to try to stir up members of the defence forces. They have a very good Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in Minister Kelly. They have no worries. She will look after them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they have Minister Beazley.

—Yes. They have the mega Minister and the minor Minister-they are both here. Next time Opposition members debate anything they should not demean the people at Westpac. They should not demean the officers responsible for the Defence Service housing scheme. They have all worked very hard. They should not demean the highly distinguished Australians who were on the negotiating committee. It took a long time to devise the scheme and it is gilt-edged. No veteran will be disadvantaged by this scheme. Minister Kelly knows, the shadow Minister knows, and I know, that all veterans are happy with the scheme. The veteran community and the majority of the defence forces are very happy with the scheme. The shadow Minister knows about the good parts of it. The strange thing is that the Opposition is supporting the legislation. The shadow Minister will move an amendment shortly which is absolute nonsense. We will not accept it. The Opposition will not call for a division because they are not all here. We have the numbers and the Opposition does not.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 4, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:

``(2) On and after 15 May 1991, the words added to section 4aaa of the Principal Act by subsection (1) are omitted from that subsection and, subject to subsection (3), the Principal Act has effect as if subsection (1) had not been enacted.

``(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (2), the Secretary shall not issue a certificate of entitlement in relation to an advance to a person whose first service in the Defence Force began after 14 May 1985, and no such person may exercise any right under that subsection, unless and until a new or amended arrangement, concerning these persons, is negotiated and endorsed by the enactment of legislation.''.

I will not detain the Parliament for too long. I just wish to draw attention again to clause 5 of this incredible piece of legislation. I acknowledge that the Defence Services Homes Amendment Bill contains a number of benefits, and I indicated that in my speech during the second reading debate. I commend to the Committee the `scalpel' sunset clause which we seek to insert after clause 5. In so doing I make it clear that neither the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) in his excellent contribution nor the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) in any way demeaned the role or integrity of the officers of the Defence Services Homes Corporation or the Westpac Banking Corporation. Certainly I recognise that there is an agreement in schedule 1 and if there are alterations to that by the Parliament these will have to be referred back to Westpac in that context. But in the drafting of this Bill any other matters relating to this general area of legislation, but not impinging on that agreement, have been caught up in this same reduction in the capability to move amendments.

Indirectly our amendment also relates to the role and function of the staff of the Defence Service Homes Corporation, which has not been discussed in the debate thus far tonight. Staff members have a right to expect proper recompense under the new arrangements. Their employment basis is being completely altered and negotiations are continuing in that regard. It is important that a fair go be extended in that respect and that no deeds are held up as a result of industrial troubles. That would create massive and unfair hardship for those who are affected.

I commend the amendment. There are different interpretations in respect of the complexities of this Bill and there are different interpretations even with the revised wording which I have proposed. This scalpel sunset clause seeks to provide a legally binding timetable in legislation for the Government to act in respect of new enlistees. That is not unreasonable. I seem to have flushed out a team of three Ministers for this debate tonight and I point out to them that it is not unreasonable to insert a legally binding timetable. I shall give an example of another assurance that was given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) during the tangle on the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The Minister will remember giving an assurance to this House that a defence compensation scheme would be introduced and that this would occur within a matter of months. At the time he said that there was no need to keep Armed Forces personnel under the auspices of the Veterans' Entitlements Act because he would look after them in the next session of Parliament. Here we are, two years later, not having seen hide nor hair of that defence compensation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member must keep to the Defence Services Homes Amendment Bill. He must not stray into any previous legislation that has been before the House.

—It is relevant to make a passing reference. This amendment seeks to insert a legally binding timetable. It does not interfere or alter in any way, shape or form the thrust and fundamental aspects of this Bill. It is all about a scalpel sunset clause to ensure that, come May 1991, new enlistees will make a further progress down the path to becoming eligible for the Defence Service Homes loans scheme if the Government has taken no action by that time. The Government has given some assurances. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has placed those assurances in Hansard and I acknowledge that, but nothing can be stronger than the insertion of the exact words into the legislation in a way which is neutral in terms of its impact on Westpac and on the schedule 1 agreement. I highlight to the Committee that the actual construction of the words of the amendment is such that the amendment, which is in two parts, has to be read, considered and taken as a whole. There are two interlocking clauses which specifically provide for (2) and (3) to be taken as a whole. The amendment must be considered as a whole. I commend it to the Committee for all those reasons in the same way as I commend the thrust of the coalition's veterans' affairs policy which is the genesis for this action, because it is all about a fair go for veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendments Nos 1 to 7 and 9 be disagreed to.

These amendments are basically a series put forward by the Opposition in the Senate. In all cases, on examination of the amendments the Government feels that most of the underlying reasons for the Opposition's amendments have in fact been picked up in the legislation. A substantial number of the suggested changes, rather than advancing the privacy requirements, in fact create unnecessary impediments to those who have the substantial task of ensuring that the right of privacy are protected. For those reasons, on whole, the Government has rejected the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks on each of the amendments, although I believe our attitude was adequately expressed in the debate in the Senate on each of those amendments. With respect to amendment No. 1, this was moved by the Australian Democrats. It is an amendment to information privacy principle No. 2. Senator Hill explained the Opposition's attitude and our support for the amendment is in the Senate Hansard at page 2542. I believe that is an adequate explanation of our position. I will not detain the Committee to advance any further arguments on it. It should be noted, however, that the amendment was in fact carried without a division. Our submission to the Government is that it should support the amendment. It does not do any damage to the information privacy principle. We do not accept the Government's arguments about it. We believe the Government should support this amendment because it is an improvement to the information privacy principles. For those reasons and for the reasons advanced by Senator Hill in the Senate we believe that the Government is unwise in rejecting this amendment. It should have accepted it and it should now.

SPEECH.PARA: 24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

With respect to amendment No. 2, this likewise is an amendment that was moved by the Australian Democrats. It is an amendment to information privacy principle No. 3. Senator Hill explained the reasons for our support for the Democrats' amendment at page 2543 of the Senate Hansard. There is no need for me to advance further arguments at this stage. As with its predecessor, the amendment was carried in the Senate without a division. Our belief is that the Government should have supported the amendment then and should support it now.

With respect to amendments Nos 3 and 4, these also were Australian Democrats' amendments and the Opposition supported them in the Senate. Senator Hill explained our support for these two amendments at page 2545 of the Senate Hansard. On that occasion also the amendments were carried without a division. Likewise we believe in this case that the amendments should be supported. They are in fact again amendments to the information privacy principles. Amendment No. 3 is an amendment to information privacy principle No. 5. Amendment No. 4 is an amendment to information privacy principle No. 5. They are both worthwhile amendments. They are, of course, not absolutely vital, and that can be said of the previous amendments that I have referred to, but they are significant and desirable. I cannot understand why the Government puts its head in the sand and refuses to accept sensible and reasonable amendments. Even at this late stage the Government should accept the amendments. With respect to amendment No. 5, this was an Opposition amendment, as were amendment Nos 6 and 7. These amendments were agreed to by the Senate. They were carried with the support of the Australian Democrats without a division. The Opposition believes that the amendments are worthwhile.

Very briefly, the situation is this: Under this Bill there may be an individual or, if you like, a personal complaint made about an infringement of privacy and there may be what is known as a representative complaint, that is to say, where the complaint is made on behalf of other persons. The odd thing is that the remedies available and the relief available are different in both of those cases. There is no reason why the relief should be different. As Senator Hill said in the Senate, where there is a representative complaint and somebody is acting on behalf of two or more complainants, it is now not possible for a declaration to be made that the complainant, that is to say, the person who complains about the infringement of privacy, is entitled to a specific amount by way of compensation for any loss or damage suffered by reason of the act or practice the subject of the complaint. That is the case where a representative complaint is made. Senator Hill went on to say that, in other words, one of the remedies available to the Privacy Commissioner in the case of an individual complaint is not available in relation to a representative complaint as the Bill stands at the moment. Our amendment is designed to remedy that deficiency, and deficiency we believe it to be. There is no reason why in the case of a representative complaint there should not be an award of compensation made or an award of costs, and the amendments are designed to put that proposition into practice. So as the amendments were carried by the Senate, we believe that they should be accepted here.
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

With respect to amendment No. 9, this also was an opposition amendment. We believe it was a reasonable, sensible and worthwhile amendment and an amendment which the Democrats supported and which was agreed to without a division. How the amendment arises is quite simply this: the Privacy Bill provides a statutory method of obtaining relief if one's privacy is infringed. The way it is done-there is no need to go into it in detail-is that one makes a complaint to the Privacy Commissioner and the Privacy Commissioner investigates it and may make an award of compensation to the complainant because of the invasion of his privacy. Indeed, the Commissioner may then make an award of compensation to the complainant because of the invasion of his privacy. Indeed, the Commissioner may then make an award or an order for the expenses incurred by the complainant. We say that is fair enough. That is one way of doing it. But there should also be a right to sue for breach of privacy. Amendment No. 9 sets out how that would operate; that is, where there is an interference with the privacy of an individual, then the individual may sue for breach of privacy and may obtain from the court damages, or an injunction or some other appropriate order.

There is no reason why that amendment should not be accepted by the Government. It is an additional remedy. It is a sensible remedy. It is a worthwhile remedy. It is a remedy which will operate as something of a sanction. It will keep agencies and the private sector on their toes to make sure that they make efforts to prevent infringements of privacy taking place. A person whose privacy is invaded should have the right to sue. The amendment is designed to give to people in those circumstances the right to sue for damages. The Government should think again about this. It is not too late for the Government to accept the amendment. That is what should be done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
