Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to;
That Mr Cunningham, Mr Lamb and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendments Nos 1 to 7 and 9 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendments Nos 1 to 7 and 9 of the Senate, I bring up such reasons, which are being circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons read as follows-
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable because-
The proposed requirement that the individual be informed in writing would be burdensome for agencies and of limited benefit to some individuals.

Information Privacy Principle 2 is expressed in terms that would cover a wide range of collection practices of agencies and can be tailored to suit a variety of circumstances. The Privacy Commissioner is empowered to issue guidelines on what would be sufficient information for an individual to be made generally aware of the purpose of collection, the legal authority for the collection and the usual disclosure practices of the collector.
Senate amendment No. 2 is not acceptable because-
There are practical difficulties in imposing an obligation on agencies to check the accuracy of personal information at the time of collection.

Information Privacy Principle 3 requires a record-keeper collecting personal information to take reasonable steps to ensure that the information is relevant to the purpose of collection, up to date and complete. The record-keeper is also required to ensure that the collection of the information does not intrude to an unreasonable extent upon the personal affairs of the individual concerned.
Information Privacy Principles 7 and 8 provide important privacy safeguards for individuals by requiring record-keepers to correct inaccuracies before making any use of information in records.
Senate amendment No. 3 is not acceptable because-
Information Privacy Principle 5 requires the record-keeper to provide information to enable any person to ascertain the main purposes for which that information is used.

Agencies may have a range of purposes for which personal information is used. It would be impractical to require agencies to set out all the possible purposes for which information held by an agency is used.
Senate amendment No. 4 is not acceptable because-

The amendment is directed at enabling a person to find out the information handling practices of the record-keeper. The Information Privacy Principles already do this. Information Privacy Principle 2 requires information to be provided by record-keepers about their disclosure practices. Information Privacy Principle 5 also requires the record-keeper to maintain a public record setting out extensive information about the personal records kept and how to obtain access to those records.

The Privacy Commissioner is empowered to issue guidelines on the safe storage and security or records of personal information. It is not appropriate for individuals to be given details of security controls on information held by a record-keeper.
Senate amendment No. 5 is not acceptable because-

It is a condition for the handling of a complaint as a representative complaint that the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied that the class of persons making complaints is so numerous that joinder of all its members is impracticable. The Commissioner can waive this condition if justice demands that the matter be dealt with as a representative complaint. Accordingly, the awarding of compensation to each member of the class is likely to give rise to practical difficulties.

In the case of representative complaints, the main remedy is likely to be the cessation of the act or practice giving rise to the complaint rather than compensation. A similar approach has been taken in relation to complaints under the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.
An individual who believes compensation is justifiable can bring an individual complaint notwithstanding that a representative complaint has been brought.
Senate amendment No. 6 is not acceptable because-

It is a condition for the handling of a complaint as a representative complaint that the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied that the class of persons making complaints is so numerous that joinder of all its members is impracticable. The Commissioner can waive this condition if justice demands that the matter be dealt with as a representative complaint. Accordingly, the awarding of expenses for cost incurred in making the complaint to each member of the class is likely to give rise to practical difficulties.
Senate amendment No. 7 is not acceptable because-
The provision should not be deleted as the definition of complainant in relation to a representative complaint needs to include all the persons on whose behalf the complaint is made.
Senate amendment No. 9 is not acceptable because-

The Bill provides a right to complain to the Privacy Commissioner, who conducts an investigation and may award compensation. This will give the Australian people a simple and effective remedy. For most people, it will be a more accessible and cheaper remedy than an action in the courts.
This is the approach the Parliament has adopted for other interferences with the rights of individuals in the areas of sex discrimination and race discrimination.

An injunction can also be obtained from the Federal Court to restrain a breach of the Privacy Act. The remedy enables the Privacy Commissioner or an individual to get a privacy infringing practice stopped.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the Committee's reasons be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must acknowledge at the outset my appreciation of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for having said that there was sufficient force in the arguments advanced as to why this matter should be recommitted and that the Government felt that that was the proper course to take. Indeed, it must be true to say that there was sufficient force in that argument. The view has been expressed by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and me that some regularisation should take place with respect to the passage or otherwise of Opposition amendments which were moved to the Copyright Amendment Bill at about 5.30 yesterday afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: 24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

Because the Minister has said that there was sufficient force in the argument to justify this course being taken I will certainly say less about the matter than I otherwise would have said. However, it must be placed on record that the bare facts of the matter are that yesterday a series of Opposition amendments was declared by the Chairman of Committees, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) to have been passed. There must be no doubt about that. The amendments were put to a vote. It was announced that the vote had been carried. As I say, there is no doubt but that the Opposition's amendments, judging by what was said in the House, were carried. Indeed, the tape recording of the Hansard record of those proceedings makes that abundantly clear. I have had the opportunity to hear the Hansard tape recording myself and can verify that personally.

Two other things must also be said. The first is that the Clerks of the Parliament recorded what undoubtedly they genuinely believed had happened. That should be said quite clearly. They did that because they assumed that the Government knew what it was doing and that the Government was doing what it wanted done. That is not an assumption made by everyone in the Australian community, but it clearly was the genuine assumption that was made on this occasion.

The second thing that must be said with equal force is that the fault in this matter and the fact that we are now driven to take these proceedings clearly must be sheeted home to the Government and especially to the Minister who was in charge of this Bill at the time. He is called the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, a very curious title for a Minister, I must say. It sounds like he is in charge of some sort of dry dock. In any event, he was the Minister in charge of the Bill. It was his responsibility to make sure that the Government's intentions were expressed clearly. He clearly did not do that. The result was that the Opposition amendments-as I have said, judging by what was said in the House and recorded on the Hansard recording-were carried.

An unfortunate situation has arisen. It can fairly be described as a shambles. The shambles has the Minister's fingerprints all over it. We will proceed-not at too much length-with the amendments again solely because a Government Minister did not have his wits about him and did not understand what he was doing. He was sitting there drawing his salary. I do not know whether he was doing the Herald crossword at the time or what, but whatever he was doing he was certainly not paying attention to the amendments that were being promoted by the Opposition and he certainly was not aware of the Government's position on the amendments. Nor was he taking the proper course to ensure that the Opposition amendments were negatived, if that was his intention. So, for those reasons we support this motion, but we say that the motion has come about only because of Government incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:

``(1a) Section 10 commences on a day on which it is declared by Proclamation that an amendment has been made to the Designs Act 1906 and that that amendment has commenced operation, being an amendment that enables the registration under the Designs Act 1906 of corresponding designs that are presently not registrable under that Act for any reason other than that they are not new or original.''.
(2) Clause 10, page 4, lines 33 and 34, omit all words after ``whether'' to the end of proposed paragraph 77 (1) (a) substitute ``made at any time on or after the commencement of this section''.
(3) Clause 10, page 4, line 36, after ``elsewhere,'' insert ``at any time on or after the commencement of this section,''.

We believe that these amendments are important, in the first place, because the Copyright Act and the Copyright Amendment Bill are important themselves. They are important to industry and commerce in general and, with respect to the particular part that we are concerned about at the moment, they are of importance to that section of industry which is concerned with industrial designs.

Briefly, what has happened in this case is that the new section 75 of the Copyright Act will provide that in certain cases, with respect to what are defined as corresponding designs, there will not be an infringement of copyright if there are reproduced works which have had the design applied to them. I know that sounds a bit complicated to those who come new to this particular field, but the situation, briefly, is that there has been some overlap between protection for industrial designs provided by copyright and protection for them provided under the Designs Act 1906.

The purpose of the amendment is as follows. I have already said that the new section 75 of the Act will remove, in effect, copyright protection where the corresponding design is or has been registered under the Designs Act. One might say, so far so good. But the problem arises because of the new section 77 of the Copyright Act. The new section 77 will say that in those cases where copyright subsists in an artistic work and where a corresponding design of that artistic work is applied industrially and articles to which the corresponding design has been applied are sold, and also, and, finally, where the corresponding design is not registered under the Designs Act, then in those cases it is not an infringement of the copyright in the artistic work to reproduce the work on or after the day on which the articles made to the corresponding design are first so sold, let for hire, or offered or exposed for sale or hire.
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

What the consequence of that is, in our belief-and we have had advice to this effect-is that it is, in effect, removing all protection from some industrial designs. It is saying, in the first place, that there is to be no copyright protection for them. There may be some case for doing that. But then having said that, one then picks out a class of designs and one says that where these are not registered under the Designs Act, and indeed, where they are not registrable under the Designs Act, then likewise there is no infringement of copyright. In other words, there is no protection from the copyright law in that case either. That is a very curious situation to bring about deliberately. Representations have been made to use to the effect that investors and entrepreneurs will not invest in research and development if the product of their labours is some design and where, perhaps without their control, articles are being made as a result, in effect, of stealing that design and there is no protection for the investor or designer. Why will people invest in research and development if the unfortunate result is that there will be no protection?

Putting it in a nutshell-and it is a very simple point-the Government is removing Copyright Act and Designs Act protection from these industrial designs, to the detriment of Australian industry. I thought that part of the Government's case was that it would do everything it could to promote and protect industry-not by tariffs or in the narrow sense of the word-so that encouragement was given to people to invest and expand in industry and commerce. The Government is doing exactly the opposite. In doing so, it is putting at risk people who have put a lot of money, effort and intellectual skill into design work which they do not want to have stolen but which they want to have protected so that they can exploit it to the benefit of this country and industry as a whole. In a nutshell, the amendments propose to prevent the provisions of this part of the Bill from coming into operation until the Government rectifies the Designs Act problem. It does not cancel it out; it simply says that the Government should put the protection house in order so that there is protection under either the copyright law or the Designs Act before this part of the Copyright Amendment Bill comes into operation.

REPRESENTATIVES 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

I have received information that on 15 November-the Government should pay attention to this, if it is interested in Australian industry and its promotion and the protection of designs which can be used to the benefit of this country and its industry; if it can concentrate on it for a few minutes-in the United Kingdom, the royal assent was given to the Copyright Designs and Patents Act 1988. The result is that the United Kingdom now has an unregistered design right rather than a system of dual protection as under the Copyright Act and the Designs Act, or their equivalents in the United Kingdom. Protection has been given in this way in the United Kingdom and it should be given here. The purpose of our amendments is to achieve that end result. It will not do any harm to the Government or to its Bill. It will not do any harm to the desirable objectives of the Bill or what the Government wants to achieve. It is plain common sense that we do not take from Australian industrial designs both protection under the copyright law and protection under the Designs Act. We hope that the Government will have the good sense to accept the amendments.

It is not necessary for me to detain the Committee by debating these matters at length, because they were canvassed yesterday in the second reading debate and my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) explained the purpose of the amendments. Briefly, they apply to two situations. First, they provide a definition in the Bill of those organisations that will not be obliged to pay the royalty on blank audio tapes that the Government will impose in order to provide Mr Steedman's $80,000 a year salary, amongst other purposes. That seems to be the only specific and immediate repository and beneficiary of the royalties as far as I can see. The objectives of the scheme are to provide compensation for owners of copyright which is infringed as a result of people at home recording music and other productions on audio cassettes. It is said that the royalty will go to the copyright owners and one hopes that it will be spread amongst the artists, lyricists and musicians as a compensation for the creative endeavours they have put into their works, for which they are not presently being fully compensated.

Some organisations and persons will not have to pay the royalty when they buy the blank tapes and we believe that, because under the Bill there will be prescribed organisations, it is only commonsense that the Bill should state what those organisations are. The purpose of the amendment is to make plain exactly what those organisations are. What earthly reason there is to oppose that amendment, I do not know at this stage, but I trust that the Minister will provide an explanation when he rejects it. It will certainly be a fuller explanation than the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) gave. Frankly, I can see no reason why the amendment cannot be accepted.

The second amendment does a fairly harmless thing: nevertheless it is an important and significant thing, and that is to require the Attorney-General to table in the Parliament the annual report that he will receive on the operation of the fund under which the royalty is collected and how it is distributed. We ask, why should it be kept a secret? What is the big secret about it? The Government is taking a royalty-a fancy name for a tax-from the Australian public whenever people buy an audio cassette tape. It is compulsory that people pay the royalty if they are to use the tape to record copyright material. I know that you, Mr Chairman, are about to ask, `What happens to the money after that?' After that, the money goes into a fund that is run by a collecting society, which consists of the owners of copyright. One may well ask, `How do we know that some of the money will find its way to the lyricists and others who are, at the end of the day, entitled to some of it? How do we know it will work efficiently? How do we know there is not a better way of operating the royalty scheme? How do we know those things? We do not know them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the detailed expenditure on Aboriginal assistance by (a) each department and (b) statutory authority in 1986-87.
(2) What funds have been received for mining royalties on land owned by Aborigines by (a) Aboriginal recipient organisations and (b) the Federal Government in each year since 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims made by the Queensland Health Minister that the Commonwealth is discriminating against that State by way of health grants and Commonwealth assistance.

(2) What is the correct position and will he outline the financial assistance given by the Government to Queensland from 1983 to 1987 and to be granted in 1988-89 in the area of (a) Medicare, (b) identified health grants and (c) general financial assistance grants.
(3) What changes has the Government made to ensure and, if necessary, force the Queensland Government to spend its full health appropriations and grants in the health area.
(4) How does Queensland fare in comparison with the national average and other States under the new arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. My attention has been drawn to claims made by the Queensland Health Minister that the Commonwealth discriminates against that State when determining health grants. It appears to be a Queensland ritual that, once the Commonwealth Budget is announced, the claim of inequitable distribution of Medicare and other health funding is raised by the State Health Minister. In making these claims, the Minister conveniently forgets how these grants are derived and the overall Commonwealth/State financial arrangements which are negotiated at Premiers' Conferences.

I refer the Queensland Health Minister to the 1985 Premiers' Conference where a number of issues relevant to her claims were raised. In the context of that Conference, the Health Minister may recall that when Medicare was introduced, the Commonwealth requested the Grants Commission, in its review of tax-sharing relativities, to identify specifically whether the introduction of Medicare had disturbed the health relativities between States that existed prior to Medicare. The Grants Commission reported that health relativities had been disturbed and an amount of $10m was identified as necessary to restore Queensland's relativity for the two years 1983-84 and 1984-85. The Commonwealth accepted the Grants Commission report and the $10m was paid to Queensland in 1985-86.

At the Premier's Conference, it was also agreed that the identified Health Grants would continue as separate payments for the 1985-86 triennium. However, in the context of overall Commonwealth/ State financial arrangements, adjustments and offsets were made to the general financial assistance grants in lieu of adjusting the Identified Health Grants. In other words, the Identified Health Grants would be health grants in name only. This means that when comparing Identified Health Grant payments amongst States, general financial assistance grants must also be taken into account.

Table 1 shows the Medicare Compensation Grants. Identified Health Grants and general financial assistance grants paid to the States and the Northern Territory from 1983-84 to 1987-88 and compares the corresponding per capita distribution of these grants. The table shows that the per capita funding for Queensland exceeds the national average and those of the two most populous States.

Medicare Compensation Grants, Identified Health Grants and Financial Assistance Grants paid to the States and the Northern Territory in the period 1983-84 to 1987-88 and the corresponding per capita distribution

Medicare Compensation Grants and Identified Health Grants ceased on 30 June 1988. New hospital funding arrangements will apply from 1988-89 and continue for the next five years. Under these new arrangements, the Commonwealth has allocated about $3063m nationally for hospital funding, to be distributed to the States and Territories on an age and sex weighted per capita distribution.

The new grants identify unequivocally the level of Commonwealth support for the Queensland public hospital system. No longer can the Queensland Health Minister produce selective facts to support her claim that Queensland suffers some disadvantage compared to other States.

The hypocrisy surrounding the claims of the Queensland Health Minister can be judged by her reaction to the Commonwealth offer of an age and sex per capita distribution of hospital grants, an offer which, incidentally, would increase the level of Commonwealth funding specifically identified for health in Queensland from around $224m in 1987-88 to $500m in 1988-89. The Minister claimed the new arrangements were an intrusion by the Commonwealth into State affairs and that they constrained her Government's ability to control its own health care system. There could not be a more equitable way to distribute the new grants than the method adopted nor is there any substance to the claim that the Commonwealth will exercise effective control over the Queensland health system.
Table 2 details the estimated Financial Assistance Grants and the new Hospital Grants that will be paid to the States and the Northern Territory and their per capita distributions in 1988-89

(3) Almost all of the new Hospital Funding Grant is in the form of untied grants and, in that sense, the Commonwealth cannot be prescriptive about its specific use. However, the estimated net cost of maintaining the Queensland public hospital system in 1987-88 was $895m. On this basis, it can be assumed that all of the Commonwealth Hospital Funding Grant will be allocated to public hospitals in 1988-89.

Nevertheless, there are a number of specific components within the Hospital Funding Grants which provide incentives to Queensland to make more effective use of hospital resources. There is $1.652m for the development of additional day-only procedure arrangements and $4.129m for post-acute and palliative care services. These funds are specific purpose grants and the State will be required to expend them on jointly agreed projects.

The Commonwealth also has applied conditions under the new arrangements that require each State to maintain at least 53% of its bed-day utilisation for public patients. Further, in-hospital Medicare benefit payments are to be maintained at or below 105% of the national average. If States do not adhere to these conditions, reductions will be made to their hospital funding grants.

(4) It can be seen from Table 2 that, once again, Queensland's per capita share of the combined total of both grants is greater than the national average and greater than those for New South Wales and Victoria. More importantly, a comparison of the per capita distribution figures for 1987-88 in Table 1 compared with the estimated for 1988-89 shows Queensland is the only State to record an increase in the overall distribution.

Queensland's per capita share of the hospital grants in 1988-89 is marginally lower than the national average and lower than all the other States except Western Australia. This does not, of course, imply Commonwealth discrimination against Queensland: it simply reflects the fact that Queensland has a younger population than the other States and therefore has a lower demand for hospital services.

In the final analysis, recourse to the facts disproves the claims of the Queensland Health Minister and reveals her position on Commonwealth health funding to be nothing more than political posturing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the recently released report on the Options Project indicate that (a) it was intended that there be an increase of 11 585 hostel options between 1987 and 1989, (b) the personal care subsidy rate would increase by 68% between 1987 and 1992 and (c) there would be an increase in the proportion of residents who would be in receipt of the highest level of benefit.
(2) Have estimates been prepared to assess the likely increase in capital and operating expenditure caused by these increases.
(3) What is the level of operating expenditure estimated annually from 1989 to 1992 and what percentage increase does this represent over expenditure for 1987-88.
(4) How does the level of capital and operating expenditure and the rate of increase in total expenditure compare with increases in expenditure under the Home and Community Care Program.
(5) What grounds are there for an expansion at the rate of over 3000 places a year for the next 3 years.
(6) How many of the 3082 places that were expected to be established in 1987 have been approved for funding and what is the capital commitment involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. The Hostel Options Report that was released in December 1987 did indicate that it was intended that there be an increase of 11,585 hostel places over the three years from 1987 to 1989. The Government has confirmed this intention and, as I announced on 17 July, some 12,296 new hostel places will be funded over the next three years up to June 1991.

(b) Yes. The total real increase in the Personal Care Subsidy over the period from May 1988 to April 1992 will in fact be 68%. The Government announced in March 1987 that, in addition to the annual indexation of all three hostel subsidies (i.e. personal care, hostel care and respite care) and the real increase of $2.60 a day for the Personal Care Subsidy in May 1987, the Personal Care Subsidy rate would be increased by five annual real increases of $1.50 per day in 1987 prices, commencing in May 1988. The first of these increases ($1.60 a day, in current terms) took effect on 4 May 1988.
(c) Yes. As hostels assume a greater role in caring for more frail aged people the proportion of hostel residents receiving Personal Care Subsidy will rise.

(2) and (3) Current estimates for Commonwealth expenditure on all three hostel recurrent subsidies are $118.5 million in 1988-89, $152 million in 1989-90 and $191.7 million in 1990-91, increases respectively of 30%, 67% and 110% over 1987-88 expenditure.

In this context, total expenditure on Personal Care Subsidy is estimated to increase by $14 million in 1988-89 to $103 million, by a further $32 million in 1989-90 to $135 million and by $38.5 million in 1990-91 to $173.5 million, increases respectively of 15.7%, 51.7% and 94.9% over 1987-88 expenditure as a result of both the real increases in Personal Care Subsidy commencing in May 1988 and the increase in the proportion of residents receiving Personal Care Subsidy.

Capital expenditure for aged residential care is estimated to increase from $65 million in 1987-88 to $96 million in 1988-89 with further increases to $126 million in 1989-90 and to $137 million in 1990-91. This represents increases respectively of 47%, 93.8% and 110.8% over 1987-88 expenditure.

(4) Expenditure by the Commonwealth on HACC is expected to rise by $40 million in 1988-89 from $169 million to $209 million, by $48.7 million to $257.7 million in 1989-90, by $64.7 million to $322.4 million in 1990-91 and by a further $64.4 million to $386.8 million in 1991-92. This represents increases respectively of 23.7%, 52.5%, 90.8% and 128.9% over 1987-88 expenditure.
It is obvious from the figures set out above that both the hostel program and the HACC program are experiencing significant increases in Commonwealth funding.

(5) The proposed expansion of over 3000 hostel places a year is based on the Government's residential planning arrangements which aim to maintain a national average provision ratio of 100 residential places per 1000 persons aged 70 and over. A maximum 10% of new approvals in any one year will be for nursing home approvals, in order to effect a gradual change in the current mix of 63 nursing home places to 37 hostel places nationally to a ratio of 40 nursing home places to 60 hostel places.

The Government's approach to planning of residential care services is consistent with the findings of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review which concluded that there are a number of indications that present provision in Australia is sufficient for current needs, particularly given the relatively high level of provision when compared with other countries.
(6) In 1987-88, 3,192 new nursing home and hostel places and 131 staff places were approved for capital funding. The total capital commitment by the Commonwealth is $79,538,712.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Government prepare the publication entitled ``Short guide to living in a nursing home''.
(2) What was the cost of producing the publication and how many were printed.
(3) Who received copies of the publication and how were they distributed.
(4) What was the cost of distribution.
(5) Was any other material enclosed with the publication; if so, what was it and what was its cost to produce.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of the need to consult widely on aged care reforms and to ensure that the nursing home industry and the community generally are kept fully informed of details of, and progress in, implementation of the reforms. New nursing home standards were introduced from 1 July 1987 based on the recommendations of a joint Commonwealth/State Working Party on Nursing Home Standards. The publication ``A Short Guide to Living in a Nursing Home'' was produced to give existing and potential residents and their relatives an indication of the quality of life and quality of care standards the Commonwealth expects nursing homes and their staff to provide. It was also produced for community groups to inform them of the new standards.
(2) The publication cost approximately $32,000 to produce, and more than 150,000 copies were printed. It is therefore estimated that the booklets cost a little over twenty cents each.

(3) ``A Short Guide to Living in a Nursing Home'' has been distributed to residents of aged care facilities, to community groups and, through State Offices of the Department of Community Services and Health, to other interested organisations and individuals.

(4) Because the publication has been distributed in conjunction with other material on the reforms and distributed progressively in response to requests through the various State Offices of the Department, it is not possible to accurately determine the total distribution costs.

(5) The other material enclosed with the publication varied depending upon when, and to whom, it was distributed. ``A Short Guide to Living in a Nursing Home'' now forms part of the range of material available which provides information to members of the public and to relevant Government and community organisations on different aspects of the Government's aged care program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Does his Department produce a publication called Aged Care, if so, (a) what is this publication, (b) what is its purpose, (c) how many issues have been produced, (d) what is its publication schedule, (e) how many copies of each issue are published, (f) who prepares the contents of the publication, (g) who prints the publication, (h) how is the publication distributed, (i) who receives copies and (j) what is the cost of distribution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Yes. The publication is known as the Aged Care Update.

(b) The Aged Care Update enables major policy and program initiatives and developments to be announced to aged care residents and relevant industry, union and consumer groups. The Aged Care Update expands on information contained in press releases and ensures that all nursing homes and hostels and their residents are aware of major policy changes and reforms. Residents and service providers alike have a right to be kept informed of developments likely to affect their future. There has been a lack of such information in the past. A successful aged care program must include good dissemination of information.
(d) There is no regular publication schedule. The dates of the three issues published are April 1986, March 1987 and May 1988.

(e) The number of copies published is dependent upon the main subject matter which, in turn, determines whether the publication would more appropriately be distributed to proprietors, directors of nursing, consumer groups, unions, peak organisations or residents.
(f) The contents of the publication are prepared by Departmental staff for my approval.
(g) The publication is printed under contractual arrangements organised through the Australian Government Publishing Service.
(h) The publication is distributed by the most efficient method available at the time, usually Australia Post, but Departmental State Offices may also be used as the mail-out point.

(j) The cost varies depending upon the number of copies printed, and the method and target of delivery. Given that this publication was distributed with other material, although cost savings were no doubt effected, it is not possible to accurately determine the actual cost of distributing the Aged Care Update.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Resident Classification system assess intellectual disability other than that arising from dementia; if so, how is this done and what special care is provided.

(2) Does the policy for aged care recognise that the care needs of the mentally disabled and physically disabled are different to the aged in general; if so, how does the policy recognise this difference.
(3) If the care needs of the mentally and physically disabled are not recognised as being different from those of the aged in general, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Resident Classification system assesses the care needs of residents irrespective of the precipitating factors. It takes into account a range of characteristics relating to behaviour, whether caused by intellectual disability, or dementia. People who, because of intellectual disability or for any other reason require assistance with a range of basic skills, such as eating and dressing, and who also need careful supervision because of anti-social or otherwise irrational behaviour, for example, will be entitled to very high levels of nursing and personal care.

(2) Yes. The new measures only apply to non-Government nursing homes for the aged and not to special purpose nursing homes in which the majority of younger intellectually and physically disabled people are accommodated. In recognition of the very differing care needs of younger disabled and aged people, program responsibility for special purpose nursing homes have been transferred to the Commonwealth Disability Services Program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there in the nursing home legislation a mechanism to facilitate an appeal against the assessors' categorisation of a patient under the Resident Classification Instrument (RCI); if so, who will have the right of appeal.
(2) What is the process a person will be required to go through, in order to appeal against a decision of the RCI assessors.
(3) What would be the cost to the Government of such an appeal.
(4) Will nursing home proprietors have the right to appeal; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) Yes. Sections 40afe and 40aff of the National Health Act provide mechanisms for review of Resident Classification Instrument (RCI) assessments. The RCI will generally be completed by a Director of Nursing (DON) of a nursing home after a person's admission to a home, but may also be completed by an assessment service before a person is admitted to a home.

A Director of Nursing may not seek a review of his or her or another Director of Nursing's assessment of a resident, but may seek, within 28 days of admission, a review of an assessment service's assessment of a resident. Appropriate professional staff from the Department of Community Services and Health will visit the nursing home (generally within 28 days of receipt of the request for review) and make a recommendation regarding the Director of Nursing's request. If the Secretary confirms the Director of Nursing's assessment, and a higher classification level results, the date of effect will be backdated to the `approved from' date of the RCI. If a lower level is approved, payment at the new level will commence from the date of the Secretary's decision.

The Department of Community Services and Health may initiate a review of one or all residents of a nursing home where the home's resident profile varies significantly from the State dependency profile or where responses to individual questions on the RCI are atypical. Whether the review results in a higher or lower classification level, payment at the new level will commence from the date of the Secretary's decision.

Where a Director of Nursing is dissatisfied with the Secretary's decision in either of the two cases cited above, the proprietor of a nursing home may appeal to the Minister within 28 days for a review of that decision.
The cost of a review to the Government will vary depending upon the individual circumstances of the case. In the case of any downward adjustment, the appeal process may result in a saving.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 28 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Government renege on its undertaking to provide $6.5m for the national Attendant Care Scheme, by only increasing its commitment to the scheme by $2.6m in the 1988-89 Budget.
(2) Why has there been such a low take-up rate of the scheme.
(3) Is it expected that the take-up rate will improve during 1988-89; if not, why not.
(4) If the take-up rate is expected to improve during 1988-89, when in the year will it do so.
(5) To what level is the rate expected to increase.
(6) What change in circumstances will facilitate this boost in the take-up rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's commitment to the Attendant Care Scheme has not changed. Although the estimated expenditure for 1988-89 is $4m because of delays in commencements, there is no change to the $6.5m budgeted for subsequent years.
(2) Implementation of the Scheme has been slower than anticipated primarily due to the time involved with arranging applicants' transition requirements, particularly housing.
(3) and (4) The commencement rate is dependent on factors which are often not able to be anticipated, and relate to the individual transition requirements of participants.
(5) The Scheme has a ceiling of up to 360 places which can be provided within the recurrent budget of $6.5m.

(6) It is expected that further approvals will be made and delays in arranging transition will be overcome as a result of additional assistance available to applicants and a once only grant made to State and Territory housing authorities to provide accommodation for Attendant Care Scheme consumers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is the principal registry of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to be moved from Canberra to Brisbane.
(2) What special arrangements will be made to accommodate the handling of proceedings before the Tribunal, consequent upon its move from Canberra to Brisbane.
(3) What is the cost of moving the principal registry from Canberra to Brisbane.
(4) What is the annual rental of the premises occupied in Canberra by the (a) principal registry and (b) ACT registry of the Tribunal.
(5) What will be the annual rental of the premises occupied in Canberra by the ACT registry of the Tribunal after the principal registry is moved to Brisbane.
(6) What is the annual rental of the premises occupied by the Queensland registry of the Tribunal.
(7) What will be the annual rental of the premises occupied in Brisbane by the Tribunal after the Principal registry is moved to Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Relocation of the Principal Registry of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to Brisbane is considered a more efficient use of resources than present arrangements. The Canberra Registry, to which the Principal Registry is presently attached, is one of the smallest ATT registries in terms of workload. Relocation of the Principal Registry with a District Registry in one of the major cities where there is a higher workload has been considered for some time. Brisbane has the third largest workload of all AAT registries. Suitable accommodation is available in Brisbane for the Registry in premises already leased by the Commonwealth.
(2) None. Changes in the handling of proceedings before the Tribunal which are currently being put in place would have been made wherever the Principal Registry was located.
(3) The estimated costs of moving the Principal Registry from Canberra to Brisbane are as follows:
Purchase of new furniture and equipment...
Removal expenses on transfer of staff...

(4) The annual rental of the premises occupied by the Tribunal in Canberra is currently $373,277.17. The accommodation is for the whole of the Tribunal's operations in Canberra. The functions of the ACT District Registry have been performed by officers in the Principal Registry.
(7) $399,676.80. This includes the accommodation occupied by the Queensland Registry.
